headline: Things Will Get Better. Seriously.
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Reasons to be hopeful about the Biden economy.
lead_paragraph: The next few months will be hell in terms of politics, epidemiology and economics. But at some point in 2021 things will start getting better. And there’s good reason to believe that once the good news starts, the improvement in our condition will be much faster and continue much longer than many people expect.

headline: Minneapolis Police Release Body Camera Video of Its First Killing Since George Floyd
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Attacks on Police', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
abstract: The video shows a man raising something to his car window before a bang is heard. An officer ducks for cover and then fires several rounds at the man.
lead_paragraph: The Minneapolis Police Department released body camera footage on Thursday that shed new light on a fatal police shooting the night before, the first killing by a city police officer since George Floyd’s death in the spring.

headline: Resolving to live a lot better than in 2020.
abstract: Every December since 2017, Ada Rojas has guided women through the process of memorializing their New Year’s resolutions on a vision board, a collage that reflects their goals and helps keep them on track. But this time around, Ms. Rojas is not holding the workshop Good Vibes & Chill until February.
lead_paragraph: Every December since 2017, Ada Rojas has guided women through the process of memorializing their New Year’s resolutions on a vision board, a collage that reflects their goals and helps keep them on track. But this time around, Ms. Rojas is not holding the workshop Good Vibes & Chill until February.

headline: Justice Dept. Asks Judge to Toss Election Lawsuit Against Pence
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Electoral College']
abstract: The suit, led by Representative Louie Gohmert of Texas, seeks to give the vice president the power to reject electoral votes that were cast for Joseph R. Biden Jr.
lead_paragraph: [Here’s what you need to know about President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s Inauguration Day.]

headline: The U.S. reaches 20 million cases.
abstract: The United States recorded its 20 millionth case since the start of the coronavirus pandemic on Thursday, surpassing a grim milestone just as the prospects for getting the virus under control quickly in the new year appeared to dim.
lead_paragraph: The United States recorded its 20 millionth case since the start of the coronavirus pandemic on Thursday, surpassing a grim milestone just as the prospects for getting the virus under control quickly in the new year appeared to dim.

headline: Party Hearty
abstract: Milo Beckman hides some pleasant surprises in his New Year’s puzzle — let’s hope for more of that!
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I hope people have a lot of fun with this “themeless” Friday, which revealed its center (to this solver, at least) like a secret box with a series of sliding parts. If Milo Beckman's name isn’t quite unexpected, that’s because he’s constructed for The Times before, mainly in the early 2010s. Hopefully this lively grid marks his return to the regular rotation and we see more of him in the future.

headline: The celebration at Mar-a-Lago doesn’t include President Trump.
abstract: The town of Palm Beach, Fla.,  imposed a 1 a.m. curfew, limiting New Year’s Eve festivities.
lead_paragraph: The glittering, black-tie New Year’s Eve celebration at the president’s Mar-a-Lago resort had in previous years been one of the highlights of the social season in Palm Beach, Fla. People paid hundreds of dollars for tickets. Celebrities including Sylvester Stallone, Rod Stewart and Woody Allen attended. Guests feasted on caviar and drank Champagne.

headline: Shhh! In Los Angeles, New Year’s Eve parties are still happening.
abstract: Throughout the coronavirus pandemic, well-attended parties have mostly been shut down across Los Angeles, which has led to a culture of secrecy on social media.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the coronavirus pandemic, well-attended parties have mostly been shut down across Los Angeles, which has led to a culture of secrecy on social media.

headline: Quotation of the Day: For New York, a Year of Pain and Reflection
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Jan. 1, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “We’ll all dance together as a family, and just have to go with the flow.”

headline: Corrections: Jan. 1, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Jan. 1, 2021.
lead_paragraph: A headline with an article on Thursday about cases of a more contagious form of the coronavirus in Colorado and California referred incorrectly to the virus. The new cases show a new variant of the virus, not a new strain.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: A very different New Year’s Eve.
lead_paragraph: Most places in the world, from a virtually coronavirus-free New Zealand to an Ireland in lockdown, have now greeted the arrival of 2021.

headline: Florida health officials detect the state’s first identified coronavirus variant case.
abstract: A highly contagious coronavirus variant first identified in Britain has been discovered in Florida, health officials said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A highly contagious coronavirus variant first identified in Britain has been discovered in Florida, health officials said on Thursday.

headline: No Rose Parade: Southern California laments the loss of a tradition.
abstract: The pandemic caused the cancellation of the Rose Parade, an institution since 1890, for the first time since World War II.
lead_paragraph: For just about every New Year’s Day since 1958, Carla Hall has situated herself on a patch of asphalt in front of a car dealership in downtown Pasadena, Calif. To a 10-year-old girl, it was the perfect spot to watch the majesty unfold — the “artistry” she calls it, of the floats and the marching bands, the beauty queens and horses.

headline: My Five-Week-Long First Date
abstract: Once I joined him on that ship for the Antarctic, there was no turning back.
lead_paragraph: “Wind twenty knots,” he wrote. “Thinking of you.”

headline: In Pasadena, Moving the Rose Bowl Makes For Unusual Rancor
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Rose Bowl (Football Game)', 'Bowl Games', 'Television', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Playoff Games', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'College Football Playoff National Championship', 'Trademarks and Trade Names']
abstract: The Rose Bowl moved to Texas from California to accommodate fans. But in Pasadena, city officials worried the maneuver could threaten its long-held ties to the game.
lead_paragraph: Many people know of genteel Pasadena, Calif., if only from New Year’s Day television, waking up to the palm-tree-lined Rose Parade down Colorado Boulevard, or stirring from a football-watching stupor long enough to admire the Technicolor sunset splashed on the San Gabriel Mountains behind the Rose Bowl stadium.

headline: New York to Delist Chinese Telecom Firms in Symbolic Shift
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States International Relations', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Blacklisting']
abstract: The move follows an order from the Trump administration, which says the companies are tied to China’s military. But they don’t need Wall Street as much as they once did.
lead_paragraph: The New York Stock Exchange said it would delist China’s three big state-run telecommunications companies following an executive order from the Trump administration, in a symbolic severing of longstanding ties between the Chinese business world and Wall Street.

headline: Virus Numbers Are Surging. Why Is New York’s Vaccine Rollout Sluggish?
abstract: With a new variant of the virus emerging elsewhere in the country, it’s crucial to vaccinate New Yorkers quickly. But so far, only about 88,000 have received the shots.
lead_paragraph: As the final hours ticked away in a harrowing year, New York City on Thursday once again found itself in a worrying position in the pandemic: Hospitalizations were climbing for the fourth consecutive month, the positive test rate in some areas had doubled and vaccinations that were supposed to bring normalcy had gotten off to a slow start.

headline: What You Need to Know About Today’s College Football Playoff Semifinals
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Rose Bowl (Football Game)', 'Sugar Bowl', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Playoff Games', 'Bowl Games', 'College Football Playoff National Championship']
abstract: Alabama will play Notre Dame and Clemson will meet Ohio State on Friday as a chaotic season nears its end.
lead_paragraph: Four of the most fabled programs in college football — Alabama, Clemson, Ohio State and Notre Dame — still have hopes of winning the championship in one of the most chaotic, uncertain, week-to-week seasons in the sport’s history.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: A New Coronavirus Variant, Diet Guidelines and Really Short Workouts
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Swimming in Very Cold Water Keeps Me Sane
abstract: Maybe at another time in human history I would have cared about the health benefits, but at this point, I’m like, what does “good for you” even mean?
lead_paragraph: I’m standing with two friends in the 39-degree air on the edge of a lake in northeastern California in just our bathing suits. A lone fisherman in several layers of outerwear stares, drinks from a bottle of Racer Ale and says, “Tell me you ladies aren’t going in that water.”

headline: How 2020 Changed Our Minds
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Two Thousand Twenty', 'Podcasts']
abstract: Listeners join the hosts to weigh in on the many ways this hellish year made them think differently.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to “The Argument” from your mobile device:

headline: 7 Ways to Socialize in a Frigid New York City
abstract: The best bet to see other people continues to be in the outdoors. But now the real test is here.
lead_paragraph: It’s officially winter. So what?

headline: Teaching My Child to Love a Dying World
abstract: My toddler son and I spoke about the trees as people — and indeed, for the first month of quarantine, they were the only people besides us he got to see up close.
lead_paragraph: This spring, as the world fell apart faster than we’d expected, I fell in love with trees. Not the crush of my girlhood when I admired them and fancied myself the child at the end of Dr. Seuss’s “The Lorax.” In love like I dreamed about them. I saw their bodies when I closed my eyes. Branches and trunks of different species traced my insides — the arch of the redbud’s trunk in joy and pleasure; the tight winter huddle of the spruce in fear.

headline: Confessions of a Virtual Reality Gym Rat
keywords: ['Exercise', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Mobile Applications', 'Headphones and Headsets', 'Content Type: Service', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: The workouts are real, even if the impossibly beautiful scenery is not.
lead_paragraph: This year has created a lot of reluctant converts. Months ago, in less dire circumstances, we swore we’d never do any number of strange-sounding things: attend Zoom weddings, embrace ring lights, feed a sourdough starter. And yet here we are, making do.

headline: For a Healthier 2021, Keep the Best Habits of a Very Bad Year
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Habits and Routines (Behavior)', 'New Year', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Our 7-Day Well Challenge will show you how to build on the healthy habits you learned during pandemic life.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a better way to start the new year: Skip the traditional January resolutions and make time for some New Year’s reflection instead.

headline: How the Oldest Old Can Endure Even This
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Nursing Homes', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: No visitors. No friends at the dining table. Neighbors dying without notice. But many older adults have proved resilient during the pandemic, a phenomenon known as “crisis competence.”
lead_paragraph: It was sometime in the spring that Ruth Willig, then 96, first compared her pandemic life to being in prison. My mother, Dorothy, was still alive then, in a building much like the assisted-living facility in Brooklyn where Ruth lives. The buildings had shut down all visitors and stopped all group activities, including meals in the dining room. Residents spent their days in their apartments, alone.

headline: A Top Equestrian Paralyzed in an Accident Sees Hope in a Coming Treatment
keywords: ['Horsemanship and Equestrian Events', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Paralysis', 'Spine (Body Part)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Kevin Babington was a go-to coach in the sport of show jumping, but an accident at a prime event left him paralyzed from the chest down and threatened his livelihood.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Sports department is revisiting the subjects of some compelling articles from the last year or so. Here is our April report on Kevin Babington’s efforts to continue working in the equestrian world after a show-jumping accident left him paralyzed from the chest down.

headline: David Fincher, the Unhappiest Auteur
abstract: The director makes beautiful bummers in an industry that prefers happy endings. Perhaps that’s why his movies seem like an endangered species.
lead_paragraph: For nearly three decades, David Fincher has been making gorgeous bummer movies that — in defiance of Hollywood’s first principle — insist that happy endings are a lie. Filled with virtuosic images of terrible deeds and violence, his movies entertain almost begrudgingly. Even when good somewhat triumphs, the victories come at a brutal cost. No one, Fincher warns, is going to save us. You will hurt and you will die, and sometimes your pretty wife’s severed head will end up in a box.

headline: Why Markets Boomed in a Year of Human Misery
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Savings', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: It wasn’t just the Fed or the stimulus. The rise in savings among white-collar workers created a tide lifting nearly all financial assets.
lead_paragraph: The central, befuddling economic reality of the United States at the close of 2020 is that everything is terrible in the world, while everything is wonderful in the financial markets.

headline: How Trump Tried, but Largely Failed, to Derail America’s Top Climate Report
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Research', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The White House repeatedly attempted to thwart the country’s premier climate science document, one meant to steer policy for years. Scientists got in the way.
lead_paragraph: The National Climate Assessment, America’s premier contribution to climate knowledge, stands out for many reasons: Hundreds of scientists across the federal government and academia join forces to compile the best insights available on climate change. The results, released just twice a decade or so, shape years of government decisions.

headline: In a Widening News Desert on the Border, a Tabloid Start-Up Defies the Odds
abstract: People in Del Rio, Texas, complain that nothing ever happens there. Those are fighting words for the publisher of The 830 Times, though he admits that keeping his paper afloat might be the biggest news of all.
lead_paragraph: DEL RIO, Texas — At the Chihuahuan Desert’s eastern limits, in a parking lot above Lake Amistad, Brian Argabright photographed anglers and their catch at the Border Bass Battle for The Del Rio News-Herald, a chronicler of the wind-swept border town since 1884.

headline: Upcoming N.H.L. Season Will Have Flashes of Other Difficult Eras
abstract: All of the Canadian teams will be in the same division, as they were in the late 1920s and most of the 1930s. And as during World War II, external circumstances will affect roster sizes.
lead_paragraph: The first time a pandemic halted a professional hockey season was in 1919, when an outbreak of the Spanish flu ended the Stanley Cup finals before a champion could be crowned. Just days after the cancellation, Montreal Canadiens defenseman Joe Hall, who had played in the finals, died in a Seattle hospital of pneumonia related to the flu. He was 37.

headline: How a Zen Buddhist Monk and Hospital Chaplain Spends His Sundays
abstract: To care for Covid-19 patients and their families, Seigan Ed Glassing reserves one day of the week to care for himself.
lead_paragraph: Even for someone accustomed to facing death, like Seigan Ed Glassing, who serves on the palliative care team at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, 2020 was a brutal year.

headline: Why Emptier Streets Meant an Especially Deadly Year for Traffic Deaths
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Speed Limits and Speeding', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: In New York City, at least 243 people died in crashes in 2020 — the most since Mayor Bill de Blasio introduced his signature street safety plan in 2014.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic hit New York City, cars seemed to disappear from many streets as the lockdown brought urban life to a halt and drivers stayed home.

headline: Infrared Drones, Search Parties and a Lasso: Chasing a Runaway Llama
abstract: In a season of uncommon grief and worry, people far beyond the Westchester County estate from which Gizmo escaped were all too happy to fret about something else, for a change.
lead_paragraph: BEDFORD CORNERS, N.Y. — Diana Heimann is the kind of person who traps mice in her farmhouse and releases them into nature preserves. The kind of person who kept Silkie chickens in her living room and their eggs in the cup holders of her car.

headline: Meteor Showers in 2021 That Will Light Up Night Skies
abstract: All year long, Earth passes through streams of cosmic debris. Here’s a list of some major meteor showers and how to spot them.
lead_paragraph: All year long as Earth revolves around the sun, it passes through streams of cosmic debris. The resulting meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to catch one.

headline: The Problem With Problem Sharks
keywords: ['Sharks', 'Animal Cognition', 'Animal Behavior', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'Research', 'Marine Biology', 'your-feed-animals', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: A marine biologist’s ideas for singling out sharks that attack humans have prompted objections from other shark scientists.
lead_paragraph: The war on sharks has been waged with shock and awe at times. When a shark bit or killed a swimmer, people within the past century might take out hundreds of the marine predators to quell the panic, like executing everyone in a police lineup in order to ensure justice was dispensed on the guilty party.

headline: A Monster Wind Turbine Is Upending an Industry
keywords: ['Wind Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Innovation']
abstract: G.E.’s giant machine, which can light up a small town, is stoking a renewable-energy arms race.
lead_paragraph: Twirling above a strip of land at the mouth of Rotterdam’s harbor is a wind turbine so large it is difficult to photograph. The turning diameter of its rotor is longer than two American football fields end to end. Later models will be taller than any building on the mainland of Western Europe.

headline: An Embattled Public Servant in a Fractured France
keywords: ['Religion-State Relations', 'Politics and Government', 'Discrimination', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Nicolas Cadène sees the failings of France’s secular model even as he upholds it.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France is in theory a nondiscriminatory society where the state upholds strict religious neutrality and people are free to believe, or not, in any God they wish. It is a nation, in its self image, that through education dissolves differences of faith and ethnicity in a shared commitment to the rights and responsibilities of French citizenship.

headline: Choosing to Be Displaced
abstract: More than 400,000 New Yorkers left the city at the beginning of the pandemic. Many have returned; all have re-evaluated their relationship with the city.
lead_paragraph: More than 400,000 New Yorkers left the city at the beginning of the pandemic. Many have returned; all have re-evaluated their relationship with the city.

headline: New Yorkers Who Fled the Virus Are Returning Home, Warily
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Tens of thousands of New Yorkers left the city when the pandemic struck and spent months living elsewhere. What did they learn?
lead_paragraph: They fled east to Long Island, west to New Jersey and Pennsylvania, north across New England and south to Florida, seeking freedom of movement and safe shelter anywhere the virus wasn’t yet raging like an out-of-control fire. Between March 1 and May 1, as the first wave of the Covid-19 pandemic hit New York, about 5 percent of the population, or 420,000 New Yorkers, left the city, according to cellphone data analyzed by The New York Times.

headline: An Imprint Neither Could Forget
abstract: Matthew Specktor and Samantha Culp first met at a book-signing benefit in 2013. They reconnected nearly six years later on a dating website.
lead_paragraph: Long before the name Matthew Specktor was inscribed on Samantha Culp’s heart, it could be found beneath a short, sweet note inscribed on a page of Mr. Specktor’s book, “American Dream Machine,” which she bought at a benefit at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles in June 2013.

headline: Brexit Customs Checks Make a Quiet Debut at U.K. Ports
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Transportation']
abstract: Starting the new rules on a holiday helped, with some predicting more confusion and backups in the days ahead.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At the ports and terminals on Britain’s southeastern coast, a new era began on Friday morning without much fuss. Ferries and trains that carry goods to France from Dover and Folkestone were running on time, and drivers snaked their trucks into the port unencumbered by congestion.

headline: A Soft Spot for Yalies
abstract: Prof. Liz Schneider put a personal ad in the Yale Alumni Magazine. Dr. Ben Liptzin answered it six months later.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth M. Schneider always had a soft spot for Yalies — her father and son went there — and she could belt out Bulldog football team fight songs and the “Bright College Years” unofficial alma mater with the best of them.

headline: Getting Married Where It All Began
abstract: Brandon Shih and Wenyi Gu met in their first college class, only to discover they lived in the same dorm. Almost a decade later, they eloped on the college campus where they fell in love.
lead_paragraph: On the first day of his first college class, Brandon Hsuan-Yuan Shih was nervously awaiting his turn to speak. He was in a freshman seminar at Princeton, and the students were asked to share something about themselves as an icebreaker. Mr. Shih had an answer prepared about how he loved music and playing tennis, until the woman sitting right next to him said the exact same thing.

headline: A Ceremony Led by Richard Branson
abstract: Sayé Yabandeh and Dr. Jeffrey Neal were instantly drawn to each other at a snow polo event in Aspen, Colo.
lead_paragraph: For the last five Decembers, Sayé Yabandeh has participated in the St. Regis World Snow Polo Championship, a charity event in Aspen, Colo. It’s a magical affair held in a magical location, and exactly the sort of place you want to share with someone.

headline: Happy New Year
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Last night, mostly in muted celebrations, people around the world said goodbye to a difficult year and rang in 2021. We hope your night was meaningful and enjoyable in its own way.

headline: Furnishing Your Home in a Pandemic Will Require Patience
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Furniture', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The coronavirus has disrupted supply chains in unpredictable ways, creating long waits for basic items like dishwashers and love seats.
lead_paragraph: Shopping for a dishwasher isn’t what it used to be.

headline: Virginia Judge Won’t Try Black Man in Courtroom Lined With White Portraits
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Discrimination', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: David Bernhard, a circuit court judge, wrote in his decision that the display of portraits of white judges “is based on a non-racial principle, yet yields a racial result.”
lead_paragraph: When a Black man appears in a Virginia courtroom this month to stand trial on charges of eluding the police, assaulting an officer and other crimes, he will face a scene that defendants in that room have not experienced in decades: The portraits of white judges will no longer line the walls.

headline: Pandemic Driving Is Still Down, but Will Insurers Grant More Relief?
keywords: ['Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'Content Type: Service', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Rebates and Refunds', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Many gave drivers a break in the spring. With accident claims remaining below normal, consumer advocates are calling for another one.
lead_paragraph: When Americans abruptly cut back on driving early in the pandemic, many auto insurance companies gave customers credits or refunds on their premiums, reflecting the lower risk of accidents with fewer cars on the road.

headline: Top Sales Show How Pandemic Continues to Influence the Market
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Single-family houses and penthouses remained in demand in December as buyers sought out homes with more personal space.
lead_paragraph: Several more Manhattan townhouse sales closed in December, many at holiday-style discounts.

headline: What to Know as Troubled Afghan Peace Talks Enter a New Phase
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Peace Process', 'Politics and Government', 'Terrorism', 'Civilian Casualties', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Afghan government and the Taliban are set to continue negotiations toward a cease-fire in early January, but several fundamental issues stand in the way of progress.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After four decades of grinding combat in Afghanistan, peace negotiations between the Afghan government and the Taliban have raised at least a possibility that the long cycle of violence might someday end.

headline: France couldn’t stop the New Year’s parties. One rave drew 2,500 people who fought off the police.
abstract: Local authorities said that stones and bottles were thrown at police officers who tried to break up the party, and that a police car was set on fire.
lead_paragraph: Faced with a resurgence of Covid-19 infections, French authorities pulled out all the stops to ensure that France would step into 2021 in safety. An existing nationwide overnight curfew was enforced on New Years’s Eve by some 130,000 police officers; all public celebrations were banned and the government advised to limit private gatherings to six people.

headline: Black and Hispanic Americans turn to doctors who look like them for reassurance on vaccinations.
abstract: Denese Rankin, a 55-year-old retired bookkeeper and receptionist in Castleberry, Ala., did not want the Covid-19 vaccine. Her opinion toward the vaccine was like many Black, rural Americans: The vaccine had come about too quickly to be safe.
lead_paragraph: Denese Rankin, a 55-year-old retired bookkeeper and receptionist in Castleberry, Ala., did not want the Covid-19 vaccine. Her opinion toward the vaccine was like many Black, rural Americans: The vaccine had come about too quickly to be safe.

headline: Chief Justice John Roberts commends the courts’ responses to the pandemic.
abstract: The nation’s courts have reacted nimbly to the coronavirus pandemic, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wrote in his year-end report on the state of the federal judiciary.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s courts have reacted nimbly to the coronavirus pandemic, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wrote in his year-end report on the state of the federal judiciary.

headline: The U.S. enters 2021 playing catch-up with its vaccine distribution, prompting sharp words from Mitt Romney.
abstract: The Utah senator called it “as incomprehensible as it is inexcusable” that “comprehensive vaccination plans have not been developed at the federal level and sent to the states as models.”
lead_paragraph: The United States begins the new year far behind schedule in its coronavirus vaccine rollout, having distributed shots to a mere fraction of the 20 million it had hoped to reach by this time, even as the nation hit a grim new milestone on New Year’s Eve: 20 million cases since the start of the pandemic.

headline: The Premier League Has a Schedule. It Really Needs a Plan.
abstract: As the coronavirus invades locker rooms and postpones matches, soccer needs to face up to a potential worst-case scenario.
lead_paragraph: On the face of it, the Premier League’s decision was an easy and an obvious one. Manchester City and Manchester United had finished last season late, thanks to their commitments in the summer’s European competitions.

headline: Jovan Adepo Pushes Through With Rachmaninoff and ‘Love Island’
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Actors and Actresses']
abstract: The actor, starring in the latest adaptation of Stephen King’s “The Stand,” shared an eclectic list of what he is consuming to pass the time.
lead_paragraph: Jovan Adepo, known for his breakout turn in “Watchmen,” wasn’t familiar with “The Stand,” Stephen King’s dark fantasy novel about the survivors of an apocalyptic pandemic, before filming the TV adaptation that premiered as a mini-series in December on CBS All Access — and had no idea how close to home it would hit.

headline: Love Music to Surprise You? Jon Caramanica Recommends TikTok Dives
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Music', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: The Times’s Culture editor has questions. Our critic has answers.
lead_paragraph: As the editor of the Culture department at The New York Times, Gilbert Cruz relies on critics, reporters and editors in every field of the arts for their expertise. Now we’re bringing his personal questions — and our writers’ answers — to you. Currently on his mind: how to open himself up to new music, and tangle with the beast known as TikTok, which he posed to Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic.

headline: Britain Has Lost Itself
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Politics and Government', 'Discrimination']
abstract: My grandparents, who fled Nazi Germany for Britain, would be heartbroken to see the country today.
lead_paragraph: At long last, it happened.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: Discover readers’ positive moments of 2020. Also in this edition: the inspiring resilience of a marathoner, the bizarre story of a runaway llama and more.
lead_paragraph: Discover readers’ positive moments of 2020. Also in this edition: the inspiring resilience of a marathoner, the bizarre story of a runaway llama and more.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Mapo tofu, Sicilian-style citrus salad, black bean soup: Start the year off with great eating.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. You aren’t, I hope, struggling this morning after a night of excess, considering your options at the crossroads of madness and death. If 2020 gave us anything it was an excuse — an order, really — not to gather on New Year’s Eve for its sad, sentimental dance of forced cheer and sweet Champagne, its endless hours before that dreadful song. Here we are in a new year, still very much like the last one, though there’s light now at the end of the tunnel and we dare to be hopeful sometimes, particularly today. We feel good, despite all!

headline: After Five Centuries, a Native American With Real Power
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Native Americans', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The expected nomination of Deb Haaland.
lead_paragraph: In the American West, a ration of reverence is usually given to the grizzled Anglo rancher who rises at a public hearing and announces that his people have been on the land for five generations.

headline: ‘Because of You Guys, I’m Stuck in My Room’
abstract: Residents and caregivers at senior living facilities write about life during the pandemic — and trying to stay safe while facing the challenges of long-term isolation.
lead_paragraph: Devora Greenspon, 88, spent most of April, May and June confined to her room after residents at her long-term care facility in Toronto tested positive for the coronavirus. She couldn’t see her family and had very little human contact at all. A former special education teacher, she told me she found the isolation and loneliness of lockdown “so heartbreaking.”

headline: Fareed Zakaria on Life After the Pandemic
abstract: Zakaria discusses “Ten Lessons for a Post-Pandemic World,” and Margaret MacMillan talks about “War: How Conflict Shaped Us.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: What New Science Techniques Tell Us About Ancient Women Warriors
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'Archaeology and Anthropology', 'Vikings', 'Research']
abstract: Recent studies show that man was not always the hunter.
lead_paragraph: Though it’s remarkable that the United States finally is about to have a female vice president, let’s stop calling it an unprecedented achievement. As some recent archaeological studies suggest, women have been leaders, warriors and hunters for thousands of years. This new scholarship is challenging long-held beliefs about so-called natural gender roles in ancient history, inviting us to reconsider how we think about women’s work today.

headline: Can You Poison Your Way to Good Health?
abstract: West Coast wellness elites think kambo, an Amazonian frog poison drug, is helping them purge “toxins” from their lives.
lead_paragraph: “It’s like you’re having a fever or a major allergic reaction,” said Julia Allison, 39, now a media strategist for tech companies in San Francisco, recalling her first time taking kambo, a poisonous substance from an Amazonian frog that is trending as an alt-wellness wonder drug. “Then your face starts to blow up.”

headline: Will 250 Lanterns Be Enough to Save Chinatown?
abstract: After a devastating year for small businesses, a new organization has a plan to bring life back to the neighborhood. First, hang some new lights.
lead_paragraph: Two days before Christmas, Mott Street, right in the heart of Chinatown, was filled with lights overnight. Residents woke up to 250 violet, pink, orange and gold lanterns hanging above the street. Local artists had painted whimsical designs and auspicious characters onto them: fu, for good fortune; he, for peace. Other characters stood for love, happiness, wealth and longevity.

headline: Ontario’s finance minister resigns after a jaunt in the Caribbean.
abstract: A senior minister in Ontario’s cabinet has resigned after vacationing in the Caribbean as residents of Canada’s most populous province were being urged to stay home.
lead_paragraph: A senior minister in Ontario’s cabinet has resigned after vacationing in the Caribbean as residents of Canada’s most populous province were being urged to stay home.

headline: Meals for a New Year
abstract: Start the new year with a lovable combination: chicken soup with rice.
lead_paragraph: We made it! Happy New Year, and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. I’m hopeful we’ll have a year that is better than the last, though 2020 was not entirely without small pops of good news. (If you haven’t heard it yet, there is a wonderful episode of “The Daily” devoted to this subject.) For me, it was the arrival of my second child, whose first word (besides Mama), uttered in December, was “Hi!” It feels particularly sunny and gregarious after a year that was so dark and insular. We hear her yelling it all over the house. HI!

headline: Before Embracing America-First Agenda, David Perdue Was an Outsourcing Expert
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Outsourcing']
abstract: Mr. Perdue, who faces one of two runoff elections in Georgia that will determine control of the Senate, built a business record that shifted manufacturing and jobs overseas.
lead_paragraph: The biographical video from Senator David Perdue’s first campaign, in 2014, celebrated a narrative arc that many fellow Georgians either related to or have aspired to: the story of a humble boy from rural America whose hard work catapulted him into a global business career, navigating free markets and faraway lands, all the while gathering stores of wisdom and wealth.

headline: Armando Manzanero, Influential Mexican Balladeer, Is Dead
abstract: He was known as one of the great romantic composers. His songs were performed by Elvis Presley, Andrea Bocelli, Christina Aguilera and many others.
lead_paragraph: Armando Manzanero, one of Mexico’s greatest romantic composers, whose ballads were performed by the likes of Elvis Presley and Christina Aguilera, died on Monday in Mexico City.

headline: New York Halted Evictions. But What Happens When the Ban Ends?
abstract: A crisis looms in the pandemic’s wake: Evictions that threaten to overwhelm schools, homeless shelters and food pantries.
lead_paragraph: When New York State lawmakers approved emergency legislation this week to ban evictions for at least two months, they were seeking to prevent hundreds of thousands of people from being forced from their homes during the winter, with the pandemic still raging. But they also feared something more perilous: a broad ripping at the fabric of society.

headline: ‘Elizabeth Is Missing’ Review: Glenda Jackson’s Return to TV
abstract: The renowned actress stars as a woman fending off dementia while she searches for a lost friend.
lead_paragraph: The BBC television movie “Elizabeth Is Missing” — a stand-alone episode of “Masterpiece” on PBS this Sunday — contains Glenda Jackson’s first screen performance since 1992. That certainly merits attention — Jackson, now 84, is one of the most technically accomplished and ferociously intelligent actresses of our time. Did it merit the rapturous British reviews on its release in 2019 and perhaps inevitable awards, including a BAFTA and an international Emmy, that she received for it? Not really, but it isn’t Jackson’s fault.

headline: Tyshawn Sorey: The Busiest Composer of the Bleakest Year
abstract: An artist straddling jazz and classical styles had perhaps the most exciting fall in new music.
lead_paragraph: “Everything Changes, Nothing Changes”: Tyshawn Sorey wrote the string quartet that bears that title in 2018. But the sentiment is so tailor-made for the past year that when the JACK Quartet announced it would stream a performance of the work in December, I briefly forgot and assumed it was a premiere, created for these tumultuous yet static times.

headline: States Are Shutting Down Prisons as Guards are Crippled By Covid-19
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Shortages', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'States (US)']
abstract: States and counties are finding it hard to keep jails and prisons open as the virus ravages both prisoners and staff members. But transferring inmates can spur new outbreaks.
lead_paragraph: Battered by a wave of coronavirus infections and deaths, local jails and state prison systems around the United States have resorted to a drastic strategy to keep the virus at bay: Shutting down completely and transferring their inmates elsewhere.

headline: U.K. Eliminates Tax on Tampons and Other Sanitary Products
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Menstruation', "Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Value-Added Tax']
abstract: Britain is the latest of several countries to get rid of the tax in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Britain on Friday became the latest country to transform its measures on sanitary products by abolishing the so-called tampon tax, no longer classifying the products as nonessential and eliminating extra costs that many have criticized as sexist.

headline: Horrified by the Blackwater Pardons
keywords: ['Mercenaries and Private Military Contractors', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The F.B.I. agent who led the Blackwater investigation and two other letter writers are appalled by the pardon of men who killed innocent civilians.

abstract: Readers are shocked that the question is being asked and speculate that the vice president may find an excuse not to be present. They also criticize Senator Josh Hawley.

headline: Senate Overrides Trump’s Veto of Defense Bill, Dealing a Legislative Blow
keywords: ['Vetoes (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Republicans joined Democrats to deliver President Trump the first veto override of his presidency in the last days of his term in an overwhelming, bipartisan vote.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Friday voted overwhelmingly to override President Trump’s veto of the annual military policy bill as most Republicans joined Democrats to rebuke Mr. Trump in the final days of his presidency.

headline: Congress Poised to Apply Banking Regulations to Antiquities Market
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Art', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation', 'Auctions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vetoes (US)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Money Laundering']
abstract: Regulators have long worried that the secrecy of the antiquities trade, where buyers and sellers are seldom identified, made it an easy way to launder money.
lead_paragraph: The antiquities trade, which regulators have long feared provided fertile ground for money laundering and other illicit activities, will be subject to greater oversight under legislation passed by Congress on Friday when it overrode President Trump’s veto.

headline: Britain Opens Door to Mix-and-Match Vaccinations, Worrying Experts
abstract: If a second dose of one vaccine isn’t available, another may be substituted, according to the guidelines.
lead_paragraph: Amid a sputtering vaccine rollout and fears of a new and potentially more transmissible variant of the coronavirus, Britain has quietly updated its vaccination playbook to allow for a mix-and-match vaccine regimen. If a second dose of the vaccine a patient originally received isn’t available, or if the manufacturer of the first shot isn’t known, another vaccine may be substituted, health officials said.

headline: How Israel Became a World Leader in Vaccinating Against Covid-19
abstract: Badly hit by the coronavirus, Israel has distributed the first of two vaccine doses to more than 10 percent of its population. Prime Minister Netanyahu is leading the charge, bolstering his own battered image along the way.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — More than 10 percent of Israel’s population has received a first dose of a coronavirus vaccine, a rate that has far outstripped the rest of the world and buoyed the battered domestic image of the country’s leader, Benjamin Netanyahu, at a critical juncture.

headline: Make Tinier New Year’s Resolutions This Year
abstract: Go for small and achievable.
lead_paragraph: Sign up to receive the At Home newsletter.

headline: Is There a Future for Winnipeg’s Landmark Department Store?
abstract: The Hudson’s Bay Company’s now-closed downtown department store is surrounded by warm memories — and significant challenges in a post-pandemic world.
lead_paragraph: While it was already on death row, Hudson’s Bay Company’s presence in downtown Winnipeg ended with unexpected abruptness. After announcing that its much diminished former flagship outlet would be shut in February, the retailer permanently locked the doors of the 600,000-square-foot store at the end of November. Less than two weeks later, a crew arrived and stripped it of its signs.

headline: How Support for Legal Abortion Went Mainstream in Argentina
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'ABORTION', "Women's Rights", 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The fight for legalization began decades ago, but it gained traction only as more women became lawmakers and a massive grass-roots effort shifted the conversation.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — It was just two years ago that the organizers of a stirring women’s movement in Argentina were handed what felt like a bitter loss, their efforts to legalize abortion rejected in the Senate after intense lobbying by the Catholic Church.

headline: Dr. Fauci advises against the British approach of delaying a second dose of vaccine.
abstract: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert, told CNN on Friday that the United States would not follow Britain’s lead in front-loading first vaccine injections, potentially delaying the administration of second doses.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert, told CNN on Friday that the United States would not follow Britain’s lead in front-loading first vaccine injections, potentially delaying the administration of second doses.

headline: Joan Micklin Silver, Director of ‘Crossing Delancey,’ Dies at 85
abstract: She broke barriers for women, directing seven feature films, including “Hester Street” and “Between the Lines,” as well as TV movies.
lead_paragraph: Joan Micklin Silver, the filmmaker whose first feature, “Hester Street,” expanded the marketplace for American independent film and broke barriers for women in directing, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

headline: Senate Votes to Override Trump’s Veto of Defense Bill
abstract: Republicans joined Democrats on Friday to override President Trump’s veto of the annual defense bill, delivering him the first such legislative rebuke of his presidency.
lead_paragraph: Republicans joined Democrats on Friday to override President Trump’s veto of the annual defense bill, delivering him the first such legislative rebuke of his presidency.

headline: New Year’s Lawbreakers: 3 N.Y.C. Parties With Hundreds Are Broken Up
abstract: New Year’s Eve was mellow for most New Yorkers, and Times Square was practically empty. But some could not resist the lure of a big night out.
lead_paragraph: New York City, a place synonymous with the glitter and noise of New Year’s Eve, marked the close of a most unpredictable and upside-down of years in quiet deference to its dangers. In sending off a year so many would like to forget, New Yorkers spent a night that will instead be remembered, for its communal rejection of the usual fanfare.

headline: John Outterbridge, Who Turned Castoffs Into Sculpture, Dies at 87
abstract: Leftover wood, rags, rusted metal — all were his materials, and pieced together as assemblages, they told stories about history, about culture and about him.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — John Outterbridge, a Los Angeles cultural leader and artist who made powerful sculptures from what is usually dismissed as junk or castoffs — a means of exploring loaded social issues as well as celebrating a history of African-American resourcefulness — died here on Nov. 12. He was 87.

headline: Without Trump, or Masks, Mar-a-Lago Partied On
abstract: President Trump did not attend his private social club’s annual New Year’s Eve bash, which hundreds of guests attended despite the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s private social club in Palm Beach, Fla., hosted a New Year’s Eve gala at which revelers without masks dined indoors and danced to performances by Vanilla Ice and members of the Beach Boys.

headline: In Abrupt Reversal of Iran Strategy, Pentagon Orders Aircraft Carrier Home
keywords: ['Aircraft Carriers', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Targeted Killings', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: After weeks of escalation and threatening language, the Defense Department is sending mixed messages as the anniversary of the death of an Iranian general nears.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has abruptly sent the aircraft carrier Nimitz home from the Middle East and Africa over the objections of top military advisers, marking a reversal of a weekslong muscle-flexing strategy aimed at deterring Iran from attacking American troops and diplomats in the Persian Gulf.

headline: Washington Has Been Lucrative for Some on Biden’s Team
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: Janet Yellen, the president-elect’s pick for Treasury secretary, collected more than $7 million in speaking fees over the past two years. Antony J. Blinken and Avril Haines did well, too.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s choice for Treasury secretary, Janet L. Yellen, collected more than $7 million in speaking fees over the past two years from major corporations and Wall Street banks that have a keen interest in the financial policies she will oversee after her expected confirmation to lead the Treasury Department.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 2, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 2, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend on Page 16 about a patient who had hereditary angioedema refers incorrectly to a protein that blocks swelling and inflammation. It is C1-inhibitor, not C1.

keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Rose Bowl (Football Game)', 'Sugar Bowl', 'Playoff Games', 'College Football Playoff National Championship']

headline: Trump Calls Georgia Senate Races ‘Illegal and Invalid’
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: President Trump continued his assault on election integrity, baselessly claiming the presidential results and the Senate runoffs in Georgia were both invalid — which could complicate G.O.P. efforts to motivate voters.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — President Trump took to Twitter Friday evening to make the unfounded assertion that Georgia’s two Senate races are “illegal and invalid,” an argument that could complicate his efforts to convince his supporters to turn out for Republican candidates in the two runoff races that will determine which party controls the Senate.

headline: Federal Judge Dismisses Election Lawsuit Against Pence
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: President Trump’s congressional allies had hoped to give the vice president the power to reject electoral votes that were cast for Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Sudden Sisterhood of Covid Widows, United in Unthinkable Loss
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 2, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “I think it could have made a difference, if I was there seeing him, to soothe him or scratch his arm or kiss his head.”

headline: Drink That You Could Really Use
abstract: Joe Deeney hydrates us.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is the second grid in two days with number symbols; Joe Deeney adds some star power and a number of watery elements. There’s also some interesting geometry today: an extra column, necessitated by that spelled-out 16-letter span. It's the centerpiece, but with 11 other lengthy debuts and fantastic cluing, it certainly doesn’t have to carry the rest of this excellent solve.

headline: A Virginia state senator, Ben Chafin, has died from complications of Covid-19.
abstract: He died after two weeks in a Richmond hospital.
lead_paragraph: Ben Chafin, a Republican state senator from Virginia, has died of complications of Covid-19, the State Senate’s Republican Caucus confirmed on Friday evening. He had been receiving treatment at the VCU Medical Center in Richmond for two weeks, his family said in a statement.

headline: The New Orleans Saints’ star running back, Alvin Kamara, is placed on the N.F.L.’s Covid reserve list.
abstract: Alvin Kamara, the star running back for the New Orleans Saints and one of the best players in the N.F.L. this season, has been placed on the N.F.L.’s Covid-19 reserve list, a move that will keep him out of the team’s regular-season finale on Sunday and that may jeopardize his chances to appear in the team’s first game of the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: Alvin Kamara, the star running back for the New Orleans Saints and one of the best players in the N.F.L. this season, has been placed on the N.F.L.’s Covid-19 reserve list, a move that will keep him out of the team’s regular-season finale on Sunday and that may jeopardize his chances to appear in the team’s first game of the playoffs.

headline: Blake Griffin: Thriving Away From the Rim and Feeling ‘Ancient’
abstract: At 31, Griffin is a Detroit Pistons elder who still knows how to entertain, even if soaring dunks are no longer his specialty.
lead_paragraph: There must be some mistake. There is no way Blake Griffin, the star forward for the Detroit Pistons, is in his 11th N.B.A. season. Wasn’t he just soaring over the hood of a Kia to win the slam dunk contest? Being schooled in “dunkology” by Jeff Goldblum? That was almost a decade ago?

headline: How Taiwan Plans to Stay (Mostly) Covid-Free
abstract: The island’s success against the coronavirus has created a sinking feeling for many residents: How much longer can their good fortune last?
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Consider for a moment, in this time of anguish and loss and death, of mass unemployment and flattened national economies, the Twilight Zone alternate reality that is Taiwan.

headline: Rowing the Nile: A Soothing Respite in a Chaotic Metropolis
abstract: Ancient pharaohs rowed the Nile. Now Egyptians have rediscovered the practice, finding a new perspective on the river that shaped their country.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Sunset is when the Nile blinks to life in Cairo, the party boats twinkling like Vegas, the couples on the Qasr el-Nil bridge lingering in the breeze, the riverside cafes clinking with commerce long past most cities’ bedtimes.

headline: He Calmed Gaza, Aided Israel’s Arab Ties and Preserved Hopes for Peace
abstract: After six years of quiet diplomacy as the U.N.’s Middle East envoy, Nickolay Mladenov leaves his post to a chorus of praise from an unlikely choir.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Preventive diplomacy, by its nature, does not often lead to splashy headlines for the practitioner.

headline: The Year of Buyer’s Remorse
abstract: In 2020 we stocked up on a lot. Maybe some things we didn’t need.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Lady of the Lakers
abstract: Jeanie Buss inherited a team, and a legacy, from her father. What will her imprint be?
lead_paragraph: In November 2015, when Kobe Bryant had decided it would be his final basketball season, he requested a meeting with Jeanie Buss, the controlling owner of the Lakers. They met at the house she was sharing with her then-fiancé, Phil Jackson.

headline: A Canadian ‘Buy Local’ Effort Fights Amazon on Its Own Turf
abstract: A website called Not Amazon was created to drive sales to more than 4,000 independent stores in four cities. The initiative aims to keep expanding.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The snow was falling outside Ali Haberstroh’s apartment in late November when the idea came to her.

keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'National Debt (US)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Over the past four years, President Trump and his allies in Congress have all but obliterated the Republican Party’s self-professed commitment to less spending and smaller deficits, pushing policies that have bloated the federal budget deficit to record levels.

headline: The Vegas Chapels Are Open, and Waiting

keywords: ['US Federal Government Data Breach (2020)', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Those behind the widespread intrusion into government and corporate networks exploited seams in U.S. defenses and gave away nothing to American monitoring of their systems.
lead_paragraph: On Election Day, General Paul M. Nakasone, the nation’s top cyberwarrior, reported that the battle against Russian interference in the presidential campaign had posted major successes and exposed the other side’s online weapons, tools and tradecraft.

headline: Tokyo asks for a national state of emergency.
abstract: After days of record-setting coronavirus tallies in Tokyo, the city’s governor on Saturday asked Japan’s central government to declare a national state of emergency for the first time since April.
lead_paragraph: After days of record-setting coronavirus tallies in Tokyo, the city’s governor on Saturday asked Japan’s central government to declare a national state of emergency for the first time since April.

headline: Fleeing Lockdown, Americans Are Flocking to Mexico City
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Americans Abroad', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Quarantines', 'Disease Rates', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Hospitals are at capacity and coronavirus cases are surging, but many foreigners, especially Americans, are heading to the Mexican capital — some intending to stay awhile.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — At first, life in lockdown was OK, between working from home, exercising with his roommate, and devouring everything on Netflix.

headline: Do Children Really Need to Learn to Code?
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'E-Learning', 'Children and Childhood', 'Education (K-12)', 'Parenting', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: In India, parents are being aggressively sold the idea that their children must start coding at 4 or 5 or be future failures.
lead_paragraph: LUCKNOW, India — I am a parent, and this is my little mutiny. I withdrew my 5-year-old daughter, Vaidehi, from her school in this northern India city. The school had 110 students joining each online class, all of them instructed to be in their school uniforms. India has about 10 million coronavirus cases now, and schools have been offering online instruction since March.

headline: A Continent Where the Dead Are Not Counted
abstract: All 54 African countries put together have registered fewer Covid deaths than France. That doesn’t mean people aren’t dying from the virus.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — Christopher Johnson was known for two things. His enthusiastic dancing in the street, which made everyone laugh. And his habit of hurling insults at strangers, which constantly got him into trouble.

headline: ‘Year of the Reveal’: Runoffs Follow Pandemic, Protests and a Test of Atlanta’s Promise
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The high-stakes Senate contests come after months of tumult and activism in a city often seen as both resolutely Southern and somehow distinct from the rest of the region.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Like Atlanta itself, the rapper T.I. has known both defeat and a long twisting road toward redemption and prosperity.

headline: Ensuring the Survival of Our Democracy

headline: My Packages Keep Getting Stolen. What Can I Do?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Delivery Services', 'Content Type: Service', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: A 2019 analysis found that 90,000 packages are lost or stolen every day in New York. And it’s only getting worse during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Q: Packages have been getting stolen from my rental building in Sugar Hill, Harlem. We’ve been getting more packages delivered since the pandemic, and they are often left in the lobby with no protection. Tenants are working hard to notify neighbors about the deliveries, but we don’t all know each other. How do we petition our landlord for lockers or a mailroom? Would he be liable for stolen packages after he’s been put on notice? What can we do to protect our deliveries?

headline: Some Covid Survivors Haunted by Loss of Smell and Taste
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Taste', 'Smell (Olfaction)', 'Chronic Condition (Health)', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Emotions', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Research', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: As the coronavirus claims more victims, a once-rare diagnosis is receiving new attention from scientists, who fear it may affect nutrition and mental health.
lead_paragraph: Until March, when everything started tasting like cardboard, Katherine Hansen had such a keen sense of smell that she could recreate almost any restaurant dish at home without the recipe, just by recalling the scents and flavors.

headline: The Easy Weeknight Recipes You Need
abstract: Whether you’ve got 10 minutes or an hour, we’ve got you covered.
lead_paragraph: With January upon us you may be thinking, “Now what do I cook?” There’s no better time to get inspired by ingenious weeknight meals — and we have lots of them. Go meatless with Yewande Komolafe’s crispy tofu with cashews and blistered snap peas (above), make a delicious lemon-caper pan sauce to accompany Toni Tipton-Martin’s pork chops, or liven up Alexa Weibel’s creamy white bean soup with spicy paprika oil. We have all the collections and recipes you need in the link below, whether you have 10 minutes or an hour to get food on the table. (Sign up here to receive the Five Weeknight Dishes newsletter in your inbox every Friday.)

headline: India nears approval for two vaccines.
abstract: An expert coronavirus panel in India has recommended authorizing the vaccine created by AstraZeneca and Oxford University, as well as a local candidate, for emergency use.
lead_paragraph: An expert coronavirus panel in India has recommended authorizing the vaccine created by AstraZeneca and Oxford University, as well as a local candidate, for emergency use.

headline: Conjuring Up the World Through the Sense of Taste
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Pickles and Relishes', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Grandparents']
abstract: Housebound because of the pandemic, an international correspondent finds a way to travel the globe in her kitchen.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — My grandmother in Tokyo kept a pail under her sink. It was filled with what resembled wet sand. But from its pungent depths came what I considered to be the most miraculous of treats — a pickled carrot or daikon or, one of my favorites, a bud of a ginger-like plant called myoga.

headline: Adál Maldonado, Provocative ‘Nuyorican’ Photographer, Dies at 72
abstract: Adál, who moved from Puerto Rico to New York as a teenager, created art that was often bitingly satirical and politically subversive.
lead_paragraph: Adál Maldonado, an influential Puerto Rican photographer and artistic provocateur who explored the psychological and cultural fallout of the Puerto Rican diaspora in New York, died on Dec. 9 in San Juan. He was 72.

headline: This Rescue Moose Was Also 2020
keywords: ['ANIMALS', 'Moose', 'Rats', 'Butterflies and Moths', 'Owls', 'Birds', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Spiders', 'Whales and Whaling', 'Two Thousand Twenty']
abstract: Let’s celebrate the strange and marvelous creatures of Earth while we still can.
lead_paragraph: Let’s celebrate the strange and marvelous creatures of Earth while we still can.

headline: What’s the First Thing You Will Do When the Pandemic Ends?
abstract: We put that question to readers and received more than 800 responses. Here are some of the highlights.
lead_paragraph: Though public health officials have cautioned that the coronavirus pandemic is far from over, the rollout of vaccines around the world signals the start of a hopeful chapter after nearly a year of lockdowns, restrictions and social distancing. Now that imagining an “after time” seems possible, At Home readers were asked to share their “firsts” — the first things they plan to do when the world returns to normal.  A total of 803 readers responded, with plans for hugs, family visits and dream trips that have been delayed.

headline: Tesla Says It Hit Goal of Delivering 500,000 Cars in 2020
abstract: The milestone seemed unreachable just three years ago and comes as Tesla has seen a string of profitable quarters and a buoyant stock.
lead_paragraph: The electric carmaker Tesla reported on Saturday that it had produced more than half a million cars in 2020, a milestone that seemed unreachable just three years ago.

headline: A Season of Chaos Will End With a Powerhouse Matchup College Football Wanted
abstract: Alabama and Ohio State took different paths to the national championship game, with twists that showed how much college football wanted its biggest stage to feel familiar.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live score and game tracker of Alabama vs Ohio State.]

headline: Coast Guard Suspends Search for Missing Boat With 20 Aboard
abstract: The 29-foot boat departed from Bimini, the Bahamas, and was headed to Lake Worth Beach, Fla., officials said.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The U.S. Coast Guard suspended its search on Friday for an overdue boat that was headed to Florida from the Bahamas with 20 people aboard, after the authorities said they had exhausted their efforts to find it.

headline: Tim Severin, Seafarer Who Replicated Explorers’ Journeys, Dies at 80
keywords: ['Sailboats and Sailing', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Exploration and Explorers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: He and his crew sailed from Ireland to Newfoundland in a 36-foot boat like the one a sixth-century monk is believed to have used to cross the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: Tim Severin, a British adventurer who for 40 years meticulously replicated the journeys of real and mythic explorers like St. Brendan the Navigator, Sinbad the Sailor and Marco Polo, died on Dec. 18 at his home in West Cork, Ireland. He was 80.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon show us their 2021 stripes.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Happy new year, solvers! This looks to be a good book to draw from for our first puzzle in 2021: a memoir by Mary Morris, about how she overcame some rotten luck and tenaciously pursued a great adventure. The book borrows its title, “All the Way to the Tigers,” from “Death in Venice”; the excerpt describes Ms. Morris’s deep and longtime fascination with tigers, the mysterious striped cats, that inspires her odyssey.

headline: Under fire, the Netherlands is speeding up the start of its lagging vaccination campaign.
abstract: The government said that shots would begin sooner than Jan. 8, and that it would announce the new start date on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Facing broad criticism, the government of the Netherlands on Saturday said the country would speed up its lagging vaccination process and provide the first shots to frontline health care workers.

headline: Targeted Killings Are Terrorizing Afghans. And No One Is Claiming Them.
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Terrorism', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Politics and Government', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Most officials believe the Taliban are behind the attacks on civil leaders, but others fear that factions are using chaos as a cover to settle scores, in an echo of Afghanistan’s past civil war.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A military prosecutor who thought upholding the law was the highest honor, a doctor who inspired her family to study medicine, a journalist who wanted to hold those in power to account and a human-rights activist who sought to combat poverty in her home province: all murdered within weeks by unknown attackers as winter settled over Afghanistan.

headline: Raphael Warnock, From the Pulpit to Politics, Doesn’t Shy From ‘Uncomfortable’ Truths
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Elections, Senate', 'Ministers (Protestant)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: He first wanted to run for office years ago. Now Stacey Abrams, the Democratic Party and the Rev. Raphael Warnock all believe that the time is ripe for Georgia voters to send a Black Baptist preacher to Washington.

headline: Has Africa been spared? Researchers say the numbers of cases and deaths are probably undercounted.
abstract: LAGOS, Nigeria — As the pandemic has swept across the world, it has become increasingly evident that in a vast majority of countries on the African continent, most deaths are never formally registered. Reliable data on a country’s deaths and their causes are hard to come by, which means governments can miss emerging health threats — whether Ebola or the coronavirus — and often have to formulate health policy blindly.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — As the pandemic has swept across the world, it has become increasingly evident that in a vast majority of countries on the African continent, most deaths are never formally registered. Reliable data on a country’s deaths and their causes are hard to come by, which means governments can miss emerging health threats — whether Ebola or the coronavirus — and often have to formulate health policy blindly.

headline: Pence Welcomes Futile Bid by G.O.P. Lawmakers to Overturn Election
keywords: ['Electoral College', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Vice President Mike Pence signaled his support as 11 Republican senators and senators-elect said that they would vote to reject President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Mike Pence signaled support on Saturday for a futile Republican bid to overturn the election in Congress next week, after 11 Republican senators and senators-elect said that they would vote to reject President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory when the House and Senate meet to formally certify it.

headline: Canada will require incoming international air passengers to test negative before boarding, and other news from around the world.
abstract: Canada will require passengers seeking to board international flights into the country to show their airline proof of a negative coronavirus test, in addition to entering an already existing, mandatory 14-day quarantine on arrival.
lead_paragraph: Canada will require passengers seeking to board international flights into the country to show their airline proof of a negative coronavirus test, in addition to entering an already existing, mandatory 14-day quarantine on arrival.

lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Bayle Gelle said he awoke in the middle of the night to the sound of his wife screaming. He plunged shirtless down the stairs and found her in the living room, being confronted by sheriff’s deputies.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It began with a pair of firsts, one hopeful and one grim: The most diverse Congress in the nation’s history was sworn in two years ago during the longest government shutdown.

headline: Homes of Mitch McConnell and Nancy Pelosi Are Reported Vandalized

abstract: Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, called the vandalism of his Louisville, Ky., home a “radical tantrum” taken from a “toxic playbook.”
lead_paragraph: The homes of Senator Mitch McConnell and Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the two most powerful members of Congress, have been reported vandalized, days after the contentious passage of a stimulus bill that has been criticized as inadequate by a broad coalition ranging from progressive activists to President Trump.

headline: What Has Feminism Achieved?
abstract: Readers take issue with an Op-Ed suggesting that the pandemic has undone the advances in gender equity.

headline: Starving Children Don’t Cry
keywords: ['Famine', 'Poverty', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Food Insecurity', 'Malnutrition', 'Children and Childhood', 'Two Thousand Twenty', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization']
abstract: For several years, each year was the best in human history. Then 2020 came along.
lead_paragraph: Starvation is agonizing and degrading. You lose control of your bowels. Your skin peels off, your hair falls out, you hallucinate and you may go blind from lack of vitamin A. While you waste away, your body cannibalizes itself: It consumes its own muscles, even the heart.

headline: The Wreckage Betsy DeVos Leaves Behind
keywords: ['For-Profit Schools', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Student Loans', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The Education Department lies in ruins right when it’s needed most.
lead_paragraph: The departing education secretary, Betsy DeVos, will be remembered as perhaps the most disastrous leader in the Education Department’s history. Her lack of vision has been apparent in a variety of contexts, but never more so than this fall when she told districts that were seeking guidance on how to operate during the coronavirus pandemic that it was not her responsibility to track school district infection rates or keep track of school reopening plans. This telling remark implies a vision of the Education Department as a mere bystander in a crisis that disrupted the lives of more than 50 million schoolchildren.

headline: 25 California prisons have logged more than 1,000 infections. None are in the first wave of vaccinations.
abstract: California’s prison system, which has been exceptionally hard-hit by the coronavirus, has started vaccinating some inmates — but none so far at the 25 prisons that have been most overwhelmed by infections, including San Quentin, Avenal State Prison and the California Institution for Men.
lead_paragraph: California’s prison system, which has been exceptionally hard-hit by the coronavirus, has started vaccinating some inmates — but none so far at the 25 prisons that have been most overwhelmed by infections, including San Quentin, Avenal State Prison and the California Institution for Men.

lead_paragraph: Paul Westphal, the Basketball Hall of Fame guard who played for the Boston Celtics’ 1974 N.B.A. champions, became a four-time All-Star with the Phoenix Suns and coached them to the league playoff final in 1993, died on Saturday. He was 70.

headline: Busting Moves
abstract: Paolo Pasco trips the light fantastic.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — We have had a long run of excellent and tricky themeless weekend puzzles from Paolo Pasco, so when I saw his name today, I anticipated a lot of complexity and intrigue. I didn’t realize that this is only his second Sunday puzzle for the Times. This is unacceptable: Mr. Pasco is practically out of college (a junior at Harvard, majoring in computer science), and should have ramped up his construction pace by now.

keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']

headline: Paige Rense, Trendsetting Editor of Architectural Digest, Dies at 91

headline: Draw the Year Ahead
abstract: A more/less list helps you set your intentions for this new year.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-twenty was a hard year for many people. Drawing is one way to remind yourself of some of the positive things that happened, the things that brought you joy, as well as the stuff you could do without in 2021. An illustrated More/Less list is a relaxed version of the classic New Year’s resolution list, and a way to envision the things you would like more of in your life, and the things you would like to drop. Here’s how to do it:

abstract: If you need a dose of exercise inspiration, it’s easy to find online or on your phone with these guides and apps.
lead_paragraph: It’s a hibernation season like no other: It’s colder and darker, and you're still inside. Which makes it all the more important (and all the harder) to keep yourself moving. As 2021 begins, here are some ideas to get you out of the house, or at least off the couch for a bit.

headline: Spend Less, and Smarter, in 2021
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Personal Finances', 'Content Type: Service', 'Savings', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Last year we were just trying to roll with the punches. Hopefully now we can apply some of those survival skills to our finances.
lead_paragraph: For many people, 2020 was not a year for saving money. Even those who remained employed suddenly found themselves shelling out for unforeseen expenses: A used car because public transport suddenly seemed unsafe. A salary for a pod tutor to help their children with remote learning. Subscriptions to multiple streaming services to make life at home more tolerable.
