Biden Jr. on Thursday proposed a $1.9 trillion rescue package to combat the economic downturn and the Covid-19 crisis, outlining the type of sweeping aid that Democrats have demanded for months and signaling the shift in the federal government’s pandemic response as Mr. Biden prepares to take office.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Theater', 'Music', 'Dancing', 'Children and Childhood', 'Yoga', 'Classical Music', 'Under the Radar Festival', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
lead_paragraph: In May 2019, the dancer and choreographer Bobbi Jene Smith took over the Ellen Stewart Theater at La MaMa, in the East Village, with “Lost Mountain,” a vivid, tempestuous work of dance theater for 10 dancers and musicians. Throughout the coronavirus pandemic, Smith, who is currently La MaMa’s resident artist, has continued working with members of that cast on a sequel of sorts, “Broken Theater,” further excavating the tense, almost familial relationships of the earlier project. “We’ve been really digging into themes of power, love and chaos, which I feel are all around us these days,” Smith said by phone.

headline: A Battle of Singing Stars, With Wings and Feathers
abstract: Bird song competitions — a pastime that is closer to meditation than to competitive sports — are big in Suriname. Success requires years of training and an appreciation for a slower pace of life.
lead_paragraph: PARAMARIBO, Suriname — Every Sunday just after dawn, while much of the city sleeps, a group of men gather on the overgrown lawn of a public park in a quiet neighborhood in the capital of Suriname, South America’s smallest country. They huddle together, and hush.

headline: They Used to Post Selfies. Now They’re Trying to Reverse the Election.
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'QAnon', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Right-wing influencers embraced extremist views, and Facebook rewarded them.
lead_paragraph: Dominick McGee didn’t enter the Capitol during the siege on Jan. 6. He was on the grounds when the mob of Donald Trump supporters broke past police barricades and began smashing windows. But he turned around, heading back to his hotel. Property destruction wasn’t part of his plan. Plus, his phone had died, ending his Facebook Live video midstream. He needed to find a charger. After all, Facebook was a big part of why he was in Washington in the first place.

headline: A Gadget Lover’s Guide to a Cold, Isolated Winter
abstract: No gizmos, it seems, are too out-there when it comes to staying warm (and sane) during a cold, self-isolating winter.
lead_paragraph: We hoarded flour for baking. We bought guitars. We tried everything to get through the cold, early days of the pandemic. But how are we going to make it through winter, trapped at home and cut off from so much of the world? If you’re fortunate enough to have extra bucks lying around this lean economy, here are some gadgets that will keep you warm and vaguely chipper.

headline: Cash, Breakfasts and Firings: An All-Out Push to Vaccinate Wary Medical Workers
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Motivation and Incentive Programs', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Nursing Homes', 'Hospitals', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Employee Fringe Benefits']
abstract: Some staff in hospitals and long-term care facilities don’t want to take the Covid-19 vaccine. Their employers are trying to change their minds.
lead_paragraph: Anxious about taking a new vaccine and scarred by a history of being mistreated, many frontline workers at hospitals and nursing homes are balking at getting inoculated against Covid-19.

headline: Infections remain comparatively rare among children but are rising, the C.D.C. says.
abstract: After falling over the summer, coronavirus infections among children, teens and young adults rose steadily from September through mid-December, paralleling the virus’s trajectory among older adults in the U.S. population, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: After falling over the summer, coronavirus infections among children, teens and young adults rose steadily from September through mid-December, paralleling the virus’s trajectory among older adults in the U.S. population, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Wednesday.

headline: Which Americans can get a vaccine now? Here’s a look at the new guidance.
abstract: Here are answers to some common questions about the U.S. government’s issued recommendations regarding which people in the country should be vaccinated first.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. government, faced with an unrelenting surge in coronavirus cases, issued recommendations this week regarding which people in the country should be vaccinated first. Here are answers to some common questions.

headline: Surges in Arizona and California fuel record U.S. death totals.
abstract: Deaths from the coronavirus are skyrocketing in the United States, reaching levels never before seen, largely fueled by relentless surges in California and Arizona.
lead_paragraph: Deaths from the coronavirus are skyrocketing in the United States, reaching levels never before seen, largely fueled by relentless surges in California and Arizona.

headline: Man Who Sat on Death Row Is Cleared After Bite-Mark Evidence Is Doubted
abstract: Eddie Lee Howard of Mississippi spent more than two decades in prison, but the evidence used to convict him in a 1992 killing is no longer considered reliable.
lead_paragraph: After years of fighting a murder conviction that had relied heavily on dubious evidence, a Mississippi man who spent more than quarter of a century behind bars won dismissal of his case last week.

headline: A Rohingya Camp Fire Leaves Hundreds Homeless
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The blaze comes as officials in Bangladesh look for longer-term solutions for the refugees from Myanmar, who fled anti-Muslim violence.
lead_paragraph: A large fire tore through a crowded Rohingya camp in the Cox’s Bazar area of Bangladesh on Thursday, destroying hundreds of ramshackle shelters and forcing thousands of displaced Muslim refugees to flee in the winter chill.

headline: Ugandans Voted Today. Will Their President of 35 Years Win Again?
abstract: Longtime leader President Yoweri Museveni is facing his toughest challenge ever, and has used all the levers of power at his disposal to try to overcome 10 rivals — including Bobi Wine, a popular lawmaker and musician.
lead_paragraph: Ugandans voted on Thursday in a hotly contested election that will decide whether President Yoweri Museveni wins a sixth term in office and continues his 35-year rule of the country or is unseated by one of 10 rivals, including a leading opposition candidate, Bobi Wine, a rapper-turned-lawmaker.

headline: Swimming With the Sharks in Facebook’s World
abstract: Our columnist is searching for his own niche in a universe dominated by giants.
lead_paragraph: My friends, in these difficult and frightening times, humor is more essential than ever. So let’s talk about antitrust law and content monetization.

headline: Tips for Getting Your Financial Life in Order in Hard Times
keywords: ['Individual Retirement Accounts', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Content Type: Service', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Personal Finances', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Two books provide financial advice for the immediate issues and for retirement. But for deep problems you are likely to need additional help.
lead_paragraph: Two books are intended to help people who are worried about their finances in the midst of this painful pandemic. One suggests ways of improving your situation right now. The other focuses on ensuring that when and if you retire, your accounts will be in solid shape.

headline: A Rally That Won’t Stop or a Bubble About to Pop
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Interest Rates', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Mutual Funds', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: Stock market sentiment and valuations are high, and with bonds expensive, too, there may be few safe places to turn.
lead_paragraph: After a volatile yet profitable 2020, Wall Street is hoping for a calm — and still profitable — 2021. Not just hoping. Expecting.

headline: Impeached, Again
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Impeachment']
abstract: The House of Representatives has voted for President Trump to be tried for a second time. How did it happen and what comes next?
lead_paragraph: “A clear and present danger.” Those were the words used by Nancy Pelosi to describe President Trump, and the main thrust of the Democrats’ arguments for impeachment on the House floor. Not only did the president incite a riot, they argued, but he has also spent months engaging in a broadside against American democracy.

headline: An S.U.V.? Ferrari Sees the Writing on the Road
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Antique and Classic Cars']
abstract: The Purosangue, whose details remain closely held, will be out next year. But the carmaker’s evolving lineup, too, points to a (slightly) more inclusive approach.
lead_paragraph: Like Porsche, Lamborghini and Aston Martin before it — and every workaday carmaker following the crowds — Ferrari is getting into the S.U.V. business.

headline: Unemployment claims jump sharply, showing the pandemic’s continuing economic toll.
abstract: New claims for state unemployment benefits sharply increased last week as the resurgent pandemic continued to batter the economy.
lead_paragraph: New claims for state unemployment benefits sharply increased last week as the resurgent pandemic continued to batter the economy.

headline: ‘The Most Bipartisan Impeachment’
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Even during a scandal, a president’s own party members usually defend him. Decades later, people tend to forget how overwhelming the partisan support was and exaggerate the degree of conscience among politicians of the past.

headline: ‘Locked Down’ Review: In Quarantine, Misery Hates Company
abstract: Anne Hathaway and Chiwetel Ejiofor play a couple sheltering in their London brownstone over the early weeks of the pandemic in this irritating heist comedy.
lead_paragraph: A London couple endures the most mundane of Covid-19 miseries in “Locked Down,” a desultory comedy set in the early weeks of the pandemic.

headline: ‘American Skin’ Review: Out for Justice
abstract: In Nate Parker’s film, a father takes matters into his own hands to hold a police officer to account for shooting down his son.
lead_paragraph: Nate Parker’s “American Skin” opens with a traffic stop, captured on body cams. The driver, Lincoln (played by Parker), watches helplessly as his teenage son, Kijani (Tony Espinosa), is shot down by a police officer. The incident plants the seed for what becomes a kind of vigilante courtroom drama.

headline: ‘The Marksman’ Review: In Need of a Mission
abstract: Liam Neeson plays the reluctant protector of an undocumented Mexican boy in this dusty drama.
lead_paragraph: The plot of “The Marksman,” a melancholy road movie starring Liam Neeson, could fit on a bullet casing, but a list of its clichés would require substantially more space.

headline: A Historic Impeachment and a Big Choice for the Senate
abstract: Trump enters the history books. Now what will McConnell do? This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Trump is impeached — again — but a Senate trial seems a long way off. In the meantime, the authorities are bracing for a rancorous Inauguration Day. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: ‘My Little Sister’ Review: Sibling Dependency
abstract: A cancer diagnosis only strengthens the bond between adult twins in this perceptive Swiss drama.
lead_paragraph: “My Little Sister,” a tender domestic drama from the Swiss writers and directors Stéphanie Chuat and Véronique Reymond, faces terminal illness with a refreshing emotional candor.

headline: ‘Some Kind of Heaven’ Review: Hardly an Idle Retirement
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Elderly']
abstract: This documentary co-produced by The New York Times visits a retirement community the size of a small city.
lead_paragraph: “Some Kind of Heaven,” a documentary co-produced by The New York Times, pierces the bubble of The Villages, a Florida retirement community northwest of Orlando that has grown to the size of a small city. The architecture and even the local lore foster an illusion of history.

headline: ‘Hunted’ Review: Catch Me if You Can
abstract: Riffing on “Little Red Riding Hood,” this sadistic chase movie sends a young woman and two attackers into the deep, dark woods.
lead_paragraph: Adding a fairy-tale cast to a generic horror setup is of no benefit to “Hunted,” Vincent Paronnaud’s unpleasant merger of slasher movie and survival thriller.

headline: ‘One Night in Miami’ Review: After the Big Fight, a War of Words
abstract: A 1964 meeting of Malcolm X, Cassius Clay, Sam Cooke and Jim Brown is the subject of Regina King’s riveting directorial debut.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 25, 1964, at the Convention Hall in Miami Beach, Fla., Cassius Clay — not yet known as Muhammad Ali — defeated Sonny Liston to become the heavyweight champion of the world. That’s hardly a spoiler, and the fight isn’t the main event in “One Night in Miami,” Regina King’s debut feature as a director. The movie is about what happens after the final bell, when Clay and three men who witnessed the fight gather for a low-key after-party that turns into an impromptu seminar on fame, political action and the obligations of Black celebrities in a time of crisis.

headline: ‘Film About a Father Who’ Review: Family Secrets by Omission
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Families and Family Life', 'Polyamory and Non-Monogamous Relationships']
abstract: In her new documentary, Lynne Sachs assesses her relationship with her father, Ira Sachs Sr., who fathered children with multiple women.
lead_paragraph: Lynne Sachs shot the footage that became “Film About a Father Who” from 1984 to 2019, and her ideas about what form the movie might take — along with her impressions of her father — must have changed during that time. (Even movies themselves evolved. “Film About a Father Who” mixes 8- and 16-millimeter film, home videotapes and, from the near present, digital material.)

headline: ‘Bloody Hell’ Review: An Acrid Thriller Bites Off Too Much
abstract: Cannibals and comedy are mixed in this deranged ride from the director Alister Grierson.
lead_paragraph: This noxious thriller makes a hero out of Rex (Ben O’Toole), a military veteran who served time after killing a woman in an attempt to halt an armed robbery. After Rex’s release from prison, he hopes to clear his mind with a trip to Finland — but his vacation is cut short when masked assailants attack him in an airport taxi and blast him with sleeping gas.

headline: These Bond Funds Might Offer Juicy Yields, and Unwelcome Surprises
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'Government Bonds', 'Income', 'Content Type: Service', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Unconstrained bond funds can invest in just about anything, sometimes even stock, so good luck figuring out exactly where they put your money.
lead_paragraph: Investing in a so-called unconstrained bond fund is like that team-building exercise where you fall backward into someone’s arms: It can work, but it requires a lot of trust.

headline: Grubhub will deliver Girl Scout cookies during the pandemic.
abstract: Taking a cue from the battered restaurant industry during the pandemic, the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. said this week that they would offer contactless delivery and pickup of their cookies through Grubhub.
lead_paragraph: Taking a cue from the battered restaurant industry during the pandemic, the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. said this week that they would offer contactless delivery and pickup of their cookies through Grubhub.

headline: France ramps up border controls and extends a nationwide curfew.
abstract: France strengthened border controls and extended a curfew to the entire country on Thursday to keep the coronavirus in check, but authorities warned that new restrictions were possible in the coming days if the epidemic worsened.
lead_paragraph: France strengthened border controls and extended a curfew to the entire country on Thursday to keep the coronavirus in check, but authorities warned that new restrictions were possible in the coming days if the epidemic worsened.

headline: If You Were a Member of Congress, Would You Vote to Impeach President Trump?
abstract: What consequences should the president face for his involvement in inciting a riot at the U.S. Capitol?
lead_paragraph: “The President of the United States summoned this mob, assembled the mob, and lit the flame of this attack,” Representative Liz Cheney, the No. 3 Republican in the House of Representatives, said in a statement on Tuesday. “There has never been a greater betrayal by a president of the United States of his office and his oath to the Constitution.”

headline: Martin Luther King Jr. Day: 9 Ways to Honor His Legacy
abstract: Marches and parades are on pause this year. But streamed events and exhibitions are still commemorating King’s achievements.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. Day, observed this year on Jan. 18, became a national holiday in 1983, 15 years after the death of the civil rights leader. Because the arc of history has a few kinks in it, some states declined to celebrate it until 2000 or adopted names that dilute King’s import. (Alabama and Mississippi observe it in conjunction with Robert E. Lee Day, a symbolic swipe)

keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Presidential Election of 2020']

headline: Harold N. Bornstein, Trump’s Former Personal Physician, Dies at 73
abstract: He attested that President Trump would be the “healthiest president ever,” but he was later expelled from his orbit.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Harold N. Bornstein, who for a time was President Donald J. Trump’s personal physician and who had attested that Mr. Trump would be “the healthiest individual ever elected to the presidency,” died on Friday. He was 73.

lead_paragraph: Not since the dark days of the Civil War and its aftermath has Washington seen a day quite like Wednesday.

headline: Here’s what you need to know for Inauguration Day.
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. will become president of the United States at noon Wednesday in a scaled-back inauguration ceremony. While key elements will remain traditional, many events will be downsized and “reimagined” to better adapt the celebration to a nation battling the coronavirus. Here’s a guide to the event.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. will become president of the United States at noon Wednesday in a scaled-back inauguration ceremony. headline: As Trump is impeached for a second time, Biden tries to stay above the fray.
abstract: The House on Wednesday voted for a historic second impeachment of President Trump, approving 232 to 197 a single article citing his role in whipping up a mob that stormed the Capitol last week. But as his fellow Democrats denounced the assault and Mr. Trump’s incitement of the rioters, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has maintained a studied cool, staying largely removed from the proceedings and keeping his focus on battling the coronavirus pandemic, reviving a faltering economy and lowering the political temperature.
lead_paragraph: The House on Wednesday voted for a historic second impeachment of President Trump, approving 232 to 197 a single article citing his role in whipping up a mob that stormed the Capitol last week. headline: My Brother-in-Law Should Divorce My Sister. Right?
abstract: I’m worried her actions and stubbornness are getting in the way of his happiness.
lead_paragraph: My sister is married to a great guy with a successful military career. He has supported her through diagnoses of mental illness and cancer. But my sister does many frustrating things: She hoards food, feeds her kids junk (they’re obese) and allowed her son to fail a grade in school by letting him stay home and play video games all day while his father was deployed. If anyone talks to my sister in a way she finds remotely critical, she stonewalls that person for days. Her husband is morally opposed to divorce, but I worry about his happiness. In order to maintain a relationship with my sister, I have to pretend everything she does is OK. Please help!

headline: Where Are Home Prices Rising the Most?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mortgages', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: A recent report finds that home prices rose 14 percent nationally over a year. But not all markets are created equal.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic hasn’t just created massive unemployment and economic hardships for millions, it has also inflated real estate prices across the country. A recent report by Redfin found that the national median home price climbed to $335,519 in November, 14 percent higher than a year earlier — the biggest annual gain since July 2013. A record 35 percent of homes sold for over asking price, and sales were swift, with homes averaging just 27 days on the market, a record low.

abstract: Mr. Fischbacher’s death came months after that of Roy Horn, his partner in one of the most spectacular shows in Las Vegas history.
lead_paragraph: Siegfried Fischbacher, the German-born magician who was half of Siegfried & Roy, the team that captivated Las Vegas audiences with performances alongside big cats, elephants and other exotic animals, died on Wednesday night at his home in Las Vegas. He was 81.

headline: ‘Don’t Tell a Soul’ Review: Brothers in Crime Harbor a Secret
abstract: It’s not every day you get to see Rainn Wilson at the bottom of a well, and that’s just the half of it.
lead_paragraph: An opening text in this movie quotes Jane Austen’s words: “What strange creatures brothers are.” No disrespect to Austen, but Cain and Abel beat her to that universal truth, which has run through movies as diverse as “Force of Evil,” “Scanners” and “A Simple Plan.” So, this movie’s writer/director, Alex McAulay, or someone close to him, has read some Jane Austen. Great.

headline: Meet Kidd G, Country Music’s Next Emo-Rap Star
keywords: ['Country Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: A 17-year-old from a small Georgia town built an audience as a rapper on TikTok and SoundCloud before pivoting to country music and inching his way into a notoriously cloistered industry.
lead_paragraph: Kidd G was 11 years old when his older brother, Dustin, got his first car. Dustin wasn’t quite old enough to drive it yet, but he could use it to listen to music, and he and his younger brother would sit in the front seat for hours, soaking in Rae Sremmurd, Young Thug, Chance the Rapper. Before long, Kidd G was teaching himself to freestyle.

Many had feared that the women’s tour was on the verge of folding, after it lost 10 events from 2008 to 2010 while the total annual prize purse went from $60.3 million to $41.4 million.

headline: What to Expect When You’re Expecting the Worst
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Emotions', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Parenting', 'Miscarriages', 'Stillbirth', 'Fear (Emotion)']
abstract: People who have lost pregnancies often emotionally distance themselves when they become pregnant again. But is that healthy?
lead_paragraph: When I was eight weeks pregnant, I felt like a freak. My husband and I had been trying to have our third child for two and a half years. I’d had one miscarriage in that time and an ectopic pregnancy before that. Now I was finally pregnant again and awaiting my third ultrasound. I was supposed to be glowing and excited to see a little gray gummy bear on the sonographer’s screen.

keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Inaugurations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020']

abstract: As the senior wildlife veterinarian at the Uganda Wildlife Authority, Dr. Robert Aruho, 36, finds himself in the very tricky business of moving giraffes.

headline: A Raven Queen Vanishes, and Britain Checks a Prophecy
keywords: ['Birds', 'Myths and Mythical Creatures', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Superstitions']
abstract: One of the resident birds at the Tower of London is feared to have died. Legend says at least six must be kept there, or the nation will fall.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — They flap and lollop and squawk and scavenge. They hold the future of the realm, some say, in their fearsome beaks. And now one of them — their queen, Merlina — has been reclassified to M.I.A. from AWOL, heralding the feared redemption of a purported prophecy dating from the time of King Charles II in the 17th century: When the ravens leave the Tower of London, the building will crumble and the kingdom with it.

headline: Several more Capitol rioters have been arrested including man who carried a Confederate flag inside building.
abstract: A federal prosecutor said that a retired Air Force officer who stormed the Senate chamber holding zip ties had intended to “take hostages.”
lead_paragraph: A man seen holding a Confederate battle flag, a person identified as striking a police officer with a flagpole and a retired firefighter identified as having thrown a fire extinguisher at officers were among those arrested Thursday for their role in the riot at the U.S. Capitol last week.

headline: They Can’t Leave the Bay Area Fast Enough
keywords: ['Relocation of Business', 'Telecommuting', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Work-Life Balance']

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Bay Area struck a hard bargain with its tech workers.

headline: Baryshnikov Arts Announces Digital Season
abstract: New work by Kyle Marshall, Bijayini Satpathy, Justin Hicks and others will debut throughout the spring.
lead_paragraph: The coming digital season at Baryshnikov Arts Center will feature the premieres of seven video works that the organization commissioned in September from artists including Kyle Marshall, Bijayini Satpathy and Justin Hicks. The debuts begin on Feb. 1 with the release of Satpathy’s “Vibhanga,” a piece that draws on classical Indian dance forms, and conclude in late June with Marshall’s “STELLAR,” a choreographed outgrowth of improvisation sessions that he will conduct on Zoom this spring. Each video will be available to stream on-demand for free at bacnyc.org for two weeks.

headline: L.G.B.T.Q. TV Representation Falls for First Time in 5 Years, Glaad Finds
abstract: An annual report found that 9.1 percent of characters scheduled to appear on prime-time broadcast series identified as L.G.B.T.Q. in the 2020-21 season, down from 10.2 percent.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in five years, L.G.B.T.Q. representation on television decreased, an annual report by the L.G.B.T. advocacy organization Glaad has found.

headline: Biden is said to have picked Jaime Harrison as the next D.N.C. chairman.

abstract: Beginning Jan. 26, international travelers bound for the United States must show negative coronavirus test results before boarding their flights. Here’s what you need to know.

headline: Trump and Aides Drove Family Separation at Border, Documents Say
keywords: ['Family Separation Policy (US Immigration)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Children and Childhood', 'Inspectors General', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Notes and testimony from a Justice Department official implicate President Trump and White House aides in the “zero tolerance” policy that led to family separations at the border.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and top aides in the White House aggressively pushed the get-tough policy that led migrant children to be separated from adults at the border with Mexico, according to a top Justice Department official in a new report from the department’s inspector general and other internal documents.

headline: Adriano Espaillat is the latest member of Congress to test positive for the virus after Capitol siege.
abstract: Representative Adriano Espaillat, Democrat of New York, announced on Thursday he had tested positive for the coronavirus, as concerns continue to mount on Capitol Hill that efforts to corral lawmakers into secure locations during last week’s siege by Trump supporters may have led to a super-spreader event.
lead_paragraph: Representative Adriano Espaillat, Democrat of New York, announced on Thursday he had tested positive for the coronavirus, as concerns continue to mount on Capitol Hill that efforts to corral lawmakers into secure locations during last week’s siege by Trump supporters may have led to a super-spreader event.

headline: With Pastry Beers, Have Your Cake and Drink It, Too
abstract: As breweries move beyond challenging flavors, they’re taking inspiration from desserts, snacks and candies.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Edwards has a pretty sweet job. As the head brewer of Oozlefinch Beers & Blending in Fort Monroe, Va., she thinks like a pastry chef, writing beer recipes that use toasted coconut, marshmallows, fruit purées and “more vanilla beans than I can even tell you,” Ms. Edwards said.

lead_paragraph: Next year, the nation’s oldest public park, the Boston Common, will unveil one of the largest memorials in the country dedicated to racial justice: “The Embrace,” designed by the artist Hank Willis Thomas and architects at MASS Design Group.

headline: Cheney facing internal backlash for impeachment vote as Republican rifts deepen over Trump.
abstract: A group of President Trump’s most strident allies in the House is calling on Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming, the No. 3 Republican, to resign from her leadership post after she voted to impeach Mr. Trump, dramatizing the bitter rifts within the party and setting up a messy internal feud that could define its future.

abstract: Andrew Yang favors a modified version of universal basic income that would provide payments of about $2,000 to a half million of the poorest New Yorkers.

lead_paragraph: President Trump, who became the first U.S. president to be impeached twice, is facing a trial in the Senate that could disqualify him from running for office again.

headline: Howard Johnson, 79, Dies; Elevated the Tuba in Jazz and Beyond
abstract: He helped to find a new role for a notoriously cumbersome instrument in a wide range of musical settings, including the “Saturday Night Live” band.
lead_paragraph: Howard Johnson, who set a new standard by expanding the tuba’s known capacities in jazz, and who moonlighted as a multi-instrumentalist and arranger for some of the most popular acts in rock and pop, died on Monday at his home in Harlem. He was 79.

headline: After Barring Trump, Facebook and Twitter Face Scrutiny About Inaction Abroad
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Hate Speech', 'Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Human rights groups and activists have spent years urging the companies to do more to remove content that encouraged violence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In Sri Lanka and Myanmar, Facebook kept up posts that it had been warned contributed to violence. In India, activists have urged the company to combat posts by political figures targeting Muslims. And in Ethiopia, groups pleaded for the social network to block hate speech after hundreds were killed in ethnic violence inflamed by social media.

headline: MF Doom, Magician of Memory
abstract: With his 1999 debut album, “Operation: Doomsday,” the masked rapper blurred the line between present and past.
lead_paragraph: “By candlelight, my hand will write these rhymes ’til I’m burnt out,” MF Doom raps at the beginning of “?,” the final song before the epilogue on his 1999 debut album, “Operation: Doomsday.”

keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: His documentary series chronicled the lives of its subjects every seven years since 1964. Now the participants ponder whether it can carry on without him.
lead_paragraph: Every seven years or so for more than half a century, the filmmaker Michael Apted returned to what he referred to as his life’s work: documenting the same ordinary people he’d known since they were 7 years old.

lead_paragraph: In early January, Nali Gillespie watched her social media feeds fill with vaccine selfies: Photo after photo of her peers at other medical schools around the country posed proudly next to a syringe with their dose of either the Moderna or Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine.

headline: Consumer Groups Target Amazon Prime’s Cancellation Process
keywords: ['Consumer Protection', 'Customer Relations', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A Norwegian group filed a complaint with regulators, saying Amazon had deliberately made it difficult to end memberships to its Prime service. Groups in Europe and the U.S. back the effort.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Those who have tried ending a membership in Amazon Prime, the technology giant’s digital subscription service, may be familiar with the multi-click process: warnings that cancellation will mean losing “exclusive benefits,” and prompts to reverse course, or switch to an annual membership instead.

headline: ‘MLK/FBI’ Review: King, Hoover and the Tale of the Tape
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: Sam Pollard’s fascinating documentary chronicles the F.B.I. director’s obsession with the private life and political affiliations of the civil rights leader.
lead_paragraph: In some ways, “MLK/FBI,” Sam Pollard’s new documentary, tells a straightforward story suggested by the title. Drawing on long-secret documents — and anticipating the eventual release of recordings held in the National Archives — the film chronicles the F.B.I.’s surveillance and harassment of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: ‘WandaVision’ Review: That’s Why They Became the Disney+ Bunch
abstract: A new TV era for Marvel’s roster of superheroes begins with — a high-concept salute to classic sitcoms?
lead_paragraph: R.I.P., “Jessica Jones,” “Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.,” “Runaways” and all your first-wave Marvel Television comrades. You were a motley bunch, scattered across the TV and streaming landscape, but you provided some solid entertainment value over the last seven years, until the corporate Thanos in Burbank decided your time was up.

headline: ‘Acasa, My Home’ Review: Civilization and Its Malcontents
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: A family’s dispossession to make way for a nature park is the subject of this Romanian documentary.
lead_paragraph: The home in “Acasa, My Home” is a wild, marshy expanse on the outskirts of Bucharest, an abandoned reservoir populated mainly by birds, fish and insects. At the beginning of this documentary, directed by Radu Ciorniciuc, the only human residents are Gica Enache, his wife, Niculina, and their nine children. Surrounded by chickens, hogs, pigeons and dogs, they live in proud, occasionally belligerent defiance of “civilization,” a word Gica utters with disdain.

headline: Disabled Americans Are Losing a Lifeline
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Poverty', 'Welfare (US)', 'Social Security (US)', 'Elderly']
abstract: Biden can help.
lead_paragraph: At a time when the pandemic has hit the disabled and elderly the hardest, they also face the erosion of a critical income lifeline, Supplemental Security Income (S.S.I.). The program has collapsed during the pandemic: From July to November 2020, the Social Security Administration awarded benefits to about 100,000 fewer individuals compared with the same period in 2019. In July 2020 the agency distributed just 38,318 new awards — the fewest in 20 years of available data.

headline: Why Are India’s Farmers Angry?
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Rice', 'Politics and Government', 'Sikhs and Sikhism', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Punjabi (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: The protesting farmers fear that new laws will help giant corporations and leave them at their mercy.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Despite rain and cold, tens of thousands of angry farmers have been camping on the borders of New Delhi for six weeks. In late September, Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government hurriedly passed a set of new farm laws in the Indian Parliament. Soon after, protests started in the northern Indian states of Punjab and Haryana, which constitute 3 percent of the country’s land area but produce close to 50 percent of its surplus of rice and wheat.

headline: What Students Are Saying About the Riot at the U.S. Capitol
abstract: We invited teenagers to share what they were feeling, noticing and wondering about the shocking and chaotic events as they unfolded. Here is what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the attack on the U.S. Capitol last Wednesday, we asked students “What Are Your Reactions to the Storming of the Capitol by a Pro-Trump Mob?” We hoped to give students a place to share what they were feeling, noticing and wondering about the shocking and chaotic events as they unfolded.

headline: ‘2020 Has Been a Wake-Up Call’: Reflections on Our Civil Conversation Challenge
abstract: Teenagers posted over 12,000 comments in response to our invitation to talk about politics across divides. We loved the results.
lead_paragraph: Please note: As this piece publishes — and as the United States heads toward the inauguration of a new president even as the current president is impeached for the second time — we are also publishing a summary of the 1,200-plus teenage reactions to our Jan. 6 Student Opinion question, What Are Your Reactions to the Storming of the Capitol by a Pro-Trump Mob? Though that forum focused on individual response rather than conversation, many of the positive qualities we identify below are on display there as well. Thank you, students, for raising your voices.

headline: Death Was a Theory, Until I Became a Mother
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Philosophy', 'Books and Literature', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: An existential philosopher reflects on the mortality of motherhood.
lead_paragraph: About a year ago, out of the corner of my eye, I saw my 3-year-old ball up a large wad of dental floss and shove it into her mouth. Images of floss twined around her tiny intestines flicked through my mind. My pulse spiked as I begged her to spit it out. When she grinned and shook her head, I stuck my finger into her mouth to pry her jaws open — like a dog I didn’t want to take to the vet for surgery.

headline: Coronavirus Cases Surge in Arizona
abstract: Arizona has recorded the highest number of new coronavirus cases per capita in the country. A medical official said the hospital systems are under “immense pressure” to keep up with the amount of Covid-19 patients.

lead_paragraph: Three months after Nancy Spector stepped down as artistic director and chief curator of the Guggenheim Museum amid charges of racism, the museum named Naomi Beckwith, who is Black, to the position of deputy director and chief curator.

headline: Toyota to Pay a Record Fine for a Decade of Clean Air Act Violations
abstract: Toyota’s $180 million settlement with the federal government follows a series of emissions-related scandals in the auto industry.
lead_paragraph: Toyota Motor is set to pay a $180 million fine for longstanding violations of the Clean Air Act, the U.S. attorney’s Office in Manhattan announced on Thursday, the largest civil penalty ever levied for a breach of federal emissions-reporting requirements.

headline: Abandon Trump? Deep in the G.O.P. Ranks, the MAGA Mind-Set Prevails
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'State Legislatures', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: As President Trump prepares to exit the White House, his ideas, including falsehoods and conspiracy theories, continue to exert a gravitational pull among grass-roots G.O.P. officials.
lead_paragraph: In Cleveland County, Okla., the chairman of the local Republican Party openly wondered “why violence is unacceptable,” just hours before a mob stormed the U.S. Capitol last week. “What the crap do you think the American revolution was?” he posted on Facebook. “A game of friggin pattycake?”

headline: Mary Catherine Bateson Dies at 81; Anthropologist on Lives of Women
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Archaeology and Anthropology', 'Writing and Writers', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: After a well-documented childhood as the daughter of Margaret Mead, she earned her own renown with a book on women’s lives that became a touchstone to feminists.
lead_paragraph: Mary Catherine Bateson, a cultural anthropologist who was the author of quietly groundbreaking books on women’s lives — and who as the only child of Margaret Mead had once been one of the most famous babies in America — died on Jan. 2 in Lebanon, N.H. She was 81.

headline: Trump Appointee to Temporarily Lead Pentagon; Retired Admiral Will Be Spokesman
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: David Norquist will be Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s acting defense secretary, if only for a few days. A retired rear admiral, John Kirby, will be the Pentagon press secretary.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A low-profile deputy defense secretary will be the lone Trump holdover running the Pentagon until President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s defense secretary pick is confirmed. Mr. Biden is also planning to install John F. Kirby — the former spokesman for John Kerry when he was secretary of state, Chuck Hagel when he was defense secretary and Mike Mullen when he was chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff — as the next Pentagon press secretary.

headline: Ted Lumpkin Jr., a Tuskegee Airman, Dies at 100
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'World War II (1939-45)']

headline: Working Women of Color Were Making Progress. Then the Coronavirus Hit.
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Women and Girls', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Income Inequality', 'Unemployment', 'Minorities', 'Minimum Wage', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Those hard-won gains were never guaranteed to last. Now we’re seeing just how precarious they were all along.
lead_paragraph: For years, the story of working women in the United States has been one of slow but steady progress. Against this backdrop, the latest monthly employment figures from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics delivered an acute shock.

headline: The U.K. bans travel from Latin America and Portugal, citing concern about a Brazilian variant.
abstract: Britain said on Thursday that it would ban arrivals from Latin American countries and Portugal over fears of a coronavirus variant discovered in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Britain said on Thursday that it would ban arrivals from Latin American countries and Portugal over fears of a coronavirus variant discovered in Brazil.

headline: Murkowski signals she is open to convicting Trump as the timing of the Senate impeachment trial remains unclear.
abstract: Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, said on Thursday that the House had acted “appropriately” in impeaching President Trump, signaling possible support for convicting him at a Senate trial in a statement that called his actions “unlawful” and said that they warranted consequences.

headline: Trump Ignites a War Within the Church
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Evangelical Movement', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Whites', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: After a week of Trumpist mayhem, white evangelicals wrestle with what they’ve become.
lead_paragraph: “Over the last 72 hours, I have received multiple death threats and thousands upon thousands of emails from Christians saying the nastiest and most vulgar things I have ever heard toward my family and ministry. I have been labeled a coward, sellout, a traitor to the Holy Spirit, and cussed out at least 500 times.”

headline: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: There’s no escaping American politics lately, so why not lean in? We recommend three books this week that provide perspective and historical context, from a study of the modern Senate to a true crime narrative about the fall of Vice President Spiro Agnew to an analysis of the Truman administration’s embrace of a robust foreign policy. Elsewhere, we also like a book about the Himalaya mountains, a memoir of mental breakdown and a history of the animation industry’s wild early days, along with novels about lexicography (yes, really) and parenting, a book about exercise, and more.

headline: U.S. Blacklisting of Yemen’s Houthis May Cause ‘Large-Scale Famine,’ U.N. Warns
abstract: U.N. officials say that the designation of the Houthis as a terrorist organization could choke food deliveries to Yemen, where millions face starvation.
lead_paragraph: Warning that Yemen could be consumed by a large-scale famine, top relief officials at the United Nations implored the United States on Thursday to scrap its blacklisting of Yemen’s Houthi insurgent group, arguing that the move could effectively sever food deliveries to a country where millions already face the threat of starvation.

headline: Madrid Mayor Says Snowstorm Caused Nearly $2 Billion in Damage
abstract: The storm, named Filomena, dropped more than a foot and a half of snow on the city and its surrounding areas.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Madrid’s mayor on Thursday called on the central government to declare Spain’s capital a disaster zone, warning that the damage caused by last weekend’s snowstorm would cost at least 1.4 billion euros, or $1.7 billion, to fix.

headline: Overwhelmed, More States Turn to National Guard for Vaccine Help
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Reserves (Military)', 'Public-Private Sector Cooperation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'States (US)']
abstract: At least 16 states and territories are using the National Guard to give shots, drawing on doctors, nurses, medics and other troops who are skilled in administering injections.
lead_paragraph: LANDOVER, Md. — As tens of thousands of his National Guard colleagues descended on the nation’s capital to ensure the peaceful transfer of presidential power, 10 miles up the road, Emmanuel Alfaro was doing what he viewed as the pinnacle of his career in the Guard: administering Covid-19 vaccines to his fellow citizens.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: If you need soothing, an escape, or something that’s just fun, there’s plenty worth checking out.

headline: A Conversation on ‘The Custom of the Country’

lead_paragraph: T Book Club consists of a series of articles and discussions dedicated to classic works of American literature. Here, our second (virtual) event, on the topic of Edith Wharton’s 1913 novel, “The Custom of the Country,” featuring the writer Claire Messud in conversation with T features director Thessaly La Force, and taking place at 7 p.m. E.S.T. on Jan. 28.

headline: Help Us Write the Weekly News Quiz
abstract: Every week, we test your knowledge. Now we want to tap your brainpower for compiling questions.
lead_paragraph: We invite New York Times readers to submit a question for our weekly News Quiz. Our favorite questions aren’t just matters of trivia — they also include subtle clues that allow people to puzzle out the answers. You can find examples in a recent quiz or in our year-end 2020 quiz.

headline: Helga Weyhe, Germany’s Oldest Bookseller, Dies at 98
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: She died above the bookstore, founded in 1840, where she had worked since the waning months of World War II. She locked it up for the last time in December.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After Helga Weyhe locked up her bookstore in the town of Salzwedel, Germany, each evening, she would make her usual commute — a trudge to the apartment upstairs. She had been making the same trip since World War II, just as her father had before then, and as her grandfather had before him.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Hospitals and nursing homes are using both carrots and sticks to get employees inoculated.
lead_paragraph: One reason that the start to the U.S. vaccination campaign has been so sluggish is that health care workers — among the first to be eligible — have proved more reluctant to get the inoculation than expected.

headline: Sherrod Brown Thinks Progressives Will Be ‘Pretty Happy’ With Biden
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In an interview, the incoming Senate Banking Committee chairman opened up about bypassing bipartisanship if necessary, the looming housing crisis and more.
lead_paragraph: Early in the morning on Jan. 6, Senator Sherrod Brown of Ohio woke up pleasantly surprised. Democratic victories in both Georgia Senate runoffs the night before meant he was suddenly poised to become chairman of the Senate Banking and Housing Committee, whose expansive purview includes oversight of the nation’s central bank, our financial system, the housing market and a wide network of executive branch agencies.

headline: Film Club: Three Short Films Celebrating the Lives of People We Lost to the Pandemic
abstract: How should we honor and remember those we have lost to Covid?

headline: Impeachment Briefing: Republicans Divided
abstract: Some Republicans  are thinking about voting for President Trump’s impeachment, as the Senate prepares for a trial.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week my colleague Jonathan Martin reported that Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, had concluded that Mr. Trump committed impeachable offenses and believes impeachment could make it easier to purge Mr. Trump from the party. I asked him more about how Mr. McConnell reached this point.

headline: Pastor Who Advised Two Presidents Is Sentenced to 6 Years for Cheating Investors
abstract: Kirbyjon H. Caldwell was senior pastor of the Windsor Village United Methodist Church in Houston and rose to prominence as a supporter of George W. Bush and Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: The former pastor of a Houston megachurch who advised former Presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama was sentenced on Wednesday to six years in prison after he pleaded guilty to cheating investors in a multimillion-dollar scheme, prosecutors said.

headline: A Look at What’s in Biden’s $1.9 Trillion Stimulus Plan
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Wages and Salaries', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Minimum Wage', 'Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Presidential Transition (US)']

lead_paragraph: The incoming Biden administration unveiled a $1.9 trillion stimulus plan on Thursday that offered a wish list of spending measures meant to help both people and the economy recover from the coronavirus pandemic, from state and local aid and more generous unemployment benefits to mass vaccinations.

keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'National Debt (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Basically, damn the torpedoes, full speed ahead.
lead_paragraph: Here we go again. For the second time in 12 years a newly elected Democratic president is inheriting an economy in deep distress. And while it’s hard to focus on such things after last week’s Trumpist putsch, a lot depends on whether Joe Biden’s plan to deal with our economic woes is effective.

lead_paragraph: The director of the Indian Health Service has said that he will resign, giving President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. a chance to install new leadership at an agency that has drawn intense criticism for its failures to provide adequate care to tribal communities both before and during the pandemic.

headline: Officials Assure the Public That Inauguration Will Be Safe

abstract: Vice President Mike Pence met with federal law enforcement officials on Thursday who said they were monitoring online chatter about potential protests. The vice president sought to assure the public that the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. would be safe.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Mike Pence met with federal law enforcement officials on Thursday who said they were monitoring online chatter about potential protests. The vice president sought to assure the public that the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. would be safe.

headline: One Basketball Might Not Be Enough for the New-Look Nets
abstract: With James Harden, the Nets now have an elite trio of ball-dominant playmakers. Yet there are key differences in how Kevin Durant and Kyrie Irving thrive that could allow this grand experiment to work.
lead_paragraph: The Nets’ jaw-dropping trade for James Harden has initiated a grand experiment never before tried at this scale: Can three ball-dominant playmakers coexist after spending most of their careers in offenses tailored to their needs?

headline: After 2 Impeachments, Giuliani Vows to Continue His Fervor for Trump
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Legal Profession', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: White House officials are universally angry with Rudolph W. Giuliani and blame him for both of President Trump’s impeachments. But he remains one of few people still willing to join Mr. Trump in the foxhole.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Rudolph W. Giuliani was treating his efforts to carry out President Trump’s wishes to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election as a payment opportunity — he proposed a daily retainer of $20,000 for his legal services from the burgeoning Trump campaign legal fund — the president dismissed it and responded by demanding to personally approve each expense.

headline: Senate Plans Trial for Trump as G.O.P. Weighs Risks of Convicting
keywords: ['Impeachment', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senate leaders were working to agree on a dual track to try the departing president at the same time it considered the agenda of the incoming one, an exercise never tried before.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A day after the House impeached President Trump for inciting a violent insurrection at the Capitol, Democrats and Republicans in the Senate were developing plans on Thursday to try the departing president at the same time as they begin considering the agenda of the incoming one.

headline: Inaugural Security Is Fortified in D.C. as Military and Police Links Are Eyed in Riot
keywords: ['Inaugurations', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)']
abstract: Dozens of people in Washington on the day of the attack on the Capitol were said to be on a terrorism watch list.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of armed National Guard troops were on their way to Washington to bolster security for next week’s inaugural celebration as federal investigators turned their attention to the difficult question of how many military and police personnel took part in the violent attack on the Capitol, a law enforcement official said on Thursday.

headline: Raiders Owner Mark Davis Is Set to Buy W.N.B.A.’s Las Vegas Aces
abstract: If the deal is approved by the league’s board of directors, Davis is expected to upgrade facilities for the team.
lead_paragraph: Mark Davis has agreed to buy the Las Vegas Aces of the W.N.B.A. from MGM Resorts International, a move that may raise the visibility of the team, which arrived in the city three years ago. Davis is also the owner of the N.F.L.’s Raiders, who just finished their first season in Las Vegas after relocating from Oakland.

headline: Australia’s States Are Feuding Like Siblings. What Else to Do but Laugh?
abstract: Australians are facing a messy patchwork of border restrictions that lock out both the coronavirus and fellow citizens. A new ad offers a biting, if humorous, commentary on the state of affairs.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The viral ad begins with a man repainting a towering concrete barrier. “Today marks 10 years since our once united nation was divided by the Great State Walls,” a TV presenter announces.

headline: Sentimentality
abstract: With Josh Knapp in the house, we can’t help but smile.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — After a wearying week like this one, when the Earth seems to wobble in its orbit, and mortality catches up with your chatty elderly cat, leaving the house strangely hushed, what you need is comfort food — or its crossword equivalent. For that we are lucky to have Josh Knapp, a Michelin-quality word-bender who can nourish and challenge us simultaneously, and leave us with a brighter outlook.

headline: Life Sentence for White Man Who Fatally Stabbed Black Student in Maryland
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Hate Crimes', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Law and Legislation']

lead_paragraph: A 25-year-old white man who stabbed a Black college student to death during a chance encounter on the University of Maryland’s main campus in 2017 in what prosecutors said was a racially motivated hate crime was sentenced on Thursday to life in prison.

headline: Bruno Fernandes and the Long Game
abstract: The Portuguese midfielder’s circuitous path to Manchester United stardom revealed inefficiencies in soccer’s vast scouting system, and how even a sure thing can almost slip through the cracks.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — What strikes Martelinho, whenever he watches Bruno Fernandes play, is how little he has changed. Fernandes might now be the best player on the in-form team in the world’s biggest league, but to Martelinho, he is not recognizably different from the teenager he coached in the youth teams of a struggling Portuguese club a decade ago.

headline: Lockdown Was Our Breaking Point
abstract: We needed to marry for our relationship to survive. But “le confinement” was too much.
lead_paragraph: Our two-year-old marriage was already struggling before the pandemic sent France into lockdown. Now here we were, stuck in our Paris apartment with my two teenage sons. “Le confinement,” as the French lyrically call it.

headline: U.S. Executes Corey Johnson for 7 Murders in 1992
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Johnson’s execution, the 12th during the Trump administration, was carried out weeks after he found out he had the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration executed Corey Johnson on Thursday for a series of seven murders in 1992. He was the 12th federal inmate put to death under President Trump.

headline: Joe the Pigeon Is Spared the Death Sentence in Australia

lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The racing pigeon seemed to have traveled far, from Oregon, when it showed up weak and hungry in a backyard in a Melbourne suburb.

headline: At Least 46 Killed and Hundreds Injured as Quake Hits Indonesia
abstract: The 6.2-magnitude earthquake, Indonesia’s third deadly disaster in a week, struck Sulawesi island, flattening a hospital, destroying homes and setting off landslides.
lead_paragraph: A 6.2-magnitude earthquake struck the western coast of Sulawesi island in Indonesia early Friday, killing at least 46 people, destroying houses, flattening a hospital and setting off landslides, disaster officials said.

keywords: ['Street Performers', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Impersonators and Impressionists (Entertainment)', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Mr. Kwok, who busked in the Chinese territory for 28 years, was hardly the first Elvis Presley impersonator in Asia. But he may have been the most committed.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For nearly three decades, Melvis Kwok spent his evenings dressed as Elvis Presley, playing guitar on the sidewalks of Hong Kong as neon signs reflected off his sequined jumpsuits.

lead_paragraph: AMNESTY, by Aravind Adiga. (Scribner, 272 pp., $17.) The “driving force” of this “thriller-like” novel by the Booker Prize-winning Indian-Australian author of “The White Tiger” is an unsolved murder about which its undocumented protagonist has information. Praising its “humanity,” Juan Gabriel Vásquez, our reviewer, declared it “an urgent and significant book.”

lead_paragraph: Do you have any siblings? If yes, do you ever fight? OK, silly question; what do you and your siblings fight about when you have conflicts?

headline: No, the Chaos in America Is Not a Gift to China and Russia
abstract: Autocrats around the world won’t gain from the United States’ pain.
lead_paragraph: Is the political disarray in the United States really “a godsend for America’s critics” or a “propaganda coup” for them? Is Chris Coons, a Democratic senator from Delaware, correct to warn that the crisis of American democracy “feeds into the playbooks of authoritarian leaders around the world?”

headline: A Surprising Instant Connection
abstract: Their match on Tinder didn’t reveal how similar the backgrounds of Rohini Pragasam and Chris Walton were. But they soon learned during their first date at a Japanese restaurant.
lead_paragraph: When Rohini Pragasam and Chris Walton met for a first date in April 2018 at a Japanese restaurant in Manhattan, each had arrived in anticipation of impressing the other with knowledge of all-things Japan.

headline: Finding Their Second Wind
abstract: When Dr. Mariann Channell and Benson Woo, both widowed, met on Match.com in December 2019 they bonded over jazz and sailing. Both felt “fortunate to have found each other.”
lead_paragraph: For Dr. Mariann Channell and Benson Woo, life is good.

headline: A Data-Driven Courtship Leads to a Rooftop Wedding
abstract: Nicole Woon and Jeffrey Chheng had a first date at a Seattle gelato parlor, their second at a sushi restaurant. Since then, a spreadsheet documents their relationship, meal by meal.
lead_paragraph: The spreadsheet that Nicole Alison Woon and Jeffrey Ryan Chheng use to record the restaurants they’ve patronized in Seattle, about  500 and counting, can be read as an oblique diary of the couple’s developing relationship. It contains Umi Sake House, the sushi spot where Ms. Woon and Mr. Chheng had their second date; RN74, a Valentine’s Day tradition every year since they began dating in 2017; and Sushi Kashiba, a birthday favorite of Ms. Woon’s and a place that evokes their time traveling in Japan.

headline: A Very Long Engagement Runs Its Course
abstract: Dharmesh Desai’s second proposal to Claire Umeda, six years after the first, stuck. They married on the ski slopes of Squaw Valley, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Dharmesh Desai moved to Silicon Valley in 2008 to take a job at a start-up. He met Claire Umeda on the job.

headline: Should You Worry About Your Kid’s Pandemic Weight Gain?
abstract: Think of body changes as something to be curious about, not a problem to be solved.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, scientists predicted that the Covid-19 pandemic might contribute to a rise in children’s body weight, because of school closures and families hunkering down with comfort foods, lacking access to healthful meal options and exercising less. Yet while we know that childhood hunger has risen precipitously during the pandemic, we don’t have much data on whether children’s body sizes have changed in the past year.

headline: Speed Swiping Right to a Warm, Winning Smile
abstract: Rachel Heyman spent an evening bingeing on Tinder and reality TV when Adam Joseph’s picture caught her eye.

headline: Bride and Groom, Side by Side in a Preschool Photo
abstract: On their first date in New York, Alex Olsman and Zach Frankel realized they had gone to the same Montessori preschool in Philadelphia, but had no memory of ever meeting.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Levy Olsman and Zachary Isaac Frankel lived across Rittenhouse Square from each other at a young age and went to the same Montessori preschool in Philadelphia. But, when a mutual friend introduced them in October 2016, they had no memory of ever meeting.

headline: When Raf Met Miuccia
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'your-feed-fashion', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: In an exclusive joint interview, Miuccia Prada and Raf Simons talk about working together, what to expect in their debut men’s collection and why they think the fashion world isn’t going to change.
lead_paragraph: Imagine Mark Zuckerberg naming Elon Musk his co-chief executive, or Steven Spielberg declaring that from now on he would co-direct all of his films with George Clooney. That’s what it was like for the fashion world when, last February, Miuccia Prada announced that she was naming Raf Simons, the former creative director of Jil Sander, Dior and Calvin Klein, to be her co-creative director at Prada.

headline: Snapchat Wants You to Post. It’s Willing to Pay Millions.

headline: After a Few Dates, They Traveled to the Other Side of the World
abstract: Jeffrey Basting, a government refugee officer, was on a two-month assignment in New Orleans when he met Hallie Dietsch. She didn’t think that their relationship could last.
lead_paragraph: Imagine this: In the wee hours one morning, during a vacation in Southeast Asia, you set off with a guide to hike to the top of Mount Merapi, a volcano in Indonesia. After a grueling, miles-long plod, you arrive at the top, just in time for sunrise. You find the perfect spot to sit. As you gaze across the fiery sky, you can sense the earth breathing beneath you. Then, all of a sudden, you hear a loud whirring from above. You look up. You see the belly of something mechanical. With horror, you realize that a Canadian guy in another hiking party has piloted his drone directly above your head. And just like that, your moment of transcendence has been snuffed out, 21st century style.

headline: ‘Stop the Steal’ Didn’t Start With Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mainstream Republicans and conservative commentators have been pushing the idea that Democrats can win only through fraud for decades.
lead_paragraph: To explain the attack on the Capitol, you can’t just turn your focus to Donald Trump and his enablers. You must also look at the individuals and institutions that fanned fears of “voter fraud” to the point of hysteria among conservative voters, long before Trump. Put another way, the difference between a riot seeking to overturn an election and an effort to suppress opposing votes is one of legality, not intent. And it doesn’t take many steps to get from one to the other.

headline: Trump’s Inevitable End

lead_paragraph: The House Judiciary Committee’s impeachment report quotes, at length, the speech that Donald Trump gave to his devotees on Jan. 6 before many of them stormed the Capitol, baying for execution.

headline: Disneyland as a Vaccination Site? Airports as Test Centers? The Travel Industry Pitches In
abstract: Devastated by the pandemic, many travel companies have become part of an ad hoc relief effort.
lead_paragraph: Five months ago, San Francisco International Airport opened the first airport rapid coronavirus testing site in the United States. Nine months ago, some of the world’s most luxurious hotels, including Claridges in London and the Four Seasons in New York, began housing frontline doctors and nurses. And now another entity in the travel world is performing its own pandemic shift: Disneyland. This week the Anaheim, Calif., theme park began serving as a vaccination super site.

headline: A Well-Planned Date That Sealed the Deal and Inspired an App

But they couldn’t have been blamed for expecting to attend a more action-packed celebration than normal.

headline: The Essential Octavia Butler
abstract: She created vivid new worlds to reveal truths about our own. Here’s where to start with her books.
lead_paragraph: Octavia Butler walked a singular path. A writer from her poverty-stricken childhood to her death in 2006 at the age of 58, she committed her life to turning speculative fiction into a home for Black expression. In her hands, the genre felt capacious and infinite. “I wrote myself in,” she told The New York Times in 2000.

headline: My Grandfather Was a Good Cop. Or Was He?
keywords: ['Police', 'Grandparents', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: I idolized him and his larger-than-life role in law enforcement. It’s more complicated now.
lead_paragraph: When my son crawls into my closet, he finds my grandfather’s police star. He flips open the heavy leather billfold. Etched into gold metal are the words “Chief, Stickney, Illinois.” When he moves onto another toy, I lift the suede protecting the star and slide out the ID card. There’s my grandfather’s signature, his cursive E, blue ink that still looks wet: Edward — a name I’ve passed on to my son.
