abstract: Consumer spending fell 0.7 percent, the Commerce Department reported, as the economic recovery showed signs of stalling.
lead_paragraph: Consumer spending fell for the third consecutive month in December, confirming what many economists had predicted would be a disappointing holiday season for many retailers and restaurants.

headline: Merkel’s Party to Choose New Leader, and Possible Successor as Chancellor
abstract: After nearly a year of jockeying, no clear front-runner has emerged to lead Germany’s Christian Democratic Union. Three men are vying for delegates’ votes this weekend.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s largest political party will choose a new leader on Saturday, with the winner well positioned to succeed Angela Merkel as the next chancellor of Europe’s leading economy.

headline: With Vaccines Arriving, Value Investors Try for a Comeback
abstract: After years of lagging performance, practitioners of an old approach to investing are hoping their time is nigh.
lead_paragraph: Value investors have had a tough decade, with growth stocks stealing the investing show.

headline: Joan Collins Puts Her Midtown Co-op on the Market
abstract: The three-bedroom, three-bath apartment at 110 East 57th Street, which the “Dynasty” star and her husband had used as a pied-à-terre, is being listed for $2.095 million.
lead_paragraph: The actress Joan Collins is selling her longtime Manhattan pied-à-terre, a spacious co-op where she entertained a host of celebrity friends.

headline: Blue-Collar Boom: How China Bounced Back From the Virus
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Sauces']
abstract: Officials pushed factories to reopen the same way they forced the country to shut down. In one small town, it led to a chili-sauce-fueled revival.
lead_paragraph: CHANGMINGZHEN, China — The smell, salty and pungent, wafts through the freshly paved streets near the gleaming new factory.

headline: ‘Tiny Pretty Things’ Falls for Big Ugly Ballet Stereotypes
abstract: Why is it so hard to show the dance world as it is? This Netflix series about students at a ballet school is yet another cartoonish depiction.
lead_paragraph: In the opening moments of the Netflix series “Tiny Pretty Things,” a young woman in a white dress spins along the edge of a roof. A voice-over — female and confiding, with the air of a cult survivor — spells it out: “The truth is you only fly for a second or two before gravity takes back what you tried to steal. Because no matter how hard you work, how strong you are or how thin you get, gravity always, always wins.”

headline: Regina King: Speaking Truth to Power Through Her Art
abstract: The actress-turned-director of “One Night in Miami” explains why she sees the fact-based drama about a meeting of four icons as a companion piece to “Watchmen.”
lead_paragraph: “One Night in Miami,” which will arrive on Amazon Prime on Friday, is a fictional account of a real 1964 meeting of four legends. On Feb. 24 of that year, Muhammad Ali, Jim Brown, Sam Cooke and Malcolm X got together several hours after the boxer won his first World Heavyweight Championship. Although in real life they did share ice cream as they do onscreen, in the film’s imagining, they also listened to music and vigorously debated their roles in and the goals of the civil rights movement.

headline: Trump Tried to End Federal Arts Funding. Instead, It Grew.
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Endowments', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Each year, President Trump’s proposed federal budget eliminated funding for the National Endowment for the Arts. But the agency survived, largely by relying on bipartisan support in Congress.
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump became the first president to make a formal proposal to eliminate the National Endowment for the Arts, the future looked grim to the many artists and cultural organizations that have long worried about conservative efforts to close the federal arts-funding agency.

headline: What to Watch: ’80s Romantic Comedies
abstract: The 1989 release of "When Harry Met Sally ..." was "a moon-landing sort of event" for rom-coms. Here are five movies that define the decade.
lead_paragraph: The 1989 release of "When Harry Met Sally ..." was "a moon-landing sort of event" for rom-coms. Here are five movies that define the decade.

headline: Federal watchdogs open a far-reaching investigation into failures in the lead-up to the Capitol riot.
abstract: Inspectors general from a range of federal agencies are opening a coordinated investigation into the catastrophic failures that led to the riot at the Capitol on Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: Inspectors general from a range of federal agencies are opening a coordinated investigation into the catastrophic failures that led to the riot at the Capitol on Jan. 6, amid reports that officials ignored, downplayed and responded sluggishly to a deadly assault on the nation’s core democratic institutions.

headline: Russia to Exit Open Skies Treaty, Escalating Military Rivalry With U.S.
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Treaties', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: Washington withdrew from the treaty, which lets countries make reconnaissance flights over each other’s territory, last year. Moscow’s move could signal difficulties for the Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia said on Friday that it was pulling out of a decades-old treaty that allowed countries to make military reconnaissance flights over each other’s territory. The move escalates Russia’s growing military competition with the United States and Europe just weeks before the incoming Biden administration will have to negotiate the extension of the central nuclear arms-control treaty between Moscow and Washington.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Gabrielle Hamilton has a new recipe for tripe. Let’s all make it!
lead_paragraph: Two weeks into 2021 and circus music’s playing everywhere. You’d be forgiven if all you wanted to do this weekend was cook a crispy Parmesan roast chicken with lemon (above), stretch it into sandwiches the next day, then make the bones into a nice stock for soup. You could pair the chicken with a bowl of buttered pasta and some sautéed spinach, then escape into the world of a book for a while — I’m in Beartown, myself, with Fredrik Backman’s “Us Against You.” These are hard days we’re going through. There’s much to be said for the simplicity of a roasted chicken.

headline: In Ireland, Lifting a Veil of Prejudice Against Mixed-Race Children
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Adoptions', 'Nuns', 'Single Mothers', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Music', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The singer Jess Kavanagh is working to raise awareness about the experiences of mixed-race Irish people, particularly those born in the country’s infamous mother and baby homes.
lead_paragraph: While helping her mother work merchandise tables at some of Dublin’s most respected venues, Jess Kavanagh first got a taste for the music scene. When she started doing gigs herself — a petite singer with a belter of a voice — people would come up after to tell her she sounded “like a Black person,” the last words half whispered.

headline: D.J. LeMahieu Is Staying With the Yankees on a $90 Million Deal
abstract: LeMahieu got a six-year contract that lets the Yankees avoid the luxury tax — for now. The team also agreed to a deal with Corey Kluber, an ace starter undone by injuries the past two seasons.
lead_paragraph: When the Yankees signed D.J. LeMahieu to a two-year $24 million deal before the 2019 season, some people in baseball were puzzled. How would the Gold Glove-winning second baseman fit among their glut of infielders?

headline: Unlocking the Secrets of Your Pantry
abstract: So much of 2020 was about starting from staples, but Yotam Ottolenghi hopes we can keep those cooking lessons in the new year.
lead_paragraph: As with every other person to whom 2020 “happened,” I wonder a lot about lockdown legacy.

headline: ‘Outside the Wire’ Review: At War With the Robots
abstract: This Netflix film starring Anthony Mackie is neither curious nor bold in the ways it depicts a sentient robotic revolt.
lead_paragraph: The director Mikael Hafstrom’s “Outside the Wire,” the latest Netflix combat film set in an exotic location, offers empty-calorie action in a less than fulfilling, Cold War-inspired robotic revolt narrative. The film’s redundant intertitles — several characters repeat the same information later — explain the outbreak of a civil war taking place in the year 2036 in Eastern Europe. U.S. troops, with the assistance of robotic soldiers called Gumps, serve as peacekeepers against the region’s ruthless criminal warlord Viktor Koval (Pilou Asbaek). Harp (Damson Idris), a dispassionate drone pilot, is ordered to the war zone as punishment after his cold calculation led to the deaths of two Marines. Paired with a top-secret android, Leo (Anthony Mackie), as his superior officer, he embarks on a mission to stop Koval from obtaining nuclear weapons.

headline: Several Injured in Bronx Bus Crash
abstract: A Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus crashed in the Bronx on Thursday night, causing the front portion to fall about 50 feet. At least seven people were injured.

headline: Partner of Norwegian Ex-Minister Is Sentenced for Staging Attacks

headline: She Killed an American in 2012. Why Was She Freed in the Taliban Deal?
keywords: ['Peace Process', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The internal debate in Washington over the fate of an Iranian prisoner in Afghanistan illustrates one of the difficult decisions the end of a war brings.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Nargis Mohammad Hasan was serving as an Afghan police officer when she shot and killed an American civilian adviser on Dec. 24, 2012, in Afghanistan’s capital. It was considered the first known attack by a woman in the Afghan security forces on a coalition member since the U.S. invasion in 2001.

keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Supreme Courts (State)', 'Women and Girls', 'Courts and the Judiciary']

lead_paragraph: Shirley Abrahamson, an indefatigable jurist known for her activist voice and tart dissents who was the first woman on the Wisconsin Supreme Court and later its first female chief justice, died on Dec. 19 in Berkeley, Calif. She was 87.

headline: D.I.Why?
abstract: We’ve come a long, exhausted way from trying to make the best of it. Here are some new “Do It Yourself” books that more accurately reflect the moment.
lead_paragraph: Gone are the early, heady days, when sheltering in place afforded the time to make sourdough loaves, start craft projects and consult books on new homesteading skills. With nothing to look forward to but lockdown fatigue, lukewarm take-out and more isolation, the spirit of making things has soured. Fuses are short, patience is tested and “Do It Yourself” has taken on a new tone entirely.

headline: Speaking Up for the Armchair Fan
abstract: Television, which influences everything from salaries to kickoff times, is soccer’s most convenient villain. But for the vast majority of fans, it’s the only connection they have.
lead_paragraph: Television is not a dirty word. It is not the sort of word that should be spat out in anger or growled with resentment or grumbled through gritted teeth. It is not a loaded word, or one laced with scorn and opprobrium and bile. It is not a word that has a tone. Not in most contexts, anyway.

headline: The Filmmaker as Historian: Sam Pollard and ‘MLK/FBI’
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: Whether working on his own projects or others like “Eyes on the Prize II” and “4 Little Girls,” the multihyphenate artist has built a monumental career examining America.
lead_paragraph: Midway through the new documentary “MLK/FBI,” we get glimpses of a Martin Luther King Jr. not often seen in the usual montages of the civil rights movement. The 1963 March on Washington has taken place and he has accepted the Nobel Peace Prize. This King is under myriad strains from the burdens of leadership, budding concerns about Vietnam, political and mortal threats, and round-the-clock surveillance by his own country’s chief law enforcement agency.

headline: In Montepulciano d’Abruzzo, the Gifts of Simplicity
abstract: The role of everyday wines is often overlooked, but these Italian reds are excellent reminders of how important they can be.

headline: In Fleurie, Looking Beyond the Clichés of Beaujolais
abstract: In this esteemed cru of Beaujolais, the descriptions roll out reflexively: It’s floral, it’s soft, it’s easy. The truth is in the drinking.

headline: Philip J. Smith, a Power on Broadway, Is Dead at 89
abstract: As head of the Shubert Organization, he was one of New York City’s most influential real estate and cultural entrepreneurs.
lead_paragraph: Philip J. Smith, chairman of the powerful Shubert Organization, whose empire of Broadway theaters and showcase productions made him one of New York’s most influential real estate and cultural entrepreneurs, died on Friday in a Manhattan hospital. He was 89.

headline: Does a Woman ‘Walking’ Her Boyfriend on a Leash Signal Covid Ennui?
abstract: Coronavirus restrictions across Canada, including a new curfew in Quebec, are fraying patience and spurring protests in some quarters.

headline: Reimagine Your Relationship to Alcohol
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Content Type: Service', 'Anxiety and Stress']
abstract: For many, January is a month to rethink how much they imbibe, whether they’re worried about heavy drinking or just looking for a reset.
lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, Laura McKowen started a drinking journal. She knew alcohol was an issue for her — she knew it when her 4-year-old daughter helped her clean up the morning after a blackout, and she knew it the 10th time she drove to work hung over — but she needed to see it.

headline: Hypersonic Superweapons Are a Mirage, New Analysis Says
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'Physics', 'Research', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: Two scientists find revolutionary claims about the evasion of detection and defenses to be “nonsense.”
lead_paragraph: Military experts call hypersonic warheads the next big thing in intercontinental warfare. They see the emerging arms, which can deliver nuclear or conventional munitions, as zipping along at up to five miles a second while zigzagging through the atmosphere to outwit early-warning satellites and some interceptors. The superfast weapons, experts say, lend themselves to surprise attacks.

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The images appear through next Friday on the giant BAM sign (typically used to advertise upcoming shows and events) at the corner of Lafayette Avenue and Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn.

headline: Insurers Must Pay Businesses for Pandemic Claims, British Court Rules
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of insured businesses will be paid for lost earnings after the coronavirus lockdowns forced them to close, ending a long-running battle with insurance companies.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One day last March, as the coronavirus pandemic was beginning to sweep across Northern Ireland and the rest of Britain, Daniel Duckett was forced to shut the doors of his Belfast bakery and cafe, the Lazy Claire Patisserie. Britain’s prime minister would order all dining establishments closed as the scale of the pandemic became clear.

headline: Globalfest Moves Online, Showcasing World Music Without Boundaries
abstract: With 16 bands over four nights, the festival expanded its reach at a time when live music with audiences is in short supply.

DakhaBrakha, from Ukraine, roved from Eastern European drones and yipping vocals to something like girl-group rock. Aditya Prakash, from Los Angeles, sang a joyful Hindu devotional over upbeat jazz from his ensemble, sharing its melody with a trombone. Rachele Andrioli, from southern Italy, sang a fierce tarantella accompanying herself with a tambourine and electronic loops of a jaw harp and her voice. Hit La Rosa, from Peru, topped the clip-clop beat of cumbia with surreal lyrics, surf-reverbed guitar solos and psychedelic swoops and echoes.

They have swabbed surfaces on cruise ships, tracked case numbers in gyms, sampled ventilation units in hospitals, mapped seating arrangements in restaurants and modeled boarding procedures in airplanes.

headline: A Farewell to the Trump Aesthetic
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'First Ladies (US)', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: Four years of hard-core branding, soap opera chic and designer trolling are coming to an end. What have we learned? A look back in gilt.
lead_paragraph: Few presidents have exploited the theatrical grandeur of the job quite as enthusiastically or as cynically as Donald Trump, from his proliferating forests of flags to his gilding of the Oval Office. Few have been as strategic about the power of caricature, or had such a complicit wife and court to bolster the spectacle. As a group, they tapped into the dregs of “Dynasty” and “The Bonfire of the Vanities” past that sits nestled in our lizard brains. For four years, we parsed soap opera chic instead of “The West Wing.” The visuals demanded attention, just like the tweets.

abstract: Isolated and angry, a diminished President Trump is leaving Washington for an uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Uganda’s Leader of 35 Years Is Re-elected Amid Accusations of Vote-Rigging
keywords: ['Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Censorship', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: President Yoweri Kaguta Museveni faced his strongest challenge yet from Bobi Wine, a rapper-turned-lawmaker.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — On one side was a 76-year-old grandfather in a sunny yellow shirt and hat, who has held onto power in Uganda for 35 years by doling out patronage to preserve loyalty, while deploying his security forces to intimidate critics and muzzle the media.

headline: Corporate America Flexes Its Political Muscle
abstract: Big business breaks with Republicans.
lead_paragraph: It was a long week in the fraught relationship between Washington and corporate America. Dozens of companies announced that they will end political donations to the Republicans who challenged the Electoral College count, or pause giving to all politicians.

headline: Videos show how a rioter was trampled in the stampede at the Capitol.
abstract: Rosanne Boyland, a 34-year-old Trump supporter from Georgia who died during the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, appears to have been killed in a crush of fellow rioters during their attempt to fight through a police line, according to videos reviewed by The Times.
lead_paragraph: Rosanne Boyland, a 34-year-old Trump supporter from Georgia who died during the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, appears to have been killed in a crush of fellow rioters during their attempt to fight through a police line, according to videos reviewed by The Times.

headline: Security tightens as law enforcement raises fresh alarms about extremist plots.
abstract: Law enforcement officials are vetting hundreds of potential airplane passengers and beefing up airport security as officials amplify warnings of violence before the presidential inauguration from extremists emboldened by the Capitol attack last week.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials are vetting hundreds of potential airplane passengers and beefing up airport security as officials amplify warnings of violence before the presidential inauguration from extremists emboldened by the Capitol attack last week.

headline: New inquiries into the Capitol assault aim to address security lapses before Biden’s inauguration.
abstract: Government leaders and law enforcement announced new investigations on Friday into the security failures that led to the assault on the Capitol last week, showing how the pressure to secure Washington and other American cities is increasing amid growing threats of violent right-wing unrest ahead of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inauguration next week.

Biden Jr.’s inauguration next week.

headline: Biden promises a ‘bold’ federal vaccination campaign.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., racing against a surge in coronavirus cases and the emergence of a new variant that could worsen the crisis, is planning a vaccination offensive that calls for greatly expanding access to the vaccine while using a wartime law to increase production.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., racing against a surge in coronavirus cases and the emergence of a new variant that could worsen the crisis, is planning a vaccination offensive that calls for greatly expanding access to the vaccine while using a wartime law to increase production.

headline: The Noise Upstairs Is Unbearable. How Do I Stop It?
abstract: You have the right to live in peace — easier said than done in an apartment building where everyone’s cooped up for the winter.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a rental building in Harlem and have always worked from home. Since the start of the pandemic, the family directly above me has been home, too, with two young children. Now that winter is here, they never seem to go out. I can hear running, jumping and shouting. Normally, I’d work at the cafe down the street for a few hours, but that’s not an option. I know they must have cabin fever, but so do I. What am I supposed to do?

headline: Images From the Capitol Under Siege
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The usual bustle of lawmakers moving in and out of offices gave way to a horrific scene.
lead_paragraph: On both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue, there is much bustle and churn, as lawmakers, administration officials and staff members — both incoming and outgoing — work toward a smooth transition of power in Washington.

headline: Biden and Harris introduced members of their White House science team.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Saturday that he was “always going to lead with science and truth” as he announced top science and technology officials on his White House staff, reaffirming trust in the kind of expert research that the Trump administration often ignored or disdained.

Biden Jr. said on Saturday that he was “always going to lead with science and truth” as he announced top science and technology officials on his White House staff, reaffirming trust in the kind of expert research that the Trump administration often ignored or disdained.

keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Habits and Routines (Behavior)', 'Mobile Applications', 'Social Media', 'Parenting', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: “There will be a period of epic withdrawal,” warned one addiction specialist, once schools, activities and social life return to normal.
lead_paragraph: The day after New Year’s, John Reichert of Boulder, Colo., had a heated argument with his 14-year-old son, James. “I’ve failed you as a father,” he told the boy despairingly.

headline: Another Hayride
abstract: Self-help guru Louise Hay’s “Hayrides” drew in thousands during the hopelessness and government neglect of the AIDS crisis.
lead_paragraph: Self-help guru Louise Hay’s “Hayrides” drew in thousands during the hopelessness and government neglect of the AIDS crisis.

headline: Before the Capitol Riot, Calls for Cash and Talk of Revolution
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Finances', 'Capitol Building (Washington, DC)', 'Attacks on Police', 'QAnon']
abstract: A network of far-right agitators across the country spent weeks organizing and raising money for a mass action to overturn President Trump’s election loss.
lead_paragraph: Keith Lee, an Air Force veteran and former police detective, spent the morning of Jan. 6 casing the entrances to the Capitol.

headline: She Believed Self-Love Was the Antidote to AIDS
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Men and Boys', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Sex']
abstract: Louise Hay’s controversial brand of self-love drew in thousands during the AIDS crisis.
lead_paragraph: In January 1985, six gay men gathered in the self-help author Louise Hay’s living room to discuss a terrifying new disease. At that time fewer than 8,000 cases of AIDS had been reported in the United States. Yet as the deadly epidemic rapidly expanded — within 10 years, over half a million cases would be reported, and over 300,000 deaths — so did Hay’s “Hayride” support group meetings.

headline: Marsha Zazula, ‘Metal Matriarch’ of Metallica and Others, Dies at 68
abstract: She and her husband founded Megaforce Records and introduced the world to heavy metal bands that became major stars.
lead_paragraph: Marsha Zazula, who with her husband, Jonny, founded Megaforce Records at the front end of a heavy metal wave and gave Metallica, Anthrax and other pivotal bands their start, died on Jan. 10 at her home in Clermont, Fla., about 20 miles west of Orlando. She was 68.

headline: A Ray of Hope in a Slimy Southern Cave
keywords: ['Caves and Caverns', 'Salamanders', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Conservation of Resources']
abstract: Residents in the South are coming together to protect their underground ecosystems.
lead_paragraph: One day in 2019, back when crossing state lines to go caving seemed perfectly safe, I drove eight hours from Arkansas to central Tennessee and soon found myself in a muddy belly crawl. Pushing a cumbersome pack in front of me, I used my toes to inch forward. Four younger cavers ahead had exited the tunnel and stood comfortably in a large passage, waiting to continue in the 15-mile-long system.

headline: For one of the first times in his life, Trump’s words are having consequences for him.
abstract: The relationship between President Trump’s words and their consequences has always been fairly straightforward: He says what he wants, and nothing particularly durable tends to happen to him.
lead_paragraph: The relationship between President Trump’s words and their consequences has always been fairly straightforward: He says what he wants, and nothing particularly durable tends to happen to him.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon prepare us for a busy week to come.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — If I could see the future, I’d feel comfortable making a light reference to the extraordinary cliffhanger of an inauguration we’ve got coming up. I can’t, so I’ll just say that today’s passage is from a very timely source, and ties together two occasions that we will hopefully navigate peacefully in the next few days to come. Team Cox/Rathvon’s choice today is from “The Truths We Hold,” a memoir by the first female Vice President-elect of the United States, Kamala Harris, and it involves an early childhood spent with two parents immersed in civil rights. Although it’s lighthearted, reading the excerpt reminded me of how crucial young people are to progressive movements and the risks really small children take for the future of society.

headline: The Call for a Black Migration to the South
abstract: Readers discuss an excerpt from a book by Charles M. Blow proposing that Black Americans return to the South.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Home District, McCarthy Faces Some Backlash From the Right
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Impeachment', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In conservative Bakersfield, Calif., Kevin McCarthy enjoys solid support. But in the days since impeachment, some Republicans now say he has not been loyal enough to President Trump.
lead_paragraph: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — As Congress prepared to vote on impeachment for a second time, David Bynum reached out to his former boss — Representative Kevin McCarthy of California, the Republican leader in the House.

headline: Nepali Team Says It Has Reached K2 Summit in a Wintertime First
abstract: The team endured temperatures dropping to 58 degrees below zero during its milestone ascent. “The impossible is made possible!” the leader said.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — A Nepali mountain-climbing team said Saturday that it had reached the peak of K2, the world’s second-highest mountain, a feat never before accomplished during winter.

headline: Trump will leave office with his lowest approval rating ever.
abstract: He also appears to be on track to finish his term with the lowest final approval rating of any modern-day president.
lead_paragraph: Throughout four years of scandals and investigations, President Trump has maintained an approval rating that rarely budged from a 10-point band between 35 and 45 percent. Nothing he could say, do or tweet appeared to dramatically change public opinion of him.

headline: The Story of 2020 in 52 Magazine Covers
abstract: We spent a year documenting our design process. Looking back, we realized we were telling a bigger story, too.
lead_paragraph: Last year, The Times Magazine published a weekly video series called Behind the Cover, which gave readers a behind-the-scenes look at our cover-design process. We’ve just wrapped the season, and we decided to take a look back at all the covers we put out in a profoundly eventful year, shaped by a cascade of world-changing events that changed the way we worked too.

headline: Far-right activist is among the latest Capitol rioters to be arrested.
abstract: Anthime Joseph Gionet, a far-right media personality nicknamed “Baked Alaska” who is known for livestreaming himself participating in illegal activity, was arrested by the F.B.I. on Friday and accused of illegally storming the Capitol during the attack on the building by President Trump’s supporters last week.
lead_paragraph: Anthime Joseph Gionet, a far-right media personality nicknamed “Baked Alaska” who is known for livestreaming himself participating in illegal activity, was arrested by the F.B.I. on Friday and accused of illegally storming the Capitol during the attack on the building by President Trump’s supporters last week.

headline: Germany’s Buchenwald Memorial Urges Visitors to Respect Graves
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Concentration Camps']
abstract: After some visitors went sledding on graves at the former Nazi concentration camp, the foundation running the memorial stepped up security this week.
lead_paragraph: The memorial at the former Buchenwald concentration camp in central Germany stepped up security this week after some visitors went sledding on graves, the latest example of violations that have happened at former Nazi camps in recent years.

headline: How to Get the Coronavirus Vaccine in New York City
abstract: There are multiple websites, disappearing slots and even attempts to game the system. Here’s our guide to what you have to do to get a dose in your arm.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t easy, and it’s probably going to be that way for a while. Right now, there are more eligible people than doses of vaccine. You need diligence and luck.

headline: Could Mitch McConnell Get to Yes?
keywords: ['Impeachment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)']
abstract: Why the Republican leader should be tempted by the Senate’s opportunity to bar Trump from running for president again.
lead_paragraph: The day before the Capitol Hill riot, Jonathan Last of The Bulwark wrote a dark valediction for Mitch McConnell’s attempts to “manage, contain and outlast Donald Trump.”

headline: The Next President Actually Has a Covid Plan
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Contact Tracing (Public Health)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Tests (Medical)']
abstract: America desperately needs a leader who takes the pandemic seriously.
lead_paragraph: It has been almost a year since the coronavirus first emerged in the United States, and it’s still spreading uncontrolled through much of the country. Several mutant variants have emerged — some of them with alarming new properties — and the vaccination campaign that was supposed to finally save the world from this crisis is faltering badly.

headline: When Biden Becomes … Rooseveltian!
keywords: ['Poverty', 'United States Economy', 'Income Inequality', 'Food Insecurity', 'United States Politics and Government', "New Deal (1930's)", 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', "Great Depression (1930's)", 'Recession and Depression', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Using a crisis to reduce child poverty and make America more truly a land of opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Soon after Franklin Roosevelt was inaugurated in 1933, a visitor assessed the stakes of his New Deal proposal.

headline: Shadows on the Silk Road
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Finding omens of American decline on a long walk across Asia.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — The looming decline of the United States was revealed to me, five Novembers ago, at a truck stop in Uzbekistan. I was napping after a long day’s hike near the old trading city of Kokand when a brawl exploded. Drunks howled. Fists smacked flesh. Somewhere a window shattered. An anxious waitress poked her head into my curtained dining booth. She wanted to know if I had any sugar in my backpack for a homemade compress to stanch a client’s stab wound.

headline: Biden Seeks Quick Start With Executive Actions and Aggressive Legislation
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Presidential Transition (US)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In an effort to mark a clean break from the Trump era, the president-elect plans to roll out dozens of executive orders in his first 10 days on top of a big stimulus plan and an expansive immigration bill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., inheriting a collection of crises unlike any in generations, plans to open his administration with dozens of executive directives on top of expansive legislative proposals in a 10-day blitz meant to signal a turning point for a nation reeling from disease, economic turmoil, racial strife and now the aftermath of the assault on the Capitol.

headline: What could go wrong during the test?
abstract: Just as with a real launch, technical glitches occur. In an earlier test, known as a wet dress rehearsal, in which the entire countdown was simulated except for igniting the engines, almost everything went well. But in the last few seconds, one of the propellant valves did not close as soon as expected. It turned out that the temperature was a bit lower than predicted, and that made the valve a bit harder to turn. The software has since been adjusted.
lead_paragraph: Just as with a real launch, technical glitches occur. In an earlier test, known as a wet dress rehearsal, in which the entire countdown was simulated except for igniting the engines, almost everything went well. But in the last few seconds, one of the propellant valves did not close as soon as expected. It turned out that the temperature was a bit lower than predicted, and that made the valve a bit harder to turn. The software has since been adjusted.

headline: A man with a gun arrested by Capitol Police at a security checkpoint calls it an ‘honest mistake.’
abstract: The man was arrested on Friday with more than 500 rounds of ammunition in his truck, the police said. He told a reporter he was heading to a security job in Washington and got lost.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Capitol Police arrested a man at a security checkpoint in Washington on Friday after he flashed what an officer described as an “unauthorized” inauguration credential and a search of his truck found an unregistered handgun and ammunition, the authorities said.

headline: Sonia Sotomayor will swear in Kamala Harris on Inauguration Day.
abstract: Justice Sotomayor has sworn in a vice president before.
lead_paragraph: Vice President-elect Kamala Harris will be sworn in on Wednesday by Justice Sonia Sotomayor, a ceremony in which the first woman of color to become vice president will take her oath from the first woman of color to sit on the Supreme Court.

headline: Who is Mike Lindell, one of Trump’s last remaining supporters from corporate America?
abstract: For years, Mike Lindell, the chief executive of the bedding company MyPillow, has been a fringe character in Trumpworld. A major Republican donor who made his millions inventing a pillow made from shredded foam, Mr. Lindell would regularly pop up as a V.I.P. at Trump rallies. And he was seemingly ever-present on television in the West Wing as the star of MyPillow commercials, which aired constantly on Fox News.
lead_paragraph: For years, Mike Lindell, the chief executive of the bedding company MyPillow, has been a fringe character in Trumpworld. A major Republican donor who made his millions inventing a pillow made from shredded foam, Mr. Lindell would regularly pop up as a V.I.P. at Trump rallies. And he was seemingly ever-present on television in the West Wing as the star of MyPillow commercials, which aired constantly on Fox News.

headline: George Whitmore, Climber Who Vanquished El Capitan, Dies at 89
abstract: In 1958, he was one of the first people to climb the 2,900-foot-tall sheer granite wall that looms over Yosemite National Park.
lead_paragraph: Early on the morning of Nov. 12, 1958, George Whitmore, Warren Harding and Wayne Merry accomplished something many climbers considered unthinkable: They reached the top of El Capitan.

headline: Bradie Tennell Wins Her Second U.S. Figure Skating Title
keywords: ['Figure Skating', 'Olympic Games', 'United States Figure Skating Championships']
abstract: Tennell had recently relocated from Colorado to work on recapturing the title she won in 2018.
lead_paragraph: Bradie Tennell uprooted her life last summer, moving from suburban Chicago to Colorado Springs in hopes of finding what she needed to reclaim a national figure skating title. Tennell had won in 2018, then watched Alysa Liu, a sprightly phenom seven years her junior, take the next two championships.

headline: Countries are bracing for the impact of more contagious virus variants.
abstract: Alongside the variant discovered in Britain, at least three other troubling variants are spreading less widely: one identified in South Africa and two in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: The more contagious coronavirus variant discovered in Britain has now been detected in more than 50 countries, including Argentina on Saturday, and is believed to be driving surges in at least two.

headline: Alan Canfora, Who Carried Wounds From Kent State, Dies at 71
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Vietnam War', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: He devoted his life to pursuing the truth about the tragic events of May 4, 1970, and to keeping them in the public eye.
lead_paragraph: In April 1970, Alan Canfora, a junior at Kent State University in Ohio, was outraged when a friend was killed in the Vietnam War. He was infuriated all the more when President Richard M. Nixon announced an expansion of the war into Cambodia.

headline: Double Crossed
abstract: Tracy Gray and Tom Pepper team up for a wild and woolly Sunday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — We go way back, almost a decade, with Tracy Gray on Sundays (who often teams up with Jeff Chen). Today I thought she had brought along an ingénue, but I just skip too many weekday puzzles — Tom Pepper’s been around. The two constructors met at a crossword tournament a while ago, kept in touch and now make their collaborative debut, a fun “hidden in plain sight” kind of puzzle.

headline: With Positive Tests, Australia’s Summer of Pro Tennis Has a Rocky Start
abstract: After some passengers on charter flights tested positive for the coronavirus, 72 players will not be allowed to practice for two weeks.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — A seemingly airtight plan to stage the first major tennis tournament of 2021 without compromising players’ health or the success of Australia’s efforts to combat the coronavirus pandemic fell apart over the weekend.

headline: Facebook will temporarily stop showing ads for gun accessories and military gear.
abstract: Facebook will temporarily stop showing ads that “promote weapon accessories and protective equipment in the U.S. at least through Jan. 22,” two days after Inauguration Day, according to a statement by the company.
lead_paragraph: Facebook will temporarily stop showing ads that “promote weapon accessories and protective equipment in the U.S. at least through Jan. 22,” two days after Inauguration Day, according to a statement by the company.

headline: Sylvain Sylvain of the Proto-Punk New York Dolls Dies at 69
abstract: He was a core member of a group that had limited commercial success in the early 1970s and didn’t last long but proved hugely influential.
lead_paragraph: Sylvain Sylvain, a key member of the New York Dolls, the influential though short-lived proto-punk band whose outrageous shows at Max’s Kansas City and other venues paved the way for the era of the Ramones and the Sex Pistols, died on Wednesday at his home in Nashville. He was 69.

headline: How the Green Bay Packers routed the Los Angeles Rams to reach the N.F.C. title game.
abstract: Green Bay amassed 484 total yards of offense against the N.F.L.’s toughest defense.

headline: Loews Hotels says it won’t host a fund-raiser with Senator Josh Hawley.
abstract: The decision to call off the event was the latest indication that many companies are distancing themselves from Republicans who voted to overturn the election results.
lead_paragraph: Loews Hotels said on Saturday that it would not host a fund-raiser with Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri, the latest indication that many companies are distancing themselves from Republicans who voted to overturn the election results.

headline: NASA’s Mega Rocket to the Moon Faces Setback After Test
abstract: A test firing of the engines of the Space Launch System was halted after only about a minute, meaning NASA astronauts may have to wait longer before setting foot on the moon again.
lead_paragraph: After billions of dollars and a decade of work, NASA’s plans to send astronauts back to the moon had a new setback on Saturday. A planned eight-minute test firing of the four engines of a new mega rocket needed for the moon missions came to an abrupt end after only about a minute.

headline: How to Celebrate Martin Luther King’s Birthday in 2021
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Museums', 'Food Insecurity']
abstract: Here are ways to commemorate Dr. King’s legacy, whether you want to commit to a day of service or learn about the history of the civil rights movement.
lead_paragraph: Martin Luther King’s Birthday, a federal holiday observed on the third Monday in January, is a time to reflect on the legacy of the influential civil rights leader. It is also a federal holiday dedicated to a day of service, when Americans are encouraged to heed Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s words: “Everybody can be great, because everybody can serve.”

headline: How to Safely Join the Inauguration Festivities
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Inaugurations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: There may not be huge crowds or evening balls, but you can still celebrate the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: The inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris on Jan. 20 will be different from past ceremonies. The Presidential Inaugural Committee is urging people to stay home to keep large crowds from potentially spreading the coronavirus, and there’s heightened security after a violent attack on the Capitol.

headline: Improve Your Life With These Tiny Chores
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Knives', 'Beds and Bedding', 'Cookware', 'Tableware', 'Dishwashers and Dishwashing', 'Vacuum Cleaners', 'Pillows', 'Home Appliances']

headline: Quotation of the Day: How Twitter Coaxed Its Boss on Trump Ban
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 17, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “This is a phenomenal exercise of power to de-platform the president of the United States. It should set off a broader reckoning.”

headline: Six Great Movies About Presidents
abstract: If you’re looking for some escapism, these films are a good reminder that democracy works.
lead_paragraph: When a new president is inaugurated, it’s traditionally an occasion for pageantry and pomp, showcasing the splendor of Washington and reminding the country and the world of the United States’ democratic promise: that power ultimately rests in the will of the people. As we head into these ceremonies next week, it’s a good time to let these movies remind us that the mechanisms of American politics and the institution of the presidency — at their best and worst — have endured for centuries.

headline: 7 Dead in Military Helicopter Crash in Southern Philippines
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: The helicopter had been on a supply run to troops in a remote, mountainous region where a hunt for communist rebels was taking place, the military said.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Seven Philippine soldiers, including an air force colonel, died when the helicopter they were flying in crashed in the southern Philippines during a hunt for communist rebels over the weekend.

headline: Attend a Jazz Festival and Take a Superhero Yoga Class
abstract: This week, celebrate Martin Luther King’s Birthday, revisit “The West Wing” and explore a new exhibit from the National Museum of Women in the Arts.

headline: Unplug and Craft a Maze From Newspaper
abstract: With some thoughtful folding and a little tape, you can make your own hand-held game.
lead_paragraph: Mazes are ubiquitous in the video game world. Whether you are playing or designing a game, navigating turns and obstacles are the main actions of many computer games. Here is a chance to unplug and create your own hand-held challenge, figuring out the path, the hurdles and the way to win. For an additional method of play, and to mimic the process taught in beginner computer science classes, have one person operate the maze while someone else gives directions. Just fold, cut, roll, tape and crumple newspaper and you are ready to play.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 17, 2021

abstract: A cave complex at a temple in Thailand has long drawn tourists, pilgrims and guano collectors. Now, scientists have arrived, looking for any potential links to the coronavirus.

headline: Precious Metal for Times Journalists: The Page One Plate
abstract: Carrying out this four-decade tradition at The Times has become more complicated because of the coronavirus pandemic. But it’s no less special.
lead_paragraph: The requests trickle in every two or three weeks: A reporter or photographer has made the front page of The New York Times for the first time. Could we honor them with a press plate of that day’s Page One?

headline: How Biden’s Proposed Paid Leave Would Work

abstract: Paid leave expired in December for illness and caregiving during the pandemic. Biden wants to reinstate and expand it.

headline: A QAnon ‘Digital Soldier’ Marches On, Undeterred by Theory’s Unraveling
keywords: ['QAnon', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Social Media', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Valerie Gilbert posts dozens of times a day in support of an unhinged conspiracy theory. The story of this “meme queen” hints at how hard it will be to bring people like her back to reality.
lead_paragraph: Every morning, Valerie Gilbert, a Harvard-educated writer and actress, wakes up in her Upper East Side apartment; feeds her dog, Milo, and her cats, Marlena and Celeste; brews a cup of coffee; and sits down at her oval dining room table.

headline: Peloton’s Rapid Rise Is Threatened by Its Slow Delivery
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Exercise', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment', 'Delivery Services', 'Customer Relations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The company has boomed in popularity during the pandemic but getting its exercise bikes delivered has proved a struggle, one that is angering new customers.
lead_paragraph: Peloton’s relentlessly positive Instagram posts usually attract enthusiastic responses from its 1.2 million followers, who love the company’s charismatic instructors and its $1,900-plus bikes and treadmills.

headline: How a Historian Got Close, Maybe Too Close, to a Nazi Thief
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Art', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Archives and Records', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: Over nearly a decade, Jonathan Petropoulos met dozens of times with a man who helped the Nazis loot Jewish art collections, a complicated relationship he explores in “Göring’s Man in Paris.”
lead_paragraph: By the late 1990s, most of the Nazi art experts who helped loot European Jews were either dead or living quiet lives under the radar. Not so Bruno Lohse, who served as the art agent to the Reichsmarschall Hermann Göring, Hitler’s right-hand man.

headline: How Republicans Are Warping Reality Around the Capitol Attack
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Antifa Movement (US)', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Conspiracy Theories']
abstract: Loyalists to President Trump are increasingly relying on conspiracy theories and misinformation, drawing false equivalence with last summer’s racial protests and blaming outside agitators.
lead_paragraph: Immediately after the attack on the U.S. Capitol, all corners of the political spectrum repudiated the mob of President Trump’s supporters. Yet within days, prominent Republicans, party officials, conservative media voices and rank-and-file voters began making a rhetorical shift to try to downplay the group’s violent actions.

headline: Prospect of Pardons in Final Days Fuels Market to Buy Access to Trump
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Legal Profession', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: The president’s allies have collected tens of thousands of dollars — and potentially much more — from people seeking pardons.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Trump prepares to leave office in days, a lucrative market for pardons is coming to a head, with some of his allies collecting fees from wealthy felons or their associates to push the White House for clemency, according to documents and interviews with more than three dozen lobbyists and lawyers.

abstract: Aleksei Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, landed in Russia Sunday night five months after he was poisoned with a nerve agent.

abstract: How a group of five activists decided to fight global warming by doing whatever it takes.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans treat climate change seriously but not literally — they accept the science, worry about forecasts but tell themselves that someone else will get serious about fixing the problem very soon.

headline: Behind a Secret Deal Between Google and Facebook
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Computers and the Internet', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Attorneys General', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Facebook was going to compete with Google for some advertising sales but backed away from the plan after the companies cut a preferential deal, according to court documents.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, Facebook said it was testing a new way of selling online advertising that would threaten Google’s control of the digital ad market. But less than two years later, Facebook did an about-face and said it was joining an alliance of companies backing a similar effort by Google.

headline: As Biden seeks to jump-start his term, law enforcement braces for possible violence.
abstract: With the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden just three days away, an air of anxiety hovered over Washington and state capitals across the country, as they braced for the possibility of more violence after right-wing extremists stormed the Capitol this month in a bid to stop President Trump’s loss from being certified.

abstract: The stockpile of doses was nearly empty.
lead_paragraph: After a promise from the Trump administration that it would release a stockpile of reserved coronavirus vaccine doses, several states were expecting a huge boost in doses. Some followed federal guidance to expand eligibility to wider swaths of people.

headline: ‘There Is No Safe Area’: In Kabul, Fear Has Taken Over
abstract: A new wave of violence and a growing uncertainty about the country’s future have left Afghans in the capital with a constant sense of fear.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In Kabul’s uncertain present, fear and dread intertwine in a vise. Fear has become a way of life.

headline: Kamala Harris will resign from her Senate seat on Monday.
abstract: Vice President-elect Kamala Harris, who remains a United States senator from California, plans to resign from her seat on Monday ahead of her inauguration two days later, a Harris aide said.
lead_paragraph: Vice President-elect Kamala Harris, who remains a United States senator from California, plans to resign from her seat on Monday ahead of her inauguration two days later, a Harris aide said.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Jamaican oxtail stew, white borscht, spicy noodles with chicken and peanuts: Transport yourself by way of your kitchen.
lead_paragraph: I miss traveling. I miss the humid mangrove tang that hits you when you walk out of the airport in southwestern Florida and the angle of the sun when you’re driving around Los Angeles and the weird squawking birds in the trees of Sydney. I miss the whoosh of air that comes out of the Central Line tunnel at Marble Arch station in London, Berlin graffiti, the birds you can see walking the Beluga Slough trail near Homer, Alaska.

headline: Kevin McCarthy Finds That Charm Has Its Limits
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Impeachment']
abstract: Many people will not forgive the Republican House leader’s blatant acts to embrace and perpetuate dangerous lies that threatened democracy.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Here is the important thing to understand about Kevin McCarthy: He has risen from college dropout to the highest rungs of political leadership by being the guy everyone liked. You can’t have too many friends, he likes to say. He was the guy with the pool table in the house he shared with legislators in Sacramento; the guy who slept on the sofa in his congressional office, went mountain biking with colleagues in the morning and hosted movie nights with Chick-fil-A; the guy who could deliver votes and raise money. Everyone, it seemed, liked the California Republican whom President Trump called “my Kevin.”

headline: Raphael Warnock and the Legacy of Racial Tyranny
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Elections, Senate', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: His victory in the Georgia Senate runoff made history, and also echoed it.
lead_paragraph: Lost in the horror and mayhem of the Jan. 6 Capitol riot was another momentous event that happened barely 12 hours earlier and hundreds of miles away: the election to the Senate of the Rev. Raphael Warnock of Georgia, the first Black Democratic senator from the South in the nation’s history.

lead_paragraph: Nestlé Prepared Foods has recalled more than 700,000 pounds of frozen pepperoni Hot Pockets that may contain pieces of glass and hard plastic, the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Food Safety and Inspection Service said on Friday.

headline: Phil Spector, Famed Music Producer and Convicted Murderer, Dies at 81
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Known for creating the ‘Wall of Sound,’ he scored hits with the Crystals, the Ronettes and the Righteous Brothers and was one of the most influential figures in popular music.
lead_paragraph: Phil Spector, one of the most influential and successful record producers in rock ’n’ roll, who generated a string of hits in the early 1960s  defined by the lavish instrumental treatment known as the wall of sound, but who was sentenced to prison for the murder of a woman at his home, died on Saturday. He was 81.

lead_paragraph: A 25-year-old New York man from the Hudson Valley was arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents at his home on Saturday after he posted photos and videos on social media placing him outside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 during the rampage by violent extremists.

headline: Cargo Ship Sinks Near Turkey, Leaving at Least 3 Dead, Officials Say
abstract: Emergency workers saved half the 12-member crew after the vessel sank off the Black Sea coast, state media said, but bad weather hindered further rescue efforts.
lead_paragraph: A cargo ship sank off Turkey’s Black Sea coast near the northern province of Bartin on Sunday, leaving at least three people dead, according to Turkish state media.

headline: Biden’s incoming chief of staff warns that the virus death toll will reach 500,000 by the end of February.

lead_paragraph: Officials in the incoming Biden administration braced the country for continued hardship in the days after the inauguration, with the president-elect assuming control of a struggling economy and surging coronavirus outbreak in less than three days.

headline: Standing by his decision to impeach, Peter Meijer says he ‘may very well have’ ended his career.
abstract: Representative Peter Meijer acknowledged on Sunday that “I may very well have” ended my career after joining nine other Republicans who voted last week to impeach President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Representative Peter Meijer acknowledged on Sunday that “I may very well have” ended my career after joining nine other Republicans who voted last week to impeach President Trump.

headline: Movies to Stream for Martin Luther King Jr. Day
abstract: Seven recent films help commemorate King’s legacy in fighting for racial justice.
lead_paragraph: With each year since it was designated as a holiday in 1983, Martin Luther King Jr. Day has carried new yet immovable significance. It did so the year following Rodney King’s 1991 assault. It did so in the years following the deaths of Oscar Grant, Trayvon Martin, Michael Brown and Freddie Gray. And now, following the past year’s deaths of Representative John Lewis and the Rev. C.T. Vivian, the killings of Breonna Taylor and George Floyd, the arrival of the summer’s Black Lives Matter protests, the November presidential election and this month’s storming of the Capitol by a pro-Trump mob, the holiday carries that much more meaning. In our government, in our elections, and in our law enforcement the signs of racism still lurk.

headline: The police arrested a woman who they said impersonated an officer at an inauguration checkpoint.
abstract: The authorities said the woman falsely claimed she was a police officer and a member of the president’s cabinet.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Capitol Police have arrested a woman they said drove up to an inauguration checkpoint and falsely claimed she was a police officer and a member of the president’s cabinet, the authorities said.

headline: The Pentagon warns adversaries that domestic terrorist threats won’t distract it from foreign ones.
abstract: As thousands of National Guard troops continued to flow into Washington ahead of Inauguration Day, the Pentagon on Sunday sent another strong signal to Iran and other potential adversaries in the Middle East not to exploit the nation’s focus on domestic terrorist threats to carry out attacks against Americans in the region.

abstract: He survived radiation as commander of the operation that extinguished the Chernobyl nuclear plant fire. He died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Gen. Nikolai T. Antoshkin, the commander of a perilous helicopter firefighting operation in which he and other pilots braved radiation exposure to contain the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, died on Sunday. He was 78.

lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Years of harrowing media reports in Ireland about alleged child abuse by a prominent swimming coach failed to prompt action from the Irish authorities, but now a true-crime podcast may help bring him home from exile in the United States.

headline: Dutch Police Clash With Protesters Denouncing Lockdown Measures
abstract: Police officers in riot gear used water cannons to disperse demonstrators in the center of Amsterdam opposed to government measures to contain the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people, some throwing fireworks and stones, joined an unauthorized protest against the Dutch government’s coronavirus restrictions in Amsterdam on Sunday, and riot police officers used water cannons, batons, attack dogs and horses to disperse the crowd.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Biden prepares to reverse Trump’s policies.
lead_paragraph: When he begins his presidency this week, Joe Biden will inherit a collection of crises unlike any in generations — the coronavirus pandemic, economic turmoil, racial strife and the aftermath of the assault on the Capitol. He plans to start his administration with dozens of executive directives in a 10-day blitz meant to signal a turning point for the U.S.

headline: A Trip Into the Otherworldly With Adrienne Kennedy as Guide
abstract: A digital four-play retrospective, capped by a world premiere, illuminates this writer’s fascination with doubling, violence and Black identity.
lead_paragraph: Have you experienced the familiar unfamiliarity of dreams? That quixotic sense of déjà vu that comes from snippets of memory, stray thoughts, recurring images stolen from the day or drawn wholly from the imagination — all jigsaw-puzzled together to form a portrait of a feeling, a sensation, a belief or fear.

headline: ‘I Answered the Call of My President’: Rioters Say Trump Urged Them On
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Attacks on Police', 'Impeachment']
abstract: The defense from Trump supporters arrested in the Capitol assault is emerging in court papers and interviews — and could play a role in impeachment proceedings.
lead_paragraph: In the two weeks since a raging mob stormed the Capitol, President Trump has shown no sign that he believes he shares responsibility for the worst incursion on the halls of Congress in more than two centuries. Shielding him further, his loyalists have started shifting blame for the attack to an array of distracting bogeymen: far-left anti-fascists, Black Lives Matter activists, even vague conspiracies of a setup involving Vice President Mike Pence.

headline: The Browns’ fumble for a touchback prompted reaction to controversial rule.

headline: Family Reaches $3.5 Million Settlement in Death of Maryland Football Player
abstract: Jordan McNair, a University of Maryland offensive lineman, collapsed from heatstroke during a practice in 2018 and died two weeks later.

headline: How the Kansas City Chiefs beat the Cleveland Browns and reached the A.F.C. championship game.
abstract: With his star quarterback, Patrick Mahomes, gone from the game with a concussion, Coach Andy Reid went for it on fourth-and-1 from near midfield and converted, allowing Kansas City to run out the clock and preserve a 22-17 victory.
lead_paragraph: The Kansas City Chiefs’ best player, quarterback Patrick Mahomes, was out with a concussion. The team had just allowed touchdowns on consecutive drives. And Mahomes’s replacement, Chad Henne, had just been intercepted in the end zone, giving the Cleveland Browns a chance to thwart the Chiefs’ hopes of repeating as Super Bowl champions.

headline: What We Learned From the N.F.L.’s Divisional Round
abstract: Buffalo rode its defense, Green Bay thrived on offense and Tampa Bay let Drew Brees beat himself. Kansas City, which lost Patrick Mahomes to a concussion, simply survived.
lead_paragraph: Home teams won three of four games during the N.F.L.’s divisional round, but there was plenty of fretting along the way. The Buffalo Bills rode their defense to a win, the Green Bay Packers relied on their offense and the heavily favored Kansas City Chiefs, who lost quarterback Patrick Mahomes to a concussion, mostly just survived. The weekend closed with a hyped battle in New Orleans between N.F.L. legends — Tom Brady of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and Drew Brees of the Saints — that resulted in the round’s lone upset.

headline: Black Music Has a New Home in Nashville
keywords: ['Museums', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Jazz', 'Rhythm and Blues (Music)', 'Music']
abstract: The National Museum of African American Music is opening in the capital of country music. And that’s exactly where it belongs.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — The long awaited ribbon cutting for the National Museum of African American Music is Monday, Martin Luther King’s Birthday, in the heart of the tourist district here. But there’s still so much construction equipment enveloping 5th + Broad — Nashville’s sprawling new mixed-use development at the corner of Fifth Avenue North and Broadway — that the museum can be easy to miss.

headline: The Youthful Movement That Made Martin Luther King Jr.
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: In this moment made so dark by white nationalism and truth denial, Americans should look to the country’s legacy of young leaders with forward-thinking wisdom.
lead_paragraph: There’s an image of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. that’s seared into my mind. Eyes inviting and innocent, face relaxed, the casually dressed Dr. King reminds me of a cousin at a card party — he looks so young. When Dr. King elucidated his dream at the March on Washington in 1963, he was 34 — younger than most Americans now, given the national median age of 38.

keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Political Prisoners', 'Politics and Government', 'Poisoning and Poisons']
abstract: After a near-fatal poisoning, Russia’s top dissident steps back into the bear’s den.
lead_paragraph: Aleksei Navalny knew he would be arrested as soon as he stepped foot on Russian soil, and he had no illusions about what this could mean.

headline: After Capitols Become Fortresses, Far-Right Protesters Are Mostly a No-Show
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'States (US)', 'Inaugurations']
abstract: A mass deployment of troops and police across the country turned statehouses into citadels. But, for the most part, far-right groups stayed away from protests on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — And this is how the last weekend of the Trump presidency wound down, with state capitols across the nation ringed by barricades, military vehicles guarding closed-off streets and Washington, D.C., all but shut down. In the end, it was for a handful of protesters, most from the right, a few from the left, many looking more like ragtag stragglers than the furious mob of Trump supporters that ransacked the U.S. Capitol more than a week ago.

headline: Gary Gensler Is Picked to Lead S.E.C.

abstract: The Biden administration also named Rohit Chopra as the head of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, in moves that would bring Obama-era regulators to oversee key financial agencies.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said on Monday that it is tapping two financial regulators from the Obama administration to oversee key departments that had loosened their grip of the industry under President Trump.

headline: Fox Settled a Lawsuit Over Its Lies. But It Insisted on One Unusual Condition.
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Media', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Why did the network insist an agreement with the family of a murdered young man remain undisclosed until after the election?
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 12, 2020, Fox News agreed to pay millions of dollars to the family of a murdered Democratic National Committee staff member, implicitly acknowledging what saner minds knew long ago: that the network had repeatedly hyped a false claim that the young staff member, Seth Rich, was involved in leaking D.N.C. emails during the 2016 presidential campaign. (Russian intelligence officers, in fact, had hacked and leaked the emails.)

headline: As the U.S. surpasses 24 million cases, Los Angeles confronts a more contagious variant.
abstract: At least two new variants of the virus — one discovered in Britain and another first detected in Denmark — are now showing up in California.
lead_paragraph: As the total number of U.S. coronavirus cases surpassed 24 million on Monday, Los Angeles County, one of the hardest-hit areas, may face even more dire weeks ahead. Deaths in the county have continued to climb as the national death toll nears 400,000.

headline: Drew Brees Considering Retirement After Playoff Ouster
abstract: Brees, 42, said he will weigh ending his 20-year career after the Saints’ loss to Tom Brady’s Buccaneers in the divisional round.
lead_paragraph: Drew Brees, who overcame a career-threatening shoulder injury to become the most statistically prolific quarterback in N.F.L. history, likely played the final game of his 20-year career Sunday, when his Saints lost, 30-20, to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in a divisional round playoff game in New Orleans.

headline: Questions Hover Over Samsung as Chief Returns to Prison for Bribery

headline: The Words of Martin Luther King Jr. Reverberate in a Tumultuous Time
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Dr. King’s speeches have particular resonance today amid a year of sickness and death, Black Lives Matter protests and the storming of the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: He lived and died in a time of tumult and a racial awakening, so perhaps it is no surprise that the 35th national celebration of the life and legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on Monday has particular resonance amid one of the most traumatic seasons in memory: A raging pandemic. Protest and civil unrest after the killing of Black people by the police. A momentous election. And an insurrection.

headline: She Thought the Grizzlies Wanted Hiring Advice. They Wanted Her.
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Basketball', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Women and Girls']

Most of the players figured it had to do with the coming season, and with complications stemming from the coronavirus pandemic.

abstract: As Secretary of State Mike Pompeo looks to his political future, his turbulent tenure is characterized by investigations into his leadership and ethics.

headline: It’s Not Your Parents’ Hip Replacement Surgery
abstract: Perhaps the most exciting aspect of modern hip replacement is the increasing use of robotic surgery.
lead_paragraph: If I’ve learned anything during nearly six decades of reporting on medical science, it’s that the longer you wait, the better the methods of prevention, diagnosis and treatment are likely to become. That’s true for almost every field of medicine — cardiology, gastroenterology, oncology, etc. And it may be particularly relevant for orthopedic surgery, a specialty facing ever-increasing demands from an aging population with bones, joints, ligaments, tendons and muscles that break down after decades of wear and tear.

headline: The Potential Plus of Having a Former ‘English Learner’ as Education Secretary
keywords: ['Bilingual Education', 'Education (K-12)', 'English Language Learners (ELL)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Like a growing number of U.S. students today, Miguel Cardona learned English in school, not at home.
lead_paragraph: When Miguel Cardona was 5, he started kindergarten in public school. His parents had moved from Puerto Rico to Meriden, Conn., where he was born. His father worked as a city police officer, and his family lived in public housing. They spoke Spanish at home. When Miguel began school, English was something of a mystery. He was, in the term educators use today, an English learner.

headline: My Father, Martin Luther King Jr., Had Another Dream

abstract: If he saw the issues of poverty and income inequality that exist today, he would be greatly disappointed.
lead_paragraph: As we celebrate the legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today — with just a few days until a new administration takes office — we must think about the message he would have for our country and our leadership at this moment. In the video op-ed above, his son Martin Luther King III challenges us to confront what Dr. King was fighting for when he was killed in Memphis in 1968. His cause and his message about poverty and workers’ rights resonated then but unfortunately resonate now more than ever.

headline: What You Get for $1.2 Million in California

headline: $1.2 Million Homes in California
abstract: A modern townhouse in Laguna Beach, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1932 stone cottage in Burbank.
lead_paragraph: This townhouse is in a new four-unit complex called The Sheds, designed by Horst Architects. Set between the campuses of Laguna College of Art and Design (about five minutes from each campus on foot), the units are meant to evoke the live-work style of artists’ lofts, with multiple balconies and open floor plans that allow for flexible use. The property is tucked into the base of Laguna Canyon, close to hiking trails, and is a five-minute drive from the Pacific Ocean and the Laguna beaches, as well as the upscale dining and shopping of downtown Laguna Beach.

headline: Biden plans to roll out dozens of executive orders in his first 10 days as president.

Biden Jr. plans to start his administration with dozens of executive directives on top of expansive legislative proposals in a 10-day blitz meant to signal a turning point for a nation reeling from disease, economic turmoil, racial strife and now the aftermath of the assault on the Capitol.

headline: For the most part, far-right groups stayed away from protests on Sunday as statehouses turned into citadels.
abstract: The last weekend of the Trump presidency wound down with state capitols across the nation ringed by barricades, military vehicles guarding closed-off streets and Washington, D.C., all but shut down. In the end, it was for a handful of protesters, most from the right, a few from the left, many looking more like ragtag stragglers than the furious mob of Trump supporters that ransacked the U.S. Capitol more than a week ago.

headline: Phil Spector: Listening to 15 Songs From a Violent Legacy

Some listeners may well decide that all of his music is poisoned. But it is also inextricable from pop history.

headline: The Devilish Life and Art of Lucian Freud, in Full Detail
abstract: William Feaver’s “The Lives of Lucian Freud: Fame, 1968-2011” completes a two-volume biography of the pioneering realist painter.
lead_paragraph: The critic Kenneth Tynan divided playwrights into two categories, “smooth” and “hairy,” and one could probably make a similar distinction among biographers. Smooth biographers offer clean narrative lines, well-underscored themes, and carrots, in the form of cliffhangers, to lure the reader onward. Their books are on best-seller lists. They’re good gifts for Dad.

headline: Alex Padilla, California’s First Latino Senator, on Needing to ‘Walk and Chew Gum’ in Washington
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: He was appointed to fill Kamala Harris’s seat, and will take office as his state struggles with record Covid rates, especially in the neighborhood he grew up in.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As Kamala Harris steps into her role as vice president and out of her Senate office this week, the Democrat Alex Padilla will become the first Latino senator from California, a state where Latino residents make up 40 percent of the population, and will be one of six in the Senate. Mr. Padilla, who has been California’s secretary of state since 2015, is heading to Washington at a time when the country — and California — is deeply mired in the pandemic and a sluggish vaccine rollout. His own political career began with immigration activism, and he believes that the country needs a pathway to citizenship for all undocumented immigrants. He said he was confident that the Senate would be able to focus on an impeachment trial and the pressing need to get the pandemic under control — “we will walk and chew gum at the same time.”

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
