headline: If You’re Offered a Vaccine, Take It
abstract: Declining a Covid-19 shot because you think it should go to someone else won’t help anyone.
lead_paragraph: Last week, as friends of mine learned they would soon be eligible for a Covid-19 vaccination, I received a slew of angst-ridden text messages. A teacher who sees students only once a week wondered if she should wait so teachers who were more at risk could get a shot first. A friend with a health condition who is mostly able to stay home and isolate pondered letting her dose go to someone more deserving. On social media, I stumbled across posts from friends who are eligible for vaccination but could not get appointments — and who were angry that others they knew, whom they considered lower risk, had already been inoculated.

headline: America’s Caste System Is 400 Years Old. That Doesn’t Change Overnight.
keywords: ['Caste Systems', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Isabel Wilkerson on why a new presidency alone can’t fix America’s 400-year-old race-based hierarchy.
lead_paragraph: At the inauguration on Wednesday, Kamala Harris became vice president — the nation’s first Black person, the first Asian person and the first woman to do so — and President Biden spoke of “a cry for racial justice some 400 years in the making,” adding that “the dream of justice for all will be deferred no longer.”

headline: Will the Pandemic Result in More Suicides?
keywords: ['Depression (Mental)', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: It’s too soon to know. But some recent data, especially from specific groups, is cause for worry.
lead_paragraph: Even before we entered this darkest of winters, when Covid-19 is relentlessly causing more and more sickness and death — not to mention additional stress, isolation and economic pain — there was evidence suggesting that significantly more people have thought about ending their lives during the pandemic than in recent years. In August, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released the results of a nationwide survey conducted during the last week in June: More than 40 percent of those who responded reported symptoms of anxiety or depression or increased substance use, in addition to other struggles. And more than 10 percent said that they had seriously considered suicide in the past 30 days, compared with just over 4 percent who said the same thing in 2018 — and who were referring to suicidal ideation over the previous 12 months. “We want to know, who is most at risk from suicide in the pandemic,” says Paul Nestadt, a psychiatrist at the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, who was not involved in the survey. And yet, he adds, “we won’t know until it’s mostly over.” That’s because it can take a year or two for the C.D.C. to collect and analyze national mortality data.

headline: Coffee Tied to Lower Risk of Prostate Cancer
abstract: Each additional daily cup of coffee was associated with a 1 percent decrease in the risk of prostate cancer.
lead_paragraph: Drinking coffee may lower the risk for prostate cancer.

headline: What Will Happen to Your Next Home if Builders Get Their Way?
keywords: ['Building (Construction)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Global Warming', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: A lobby is trying to block codes that save homeowners money and fight climate change.
lead_paragraph: “The Big One,” screamed a giant all-caps headline on The Miami Herald’s front page one day in 1992. Beneath it, a smaller headline: “Hurricane of our nightmares is knocking at the front door.”

headline: In Los Angeles, Teachers and Students Struggle With ‘No Human Contact’
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: The nation’s second-largest district has kept classrooms closed since March. The superintendent acknowledges it is “disproportionately hurting students who can least afford it.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In Elissa Elder-Aga’s 25 years of teaching elementary school, reading aloud has always been her favorite classroom activity, a chance to captivate her audience and impart all sorts of lessons — from grammar to morals.

headline: 13,000 School Districts, 13,000 Approaches to Teaching During Covid
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Education (K-12)', 'E-Learning', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Disease Rates', 'Quarantines', 'Minorities']
abstract: To assess how public schools have navigated the pandemic and the impact on students, The Times examined seven representative districts. The answers were strikingly different.
lead_paragraph: What does it mean to go to public school in the United States during the pandemic?

headline: Democrats, Here’s How to Lose in 2022. And Deserve It.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Law and Legislation', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: You don’t get re-elected for things voters don’t know about.
lead_paragraph: President Biden takes office with a ticking clock. The Democrats’ margin in the House and Senate couldn’t be thinner, and midterms typically raze the governing party. That gives Democrats two years to govern. Two years to prove that the American political system can work. Two years to show Trumpism was an experiment that need not be repeated.

headline: Why Joe Biden Must Not Shy Away From the Full Power of the Presidency
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'War and Emergency Powers (US)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: Democrats often benefit from unilateral authority more than Republicans do.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has signaled an ambitious legislative agenda, including plans to reform immigration, stimulate the economy and strengthen the federal Covid-19 response. Mr. Biden, who was a senator for most of his political career, respects Congress and has emphasized the importance of acting through it. During the presidential campaign, he was not shy about criticizing then-President Donald Trump for abusing his executive authority.

headline: How the American Unemployment System Failed
keywords: ['Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'United States Politics and Government', 'States (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal-State Relations (US)']
abstract: A decline in funding and changes in the workplace — and how long people are out of work — have left a program unequal to the 21st-century economy.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s unemployment insurance program, conceived during the Great Depression, was meant to keep jobless workers and their families from suffering drops in income that could tip them into poverty or force them to liquidate their assets to afford food, rent and other necessities.

headline: The Three Types of Republicans Donald Trump Created
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)']
abstract: Never Trumpers, the unlikeliest group of “RINOs” and Trump loyalists are fighting for the future of the party.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump departed the White House on Wednesday and left a Republican Party turned upside down.

headline: A Teenager Went 3 Floors Down to Play Video Games. He Never Came Home.
abstract: Kahlik Grier, 16, was fatally shot in a random encounter in the stairwell of his Bronx apartment building, the police said.
lead_paragraph: It was a routine school night for Kahlik Grier, a 16-year-old student in the Bronx. After a day of online classes, he had Chinese takeout with his mother. Then he made his way to a friend’s apartment three stories below to play video games.

headline: No Courts, No Going Outside: How Professional Tennis Players Are Improvising
abstract: The athletes waiting in quarantine for the Australian Open are figuring out creative ways to stay busy (and swing a tennis racket) before they can hit the court.

headline: The Board Voted to Keep Schools Closed. Parents Revolted.
abstract: While districts around it opened, a small Wisconsin city chose to start the school year remotely. Public pressure forced a return, just as virus cases were surging.
lead_paragraph: The anger over the decision to teach fall classes remotely was spelled in chalk on Beth Martin’s sidewalk.

headline: Providence Kept Classrooms Open, and the Students Came Back
abstract: Unlike in many Northeastern cities, a majority of families in Rhode Island’s capital have sent their children back to school.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — Rachel Santos is clear about one thing: Distance learning did not work for her.

headline: How They Proposed
abstract: Here are some of the stories of how couples, most of whom submitted their announcement information to The New York Times last year, agreed to marry each other.
lead_paragraph: It was a year unlike any other, as the coronavirus brought most of the world to a standstill in 2020. While the wedding industry suffered immensely, life went on, and people still fell in love, proposed and got married no matter.

headline: Biden Unveils National Strategy That Trump Resisted
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Masks', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Defense Production Act', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Biden has a 200-page strategy to bolster production of vaccines, treatments and medical-grade protective gear while reaching out to communities of color.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden, seeking to assert leadership over the coronavirus pandemic, signed a string of executive orders and presidential directives on Thursday aimed at creating the kind of centralized authority that the Trump administration had shied away from.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Art', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Music', 'Theater', 'Circuses', 'Jazz', 'Disabilities', 'Museums', 'Children and Childhood', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
lead_paragraph: At HotHouse, a Chicago-based nonprofit devoted to integrating the arts with community activism, organizers presented a virtual concert in July honoring Cuba’s contributions to global health — particularly those of its doctors who have provided care in over two dozen foreign countries during the Covid-19 pandemic.

headline: A School District Vowed to Stay Open, Until Its Staffing Ran Out
abstract: Nearly 11,000 people were forced to quarantine this fall in a suburban Atlanta district that didn’t mandate masks, but it stayed the course, until a staffing shortage shut the doors.
lead_paragraph: Lizzy Palermo says she was one of the few students in her suburban Georgia high school who consistently wore a mask to classes in the fall. But it didn’t save her from having to quarantine after the district opened buildings in August, as students and staff members came to school with the coronavirus.

headline: With Students Missing Online Classes, Teachers Are Going to Students
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'E-Learning', 'Absenteeism and Truancy', 'Charter Schools', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: At a charter school in a poor area of Washington, some teachers spend one day a week going door to door, tracking down students who aren’t logging on, and whose education is suffering.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was 10:30 a.m., time for math class, and Tylee Wise was in his usual spot — a twin-size bed in the room he shares with his little sister, a television droning a few feet away — when a knock came at the apartment door.

headline: Raised on Le Carré, He Wrote a Thriller Dipped in Poison
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Books and Literature', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: Sergei Lebedev is making his debut as a spy novelist with “Untraceable,” a book inspired by the attempted killing of a former Russian intelligence agent.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Moscow, Sergei Lebedev honed his English, reluctantly at first and then greedily, by reading his way through his family’s library of detective fiction.

headline: Letters Close Enough to Touch
keywords: ['Impeachment', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Newspapers', 'Art', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Three historic banner headlines on New York Times front pages contained an unusual typographic feature: a set of joined letters known as a ligature.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Amid One Pandemic, Students Train for the Next
abstract: Researchers have banded together to find safe, virtual ways to teach the principles of microbiology and epidemiology.
lead_paragraph: On a crisp afternoon in November, Teresa Bautista ventured into Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx,  on the lookout for feces. It didn’t take long for Ms. Bautista, 17 — and, to her chagrin, her white Puma shoes — to hit some serious pay dirt.

headline: ‘The Word of the Year Is Fluid’: The Pandemic Brings a New Teaching Style
abstract: Like many districts nationwide, schools in Edison, N.J., are struggling to make hybrid instruction work.
lead_paragraph: EDISON, N.J. — This is Stephanie Rasimowicz’s daily dilemma: Scattered before her in second-period geometry class at Edison High School are a handful of freshmen, seated at desks many feet apart. Arrayed behind her are nearly 20 small, disembodied faces on a computer screen — her remote students, learning from home.

headline: Charlottesville Inspired Biden to Run. Now It Has a Message for Him.
keywords: ['Charlottesville, Va, Violence (August, 2017)', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The white supremacist rally in 2017 prefigured the rise of right-wing violence in President Trump’s name. Now, as President Biden calls for national unity, residents say it requires accountability first.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Susan Bro recognized the palpable anger and open bigotry on display in the mob that attacked the United States Capitol this month. It reminded her of the outpouring of hate that killed her daughter, Heather Heyer.

headline: Traveling With a Purpose: For Some, It’s a 2021 Resolution
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Road Trips', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: The crises of 2020, particularly the pandemic and violence against Black Americans, have caused many travelers to rethink how and where to travel.
lead_paragraph: Every year, John Shackelford, 26, a bicycle messenger in New York City, takes what he calls a “tour,” or long-distance ride with friends. Following a summer of social unrest sparked by the murders of George Floyd, Breonna Taylor and other Black Americans at the hands of police, the 2020 tour, he decided, would travel roughly 1,100 miles from Mobile, Ala., to Washington, D.C., visiting places associated with Black history, including Civil Rights landmarks, history museums and memorials such as the National Memorial for Peace and Justice in Montgomery, Ala. The pandemic was an obstacle to visiting some sites, but not enough to hold back the ride.

headline: From Commander in Chief to Interloper in Palm Beach
abstract: If former President Donald J. Trump intends to live in South Florida full time, he is likely to encounter some friction. (Though his fans are thrilled.)
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — On Wednesday, Donald J. Trump did what many older New Yorkers do: He retired to Florida.

headline: Keep the Trains and Buses Running
abstract: Public transit systems urgently need more public funding so they can continue to provide an important public service.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic is jeopardizing the long-term health of the public transit systems that provide a crucial circulatory system for major American cities — particularly for lower-income residents who depend on trains and buses to get to work, the market or the doctor.

headline: What One District Did to Prevent Students From Failing
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Education (K-12)', 'E-Learning', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Academic performance rose when a tiny Texas district required all students to attend class in person. But so did coronavirus infections.
lead_paragraph: LUBBOCK, Texas — Madison Hermosillo started her sophomore year at Roosevelt High School alone in her room, bewildered and quickly falling behind.

headline: ‘I Know I’m Not Alone’: The Importance of Mentors Right Now
abstract: Most mentoring programs have moved online, but some wait lists are long and the rare person-to-person connection is sorely missed.
lead_paragraph: Last May, a 17-year-old from Queens lost his father, an essential worker, to Covid-19. For six months, the shy and soft-spoken teenager, whose name is Ansh and whose last name is being withheld for privacy, hardly left the one-bedroom apartment he shares with his mother in Astoria.

headline: ‘Moulin Rouge!’ Was Their Ticket. Then 2020 Happened.
abstract: It was a Broadway smash with big plans until 25 company members took ill and a shutdown put everybody out of work. Inside a tumultuous year, in the words of those who lived it.
lead_paragraph: From a window in his Hell’s Kitchen apartment, the theater director Alex Timbers can see the Moorish arcade adorning Broadway’s Al Hirschfeld Theater. For years, Timbers dreamed of working in the century-old house, and in the summer of 2019, he got the chance with “Moulin Rouge!,” a hot-blooded musical about bohemian artists whose revelry is tragically disrupted by infectious disease.

headline: Suicide Bombings in Crowded Baghdad Market Kill at Least 32
abstract: Such attacks, once common in the Iraqi capital, have become rarer in recent years as U.S.-backed Iraqi forces have largely defeated the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Two suicide bombers detonated explosive vests in a crowded market in central Baghdad on Thursday morning, killing at least 32 people in the biggest such attack in several years, according to the government.

headline: During one pandemic, students are training for the next.
abstract: Over the next few months, New York area high school students will gather samples from the city’s birds as a part of the Virus Hunters program, hosted by the nonprofit science outreach organization BioBus. Their goal is to catalog the flu viruses that often lurk in urban fowl, some of which might have the potential to someday hop into humans.
lead_paragraph: Over the next few months, New York area high school students will gather samples from the city’s birds as a part of the Virus Hunters program, hosted by the nonprofit science outreach organization BioBus. Their goal is to catalog the flu viruses that often lurk in urban fowl, some of which might have the potential to someday hop into humans.

headline: New coronavirus variants could challenge vaccine efforts.
abstract: Confirmed coronavirus cases from new variants found first in Britain, then in South Africa, Brazil and the United States have people worried about whether vaccines can protect against altered versions of the virus. Experts said in interviews that so far vaccines are capable of providing that protection.
lead_paragraph: Confirmed coronavirus cases from new variants found first in Britain, then in South Africa, Brazil and the United States have people worried about whether vaccines can protect against altered versions of the virus. Experts said in interviews that so far vaccines are capable of providing that protection.

headline: A year after the U.S. recorded its first virus case, the outbreak has ravaged the nation and deaths remain high.
abstract: One year ago today, health officials told Americans about a traveler who had just come home from Wuhan, China, sought treatment at an urgent-care clinic north of Seattle after falling ill — and set off alarm bells.
lead_paragraph: One year ago today, health officials told Americans about a traveler who had just come home from Wuhan, China, sought treatment at an urgent-care clinic north of Seattle after falling ill — and set off alarm bells.

headline: Florida ‘Monkey Whisperer’ Is Charged With Illegal Animal Sales
abstract: Jimmy Wayne Hammonds, who runs an exotic animal ranch, illegally sold rare monkeys, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: On its website, the Monkey Whisperer in Central Florida describes itself as a family-owned, “fastidiously clean and well organized exotic animal ranch with many unique animals in our care.”

headline: Lizzie Borden’s Notoriety Is This Home’s Selling Point
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Museums', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: The house where her father and stepmother were brutally killed with a hatchet draws thousands of visitors a year. Now it’s for sale.
lead_paragraph: The morning after Andrew Borden and his wife, Abby, were hacked to death in their home on Second Street in Fall River, Mass., in August 1892, 1,500 people gathered in front of the house, drawn by news of a grisly crime in their quiet town.

headline: New Yorkers at the Inauguration Festivities
abstract: Roles in the ceremony and related events included performing the national anthem and leading the vice president in the oath of office.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Oil companies are focused on South America, where low production costs help keep global prices down.
abstract: Suriname, Guyana and Brazil are the new areas of focus for oil companies, attracting more new investment than the Gulf of Mexico and other more established oil fields. They are helping to keep global oil prices relatively low, undermining efforts by Russia and its allies in the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, like Saudi Arabia, to manage global supply and push up prices.
lead_paragraph: Suriname, Guyana and Brazil are the new areas of focus for oil companies, attracting more new investment than the Gulf of Mexico and other more established oil fields. They are helping to keep global oil prices relatively low, undermining efforts by Russia and its allies in the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, like Saudi Arabia, to manage global supply and push up prices.

headline: Continuing Job Losses Put Spotlight on Economic Relief
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Relentless unemployment claims show the pandemic’s grip on the labor market. Help from the recent stimulus bill may lapse before an upturn arrives.
lead_paragraph: Even as it tries to right a shipwrecked economy, the Biden administration confronted fresh evidence of weakness Thursday with the report of nearly a million new state unemployment claims, heightening calls for fresh stimulus efforts.

headline: The Inauguration of Joe Biden
abstract: The president’s address conveyed a message of hope and unity, but making that vision come true will be difficult.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden has been sworn in as the 46th president of the United States and Kamala Harris has become the first woman of color to hold the office of vice president.

headline: Auto Safety Agency Faces Calls for Overhaul as Biden Presidency Begins
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Transition (US)']
abstract: The new administration can “restart” the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which “should be leading the world when it comes to vehicle safety,” the head of an advocacy group said.
lead_paragraph: For decades, across administrations of Republicans and Democrats, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has faced criticism from safety advocates who accuse it of routinely falling short of its mission.

headline: Biden’s First Day
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of his inaugural address yesterday, President Biden named six crises that the U.S. faces: the virus, climate change, growing inequality, racism, America’s global standing and an attack on truth and democracy.

headline: Bernie Sanders Is Once Again the Star of a Meme
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Photography', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Inaugurations', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The Vermont senator was cold, but comfortable. The internet noticed.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont is a fierce advocate of fair wages and a former presidential candidate who lost the Democratic nomination to now-President Biden. And thanks to his practical clothing choices he is also now the center of a seemingly endless flood of altered pictures that dominated some corners of the internet in the hours after Mr. Biden’s socially distanced inauguration on Wednesday.

headline: In a Slight to E.U., U.K. Says Not All Ambassadors Are Equal
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'International Relations']
abstract: Just weeks into its official break from the bloc, Britain is refusing to grant the bloc’s ambassador the same status as other top diplomats.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — For all the complications and wounded feelings Brexit has introduced in the relationship between the European Union and its erstwhile member, Britain, this week saw the addition of a diplomatic spat reminiscent of a similar argument initiated by former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Sri Lanka reopens its airports, despite a surge in cases and chaos around a shaman’s tonic.
abstract: Sri Lanka reopened its airports to foreign arrivals on Thursday for the first time in 10 months amid a surge in new coronavirus cases, including that of a minister photographed drinking a shaman’s tonic that some in the island nation believe protects against the disease.
lead_paragraph: Sri Lanka reopened its airports to foreign arrivals on Thursday for the first time in 10 months amid a surge in new coronavirus cases, including that of a minister photographed drinking a shaman’s tonic that some in the island nation believe protects against the disease.

headline: ‘Notturno’ Review: The Heart of the Middle East
abstract: Gianfranco Rosi’s latest, beautifully shot documentary movingly observes people and places across Syria, Iraq, Lebanon and Kurdistan in the aftermath of war.
lead_paragraph: The sound of distant gunfire crops up in the background in Gianfranco Rosi’s “Notturno,” one of many reminders of how war has shaped the inhabitants of Syria, Iraq, Lebanon and Kurdistan who appear onscreen. Rosi has a way of sitting with people, sometimes close-up, more often from afar, and soaking in their lived experience and the pulse of landscapes shaped by brutal external forces (from Western incursions to ISIS). His melancholic documentary moves beyond a sense of perpetual aftermath by picking up threads of continuity in people’s resilience.

headline: ‘Preparations to Be Together’ Review: Mysteries of Love
abstract: A neurosurgeon pursues the man of her dreams in this simmering portrait of obsession by the Hungarian filmmaker Lili Horvat.
lead_paragraph: “Preparations to Be Together for an Unknown Period of Time,” the second feature by the Hungarian writer-director Lili Horvat, considers the slippery relationship between consciousness and desire with a poignant hypothetical: what if you fall so hard for someone that you convince yourself they love you back? At the shattering of such an illusion is where we meet Marta (Natasa Stork), an accomplished, 40-year-old neurosurgeon who hastily leaves behind her life and career in the U.S. to reunite with the man she loves. Yet when she arrives at their agreed-upon meeting point — the Pest end of Budapest’s Liberty Bridge — Janos (Viktor Bodo) is nowhere to be found. And when she tracks him down at the nearby medical institute, he claims to not know who she is.

headline: ‘No Man’s Land’ Review: Leaving Home, Learning Tolerance
abstract: An act of violence forces a Texas rancher to cross the Rio Grande and question his beliefs.
lead_paragraph: Strangled by good intentions and teachable-moment clichés, Conor Allyn’s “No Man’s Land” turns the border between Texas and Mexico into a gateway to racial empathy.

headline: ‘Our Friend’ Review: Lean on Me
abstract: Jason Segel is the ballast that keeps this soggy drama from sinking completely.
lead_paragraph: As with any bad movie emerging from someone’s real-life tragedy, “Our Friend” is almost more painful to critique than to watch. Based on Matthew Teague’s raw 2015 article detailing the decline of his wife, Nicole, from ovarian cancer, this drippy drama presents precisely the kind of prettified portrait of death that Teague’s candid writing sought to rebut.

headline: ‘You Will Die at Twenty’ Review: Death, and Life, on the Nile
abstract: In his debut feature, Amjad Abu Alala deepens a fable-like premise into a lyrical confrontation with the certitudes of faith and the life-giving powers of doubt.
lead_paragraph: A folk tale turns existential in “You Will Die at Twenty,” the rapturous debut feature by the Sudanese filmmaker Amjad Abu Alala. In a sun-dappled village by the Nile, a holy sheikh tells Sakina (Islam Mubarak) that her newborn son, Muzamil, will live only two decades.

headline: ‘Identifying Features’ Review: Lost in Migration
abstract: In this confident drama, a mother searches for her son who went missing while trying to migrate from Mexico to the United States.
lead_paragraph: The drama “Identifying Features” begins with a figure approaching from across a field, his appearance obscured by a heavy fog: perhaps he’s a soldier, maybe a farmer. It becomes clear only when he’s a few feet away that the man in the mist is really just a boy. As his face emerges, with smooth cheeks and cold eyes, the beauty, elusiveness and surprise of the film around him surfaces, too.

headline: ‘Atlantis’ Review: A Bleak Apocalypse Love Story
abstract: Ukraine’s official Oscar entry, the movie depicts an all-too-convincing dystopia, with no fancy gadgets or cars.
lead_paragraph: Conventional cinematic dystopian futures almost always compensate for their bleakness with nifty gadgets or, at the very least, incredibly fast and dangerous cars chasing one another. Not “Atlantis,” Ukraine’s official entry for the Best Foreign Language Film Oscar this year. Written, directed and shot by Valentyn Vasyanovych, the movie is an especially economical, even ruthless exercise in what could be called “slow cinema,” with no shiny widgets in sight.

headline: ‘Spoor’ Review: Hunters in the Snow
abstract: This oddly structured whodunit from Poland is a reverie wrapped around a murder mystery.
lead_paragraph: “Spoor,” directed by the Polish filmmaker Agnieszka Holland and her daughter, Kasia Adamik, went nearly four years without an American release. At the New York Film Festival the fall after its February 2017 premiere, the critic Amy Taubin, one of its many champions, introduced it as perhaps her favorite film so far that decade. She has interpreted it as a politically charged critique of Polish patriarchy.

headline: ‘The Human Factor’ Review: In Peace Talks Trust Is Vital and Elusive
abstract: Negotiators recall their advances and missteps in a quest for an Israeli-Palestinian peace.
lead_paragraph: “The Human Factor” presents a cogent and involving view of the Israeli-Palestinian peace efforts, mainly from 1991 until the end of Bill Clinton’s first term, told through the recollections of United States negotiators charged with brokering a peace. It shows how much any international agreement relies on a rare alignment of concrete compromises and personal trust — what the former Middle East envoy Dennis B. Ross here calls the “human factor.” As he says at the start of the film, in a negotiation, “You can’t ignore the human factor. Someone who has a human touch treats someone else with respect. Someone who has a human touch doesn’t think they’re going to outsmart anybody.”

headline: Biden Rolls Back the Trump Legacy
abstract: The new president aims to signal a return to normalcy: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: After an almost normal inaugural ceremony, Biden gets to work. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Ex-Coach Sentenced to 10 Years for Raping Star Skater
abstract: Cho Jae-beom, who had been fired from South Korea’s national team, was accused of sexually assaulting a two-time Olympic gold medalist starting when she was 17.
lead_paragraph: A former national speedskating coach in South Korea was sentenced on Thursday to more than a decade in prison on charges of raping an Olympic athlete.

headline: Buttigieg Sees ‘Generational Opportunity’ to Transform the Nation’s Infrastructure
abstract: His confirmation as transportation secretary would cap a rise from mayor of South Bend, Ind., to the first openly gay cabinet secretary to be approved by the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pete Buttigieg, a former mayor of South Bend, Ind., was received favorably by lawmakers from both parties on Thursday as he outlined his vision for ambitious infrastructure reform if confirmed as transportation secretary.

headline: How Wall Street Reflects the Economy Biden Inherits
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization']
abstract: Big banks are sending mixed signals.
lead_paragraph: America’s biggest banks have all now released their financial results for the past year, data that reflect the strange economic situation facing President Biden and his new administration. Parts of the economy are booming, others are at a standstill and the outlook is extraordinarily uncertain.

headline: An A.S.L. interpreter who gave coronavirus updates dies of Covid-19 complications.
abstract: Patty Sakal, an American Sign Language interpreter who translated updates about the coronavirus for deaf Hawaiians, died on Friday of complications related to Covid-19. She was 62.
lead_paragraph: Patty Sakal, an American Sign Language interpreter who translated updates about the coronavirus for deaf Hawaiians, died on Friday of complications related to Covid-19. She was 62.

headline: ‘The White Tiger’ Review: Don’t Call Him a Slumdog
abstract: Ramin Bahrani directs a barbed rags-to-riches tale of modern India.
lead_paragraph: According to Balram, a wealthy young Bangalore businessman, “the Indian entrepreneur” must be a combination of opposites: “straight and crooked, mocking and believing, sly and sincere.” He explains this in a letter to the Chinese prime minister that doubles as voice-over narration for “The White Tiger,” Ramin Bahrani’s restless new film, which is itself a blend of disparate elements. Adapted from Aravind Adiga’s Booker Prize-winning novel, the movie is part satire and part melodrama, a crime-tinged rags-to-riches parable that uses the story of Balram’s improbable rise to indict the iniquities of the society that created him.

headline: Moisés Caicedo and the Perils of Too Much Interest
abstract: It did not take long for the performances of a 19-year-old in Ecuador to catch the eyes of Europe’s biggest clubs. In soccer’s cutthroat transfer market, they were not the only ones watching.
lead_paragraph: Nothing stays secret for long in soccer. So thorough is the game’s hunt for talent and so desperate its thirst for players that no territory goes uncharted, no stone unturned, no prospect unobserved. Distance is no barrier. Remoteness is not a factor. The searchlight is so bright that there is no such thing, any more, as obscurity.

headline: ‘Cannabis Factory’ Is Found in London’s Deserted Financial District
abstract: After reports of a strong smell in the area, which is largely empty because of lockdown restrictions, the police discovered more than 800 weed plants in a basement near the Bank of England.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The normal bustle of London’s financial district has been quieted by the latest national lockdown, with businesses shuttered and work shifted to home.

headline: Despite Virus Surge, I.O.C. Pledges Summer Olympics in Tokyo Will Happen
abstract: Thomas Bach, the president of the International Olympic Committee, played down growing doubts about the Games but without giving a guarantee.
lead_paragraph: With the coronavirus surging in much of the world, including a spike in Japan, the president of the International Olympic Committee on Thursday sought to quell doubts about the Summer Games in Tokyo proceeding in July while not ruling out a cancellation.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Best Rhymers of All Time’
abstract: I'm a deputy editor and an art director on the Culture desk at The Times. Here are five things I've been telling friends about lately.
lead_paragraph: I'm a deputy editor and an art director on the Culture desk at The Times. Here are five things I've been telling friends about lately.

headline: What Can I Do to End My Family’s Wedding Wars?
abstract: My dad is mad that my half sister eloped, and it’s hurting all of us.
lead_paragraph: My half sister got engaged recently and, because of the pandemic, decided to elope. When she told our dad about her plans, all hell broke loose! He wanted her to wait and have a big, beautiful wedding. Three months after her elopement, he is still upset and hurt. As a family, we’ve tried to tell him to get over it: “There’s a pandemic.” “This is not about you, Dad.” “We’ll have a celebration later.” Nothing helps. They even had a family counseling session that didn’t go well. My dad wants an apology and thinks my sister should have changed her plans after learning his view. We’re all losing patience with him, and I’m worried about the damage he’s causing to relationships. Any advice?

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Never-before-seen textiles by Rosie Lee Tompkins, a bed-and-breakfast in Mexico City — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: The New Yorker’s fact checkers walk off the job for a day.
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Magazines', 'Strikes', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: The labor action by more than 100 union workers also included web producers and some other editorial employees.
lead_paragraph: The New Yorker’s union employees did not go to work on Thursday.

headline: Manhattan Lease Signings Are Booming. Is It Enough for a Recovery?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: Looking back through a year of lease-signing data reveals the beginning of something. But what?
lead_paragraph: Like everything else in 2020, New York City’s real estate market was different than any in memory. A complete industry shutdown in March eventually led, by the end of the fourth quarter of 2020, to soaring median sale prices in Brooklyn (up 9.4 percent from Q4 2019) and Queens (up 9.5 percent). But Manhattan prices rose only marginally, largely driven by high-end condos. It’s the borough’s rental market that tells the story from a different angle.

headline: Moynihan Train Hall Becomes a Destination: ‘This Gives Us Hope’
abstract: Pandemic-weary visitors are finding uplift in the new station, with its soaring expanses of glass and light. “Perfect quarantine activity,” one says.
lead_paragraph: They whistled at it, paraded in it, posed against it, and, for a few moments, forgot themselves. They came to instill civic pride in their kids and remind themselves of all that New York could be. And they left with the satisfaction that comes when your city does something monumental, and does it right.

lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are six-bedroom houses in Babylon, N.Y., and Edison, N.J.

headline: California on Inauguration Day
abstract: Thursday: The Golden State was well represented on Inauguration Day. Here’s what it meant.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Players in a New Super League Would Be Barred From the World Cup
abstract: FIFA sends a stern warning to clubs that are considering forming their own lucrative competition.
lead_paragraph: Top players will be barred from playing for their national teams in events like the World Cup if their clubs join a breakaway league, soccer’s major governing bodies warned on Thursday.

headline: Can Robert Bigelow (and the Rest of Us) Survive Death?
keywords: ['Unidentified Flying Objects (UFO)', 'Occult Sciences', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Extraterrestrial Life', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: He’s offering nearly $1 million if you help him figure it out.
lead_paragraph: What’s across the River Styx? Robert Thomas Bigelow would like to know. Wouldn’t anyone, especially now? But Mr. Bigelow is not just anyone, or any 76-year-old mourning a wife and confronting his own mortality. He’s a maverick Las Vegas real estate and aerospace mogul with billionaire allure and the resources to fund his restless curiosity embracing outer and inner space, U.F.O.s and the spirit realm.

headline: Hispanic Lawmakers, Pushing for a Change in Hollywood, Start With ‘Selena’
abstract: Lawmakers and experts hope that by adding the film to the National Film Registry, more doors could open for Latinos in movies and television.
lead_paragraph: First there was Selena Quintanilla-Pérez, the pathbreaking Latina singer who inspired a generation of artists and was killed at the cusp of national fame. Then there was “Selena,” the film that burnished her legend and propelled another Latina artist to stardom.

headline: Playing Bach, Was He a Pioneer or a Reactionary?
abstract: The conductor and keyboardist Karl Richter’s legacy can be explored anew with a 100-disc box set.
lead_paragraph: It was Karl Richter’s Bach that pushed Nikolaus Harnoncourt over the edge.

headline: A Closer Look at Who Attended President Biden’s Inauguration
abstract: This interactive photo shows you who was there and where they sat.
lead_paragraph: This interactive photo shows you who was there and where they sat.

headline: Wood Gaylor, Quietly Dazzling, Helped an Art World Invent Itself
keywords: ['Art', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)', 'Museums']
abstract: Two shows introduce a forgotten innovator who fused modernism, folk art and documentary to portray his beloved New York scene.
lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON, N.Y. — In the early decades of the 20th-century, things happened in the New York art world when painters like Walt Kuhn, Florine Stettheimer and Wood Gaylor took matters into their own hands. They established clubs and professional organizations and mounted exhibitions — including the 1913 Armory Show, which jump-started American modernism with heady exposure to the European kind.

headline: At the Inauguration, Amanda Gorman Wove History and the Future Into a Stirring Melody
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Inaugurations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Gorman’s reading of her poem “The Hill We Climb” on Wednesday combined the personal and political.
lead_paragraph: The sun came out intermittently at President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inauguration in Washington on Wednesday, but Amanda Gorman was her own source of illumination. With her canary-yellow Prada coat, her regal red headband, her thrice-scrubbed innocence and her exacting delivery, she was a one-person reminder that if winter is here, then spring cannot be far behind.

headline: Gagosian Names a New Director and Curator
abstract: Antwaun Sargent, a critic and author, plans to work with artists who are thinking about contemporary issues around identity, desire and representation.
lead_paragraph: Gagosian, the global gallery known for ambitious exhibitions, has added a 32-year-old director and curator, Antwaun Sargent, whose first show will examine what he calls “notions of Black space.”

headline: Palberta Blends Big-Tent Pop and Art-Rock on ‘Palberta5000’
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: The New York trio remains gleefully odd on an album recorded in just four days.
lead_paragraph: Palberta is a three-piece rock band without a guitarist, a bassist or a drummer. Or, to put it another way, Palberta is a band with three of each of those things: Onstage and on its records, Ani Ivry-Block, Lily Konigsberg and Nina Ryser trade instruments between nearly every song and harmonize with a near familial tightness that makes the very notion of a frontperson seem absurd. “It kind of feels like we share a brain in a lot of ways, at this point,” Konisberg said in 2018. It kind of sounds like that, too.

headline: The Gloopy Glory of Frank Auerbach’s Portraits
abstract: The artist’s industrious paintings and drawings, made across four decades, are now on view at Luhring Augustine.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago I reread “The Emigrants,” W.G. Sebald’s sublime 1992 requiem of four men driven, in the face of totalitarianism, from Central Europe to England and America. In its last and most moving chapter we meet the refugee Max Ferber, a painter whom the narrator watches in a dusty Manchester studio, working and reworking a series of portraits with almost obsessive repetition.

headline: Chaos in Portland Hours After Biden’s Inauguration
abstract: Federal agents used tear gas in Portland, Ore., against protesters gathered on Wednesday outside an Immigration and Customs Enforcement building near downtown.
lead_paragraph: Federal agents used tear gas in Portland, Ore., against protesters gathered on Wednesday outside an Immigration and Customs Enforcement building near downtown.

headline: A TV Grand Tour, in Time for the Weekend
abstract: A jam-packed itinerary of premieres includes France (“Call My Agent!”), Italy (“Gomorrah”), Israel (“Losing Alice”) and Britain (“Flack” and “The Sister”).
lead_paragraph: Even in these boom times for television imports, it’s an unusual bounty.

headline: Do Museums Need a Shopping Network for Art Donations?
abstract: A new venture suggests it will help art institutions find works of art that collectors have decided they want to give away as gifts.
lead_paragraph: For art collectors interested in donating a work, one worry has long been that their gift, a valuable, possibly beloved, painting would end up in a museum basement, where many items from permanent collections reside, unseen.

headline: In U.K. Hospitals, a Desperate Battle Against a Threat Many Saw Coming
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hospitals', 'Nursing and Nurses', 'Shortages', 'Oxygen', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Disease Rates', 'Politics and Government', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: Hospitals are straining to cope with a new coronavirus variant, despite warnings last year that more preparations were needed for an expected surge of cases in the winter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As a new and more contagious variant of the coronavirus pounds Britain’s overstretched National Health Service, health care workers say the government’s failure to anticipate a wintertime crush of infections has left them resorting to ever more desperate measures.

headline: U.S. Covid Vaccine Supply: How to Make Sense of Those Confusing Numbers
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Content Type: Service', 'Shortages', 'Defense Production Act', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'United States Politics and Government', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: Can President Biden really boost production? Why are governors trying to buy directly from Pfizer? And when will supply exceed demand?
lead_paragraph: Demand for vaccines is skyrocketing as the United States grapples with a record death toll from Covid-19 and the threat of new, more contagious variants. After a slow start in December, many states and cities have quickly ramped up vaccine delivery, widening access to larger groups of people and setting up mass testing sites.

headline: Art Basel, Swiss Centerpiece of the Trade’s Year, Is Postponed
keywords: ['Art', 'ART BASEL (FESTIVAL)', 'Art Basel Miami Beach', 'Art Basel Hong Kong', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Finances', 'Auctions']
abstract: Dealers were looking to the event as a bellwether for a return to normality in the art world.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The international art trade’s hopes of returning to some kind of in-person normality were set back Thursday when Art Basel announced that its flagship fair in Switzerland, scheduled for June, would be postponed until September.

headline: From ‘unloved’ to ‘favorite,’ Britain’s stock market rides a wave.
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Foreign Investments', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Despite strict lockdowns and Brexit trade disruptions, investors have turned to Britain’s stock market in the first weeks of 2021.
lead_paragraph: The start of 2021 has been rocky for Britain. Its exit from the European Union unleashed a colossal amount of red tape that has left some industries desperate for help, and the country is under yet another lockdown because of a fast-spreading strain of the coronavirus.

headline: What Internet Censorship Looks Like
abstract: In East Africa, too much Facebook has been awful. So has too little Facebook.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Why Kamala Harris and ‘Firsts’ Matter, and Where They Fall Short
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: It makes a difference when the first member of a group rises to a position of power, political science shows, but it requires “work to sustain it.”
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris will forever have “first” attached to her name — the first woman, the first Black American and the first person of South Asian descent to serve as vice president of the United States.

headline: Russia Pushes U.S.-Funded News Outlet Toward Exit
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States International Relations', 'Cold War Era', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty has been threatened with fines and criminal charges for its journalists, forcing a tough decision on the Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s government is threatening Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty with multimillion-dollar fines and possible criminal charges against its employees, raising the possibility of the American-funded news organization being pushed out of Russia just as President Biden seeks to reorient the U.S. relationship with the Kremlin.

headline: At Biden’s Inaugural Events, the Music Was Earnestly Reassuring
abstract: Artists including Bruce Springsteen, Demi Lovato and John Legend tried to bring together an America that couldn’t gather in person, and irony and bombast were banished.
lead_paragraph: Throughout President Biden’s inauguration, music sent every possible signal of unabashed earnestness. Irony was banished; so were arrogance, bombast, triumphalism and confrontation. Echoing the Biden campaign, and tightly coordinated with the speeches and imagery of his first day in office, the music insisted on unity after division, hope after pain.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Climate Friendly Cars
abstract: Which cars save drivers money in the long-run? Which ones are better for the planet? What else do you notice in this graph?

headline: ‘It Will Be Soon,’ Pelosi Says of Trump Impeachment Trial
abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the impeachment charge against former President Donald J. Trump would be sent to the Senate for trial “soon,” but didn’t pinpoint a date.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the impeachment charge against former President Donald J. Trump would be sent to the Senate for trial “soon,” but didn’t pinpoint a date.

headline: Glastonbury Canceled Again, Casting Doubt Over Europe’s Music Festivals
keywords: ['Music', 'Festivals', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Glastonbury Festival of Contemporary Performing Arts', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Britain’s biggest music event won’t take place for a second year in a row. The decision has sent shock waves across Europe, where festivals have already been asking politicians for help.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s Glastonbury festival, one of the world’s most prominent pop music events, was canceled on Thursday for a second year in a row because of the coronavirus — sparking fear that large music festivals in Europe will not go ahead this summer.

headline: Prominent Lawyers Want Giuliani’s Law License Suspended Over Trump Work
keywords: ['Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Legal Profession', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The move by dozens of lawyers, including judges and former federal prosecutors, was the latest in a series of calls to censure him.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of prominent lawyers have signed a formal complaint seeking the suspension of Rudolph W. Giuliani’s law license — the latest and loudest in a series of calls to censure him for his actions as President Donald J. Trump’s personal attorney.

headline: Biden Tells OSHA to Issue New Covid-19 Guidance to Employers
keywords: ['Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: Unions, which largely support the new president, had complained that the Trump administration did little to protect workers from the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: President Biden directed the Occupational Safety and Health Administration on Thursday to release new guidance to employers on protecting workers from Covid-19.

headline: ‘Notorious’ Port Authority Bus Terminal May Get a $10 Billion Overhaul
abstract: After years of study and debate, there is finally a proposal to rebuild the Midtown Manhattan eyesore from the ground up.
lead_paragraph: Few public spaces in the country have been derided so thoroughly and so often as the Port Authority Bus Terminal in the heart of Manhattan.

headline: For Peter Nygard, Alone and Jailed, Rags-to-Riches Story Turns Upside Down
abstract: The former fashion executive’s defense team asked for more time after one of the two guarantors who put forward collateral raised suspicions.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — For years, Peter Nygard presented himself as a rags-to-riches story: a multimillionaire who built a fashion empire from nothing, hobnobbed with Canadian prime ministers and traveled between his luxurious homes on a private jet, surrounded by women a fraction of his age. And he was a modern Juan Ponce de León, claiming to have found the fountain of youth through diet, exercise and regular stem-cell infusions.

headline: Review: One Belfast Landmark Inspires Five Irish Monologues
abstract: The excellent program of short audioplays commissioned for “Under the Albert Clock” imagines the world in 2050.
lead_paragraph: Maureen has worn the wrong shoes — one of each from two different pairs. So she’s hiding in a bathroom stall, phoning a friend for some emergency footwear.

headline: Drug Prevents Coronavirus Infection in Nursing Homes, Maker Claims
abstract: A monoclonal antibody protected residents and staff members in facilities where the virus had appeared.
lead_paragraph: An unusual experiment to prevent nursing home staff members and residents from infection with the coronavirus has succeeded, the drug maker Eli Lilly announced on Thursday.

headline: Looking for a Great Courtroom Drama? Start Here
abstract: “Anatomy of a Murder,” starring Jimmy Stewart, is a legal drama that trusts audiences to dwell in gray areas.
lead_paragraph: Gateway Movies offers ways to begin exploring directors, genres and topics in film by examining a few streaming movies.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Europe takes new measures against the variant.
lead_paragraph: As European countries brace for a potential surge of coronavirus cases linked to the new variants, countries have reimposed strict lockdown measures, and some have made “medical” grade masks mandatory in some areas.

headline: Former Vatican Banker Convicted of Money Laundering and Embezzlement
abstract: The ruling by the Vatican court signaled the church’s desire to get its financial house in order following past scandals.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A Vatican court on Thursday convicted a former senior official at the Vatican bank and his lawyer of embezzlement and money laundering, sending a strong signal that the church was determined to get its financial house in order.

headline: One Martini, Ice Cold, With a Blanket and a Scarf
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Alcoholic Beverages', 'Curling', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Drinking outdoors in the winter, thanks to Covid, can be painful, but bar owners are trying to make it feel like fun — or at least less frigid.
lead_paragraph: In winters past, Del Pedro, an owner of Tooker Alley in Brooklyn, responded to snowfall by inviting a group of friends to drink martinis in the bar’s frigid backyard. Called the Polar Bear Martini Club, the gatherings were a wry gesture of hearty determination tossed into the teeth of inclement weather.

headline: What Students Are Saying About ‘Impostor Syndrome,’ Beloved Places and Finding Balance in 2021
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to another roundup of student comments on our writing prompts. This week we asked teenagers if they have ever dealt with “impostor syndrome”; what places, either nearby or around the globe, they love most; and what they hoped to have more (and less) of in 2021.

headline: Put the Money Printer on Autopilot
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: If a Biden relief package isn’t open-ended, and tied to a full recovery, America is doomed to repeat last-minute partisan fights over aid.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the Senate confirmation hearing for Janet Yellen, President Biden’s nominee to be the next Treasury secretary, turned into a de facto hearing on the president’s economic relief plan. While Ms. Yellen, a former Federal Reserve chair, is expected to be confirmed, the fate of the Biden plan is up in the air and became the focus of senators’ back and forth.

headline: The Paris Climate Agreement: What You Need to Know
keywords: ['United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Biden’s decision to return to the climate pact fulfills a campaign pledge, but the United States has some catching up to do.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has recommitted the United States to the Paris climate agreement, the international accord designed to avert catastrophic global warming.

headline: Senators Cruz and Hawley Have ‘Fancy’ Degrees. So?
abstract: A reader suggests that an Ivy League education is no guarantee of success. Also: When the police interrogate youth; the simple joy of playing catch.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Revealing Jack Whitten’s Secret Self
abstract: “I Am The Object” proves that, whether through sculpture or painting, the artist’s primary concern was capturing the essence of Black life and communal memory.
lead_paragraph: Jack Whitten, who died in 2018, was known as an abstract painter, but figuration continued to lurk around his work. His remarkable experiments come to life in “I Am The Object,” one of the best shows in the city right now but one that is unfortunately closing Saturday at Hauser & Wirth in Chelsea. It is worth seeing because these works shed new light on how the artist’s oeuvre might be considered.

headline: Biden Inherits a Vaccine Supply Unlikely to Grow Before April
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: But with 200 million doses pledged for the first quarter of the year, some experts say President Biden’s plan for 100 million shots in 100 days is far too modest.
lead_paragraph: As the Biden administration takes power with a pledge to tame the most dire public health crisis in a century, one pillar of its strategy is to significantly increase the supply of Covid-19 vaccines.

headline: After Biden’s Inauguration: Pride and Relief
abstract: Readers felt uplifted by the inauguration ceremony. One described his “renewed appreciation of American democracy and the rituals that celebrate it.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, holds a news briefing. Dr. Anthony S. Fauci is expected to attend.
lead_paragraph: Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, holds a news briefing. Dr. Anthony S. Fauci is expected to attend.

headline: ‘We Need More Vaccine,’ Mayor Says as N.Y.C. Postpones Appointments

lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio urged the federal government to send New York more coronavirus vaccine doses, saying New York City is being forced to push back inoculation appointments.

headline: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Joins Hunts Point Workers Strike
abstract: Workers at Hunts Point Produce Market in the Bronx are on strike, saying they deserve higher wages after six died and hundreds fell ill from the coronavirus. Several Democrats have also waded into the dispute, supporting the workers.
lead_paragraph: Workers at Hunts Point Produce Market in the Bronx are on strike, saying they deserve higher wages after six died and hundreds fell ill from the coronavirus. Several Democrats have also waded into the dispute, supporting the workers.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: This week’s recommended books cast their nets wide, from the shores of a Scottish loch to the hills of southern India to the story of a peripatetic childhood in Europe and East Africa. They look back in time, too: George Saunders revisits classics of Russian literature; Robert Jones Jr. imagines a love story on a Mississippi plantation before the Civil War; and the father-son team of Stephen Kendrick and Paul Kendrick write about Martin Luther King Jr.’s 1960 arrest in Georgia, which played a surprising role in that year’s presidential elections. Other books we like include James Comey’s reckoning with honesty and accountability in politics, Rich Cohen’s look at a children’s hockey league in Connecticut, a bad-seed parenting thriller and a classic Surrealist novel, reissued.

headline: The N.R.A. Wants to ‘Dump’ Its Regulators via Bankruptcy. Will It Succeed?
abstract: In a showdown with New York State, the National Rifle Association is trying an unusual strategy. Legal experts doubt it will work.
lead_paragraph: Not long after the National Rifle Association declared bankruptcy last Friday, one of its board members wanted to set the record straight.

headline: A judge declines to force Amazon to resume hosting Parler.
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Cloud Computing', 'Social Media']
abstract: The judge said forcing Amazon to allow the social media app back onto its cloud computing platform would not be in the public interest.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge declined on Thursday to force Amazon to resume hosting the social networking app Parler on its cloud computing platform, saying that doing so would not be in the public interest.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: “Blown Away” is finally back for a second season. And a favorite show starring Amy Sedaris is finally streaming.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: Antonio Sabàto, Spaghetti Western Leading Man, Dies at 77
abstract: One of his biggest roles was as a racecar driver in John Frankenheimer’s “Grand Prix.” He died of complications of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Who Won the $731 Million Powerball?
abstract: The winning ticket was sold at a convenience store in a former mining town in Maryland. “We don’t know for who,” the shopkeeper said, “but we are happy for somebody.”
lead_paragraph: Someone in Maryland is suddenly $731 million richer.

headline: Elijah Moshinsky, Met Opera Director With Fanciful Touch, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Moshinsky, known for mixing traditional staging ideas with modern flourishes, also created productions for the Royal Opera and Opera Australia. He died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: Elijah Moshinsky, an Australian theater, television and opera director known for his productions at the Royal Opera in London, Opera Australia and especially the Metropolitan Opera, died on Jan. 14 at a hospital in London. He was 75.

headline: He Called His Song ‘American Anthem.’ It Actually Became One.
keywords: ['Music', 'Inaugurations', 'Opera', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: In his inaugural address, President Biden quoted Gene Scheer’s song, a patriotic hymn championed by the opera star Denyce Graves and recorded by Norah Jones for a Ken Burns soundtrack.
lead_paragraph: Gene Scheer, an opera librettist, was at his home in Washington, Conn., on Wednesday, ostensibly working but really watching the inauguration, when two words fluttered out of the television and practically knocked him out of his chair.

headline: Six Are Accused of Helping Fugitives Escape From California Jail
abstract: The defendants were identified as friends and relatives of six inmates who had escaped from a jail in Merced County this month. Three of the fugitives remain at large, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Six relatives and friends of six inmates who used a rope of braided bedsheets to break out of a California jail this month have been arrested and charged with helping the men escape, the authorities said.

headline: The First Capitol Riot Arrests Were Easy. The Next Ones Will Be Tougher.
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Social Media', 'Treason and Sedition']
abstract: An initial wave of arrests was based on news accounts and social media. Proving a conspiracy could be much more challenging.
lead_paragraph: Of the 125 federal arrests made so far in connection with the riot at the Capitol earlier this month, most have been relatively simple: Agents and prosecutors have put together cases largely by scouring the news and social media for incriminating photographs and videos.

headline: A Big List of Podcasts for Little Kids
abstract: To keep your little ones occupied, look no further than the world of podcasts. Here are a few ideas for kids ages 2 to 6.

headline: Poem: I Now Pronounce You Dead
abstract: Martín Espada’s poem says that Bartolomeo Vanzetti was more than whatever the state chose to execute him for.
lead_paragraph: The federal death penalty has returned. Once, while I was in prison, I saw a man talk to a man on death row. The first man had no idea his friend would be executed. He asked, “When are you coming home?” The silence that followed has never left me. Martín Espada’s poem says that Bartolomeo Vanzetti was more than whatever the state chose to execute him for. This is the poem that asks us if it’s OK to name the date we’ll murder and bury another. Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts

lead_paragraph: President Biden moved into the White House this week, replacing a leader whose constant need to command attention left millions of Americans exhausted by the nonstop spectacle and facing a seemingly unparalleled set of challenges.

headline: How Martha Teichner, CBS Correspondent, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: One thing is for certain: She will have a bull terrier by her side and at least another one in her thoughts.
lead_paragraph: Like most people, Martha Teichner, a  correspondent for “CBS Sunday Morning,” expected 2021 to be an improvement over 2020. For one thing, she has a memoir, “When Harry Met Minnie,” coming out soon. The book, a tale of two women devoted to their dogs who also become devoted to each other, tells the story of how Ms. Teichner, the owner of Minnie, a bull terrier, comes to adopt Harry, the bull terrier of a friend of a friend with terminal cancer.

headline: Everybody Loves Fran. But Why?
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Television', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Fran Lebowitz, professional wit, offers her take on New York in a new Netflix series. But for a city that’s always changing, her shtick remains the same.
lead_paragraph: By nearly any measure of my affinities, I ought to love Fran Lebowitz the way I love lasagna or quickly finding a cab in a thunderstorm. But for a long time now, whenever she has entered my frame of vision, she has come at me like a mime on the subway — an unwelcome spectacle of the familiar.

headline: Warm Hearts at an Icy Elopement
abstract: Sarah Bishop and Kacey Harris, who live in San Antonio, opted for a wintry wedding in the Rocky Mountains.
lead_paragraph: At their self-uniting ceremony in Frisco, Colo., on Jan. 6, the first thing Sarah Bishop and Kacey Harris did was play a round of rock-paper-scissors. That was their way of deciding who should say their vows first. The couple were standing beside Dillon Reservoir, which was frozen, surrounded by the Rocky Mountains, covered by new snow and crisscrossed with animal tracks. The sun had just risen, but not the temperature. It was zero degrees. Ms. Harris won, so she began.

abstract: The Australian painter Gordon Hookey and the Los Angeles artist Gary Simmons found they had many things in common. Sports is just one of them.

headline: In the Bronx, a Face Lost in Time
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Sculpture', 'Vandalism']
abstract: A much-vandalized bronze statue of “Fame” in Joyce Kilmer Park is to be returned this year with a new head, arms and feet — even without any record of what the statue’s original face looked like.
lead_paragraph: Fame can be fleeting for any of us, but in the case of Louis J. Heintz, a formerly celebrated New York City streets commissioner, injury has been added to the insult of increasing obscurity. In the decades after a memorial was dedicated to Heintz in a Bronx park in 1909, the graceful bronze allegorical figure of Fame that adorned the monument suffered multiple violations that are only now being remedied.

headline: Five million in the U.K. have gotten a vaccine and officials hint the variant may be more deadly, though it’s too soon to tell.
abstract: The vaccination figure amounts to 8 percent of the population, in a country where it could take months to control the spread of the more transmissible variant.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, Britain has reported alarming coronavirus death numbers, hospitals have continued to fill up, and fears have risen that it will take months to control the spread of a more transmissible variant first detected in the Kent region of England last year.

headline: Share a Time You Saw an Act of Love in an Unlikely Moment
abstract: What the world needs now is … you get it. We want to hear your stories of unexpectedly witnessing kindness and care.
lead_paragraph: Walking home in New York City a few months ago, I became an unknown witness to a touching demonstration of love. It was an everyday scene — one I caught with an inadvertent glance through the window of a garden apartment — of a grandmother cleaning up after dinner, with a toddler in her pajamas standing by. But they were dancing. The grandmother with a mop, the baby on strong but unsteady legs. You didn’t need to hear the laughing or the encouragement — you could see their bond. Their obvious love for each other and shared joy momentarily stopped me in my tracks.

abstract: Of the 125 federal arrests made so far in connection with the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol, most have been relatively simple: Agents and prosecutors have put together cases largely by scouring the news and social media for incriminating photographs and videos, with some of the evidence almost comically easy to obtain.

headline: Why It’s So Hard to Cut Waste in Health Care
abstract: During the pandemic, people have been getting less medical treatment. That saves money, but it could harm their health, an economist says.
lead_paragraph: Cutting waste while preserving critically important treatment is the holy grail of health care policy. The coronavirus pandemic has shown why that goal has been so stubbornly difficult to achieve.
