headline: Covid-19 Kept Tourists Away. Why Did These Seabirds Miss Them?
keywords: ['Birds', 'Animal Behavior', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Research', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-animals']
abstract: When travel restrictions stopped bird-watchers from visiting a Swedish island, hidden ecosystem dynamics were revealed.
lead_paragraph: When tourists come to Stora Karlso, a limestone-ledged nature reserve off the coast of Sweden, they keep a respectful distance from the many seabirds that call the island home. Like most visitors to wild places, they aim to leave only footprints and take only photos — to slip between the strands of the web of life they’ve come to see.

headline: The Coronavirus Kills Mink, So They Too May Get a Vaccine
abstract: The pandemic has been a powerful reminder that there is no clear barrier between viruses affecting animals and people.
lead_paragraph: At least two American companies, as well as Russian researchers, are working on coronavirus vaccines for mink. The animals have grown sick and died in large numbers from the virus, which they have also passed back to people in mutated form.

headline: Director of Amazon India Drama Cuts Scenes Amid Outcry From Hindu Nationalists
abstract: Faced with boycotts and criminal complaints, the director of “Tandav” made the edits this week. But that did not appear to satisfy some of the show’s critics, who called for him to be jailed.
lead_paragraph: ARPORA, India — The director of a big-budget Amazon web series has bowed to pressure from Hindu nationalists and cut several scenes that they had deemed offensive, demonstrating the sway of a powerful political movement that strives to reshape Indian society.

headline: Recreating an Archaeological Discovery From the Ground Down
abstract: “The Dig,” on Netflix, revisits the astonishing find made by two amateurs in Britain as World War II was dawning.
lead_paragraph: GODALMING, England — Entirely covered by earth, only his face visible, Ralph Fiennes lay patiently in the ground. Simon Stone, the director of the new Netflix drama, “The Dig,” peered at a monitor, then nodded. “Let’s go,” he said. Fiennes shut his eyes, and a waiting crew poured soil over his head, burying him completely. Carey Mulligan dashed forward, panic-stricken, and began to frantically scrabble at the ground.

headline: Edward Burns Returns to Long Island with ‘Bridge and Tunnel’
keywords: ['Television', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Actors and Actresses', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Set in a 1980s version of his hometown, the filmmaker’s new Epix series captures the post-college period when “you’re not quite an adult but no longer a kid,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Edward Burns has carved a distinctive path as an indie filmmaker in the quarter-century since he made a splash with his debut, “The Brothers McMullen.” He has consistently made movies for small ($250,000 for “Looking for Kitty”) to minuscule ($9,000 — yes, you read that right — for “Newlyweds”) budgets, and was experimenting with new distribution models even before the rise of streaming. In 2007, he made the first straight-to-iTunes movie, “Purple Violets,” and in 2010 he inaugurated Comcast’s straight-to-VOD Indie Film Club with “Nice Guy Johnny.”

headline: Prompted by the Pandemic, Opera Philadelphia Innovates Online
keywords: ['Opera', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: With its own streaming service and a string of premieres, this company is setting the pace for virtual performances.
lead_paragraph: What can an opera company actually do in a pandemic? Yes, some previously planned performances can be turned into livestreams, and broadcasts of past stagings can be made freely available — if only to remind the public what it’s missing.

headline: U.S. Coronavirus Cases Are Falling, but Variants Could Erase Progress
abstract: New daily cases are starting to slow in what some health experts see as a turning point. But they warn of a bumpy vaccination rollout amid the emergence of more contagious variants.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In recent days, coronavirus cases have been dropping steadily across the United States, with hospitalizations falling in concert. But health officials are growing increasingly concerned that quickly circulating variants of the virus could cause new surges of cases faster than the country is managing to distribute Covid-19 vaccines.

headline: Rain and Snow Headed for Wildfire-Damaged Areas of California
abstract: The precipitation in drought-stricken Central and Northern California is welcome. But forecasters warned that flash flooding is possible in areas that burned last year.
lead_paragraph: A parched swath of Central California is set to receive welcome rounds of rain and snow over the next week, but the forecast is raising concerns about flash flooding and mudslides in areas that endured a treacherous wildfire season last year.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Delight in the tingly, sweat-bringing intensity of a mala beef braise.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. When our Tejal Rao fell ill with Covid-19 a while back, she lost her sense of smell. It’s a common neurological side effect of the virus, but troublesome for a journalist who writes about food. “Without smells to guide me,” she wrote for The Times this week, “my sense of taste faded and food flattened out, going gray and muted, dull and lifeless. Cheese became rubber and paste. Popcorn turned into thorny foam.”

lead_paragraph: Most of the time, the 116-year-old movie theater business is rather humdrum.

headline: Super Bowl to Host 22,000 Fans
abstract: About 7,500 health care workers who have been vaccinated will be given free tickets, the league said, but it will sell 14,500 tickets to customers who will not be required to get inoculated.
lead_paragraph: It won’t quite be the usual full house, but 22,000 seats, or roughly 30 percent of capacity, will be filled at the Super Bowl in Tampa, Fla., the N.F.L. said Friday.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: The search for a missing black hole. A new study on catnip. A tumultuous year for the Broadway smash “Moulin Rouge.” Mardi Gras in the pandemic. And more.
lead_paragraph: The search for a missing black hole. A new study on catnip. A tumultuous year for the Broadway smash “Moulin Rouge.” Mardi Gras in the pandemic. And more.

headline: Intelligence Analysts Use U.S. Smartphone Location Data Without Warrants, Memo Says
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Search and Seizure', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Mobile Applications', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The disclosure comes amid growing legislative scrutiny of how the government uses commercially available location records.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A military arm of the intelligence community buys commercially available databases containing location data from smartphone apps and searches it for Americans’ past movements without a warrant, according to an unclassified memo obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Bagpipes for a Bard’s Birthday
abstract: An illustrated ode to Scotland’s national poet, Robert Burns, on the occasion of his Jan. 25 birthday.

headline: An Artist Whose Comics Tell Us What It’s Like to Be Depressed
abstract: In her latest Graphic Content column, Hillary Chute examines the work of Allie Brosh, who has returned after a long absence with a new book, “Solutions and Other Problems.”
lead_paragraph: I came late to Allie Brosh’s “Hyperbole and a Half” — later than the outspoken fan Bill Gates and numerous enthusiastic writers for Psychology Today — but when I fell, I fell hard. (I even bought the calendar.) A selection of Brosh’s autobiographical word-and-image stories from her blog of the same name (which she began in college while procrastinating for a final), “Hyperbole and a Half” made me laugh harder than anything I could remember.

headline: I Can’t Wait to Make This Chicken
abstract: Cook Kay Chun’s latest recipe, with squash and dates, or try sheet-pan sausage with mushrooms or cod and kimchi stew.
lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. Maybe it’s just a mood, but I am embracing extra big and bold flavors this week — statement dishes, if you will. The recipes below use ingredients like capers, kimchi and barbecue sauce to bring some spark to your table, even on a Tuesday.

headline: The Next Moves in Fighting the Virus
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers discuss President Biden’s new mask requirements, logistics in getting the shot, mask-wearing as a “sacred duty,” and the prognoses for patients.

headline: Facebook Invokes Its ‘Supreme Court’
abstract: The site asks its oversight body to rule on Trump. But its justice system doesn’t work for everyone.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Trump, who spurned legislative achievement for executive action, sees his agenda quickly undone.
abstract: As President Donald J. Trump boarded the plane home to Florida on Wednesday, he cast his administration’s policy achievements as sweeping, ambitious and, above all, enduring — but the undoing of his legacy was just about to begin.
lead_paragraph: As President Donald J. Trump boarded the plane home to Florida on Wednesday, he cast his administration’s policy achievements as sweeping, ambitious and, above all, enduring — but the undoing of his legacy was just about to begin.

headline: ‘Everybody Loved Blake, Except His Wives. Sometimes, We Hated Him.’
abstract: Cate Quinn’s debut mystery, “Black Widows,” investigates three sister-wives who all had good reasons to wish their controlling husband dead.
lead_paragraph: You’d think that three wives might have been enough for Blake Nelson, the head of a Mormon household in deepest Utah who makes a nice corpse in Cate Quinn’s debut mystery, BLACK WIDOWS (Sourcebooks Landmark, 418 pp., $26.99). Rachel, the No. 1 wife and one of the story’s three narrators, is the devoted, traditional one. Emily, the second wife, is a little more flighty. And Tina, Wife No. 3, is a former sex worker and addict. All the sister-wives were admittedly miffed when Blake started shopping around for Wife No. 4, but which one of them might have been mad enough to kill him? “Everybody loved Blake,” Rachel testifies. “Except his wives. Sometimes, we hated him.”

headline: Justin Trudeau Gets Call From Biden as Canada and U.S. Mend Relations
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Canadians welcome a renewed relationship with the United States after tolerating four years of insults and threats from the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — We’re friends again!

lead_paragraph: SCORCHED EARTHEnvironmental Warfare as a Crime Against Humanity and NatureBy Emmanuel Kreike521 pp. Princeton University. $29.99.

headline: Smugglers Get Long Prison Terms in U.K. for Their Roles in Killing 39 Migrants
abstract: The migrants had paid thousands of dollars to try to reach a better life abroad. Instead, they suffered an excruciating death, suffocating in an airtight container.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Four smugglers convicted of killing 39 people from Vietnam who died in the back of a container truck as it was shipped to England were sentenced Friday to between 13 and 27 years in prison.

headline: Senate Confirms Austin, Installing First Black Defense Secretary
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The retired general was approved overwhelmingly, after Congress granted him a waiver from a law restricting those who are retired from military service fewer than seven years from leading the Pentagon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lloyd J. Austin III was swiftly sworn in as secretary of defense on Friday, filling a senior national security position in President Biden’s cabinet, one briefly threatened by unease among lawmakers to again put a recently retired general in charge of the Pentagon.

headline: Billie Eilish and Rosalía Join Eccentric Forces, and 12 More New Songs

Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Murkowski rules out switching parties to join Democrats, saying, ‘I can’t be somebody that I’m not.’
abstract: Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, said on Friday that she was committed to remaining a Republican, calling liberal aspirations that she might switch parties and hand Democrats an edge in the evenly divided Senate “a dream by some that will not materialize.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, said on Friday that she was committed to remaining a Republican, calling liberal aspirations that she might switch parties and hand Democrats an edge in the evenly divided Senate “a dream by some that will not materialize.”

headline: Kathleen Kingsbury Is Named New York Times Opinion Editor
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Newspapers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: She spent seven months as the section’s interim head after replacing James Bennet, who resigned under pressure. Now she officially takes a job that has been a steppingstone to the top editor position at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Kingsbury, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist who has led the editorial page of The New York Times on an interim basis since June, officially became the newspaper’s opinion editor on Friday, the company said.

headline: A Report Card for U.S. Schools
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Education (K-12)', 'Grading of Students', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'E-Learning', 'Education', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Education (Secondary)', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Seven districts, seven very different experiences of pandemic learning.
lead_paragraph: For the past few months, my colleagues have worked on a sweeping project on the state of American education. They wanted to address a simple question, said James Dao, a national editor at The Times who oversees education coverage: “Are American children getting adequate schooling in the pandemic?”

headline: Tesla’s U.S. sales slowed in 22 states in 2020, partly because of the pandemic.
keywords: ['Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: The pandemic dampened sales for all automakers in the spring and summer, and Tesla’s plant in Fremont, Calif., was idled from late March until the middle of May.
lead_paragraph: After several years of rapid growth, Tesla’s sales in the United States appear to have slowed in 2020, partly as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, according to fresh data on new-car registrations.

headline: 54 ZIP Codes in New York City Have Positive Test Rates Over 10%
abstract: As the focus turns to vaccinations, the virus continues to spread, leaving health experts to wonder if officials will mull new steps and restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Even as New York City officials focus on vaccinating millions of residents, the coronavirus continues to spread, with more than 50 ZIP codes showing a positive test rate over 10 percent.

headline: Salt-N-Pepa, Hip-Hop Duo That Spoke Up for Women, Tell Their Own Story
abstract: In a new biopic for Lifetime, this rap group that got its start in 1980s New York traces its roots and its conflicts.
lead_paragraph: While selling warranties on washing machines from a Sears call center in Queens, the friends Cheryl James and Sandra Denton came together as a hip-hop duo called Super Nature with the staccato 1985 track “The Show Stoppa (Is Stupid Fresh).” When they first heard it on the radio, they danced together on top of a car. It was just the beginning: James became Salt and Denton became Pepa; the group changed its name and scored 10 hits on the Hot 100, including the ’80s dance classic “Push It” and the ’90s sex anthem “Shoop,” becoming one of the few superstar female acts of hip-hop’s male-dominated golden era.

abstract: Thoroughly miserable weather calls for thoroughly cozy dishes, preferably covered in mozzarella.
lead_paragraph: It’s that casserole time of year again, when common sense dictates that dark, damp and thoroughly miserable days should end in carb-rich, cheesy and thoroughly cozy meals.

headline: After an unruly passenger was escorted off a flight, an officer identified him as a Capitol rioter.

lead_paragraph: Two days after the riot at the Capitol, a man was making such a ruckus aboard a plane on the tarmac at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport that the crew turned the flight around in order to escort him off.

headline: Watch live as President Biden speaks about economic relief.
abstract: President Biden is expected to talk about his efforts to help the economy recover from the coronavirus pandemic this afternoon and will sign two executive orders aimed at steering additional federal aid to families struggling to afford food amid the pandemic and helping workers stay safe on the job.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is expected to talk about his efforts to help the economy recover from the coronavirus pandemic this afternoon and will sign two executive orders aimed at steering additional federal aid to families struggling to afford food amid the pandemic and helping workers stay safe on the job.

headline: On ‘Rooftop of Africa,’ Ethiopia’s Troops Hunt Fugitive Former Rulers
keywords: ['War and Armed Conflicts', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Politicians and military commanders who once led Ethiopia are being tracked down, caught and sometimes killed by their own country’s soldiers in the war in the Tigray region.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — For two decades, as foreign minister, Seyoum Mesfin was Ethiopia’s face to the world — a personable and soft-spoken diplomat who brokered peace in neighboring war-torn countries, delivered speeches at the United Nations and helped establish his country as a weighty African power.

headline: Cuomo Warns New York Will Temporarily Run Out of Vaccine
abstract: On Friday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo warned that New York State would run out of vaccine doses by the end of the day, and said providers should only schedule appointments for “allocations they know they will receive.”
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo warned that New York State would run out of vaccine doses by the end of the day, and said providers should only schedule appointments for “allocations they know they will receive.”

headline: Charlene Gehm, Protean Dancer With the Joffrey, Dies at 69
abstract: She could be combative in one duet, a picture of stillness in another and witty in still another role. On Broadway, she danced in “West Side Story.”
lead_paragraph: Charlene Gehm, a dancer who thrilled audiences and critics alike with her excellence in an unusually wide range of roles with the Joffrey Ballet and other troupes, died on Jan. 10 at her home in Manhattan. She was 69.

headline: New York State is temporarily running out of vaccine doses, Cuomo says.
abstract: New York State expected to run out of its supply of coronavirus vaccines before the end of Friday, but more doses would arrive in the coming days, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced at a news conference.
lead_paragraph: New York State expected to run out of its supply of coronavirus vaccines before the end of Friday, but more doses would arrive in the coming days, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced at a news conference.

headline: Mira Furlan, Actress on ‘Lost’ and ‘Babylon 5,’ Dies at 65
abstract: The Croatian-born actress played Ambassador Delenn on the science fiction TV series “Babylon 5” throughout its five seasons and in two movies.
lead_paragraph: Mira Furlan, an actress best known for her roles on the fantastical television series “Babylon 5” and “Lost,” died on Wednesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 65.

headline: Trudeau Says He’s Looking Forward to Working with Biden
abstract: Ahead of his phone call with President Biden, Canada’s prime minister, Justin Trudeau said he would express his concerns about job loss caused by the cancellation of the Keystone XL oil pipeline.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of his phone call with President Biden, Canada’s prime minister, Justin Trudeau said he would express his concerns about job loss caused by the cancellation of the Keystone XL oil pipeline.

headline: The Crispiest, Creamiest Vegan Pasta
abstract: With just a little effort, this no-waste creamy leek pasta delivers a ton of texture and flavor.
lead_paragraph: Boredom often breeds innovation, especially in the kitchen. This pasta was the result of a life lived in lockdown, with ample time to spare and a heightened desire to use ingredients to their full potential.

headline: Breaking the Monotony of Winter
abstract: No more Groundhog Days.
lead_paragraph: Sign up to receive the At Home newsletter.

headline: Hank Aaron Was More Than His Stats. But His Stats Were Outrageous.
abstract: Known for home runs and longevity, Aaron is the career leader in R.B.I. and total bases. He is third on the career hits list.
lead_paragraph: Hank Aaron, whose death at 86 was announced on Friday, was the home run king for 33 years. His final total of 755 can be quoted by nearly anyone who follows baseball — it is a number considerably more well known than the actual record, 762, which is held by Barry Bonds. But Aaron’s accomplishments on the field extended far beyond his home run total.

headline: Lubomir Kavalek, Czech Who Became U.S. Chess Champion, Dies at 77
abstract: One of the first and most elite chess players to flee the Soviet bloc for the West, he was among the best players in the world for many years.
lead_paragraph: Lubomir Kavalek, a chess grandmaster who fled Czechoslovakia after the 1968 Soviet invasion and, after moving to the United States, became a three-time national champion, died on Jan. 17 at his home in Reston, Va. He was 77.

headline: Sweet and Savory Meet in This Sheet-Pan Dinner
abstract: Apples, shallots and Italian sausage are roasted together in this satisfying meal that can be prepared in under an hour.
lead_paragraph: January is often a “reset” month when it comes to cooking — an exciting time for broccoli and spinach, less so for filet of beef and cinnamon rolls. But after almost a year of pandemic cooking and a holiday season notably devoid of festivities, maybe a better goal for 2021 is just to find easier ways to get dinner on the table.

headline: Ticket Brokers Agree to Pay Millions in Scalping Settlements
keywords: ['Ticket Scalping', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Music', 'E-Commerce', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Compensation for Damages (Law)']
abstract: The settlements are the first enforcement actions brought under the Better Online Ticket Sales Act, which was designed to prevent brokers from buying large numbers of tickets.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials announced on Friday that three New York ticket brokers have agreed to pay $3.7 million in civil penalties to settle allegations that they bought tens of thousands of event tickets and resold them to customers at inflated prices.

headline: Hank Aaron Was More Than His Stats, but His Stats Were Outrageous

lead_paragraph: Known for home runs and longevity, Aaron is the career leader in R.B.I. and total bases. He is also third on the career hits list.

headline: The Bills Rack Up Wins. Folding Tables Get Wrecked.
abstract: Though the team prohibits it, Bills fans are carrying on a new table-slamming tradition deep into the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: Devoted N.F.L. fans show their love in lots of ways that don’t make sense out of context. Green Bay Packers fans wear foam blocks of cheese on their heads. Raiders fans paint their faces in black and silver and torment visiting players from their seats in the “Black Hole.” In Kansas City, Chiefs fans drive tricked-out school buses painted in red and gold, the team’s colors.

headline: Retirement in Florida? Tom Brady’s Next Move Might Be to the Super Bowl
abstract: The inglorious interception at the end of his career in New England seems a distant memory as he leads the Buccaneers into the N.F.C. championship game on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: One year ago, Tom Brady’s last pass as a New England Patriot was intercepted and returned for a touchdown, the final mortifying act of a bitter first-round playoff loss.

headline: The Toll of Fried Foods on Heart Health
abstract: Eating fried foods increased the risk of heart disease, stroke, heart failure and premature death.
lead_paragraph: Most of us know that a diet rich in fried foods is bad for us. A review of studies quantifies just how bad it can be.

headline: Love Letter: The Perfect Pandemic Pair
abstract: Plus: A rocky road to a wedding on ice.
lead_paragraph: The forced togetherness brought on by the pandemic has caused many relationships to become strained. However, others have found that time in lockdown has strengthened bonds.

headline: Janet Yellen Is Unanimously Approved by Senate Committee
abstract: On Friday, Janet Yellen’s nomination as Treasury secretary was approved unanimously by the Senate Finance Committee. It will head for final vote by the full Senate.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Janet Yellen’s nomination as Treasury secretary was approved unanimously by the Senate Finance Committee. It will head for final vote by the full Senate.

headline: Biden Calls Coronavirus Aid an ‘Economic Imperative’
abstract: President Biden signed two executive orders Friday, directing more federal aid to Americans struggling due to the coronavirus pandemic and laying the groundwork to institute a $15 minimum wage for federal employees.
lead_paragraph: President Biden signed two executive orders Friday, directing more federal aid to Americans struggling due to the coronavirus pandemic and laying the groundwork to institute a $15 minimum wage for federal employees.

headline: Chairwoman of San Francisco Art School Facing Budget Issues Resigns
keywords: ['Art', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Boards of Directors']
abstract: The leader of the board at the 150-year-old San Francisco Art Institute said she is confident the college has a plan to address its financial problems, but critics have suggested otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Pam Rorke Levy has resigned from her position as chairwoman of the San Francisco Art Institute, a 150-year-old college that has struggled over the last year to emerge from a multimillion-dollar debt and declining enrollment despite its history of training artists including the likes of Kehinde Wiley, Catherine Opie and Annie Leibovitz.

headline: Portraits of Strength
abstract: In this work, rendered with ink and fabric, Pierre Mukeba depicts women at various stages of life.
lead_paragraph: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-seen work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at a painting by Pierre Mukeba, who is inspired by the African diaspora in Australia, that is currently on view at the National Gallery of Victoria in Melbourne as part of its 2020 Triennial, on through April 18.

headline: A Year Later, the First Post-Pandemic City
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disease Rates', 'Quarantines', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Hospitals', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A year ago, Wuhan offered a warning about the coronavirus. Now, it heralds a world where relief at the recovery  conceals the emotional aftershocks.
lead_paragraph: The long months of harsh lockdown have faded from view in Wuhan, the first city in the world devastated by the new coronavirus. As residents look to move on, they cite a Chinese saying that warns against “forgetting the pain after a scar heals.”

headline: Does a Red Tie Immediately Scream ‘Donald Trump’ Now?
keywords: ['Ties (Apparel)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Debates (Political)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Vanessa Friedman, fashion director of The New York Times, takes reader questions.
lead_paragraph: Though the death of the tie is declared regularly — especially given the pressures of both the long-term office-casual movement and our current working-from-home reality — Guy Trebay, our men’s wear critic, maintains that you should not count the accessory out quite yet. As he said, “even if we’re not wearing them much during lockdown, you don’t want to give up on an element of the wardrobe that’s been around for 400 years.”

headline: Five Songs to Listen to Right Now
abstract: Check out five new and notable songs, including Lana Del Rey’s unsettling latest single, a Taylor Swift bonus track and a salvo in hip-hop’s gender war.
lead_paragraph: Check out five new and notable songs, including Lana Del Rey’s unsettling latest single, a Taylor Swift bonus track and a salvo in hip-hop’s gender war.

headline: Voices From China’s Covid-19 Crisis: ‘If I Survive This, What Will I Do?’
abstract: One year after China locked down Wuhan, six people describe how they found courage in adversity, calm amid grief, and meaning in chaos.
lead_paragraph: They are survivors, essential workers and specialists still trying to understand the physical and emotional effects of the coronavirus. They make up a tapestry of people, offering a view of the first months of the pandemic, and of what China’s recovery means.

headline: How Beijing Turned China’s Covid-19 Tragedy to Its Advantage
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Propaganda', 'Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Censorship', 'Social Media']
abstract: The Communist Party’s success in reclaiming the narrative has proved to the world its ability to rally the people to its side, no matter how stumbling its actions might be.
lead_paragraph: One year ago this week, the Chinese Communist Party was on the verge of its biggest crisis in decades. The coronavirus had brought the city of Wuhan to a halt. In the following days, the government’s efforts to conceal the pandemic would become public, sparking an online backlash of the kind the Chinese internet hadn’t seen in years.

headline: NBC Sports Network Will Shut Down to Bolster Peacock Streaming Service
abstract: NBCSN was the No. 2 sports channel on cable last year, but coverage of the N.H.L., the English Premier League and NASCAR is now moving to Peacock and the USA Network.
lead_paragraph: NBCUniversal will shut down its NBC Sports Network cable channel by the end of the year, according to an internal memo obtained by The New York Times, and move some of its sports programming to USA Network and the Peacock streaming service.

headline: Jimmie Rodgers, Who Sang ‘Honeycomb’ and Other Hits, Dies at 87
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Country Music', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: His crossover appeal landed him on the charts often in the 1950s and ’60s, but a violent incident in 1967 derailed his career.
lead_paragraph: Jimmie Rodgers, whose smooth voice straddled the line between pop and country and brought him a string of hits — none bigger than his first record, “Honeycomb,” in 1957 — died on Jan. 18 in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Bob Avian, Choreographer of Broadway Smashes, Dies at 83
abstract: His collaborations with Michael Bennett included “A Chorus Line.” He later worked on “Miss Saigon” and other hits.
lead_paragraph: Bob Avian, a choreographer, director and producer who was deeply involved in some of the biggest Broadway shows of the last 60 years, including — with his frequent collaborator, Michael Bennett — “A Chorus Line,” one of the longest-running musicals in history, died on Thursday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 83.

headline: Biden Joins Public Outcry After Guard Soldiers Seen Resting in a Parking Garage
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Inaugurations', 'Parking Garages and Lots', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)']
abstract: Photographs of Guard soldiers resting on the concrete floor of a parking garage prompted swift condemnation and apologies from members of Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Friday telephoned the chief of the National Guard Bureau to express dismay after troops deployed to protect his inauguration were ordered a day earlier to rest in an unheated garage after being booted from the Capitol, administration officials said.

headline: 5 Ways Teens Can Get More Fruits and Vegetables Into Their Diets
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Fruit', 'Vegetables', 'Parenting', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: A new study found that high school students aren’t getting enough produce.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been watching your teenager devour processed foods like potato chips, chicken nuggets or sugary cereals and drinks, you are not alone. Comfort food has been especially alluring during the pandemic, for parents and kids alike.

headline: New Virus Variant May Be Somewhat Deadlier, U.K. Warns
abstract: The evidence on the fatality rate is worrisome but not yet solid, scientists said. It contrasts with news that Britain is vaccinating its people at a promising pace.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson had been expected to trumpet a rare success in the campaign against the coronavirus on Friday: news that Britain had vaccinated 5.4 million people. By the end of the day, it was overtaken by a tentative finding that a new variant of the virus may be deadlier than the original.

headline: Impeachment, Wuhan, Hank Aaron: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Alice Hoagland, Grieving Inspiration in Gay Rugby, Dies at 71
abstract: She became a beloved figure in a movement that her son had helped spearhead before dying heroically aboard Flight 93 on 9/11.
lead_paragraph: Alice Hoagland, an inspirational figure for a gay rugby movement that her son, Mark Bingham, helped set in motion shortly before he perished in the 2001 terrorist attacks as one of the heroes of Flight 93, died on Dec 22 at her home in Los Gatos, Calif. She was 71.

headline: Pfizer Will Ship Fewer Vaccine Vials to Account for ‘Extra’ Doses
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hypodermic Needles and Syringes', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: After the surprise discovery of an extra dose in every vial, Pfizer executives successfully lobbied the F.D.A. to change the vaccine’s formal authorization language. The company charges by the dose.
lead_paragraph: In December, pharmacists made the happy discovery that they could squeeze an extra vaccine dose out of Pfizer vials that were supposed to contain only five.

headline: ‘A Great Friend, a Great American and a Great Player’
abstract: Teammates, Hall of Famers and former presidents mourned the loss of Hank Aaron, a player so terrific he could be taken for granted.
lead_paragraph: The baseball world and the nation at large reacted with sorrow and tributes on Friday after the death of Hank Aaron, one of the greatest to ever swing a bat. Former players, executives, commissioners and U.S. presidents honored a man who faced down withering racism with courage and strength to become the all-time home run leader and so much more.

headline: Warehouse Tenant Pleads Guilty in Ghost Ship Fire That Killed 36
keywords: ['Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Some relatives  of those killed in the Oakland warehouse fire in 2016 said they were outraged that prosecutors had a deal with the defendant that they said would allow him to avoid additional time behind bars.
lead_paragraph: The master tenant of a warehouse that had been converted into a ramshackle artists’ collective in Oakland, Calif., pleaded guilty to 36 counts of involuntary manslaughter on Friday, four years after a fire tore through the building, killing 36 people, court records show.

headline: C.D.C. Eases Coronavirus Vaccine Rules for ‘Exceptional Circumstances’
keywords: ['Clinical Trials', 'Shortages', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The agency now says patients may switch authorized vaccines between the first and second doses, and also extend the interval between doses to six weeks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has quietly changed its recommendations for coronavirus immunizations to give doctors the flexibility to handle “exceptional circumstances,” a spokeswoman said, even though the changes have not been studied in large clinical trials.

headline: Sharon Begley, a Top Science Journalist, Is Dead at 64
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Writing and Writers', 'Science and Technology', 'Magazines', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Long at Newsweek, she was regarded as one of her generation’s pre-eminent science writers. An “Enlightenment-era figure,” Jon Meacham said.
lead_paragraph: Back in the glory days of newsmagazines, the editors at Newsweek used to sit around and fantasize about their dream “doomsday” team — the clutch of journalists they would want on hand if they had to cover the end of the world. One name was always at or near the top: Sharon Begley.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Large swaths of the United States still refuse to follow simple advice from experts.
lead_paragraph: The next phase of the pandemic in the United States will most likely be determined by two factors: the new virus variants and the vaccine rollout.

headline: How the U.S. Could Double Vaccination Pace With Existing Supply
abstract: Federal data shows that the country is administering about one million doses a day and that it has enough vaccine to increase that number significantly.
lead_paragraph: Federal data shows that the country is administering about one million doses a day and that it has enough vaccine to increase that number significantly.

headline: Photographs From the Quiet Inauguration
abstract: After January 6, the capital welcomed a solemn and safe transfer of power.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was eerie, after Jan. 6, when the hush first fell. Troops plodded through posh neighborhoods, and military vehicles blocked some streets. Storefronts remained as shuttered as ever, and then the National Mall became off limits, too. Imperious black fencing already surrounded the White House, and now concertina wire encircled the Capitol. But when the inauguration finally arrived, the silence wasn’t so foreboding. Actually, it was kind of nice.

headline: There Are Hall of Famers, and Then There’s Hank Aaron
abstract: The Braves slugger occupied the rarefied space of a player who stands out in every crowd — even one full of Hall of Famers.
lead_paragraph: It was another day of mourning for Reggie Jackson and the rest of the greatest baseball players who ever lived. Another of their brethren had died, this one, perhaps, the greatest of all: Henry Louis Aaron.

headline: Listen to ‘Nice White Parents’
abstract: A five-part series about building a better school system, and what gets in the way. Brought to you by Serial Productions, a New York Times company.
lead_paragraph: From Serial and The New York Times, “Nice White Parents” is a podcast tracing the 60-year relationship between white parents and the public school down the block. Reporter Chana Joffe-Walt looks at inequality in education, focusing not on whom schools are failing, but whom they serve. Her five-part series examines what is arguably the most powerful force in our schools: white parents.

headline: The New Yorker returns an award for its story on a Japanese rent-a-family business.
abstract: “A Theory of Relativity,” a 2018 article by the staff writer Elif Batuman, was honored in the feature writing category.
lead_paragraph: The New Yorker has returned a National Magazine Award for a 2018 article about a Japanese business that rents actors who pretend to be customers’ family members. The decision to give up the award came after an investigation by the magazine found that the story’s three main subjects had deceived the article’s author and the fact-checking department.

headline: White House Orders Assessment on Violent Extremism in U.S.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: The order for the evaluation from the intelligence community comes as judges continue to deny bail for suspects in the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Friday ordered the director of national intelligence to work with the F.B.I. and the Department of Homeland Security to conduct a comprehensive assessment of the threat from domestic violent extremism, a sign of how seriously the new administration is taking the issue in the aftermath of the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol.

headline: Fresh Starts at the Top in Both Washington and Ottawa
abstract: A day after Joseph R. Biden Jr. became president, resetting Canada’s relationship with its neighbor, Governor General Julie Payette quit as Queen Elizabeth’s representative as head of state.
lead_paragraph: This week saw two transfers of power in North America. One involved direct, actual power while the other was more symbolic.

headline: McGregor’s Legal Troubles Hang Over U.F.C. and His Career
abstract: McGregor has called a new lawsuit accusing him of rape “old news.” But the case and its wide-ranging implications remain far from resolved.
lead_paragraph: Conor McGregor first met Dustin Poirier in the Ultimate Fighting Championship octagon in 2014. Like so many other McGregor opponents, Poirier, then considered the superior fighter, was vanquished quickly, with a left hook to the head and a series of punches on the ground that prompted the referee to stop the fight in less than two minutes.

headline: A New Era of Far-Right Violence
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Whites', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Neo Nazi Groups', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The imagery of the Capitol siege will have enduring resonance.
lead_paragraph: The storming of the Capitol on Jan. 6 by a rabid mob of Donald Trump supporters resulted in a failed insurrection. But for far-right extremists, including anti-government militias, white supremacists and violent conspiracy theorists, nothing about the insurrection was a failure.

headline: Trump and Justice Dept. Lawyer Said to Have Plotted to Oust Acting Attorney General
keywords: ['Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Trying to find another avenue to push his baseless election claims, Donald Trump considered installing a loyalist.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s top leaders listened in stunned silence this month: One of their peers, they were told, had devised a plan with President Donald J. Trump to oust Jeffrey A. Rosen as acting attorney general and wield the department’s power to force Georgia state lawmakers to overturn its presidential election results.

headline: Trump’s Pardon Process Was a Mix of Mercy and Favoritism
abstract: The former president doled out pardons to political allies and friends, but he also helped people serving harsh sentences.
lead_paragraph: Darrell Frazier believed he had found a path out of his life sentence in federal prison, with a president whose allies had advocated a broad use of pardons and a new clemency initiative. Mr. Frazier thought he seemed like a perfect candidate.

headline: Senate Leaders Agree on Impeachment Trial Delay, Giving Biden Breathing Room
keywords: ['Impeachment', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The plan would put off the historic proceeding until Feb. 9, giving former President Donald J. Trump time to prepare his defense and allowing President Biden to fill his cabinet and begin work on his agenda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders struck a deal on Friday to delay former President Donald J. Trump’s impeachment trial for two weeks, giving President Biden time to install his cabinet and begin moving a legislative agenda before they begin a historic proceeding to try his predecessor.

headline: Trump’s Last-Minute Pardon Frees Man Still Facing Accusations of Violence
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Smuggling', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Jonathan Braun’s 10-year sentence for running a drug ring was commuted by the departing president. The White House did not mention that he faces separate accusations of violence and threats.
lead_paragraph: President Donald J. Trump’s late-night commutation of a 10-year prison sentence being served by a drug smuggler named Jonathan Braun made the action sound almost routine. The White House said only that upon his release, Mr. Braun would “seek employment to support his wife and children.”

headline: Long Lines as Beijing Starts Mass Coronavirus Testing
abstract: The authorities in Beijing set up temporary testing sites after a spike in coronavirus infections. Long lines formed as the city tested nearly two million people on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Beijing set up temporary testing sites after a spike in coronavirus infections. Long lines formed as the city tested nearly two million people on Friday.

headline: The Lure of Executive Orders: Easy to Implement, but Just as Easy to Cancel
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: President Donald Trump came to rely on executive action for many of his achievements. But his successor seems to understand that it is best used to repeal someone else’s legacy, not build his own.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Donald J. Trump boarded the plane to Florida on Wednesday, he cast his achievements as sweeping, ambitious and, above all, enduring — a few hours before his successor began demolishing that legacy at breakneck speed.

headline: Giuliani concedes that an associate did ask for $20,000 a day to help Trump post-election.
abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani, former President Donald J. Trump’s personal lawyer, conceded on Friday night that an associate had sent an email to campaign officials asking that Mr. Giuliani be paid $20,000 a day for his work after the Nov. 3 election, but he insisted he was unaware of it at the time.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, former President Donald J. Trump’s personal lawyer, conceded on Friday night that an associate had sent an email to campaign officials asking that Mr. Giuliani be paid $20,000 a day for his work after the Nov. 3 election, but he insisted he was unaware of it at the time.

headline: Senate Impeachment Trial to Begin Week of Feb. 8
keywords: ['Impeachment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)']
abstract: Chuck Schumer, the Senate majority leader, laid out the schedule for impeachment proceedings against former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Chuck Schumer, the Senate majority leader, laid out the schedule for impeachment proceedings against former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Beny Steinmetz, a Mining Magnate, Found Guilty in Swiss Corruption Trial
abstract: Mr. Steinmetz, a French-Israeli businessman, was convicted on charges of corrupting foreign public officials in a bid to reap iron ore resources in Guinea. He was sentenced to five years in prison.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — A Swiss court on Friday convicted the French-Israeli mining magnate Beny Steinmetz on charges of corrupting foreign public officials and forging documents, in a trial over his successful bid to reap lavish iron ore resources in the West African nation of Guinea.

headline: Two Trump appointees are being investigated for posting reports denying climate change.
abstract: The Commerce Department’s Office of Inspector General said it will investigate an incident earlier this month in which two former Trump appointees posted debunked scientific reports denying the existence and significance of man-made climate change, purportedly on behalf of the United States government.
lead_paragraph: The Commerce Department’s Office of Inspector General said it will investigate an incident earlier this month in which two former Trump appointees posted debunked scientific reports denying the existence and significance of man-made climate change, purportedly on behalf of the United States government.

headline: Pester Playfully
abstract: Doug Peterson and Brad Wilber are back with a bite.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Doug Peterson and Brad Wilber have collaborated before (recently, in fact, back in October). Their puzzles are very congenial and inventive, and I think their emphasis is on entertaining us rather than making us pull our hair out in frustration. Of the eight debuts in this grid, you get three fantastic pop culture references and two desserts! Crowd pleasers, that’s what I’m talking about.

headline: Hong Kong and Madrid tighten lockdowns amid concerns over the new variant.
abstract: New infections in recent months and a contagious new variant threatening to accelerate the pandemic have prompted some governments to revert to their harshest social-distancing measures.
lead_paragraph: New infections in recent months and a contagious new variant threatening to accelerate the pandemic have prompted some governments to revert to their harshest social-distancing measures.

headline: Quotation of the Day: U.K. Variant May Be Deadlier, Johnson Warns
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 23, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “2021 is going to be a cat-and-mouse game to see if we can vaccinate people quickly enough to stay ahead of the variants.”

headline: What to Watch as McGregor and Poirier Fight at U.F.C. 257
abstract: McGregor is back in the octagon for the first time in a year.
lead_paragraph: Conor McGregor is set to headline U.F.C. 257 against Dustin Poirier, and the Ultimate Fighting Championship and its business partners would prefer that McGregor, the 32-year-old Irish star, stick around this time.

headline: Biden’s Education Department moves to cut ties with an accrediting body linked to a fraud scandal.
abstract: The Biden administration’s Education Department is moving to cut ties with an organization that was thrown a life raft under the Trump administration even though it was at the center of an enormous fraud scandal related to for-profit colleges.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration’s Education Department is moving to cut ties with an organization that was thrown a life raft under the Trump administration even though it was at the center of an enormous fraud scandal related to for-profit colleges.

headline: A Hockey League Is Coming Back, for Two Weeks Only
abstract: The National Women’s Hockey League, which has been shut down since March because of the coronavirus pandemic, will begin its very brief sixth season with a new team and a deal to have its playoffs broadcast on NBC Sports.
lead_paragraph: The National Women’s Hockey League is returning to the ice on Saturday for a brief season — a teaser of sorts — a mere 14 days intended to remind fans and potential sponsors of what has been missing for the past 10 months.

headline: 10 Republicans Voted to Impeach Trump. The Backlash Has Been Swift.
abstract: The House Republicans who voted to charge President Donald J. Trump with inciting the Capitol riot are facing a fleet of primary challengers, censures and other rebukes from their party.
lead_paragraph: It’s been less than two weeks since Representatives Peter Meijer, Tom Rice and Liz Cheney broke with nearly all of their Republican colleagues in the House and voted to impeach President Donald J. Trump, but in their home states, the backlash is already growing.

headline: New Pandemic Plight: Hospitals Are Running Out of Vaccines
abstract: Health officials are frustrated that available doses are going unused while the virus is killing thousands of people each day. Many vaccine appointments have been canceled.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus tears across much of Texas, Dr. Esmaeil Porsa is grappling with one of the most formidable challenges he has faced: The Houston hospital system he operates is running out of vaccines.

headline: Philippine Drug Raid Leaves 13 Dead
abstract: Officials said 12 suspects and a police officer were killed in the shootout, the bloodiest episode in years in President Rodrigo Duterte’s war on drugs.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Security forces killed 12 people during a drug raid in the southern Philippines on Saturday, officials said. It was the bloodiest episode in years in President Rodrigo Duterte’s war on narcotics.

headline: In Aleksei Navalny Protests, Russia Faces Biggest Dissent in Years
abstract: Demonstrations in support of the jailed opposition leader swept the nation, beginning in the Far East, where people braved subzero temperatures, and reaching the capital. Arrests climbed into the thousands.
lead_paragraph: From the frozen streets of Russia’s Far East and Siberia to the grand plazas of Moscow and St. Petersburg, tens of thousands of Russians rallied in support of the jailed opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny on Saturday in the biggest nationwide showdown in years between the Russian authorities and critics of the Kremlin.

headline: Harold Bloom Is Dead. But His ‘Rage for Reading’ Is Undiminished.
abstract: Robert Gottlieb considers the celebrated Yale critic on the occasion of his last, posthumously published book, “The Bright Book of Life,” which revisits the novels that inspired his passion and awe.

headline: Celebrity Pregnancy Is Big Business
abstract: These days, content begins at conception.
lead_paragraph: The year 1948 yielded one of history’s great non-announcements: an opaque statement from Buckingham Palace that Elizabeth — still a princess at the time — would undertake “no public engagements after the end of June.” That she was pregnant with her first child, Prince Charles, went wholly unmentioned.

headline: Is President Biden Ready for the New Senate?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Mr. Biden, a man of old Washington, might be in for a rude awakening.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: He Allowed Hank Aaron’s 715th Homer and Wouldn’t Change a Thing
abstract: Forever linked to a legend, Al Downing says Aaron, the Hall of Famer who died on Friday, “couldn’t have been a nicer man.”
lead_paragraph: Of Hank Aaron’s 755 career home runs — a total surpassed only by Barry Bonds — it was the 715th that defined him. It was that home run that pushed Aaron past Babe Ruth as the sport’s career leader, and the abuse he took to get to that point became a huge part of his legacy.

headline: How Doug Ducey, Arizona’s Republican Governor, Views His Party After Trump
abstract: Mr. Ducey, who is facing censure by his state party on Saturday, says the divisions within the Republican Party are nothing new.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona drew criticism from some fellow Republicans in November for what in other years would merely be routine: certifying the state’s election. But it was only the second time a Democratic presidential candidate had won the state in 50 years, and many Republicans supported former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to subvert the results.

headline: How to Tell If Your Parents Are in Love
abstract: For one thing, you might notice how all their bickering melts away during a single moment, like during a slow dance or a sunset. Still, after 57 years.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, I could never tell if my parents were wildly in love or careening toward divorce. I awoke some mornings to the noise of their voices climbing, straining to make out their words from two rooms away. Other times I’d catch them planted in the middle of the couch watching “Moonstruck,” their hair back then ink-dark like Cher’s.

headline: Help With Vaccination Push Comes From Unexpected Businesses
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Public-Private Sector Cooperation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Microsoft, Starbucks and Amazon are among the companies offering the government assistance with logistics and operations.
lead_paragraph: Amazon wrote to President Biden on Thursday offering to assist with communication and technology. Microsoft is opening up its largely empty office campus as a vaccination center as part of a broader partnership with the State of Washington. Starbucks is assigning workers from its operations and analytics departments to help design vaccination sites, donating the labor to the same state while continuing to pay employees.

headline: Do Curfews Slow the Coronavirus?
abstract: A restriction more often used in natural disasters, or to quell unrest, has never been tested against a pathogen like the virus.
lead_paragraph: With coronavirus infections rising and a contagious new variant threatening to accelerate the pandemic, France has implemented a stringent 6 p.m.-to-6 a.m. curfew. Citizens nationwide are sequestered indoors, and businesses must close down.

headline: The Maker of the Aeron Chair Grapples with Politics and the Pandemic
keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Furniture', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: As the C.E.O. of Herman Miller, Andi Owen has had to navigate a polarized work force while thinking about the future of the offices her company makes furniture for.
lead_paragraph: When Andi Owen took over the furniture company Herman Miller, in 2018, she didn’t expect to get caught up in politics. But these days, it seems no chief executive is safe from the culture wars.

headline: How Alvin the Beagle Helped Usher In a Democratic Senate
keywords: ['Dogs', 'Political Advertising', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Senator Raphael Warnock was sworn in this week as Georgia’s first Black senator, and he arrived with a canny canine assist.
lead_paragraph: The dog had a lot of work to do.

headline: In Crises, Vaccines Can Be Stretched, but Not Easily
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Epidemics', 'Shortages', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: Shortages of shots for yellow fever, polio and other diseases have led to innovative solutions even in very poor countries.
lead_paragraph: In desperate times, there are many ways to stretch vaccines and speed up inoculation campaigns, according to experts who have done it.

headline: If Poor Countries Go Unvaccinated, a Study Says, Rich Ones Will Pay
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Poverty', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A failure to distribute the Covid-19 vaccine in poor nations will worsen economic damage, with half the costs borne by wealthy countries, new research shows.
lead_paragraph: In monopolizing the supply of vaccines against Covid-19, wealthy nations are threatening more than a humanitarian catastrophe: The resulting economic devastation will hit affluent countries nearly as hard as those in the developing world.

headline: 2 Years After Legalizing Cannabis, Has Canada Kept Its Promises?
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: Legal pot has made Canadian justice a little fairer, with “heavily racialized” arrests for possession mostly ending. But vows on amnesty, illicit sales and Indigenous inclusion are works in progress.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — When Robert was 18, he was arrested by Montreal’s police for possession of a small amount of hashish, an event that would upend his young life.

headline: The Vaccinated Class
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Online Dating', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: “Getting the vaccine is the hottest thing you could be doing on a dating app right now,” said a spokesman for OKCupid.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus vaccine wasn’t supposed to be a golden ticket. A tiered and efficient rollout was meant to inoculate frontline workers and the most vulnerable before the rest of society.

headline: A Quiet Life of Loud Home Runs: Hank Aaron in Photographs
abstract: The slugging outfielder was a rock of consistency for 23 seasons. He was a superstar unlike any before him — or any since.
lead_paragraph: Hank Aaron wasn’t as loud as some other stars, on or off the field. He was a steady presence, a fixture in right field, a mainstay at the All-Star Game and a terror at the plate. His path was often difficult, and his name is sometimes overlooked when rattling off the greatest to ever play the game. But make no mistake: To his peers — or the closest thing baseball could offer in terms of peers — Aaron was nothing short of a god among men.

headline: High School Grades Could Be Worth $100,000. Time to Tell Your Child?
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Personal Finances', 'Education (K-12)', 'Grading of Students', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Parenting', 'Tuition', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Most colleges and universities now use a “merit” aid strategy to solicit teenagers. Your eighth grader probably ought to know how it works.
lead_paragraph: Financial aid is no longer just about what you earn and what you have. It’s also about your children and what they do — and that means that good grades can be worth a whole lot of money.

headline: Six Stars, Six Eclipses: ‘The Fact That It Exists Blows My Mind’
keywords: ['Stars and Galaxies', 'Eclipses', 'Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (Spacecraft)', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Research']
abstract: A handful of other six-star systems have been discovered, but this one is unique.
lead_paragraph: From star-destroying black holes to exploding comets, NASA’s Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite, or TESS, has spotted its share of surprises since it began searching the galaxy for exoplanets in 2018. But the source of starlight that was mysteriously brightening and dimming some 1,900 light-years away may top all those discoveries for its science fiction-like grandeur.

headline: A Decade On, Silence Fills Egypt’s Field of Broken Dreams
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Museums', 'Egyptian Civilization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: In 2011, Tahrir Square was at the vanguard of popular uprisings known as the Arab Spring. But hopes for a democratic Egypt were crushed and the historic square given a sterile new look.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The last guest had checked out, leaving Ahmed Taha sitting on an unmade bed in a deserted room amid rumpled sheets and half-drunk coffee cups, contemplating his future.

headline: Explore the World With These 100 Country Quizzes
abstract: Expand your knowledge of geography and culture with our short “Country of the Week” quizzes, all based on reporting, photos and videos from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: How much do you know about Cape Verde? What about Colombia, Bangladesh or Montenegro?

headline: Black, Deaf and Extremely Online
keywords: ['Deafness', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Sign Language', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Social Media']
abstract: On TikTok and in virtual hangouts, a younger generation is sharing the origins and nuances of Black American Sign Language, a rich variation of ASL that scholars say has been overlooked for too long.
lead_paragraph: “I have to make sure my hands are not ashy before I sign,” Nakia Smith, who is deaf, explained to her nearly 400,000 followers.

headline: The Business Case for Boardroom Diversity
abstract: When big banks see a benefit in helping companies recruit more diverse directors, it’s a sign that there are not just morals at play — there is money at stake, too.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of a big issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: Larry King, Breezy Interviewer of the Famous and Infamous, Dies at 87
abstract: Over five decades, he chatted with an estimated 50,000 people from all walks of life, from presidents and pundits to swindlers and U.F.O. “experts.”
lead_paragraph: Larry King, who shot the breeze with presidents and psychics, movie stars and malefactors — anyone with a story to tell or a pitch to make — in a half-century on radio and television, including 25 years as the host of CNN’s globally popular “Larry King Live,” died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 87.

headline: Barred From U.S. Under Trump, Muslims Exult in Biden’s Open Door
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Discrimination', 'Travel Warnings', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Few foreigners welcomed President Biden’s election victory as enthusiastically as the tens of thousands of Muslims who have been locked out of the United States for the past four years.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — As the results of the American presidential election rolled in on Nov. 4, a young Sudanese couple sat up through the night in their small town south of Khartoum, eyes glued to the television as state tallies were declared, watching anxiously. They had a lot riding on the outcome.

headline: How to Make Your Home Fun for Your Confined Kids
abstract: To make it through these next few months, you may need to make your apartment feel new again.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a two-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn. My partner and I are running out of ways to keep our two young children occupied indoors this winter without driving us or the neighbors nuts. Normally we’d take them to indoor play spaces, visit with friends or family or enroll them in gymnastics or dance classes. But we can’t safely do any of that. Any thoughts on how we can make a small space work for rambunctious children?

headline: Everyone Loves This Chickpea Pasta
abstract: Try Yotam Ottolenghi’s fried tagliatelle with chickpeas and smoky tomatoes.
lead_paragraph: This weekend make Yotam Ottolenghi’s pasta with chickpeas and smoky tomatoes (above), which calls for frying tagliatelle nests before cooking them to add texture. Or try our other top recipes of the week, including Julia Moskin’s chicken Francese and Lidey Heuck’s red curry lentils with sweet potatoes and spinach. Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: How to Take a Walk
abstract: I have a heart monitor. I have a pulse oximeter. I have an oxygen tank. It’s going to be a relaxing stroll.
lead_paragraph: I’m going for a walk. It’s a brisk morning. The sun is shining; it’s a beautiful winter day. I have my N95 mask. I have my bottle of hand sanitizer. I’m wearing a polyurethane laminate jacket over a fluid-resistant surgical gown over a Kevlar vest, all of which is covered by a high-visibility orange safety parka. It will be a refreshing stroll.

headline: Is There a Small Business That’s Special to You?
abstract: Behind every one of them is a person who is part of a community.
lead_paragraph: This has been a challenging time for small businesses. The pandemic has forced a lot of owners to close down their physical storefronts, and it’s unclear how many businesses will survive the coming months.

headline: America Has a GPS Problem
keywords: ['Global Positioning System', 'Navigation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The system is essential but also vulnerable. We need a backup.
lead_paragraph: Time was when nobody knew, or even cared, exactly what time it was. The movement of the sun, phases of the moon and changing seasons were sufficient indicators. But since the Industrial Revolution, we’ve become increasingly dependent on knowing the time, and with increasing accuracy. Not only does the time tell us when to sleep, wake, eat, work and play; it tells automated systems when to execute financial transactions, bounce data between cellular towers and throttle power on the electrical grid.

headline: The Trump Presidency Is Now History. So How Will It Rank?
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment']
abstract: As scholars consider the legacy of Donald J. Trump, it appears that even the woefully inadequate James Buchanan has some serious competition.
lead_paragraph: In the race to the bottom for the title of worst American president, the same few sorry names appear at the end of almost every list, jockeying for last place. There’s Andrew Johnson, whose abysmal behavior during Reconstruction led to the first presidential impeachment. There’s Warren G. Harding, responsible for the Teapot Dome scandal. There’s hapless, hated Franklin Pierce; doomed, dead-after-32-days William Henry Harrison; and inevitably, James Buchanan, often considered worst of all because of how badly he bungled the lead-up to the Civil War.

headline: Olympic Athlete Speaks of Assault and Breaks a Bigger Silence in Greece

headline: ‘We Are Forced to Live in These Conditions’: In Los Angeles, Virus Ravages Overcrowded Homes

headline: Will Indian Buffets Survive the Pandemic?
abstract: Eating at buffets, which now seems unthinkable because of the coronavirus, was more formative for me than any bourgeois sit-down restaurant could offer.
lead_paragraph: I drove past a mini mall the other day in my hometown, Commack, N.Y., where my favorite Indian buffet, Kiraan Palace, once stood. My brother, Ravi, and I used to spend almost every Saturday afternoon as teenagers at the corner table, closest to the buffet line, while our regular waiter refilled baskets of garlic naan at our table every 20 minutes. While most of our friends were eating at the pizza place up the block or scarfing down hot dogs at Nathan’s across the street, we held court at our unusual hangout because it felt most like home. And when it closed a few years later, we made sure to find a new refuge.

headline: Joe Biden’s Catholic Moment
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Protestant Churches', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The new president elevates a liberal Catholicism that once seemed destined to fade away.
lead_paragraph: The inauguration of our second Catholic president was, in its way, a very American-Catholic spectacle. A Jesuit delivered the invocation, the president quoted St. Augustine and paused for a moment of silent prayer just long enough for a quick Hail Mary, and the justices and celebrities represented various ethnic-Catholic inheritances — Irish for John Roberts, Italian for Lady Gaga and Nancy Pelosi, Latina for Jennifer Lopez and Sonia Sotomayor. (It was left to Garth Brooks, singing “Amazing Grace,” to represent Protestant culture.) As America Magazine’s James Keane noted, even Biden’s proposed cabinet is stuffed with Catholic Democrats, with few white male Protestants in sight.

Her husband, Andrés Jiménez, whom she described as a hard worker, had been deported in 2013 after he was caught driving without a license, and she was raising her five children by herself. Her voice broke with emotion when she asked, “What can you do to stop deportations and reunify families?”

headline: Sugar, Sugar
abstract: Get hyped for Ross Trudeau’s return and Lucy Howard’s twisty, tasty debut.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I love the descriptive term “confection” for a puzzle like this one, even though in this case it’s a spoiler. So's the title, and so’s the way that our two constructors sweetly met and started their puzzle-making venture together. Lucy Howard, who’s new to us, constructed her first puzzle last year as an “icebreaker” for her wedding; she met Ross Trudeau (whom we already knew) online, and they made this joint via Zoom. Oh, and they both rock climb, another thing crazy people do. Be careful up there and don’t combine the two sports.
