headline: Debajo, From a Former Ferris Chef, Opens in the Made Hotel
abstract: A pizzeria from Pino Luongo, Vietnamese on the Upper West Side, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Ferris, the restaurant in the Made Hotel that got two stars from Pete Wells three years ago as a “modest restaurant that overdelivers,” closed in March as a result of the pandemic. By that time, the chef Greg Proechel, formerly of Le Turtle, who garnered positive attention, was gone for almost a year. Last fall Mr. Proechel came back and turned it into a pop-up called Day Off, with Sam Gelin, who runs the Made Hotel. That pop-up has been replaced by this new spot for tapas, with outdoor seating in its covered, heated sunken garden. Mr. Proechel called on Victor Manuel Amarilla, also in the kitchen at the Turtle, to join him as the chef. Standard-bearing tapas include plates of cheeses and cured meats, boquerones and patatas bravas; larger raciones plates include a hamburger, a  crispy chicken sandwich with romesco sauce, and a short rib and lentil stew.

headline: Trump Began With His ‘Great’ Wall. He Ended With It, Too.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Border Barriers', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: His legacy will be the divisions he has sown between Americans.
lead_paragraph: “It all started with the border, and that’s still where it is today.” These are the first lines of the Drive-By Truckers’ song “Ramón Casiano,” released just before the election of Donald Trump in 2016. I’ve been humming the song for much of the last four years, because Mr. Trump’s journey to the White House began with promises of a “great wall” along the border, and that’s also where it ended.

headline: Treat Yourself to a Parisian Cocktail Snack That Is Easy to Make
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Cakes', 'Recipes', 'French Food (Cuisine)']
abstract: In France, savory cakes salés are served as a light nibble before dinner. They’re remarkably versatile and come together in a snap.
lead_paragraph: By the time we moved to Paris in the late ’90s, I felt comfortable there. I’d visited dozens of times, published stories about the city’s food and restaurants and even co-written a book with a Parisian pastry chef. I knew some French people in town and some American expats too. I could crisscross the city by Métro with ease, even if I was (and sometimes still am) flummoxed by the bus routes — in a serious breach of logic, the streets that you catch the bus on don’t always match the names of the stops. I knew that a droguerie was where I could get straw market baskets (although I originally thought it was where I’d find aspirin); that a quincaillerie (a word I eventually learned to pronounce) was the place for screwdrivers and a staggering assortment of spot removers; and that Monoprix was where I could buy everything from saucepans and fresh fruit to that bright yellow raincoat that I still wear. As I settled in, French friends helped me open a bank account, taught me the etiquette of cheese (the most important rule: never cut the nose off the Brie) and shared the names of their favorite butchers, fishmongers and wine shops. But no one ever told me what they bought at Picard.

headline: How Gov. Kristi Noem Rebranded Her Failures as ‘Freedom’
abstract: South Dakota’s public health isn’t a matter of “personal responsibility.” It’s her job.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the pandemic, Gov. Kristi Noem has advised South Dakotans to exercise “personal responsibility” and said she “trusted” her citizens to make the right decision when it came to coronavirus precautions. At the same time, she imposed almost no restrictions on the state and remains indifferent to low-stakes safety measures like mask wearing. As a result, South Dakota’s Covid-19 death rate is one of the worst in the nation — but Governor Noem’s approval ratings remain high. In this video, we unpack her deadly playbook for how to handle a pandemic all wrong while preserving a reputation for being credible and competent.

headline: No More Lies. My Grandfather Was a Nazi.
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Jews and Judaism', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: In Lithuania, he was celebrated as a hero. But we can’t move on until we admit what he really did.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up in Chicago during the Cold War, my parents taught me to revere my Lithuanian heritage. We sang Lithuanian songs and recited Lithuanian poems; after Lithuanian school on Saturdays, I would eat Lithuanian-style potato pancakes.

headline: New Yorkers Can’t Find Parking. For Bikes.
abstract: The uptick in cycling during the pandemic has shined a light on the problem.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Why Are Farmers Protesting in India?
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Politics and Government', 'Income Inequality', 'Sikhs and Sikhism']
abstract: Thousands of protesters, many driving tractors, took to the streets of New Delhi on Tuesday. Who are they, and what do they want?
lead_paragraph: At least one protester was killed and 300 police officers were injured after tens of thousands of farmers, many driving tractors, took to the streets of New Delhi on Tuesday to call for the repeal of contentious new agriculture laws.

headline: The Girl Who Walked Away
abstract: As an adolescent, Leslie Doyle felt embarrassed by her father. As an adult, she learned to be grateful for what he taught her.
lead_paragraph: The word “revolutionary” contains all five vowels plus the sometimes-vowel Y.

headline: Why Are U.S. Coronavirus Cases Falling? And Will the Trend Last?
abstract: With vaccinations underway, and as multiple new coronavirus variants begin to spread, we check in on the state of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The number of new coronavirus cases in the United States is falling, but does that mean the country has turned a corner in the pandemic?

headline: The Wisconsin Senate voted to end a statewide mask mandate.
abstract: The Wisconsin State Senate has voted to end a statewide mask mandate issued by the governor, a resolution that would put Wisconsin among a minority of states without such a requirement if assembly lawmakers approve it.
lead_paragraph: The Wisconsin State Senate has voted to end a statewide mask mandate issued by the governor, a resolution that would put Wisconsin among a minority of states without such a requirement if assembly lawmakers approve it.

headline: College Costs Are Less Terrifying Than You Think
abstract: You probably won’t pay the sticker price, and you can start saving now.
lead_paragraph: Most of us become parents with the hope that our kids will do better and achieve more than we have — or at least be happier. The right kind of higher education can help. But then, at some point, we contemplate saving and paying for it.

headline: The Filibuster Fight
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: If you examine the history of the filibuster — a Senate rule requiring a supermajority vote on many bills, rather than a straight majority — you will quickly notice something: It has benefited the political right much more than the left.

headline: Moscow mayor lifts restrictions, declaring the pandemic is ‘on the decline.’
abstract: The mayor of Moscow, Sergei S. Sobyanin, declared on Wednesday that the coronavirus pandemic was easing in the Russian capital, and abruptly lifted most of the remaining restrictions in place in the city, saying the focus must shift to strengthening the economy.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Moscow, Sergei S. Sobyanin, declared on Wednesday that the coronavirus pandemic was easing in the Russian capital, and abruptly lifted most of the remaining restrictions in place in the city, saying the focus must shift to strengthening the economy.

headline: ‘Penguin Bloom’ Review: Relearning to Fly
abstract: In this sentimental Netflix film, Naomi Watts plays a woman who, after a life-changing accident, finds inspiration in a magpie.
lead_paragraph: Anyone paying a smidge of attention to the early scenes of “Penguin Bloom” should be able to write the ending — and most of what precedes it — long before it arrives. Yet predictability isn’t the only problem with this based-on-true-life drama, one that underscores every sentiment and tugs every heartstring with wincing insistence.

headline: Could Trump Be Convicted? ‘Just Do the Math’
abstract: G.O.P. senators appear unwilling to punish the party’s leader: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: The Capitol Police’s acting chief expresses remorse for the Capitol riot, but Senate Republicans aren’t eager to relitigate Trump’s role in it. It’s Wednesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: A Populist Leader Kicks Off a Culture War, Starting in Museums
abstract: Slovenia’s government has replaced the directors of major institutions. But it says “run-of-the-mill artists really have nothing to complain about.”
lead_paragraph: Last March, Janez Jansa, a nationalist politician who has been compared to President Donald Trump, became Slovenia’s leader for a third time. He was previously prime minister from 2004 to 2008, and, briefly, from 2012, until a corruption scandal brought his government down.

headline: The hotel industry is renting its empty kitchens to restaurateurs hunting for cut-rate space.
abstract: Restaurateurs hunting for cut-rate space in the pandemic are teaming up with eager partners in another beleaguered industry.
lead_paragraph: The hotel industry, where occupancy rates are still down 30 percent from a year ago, is getting in on the ghost kitchen trend.

headline: Watch live as Jerome Powell speaks after the Fed leaves rates unchanged.
abstract: Wall Street’s focus is on the news conference of the Fed chair, Jerome H. Powell, and what he might say about the central bank’s intentions as Covid-19 vaccines become more widely available, the Biden administration pushes for another round of stimulus spending and the economy continues to recover.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s focus is on the news conference of the Fed chair, Jerome H. Powell, and what he might say about the central bank’s intentions as Covid-19 vaccines become more widely available, the Biden administration pushes for another round of stimulus spending and the economy continues to recover.

headline: What More Do Voters Want? A History of Hall of Fame Snubs
abstract: For the ninth time since 1936, baseball writers failed to elect any Hall of Famers. The jilted players are in good company.
lead_paragraph: There are few things more perfect than a Sunday afternoon in Cooperstown, N.Y., as members of the newest class of the Baseball Hall of Fame take turns speaking in front of their fellow Hall of Famers and an enormous crowd of fans, any of whom are free to simply walk up on the day of the event. There is usually plenty of room to spare.

headline: Can Anything Stop GameStop?
keywords: ['Financial Brokers', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Campaign Finance', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The stock has soared to scarcely believable levels, for unlikely reasons.
lead_paragraph: Why is Wall Street obsessed with GameStop, the video game chain that until recently was known for middling performance? The company’s stock has soared to scarcely believable levels — its market cap as of yesterday was $10 billion, and its shares briefly doubled in premarket trading today — thanks to an army of small traders spurred on by a Reddit message board.

headline: S.B.A. finds ‘anomalies’ in hundreds of thousands of small business relief loans
abstract: The restarted Paycheck Protection Program allows hard-hit small businesses to get a second government-backed relief loan, but thousands of business owners who are trying to apply have been ensnared by what the Biden administration said are significant errors in the program’s loan records.
lead_paragraph: The restarted Paycheck Protection Program allows hard-hit small businesses to get a second government-backed relief loan, but thousands of business owners who are trying to apply have been ensnared by what the Biden administration said are significant errors in the program’s loan records.

headline: Iran Angles for Advantage on Biden’s Priority List
abstract: With a combination of threats, provocative acts and public appeals, Iran is jostling for attention from an administration preoccupied with spillover crises from the Trump years.
lead_paragraph: Iran has threatened to block nuclear inspections next month, and further increased production of fuel that could be enriched for use in bombs. It has seized an American ally’s cargo ship. And it has incarcerated yet another American citizen on spying charges.

headline: Police Officer Who Resigned After Fatal Shootings Is Hired as Sheriff’s Deputy
abstract: Protests erupted in Wisconsin after the officer, Joseph Mensah, killed a teenager in February — his third fatal shooting in five years. He resigned but was sworn in on Monday as a deputy in a nearby county.
lead_paragraph: A former police officer in Wauwatosa, Wis., who shot and killed three people during his tenure and resigned following protests last year, became a law enforcement officer again on Monday when he was sworn in as a deputy sheriff just across the county line.

headline: San Francisco Scraps 44 School Names, Citing Reckoning With Racism
abstract: The school board said the move would shed homages to figures including Abraham Lincoln, George Washington and Dianne Feinstein. But critics — including the mayor — said the matter was ill-timed amid the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco Board of Education voted this week to rename 44 of its schools named after prominent figures, in an attempt to purge the district of homages to what it said were controversial people with ties to racism, sexism or slavery.

headline: Biden plans to reopen Obamacare exchanges in many states.
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The move will be announced on Thursday as part of an executive order describing administration policies on shoring up health insurance coverage, according to three people familiar with the details.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration plans to reopen enrollment in many of the Affordable Care Act marketplaces, both to help those who may have lost health insurance during the pandemic and to offer coverage to those who did not have any and now want it. The move will be announced on Thursday as part of an executive order describing administration policies on shoring up health insurance coverage, according to three people familiar with the details.

headline: McConnell Was Done With Trump. His Party Said Not So Fast.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three times in recent weeks, as Republicans grappled with a deadly attack on the Capitol and their new minority status in Washington, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky carefully nudged open the door for his party to kick Donald J. Trump to the curb, only to find it slammed shut.

keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Frontex, the European Union agency responsible for monitoring the bloc’s external borders, announced on Wednesday that it was suspending operations in Hungary, which has ignored a court order to bring its asylum practices in line with European Union law.

headline: Extremists Emboldened by Capitol Attack Pose Rising Threat, Homeland Security Says
keywords: ['Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Whites', 'Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Warning that the deadly rampage of the Capitol this month may not be an isolated episode, the Department of Homeland Security on Wednesday said publicly for the first time that the United States faced a growing threat from “violent domestic extremists” emboldened by the attack.

headline: Whitmer pleads with Michigan lawmakers to find common ground amid the pandemic.

headline: Health Workers, Stuck in the Snow, Administer Coronavirus Vaccine to Stranded Drivers
abstract: Public health workers in Josephine County, Ore., said they had walked from car to car, giving shots to drivers with vaccine doses that would expire in six hours.
lead_paragraph: The public health workers were driving back from a vaccination site in rural Cave Junction, Ore., on Tuesday when they got stuck in a snowstorm on the highway.

headline: ‘It’s Still Getting Worse.’ Inside Britain’s Vicious Second Wave.
abstract: One hundred thousand people dead. A new, more contagious variant. The toll is close to unbearable.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year into the pandemic, the situation in Britain is dire. A vicious first wave has given way to an even more deadly second one. On Tuesday, the country passed a milestone of 100,000 deaths from the coronavirus — which amounts to one of the worst fatality rates in the world. A national lockdown, in place since Jan. 4, has only recently begun to lower the eye-wateringly high number of cases, fueled in part by the emergence of a new, apparently more contagious variant of the virus. The toll on the National Health Service is close to unbearable: Nearly 40,000 Covid-19 patients are in hospitals, almost double the peak last year.

headline: Thailand Legalizes Abortion in 1st Trimester but Keeps Other Restrictions
abstract: Women who end a pregnancy after 12 weeks could still face prison or fines. Abortion rights advocates say more change is needed.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Thailand’s Parliament has voted to make abortion legal in the first trimester, while keeping penalties in place for women who undergo it later in their pregnancies.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Gassy Siblings
abstract: Are a sister’s burps any worse than a brother’s farts?
lead_paragraph: Annie writes: My boyfriend complains often about his sister’s loud burping. But he has a sensitive gut and produces frequent, loud farts. I do not condemn either action, as they are normal and natural. But when I confronted my boyfriend about his hypocrisy, he claimed that burps are grosser than farts, which are contained by clothing or bedsheets.

headline: The Dark Reality Behind Saudi Arabia’s Utopian Dreams
abstract: Mohammed bin Salman’s absurd plan for the Line — a 106-mile long city with no cars and no roads — comes with a grisly human price.
lead_paragraph: To the rest of the world, Saudi Arabia may look like a quasi-medieval kingdom where women still struggle for basic rights, where bearded clerics run the courts and where convicts are routinely beheaded by sword in public. But the Saudi monarchy — like its neighbors in Dubai and Abu Dhabi — has long cherished dreams of leapfrogging into a high-tech future. The last Saudi king created plans for six new cities in the desert, all billed as transformative steps toward a world beyond oil.

(Her new novel, “Concrete Rose,” is No. 1 on the young adult hardcover list and her debut, “The Hate U Give,” is No. 4.)

headline: Poem: ‘Track: “A Girl in Trouble (Is A Temporary Thing),” Romeo Void (1984)’
abstract: Every word of Reyes’s makes sense when we admit that for a woman “there’s no time for her to be afraid.”
lead_paragraph: The blue whale calibrates its migrations to find the krill that sustains it. You discover yourself in what you choose to notice. Listen to Reyes’s last line: “They say the earth’s most unruly parts sing like you.” This poem is named after Romeo Void’s “A Girl in Trouble (Is a Temporary Thing),” and every word of Reyes’s makes sense when we admit that for a woman “there’s no time for her to be afraid,” not hardly, not carrying what they carry, what they know. Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts

headline: What if the ‘Karate Kid’ Isn’t the Hero?

Now he’s back, with the actor Ralph Macchio reprising the role for the series “Cobra Kai.” The story is ostensibly a classic battle between a hero and a villain. But as Mr. Macchio notes, it’s actually more complex. Audiences, he says, “recognize the good and bad in both these guys and are rooting for both with their two separate types of shortcomings and problems and demons.”

abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.

The film is the first offering of Films.Dance, an ambitious global series that will debut a digital dance piece every Monday through May 3. The works will be available free on the project’s website and its Instagram and Facebook pages.

headline: Vaccination Day at Dodger Stadium: Hours of Traffic and 7,730 Shots
abstract: The lines at Los Angeles’s mass vaccination site are a portrait of the city. Men on motorcycles. Bangladeshi merchants. Retired record-company executives. Latina health care workers. Arnold Schwarzenegger.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was about 9 p.m. when a nurse at one of the largest vaccination sites in the country ran out of doses.

headline: Health workers were stuck in the snow in Oregon with vaccines, so they improvised.
abstract: Public health workers found themselves stuck in a snowstorm on an Oregon highway this week, with only six hours to get the coronavirus vaccines they were carrying to people waiting for their shots about 30 miles away.
lead_paragraph: Public health workers found themselves stuck in a snowstorm on an Oregon highway this week, with only six hours to get the coronavirus vaccines they were carrying to people waiting for their shots about 30 miles away.

headline: ‘Get your shot here’: At Dodger Stadium, the lines are for vaccine, not beer.
abstract: A civil rights activist once called Los Angeles an “imperfect paradise.”
lead_paragraph: A civil rights activist once called Los Angeles an “imperfect paradise.”

headline: Check this out to get your every Covid-19 vaccine question answered. Really.
abstract: The Well section set out to answer some of the most commonly asked questions about the coronavirus vaccine, and a few that are perhaps not so common. Using an experimental tool that relies on machine learning, you can even try posing a few questions of your own.
lead_paragraph: The Well section set out to answer some of the most commonly asked questions about the coronavirus vaccine, and a few that are perhaps not so common. Using an experimental tool that relies on machine learning, you can even try posing a few questions of your own.

headline: Will Indoor Dining Resume at City Restaurants?
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said the virus “holiday surge” was beginning to recede, which meant that relaxed restrictions were being considered.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Germany says vaccine shortages are likely to last another 10 weeks, and other news from around the world.
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel will convene the governors of Germany’s 16 states, along with representatives of pharmaceutical companies to discuss the country’s troubled vaccination scheme, after her health minister, Jens Spahn, warned that the country is facing another 10 weeks of vaccine shortages.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Angela Merkel will convene the governors of Germany’s 16 states, along with representatives of pharmaceutical companies to discuss the country’s troubled vaccination scheme, after her health minister, Jens Spahn, warned that the country is facing another 10 weeks of vaccine shortages.

headline: The Fate of the Filibuster
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: An exploration of the debate over the rule’s future in the U.S. Senate.
lead_paragraph: The filibuster rule is a tricky affair. As with any power worth having, it has its advantages and drawbacks.

headline: English Charm, Italian Flair and a Global Fan Base
abstract: The Jensen Interceptor, introduced in 1949, has been reborn numerous times since. Restorations are common, and there are whispers of another incarnation.
lead_paragraph: The Jensen Interceptor’s very name suggests exceptional power and drama, tugging at the heartstrings of car lovers. The machine in the flesh makes good on the imagery.

headline: A Fall in Virus Cases
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: The United States has never experienced a sharp and sustained decline in new coronavirus cases — until, perhaps, now.

headline: Eurozone banks are underestimating risks from the pandemic, E.C.B. warns.
abstract: The European Central Bank on Thursday effectively warned eurozone banks to clean up their acts, saying that many are complacent about losses they may suffer from a surge in problem loans caused by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank on Thursday effectively warned eurozone banks to clean up their acts, saying that many are complacent about losses they may suffer from a surge in problem loans caused by the pandemic.

headline: ‘Just Don’t Think I’ll Scream’ Review: Writing With Movies
abstract: Created from 400-plus movie clips, this film reflects on the filmmaker’s recovery from a breakup in a small town.
lead_paragraph: Frank Beauvais’s pastiche “Just Don’t Think I’ll Scream” paints with a palette of 400-plus films. In 2016 Beauvais recovered from a breakup in an Alsatian village by filling his days with music, beer, pot, and torrents of movies. The cineaste monologues over clips from his half-year of viewing to create something resembling a dyspeptic novelist’s journals.

headline: ‘Savage State’ Review: Escape to New York
abstract: French settlers flee the American Civil War in this heavily allegorical, yet strangely compelling drama.
lead_paragraph: “Savage State,” the sophomore feature from the French writer and director David Perrault, is a fascinating oddity: An unconventional western dominated by the desires of women.

headline: ‘Finding Ohana’ Review: Treasure Hunting and Family Healing
abstract: The adventure narrative in this Hawaii-set Netflix film distracts from a deeper story about cultural heritage and family dynamics.
lead_paragraph: The Hawaiian term ohana, which means family, may be most recognized from its popularization by the Disney animated film “Lilo and Stitch.” Like that alien-populated coming-of-age comedy, the Netflix film “Finding Ohana” uncovers adventure in the midst of familial dysfunction. But the treasure-hunting escapade at the center of this film weakens a more compelling look at the dynamics of a family and the uncertain future of its cultural legacy.

headline: ‘Supernova’ Review: On the Road, to a Heartbreaking Destination
abstract: Colin Firth and Stanley Tucci play a longtime couple facing unpleasant facts in this spectacularly moving film from Harry Macqueen.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare to see a cinematic drama executed with such consistent care as “Supernova,” written and directed by Harry Macqueen and starring Colin Firth and Stanley Tucci. And here, that care pays off to devastating effect.

headline: ‘Beginning’ Review: Faith Under Attack
abstract: Dea Kulumbegashvili’s debut feature ensnares its heroine in circles of religious and patriarchal persecution.
lead_paragraph: The boxy frame of the camera turns into a trap in “Beginning,” the masterful debut feature by the Georgian filmmaker Dea Kulumbegashvili. For the film’s opening, the camera plants itself on one end of a small Jehovah’s Witness Kingdom Hall and stays there, unmoving, as the congregants slowly filter in and the preacher begins his sermon. It doesn’t budge even when, nearly eight uninterrupted minutes into the shot, a Molotov cocktail flies into the room and explodes into flames, scattering the panicked worshipers.

headline: ‘Softie’ Review: Battling for Votes in Kenya
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: In this political documentary, the activist and photographer Boniface “Softie” Mwangi runs for office in a quixotic struggle against a corrupt system and a legacy of election violence.
lead_paragraph: As a photographer, Boniface “Softie” Mwangi made his name recording the carnage of Kenya’s postelection violence in 2007 (including work published in this paper). Embracing activism, he agitated for reform of the country’s corrupt politics with its dynasties, vote-buying and postcolonial tribalism. In Sam Soko’s sometimes bewildering documentary “Softie,” Mwangi presents as an unassumingly stirring figure: an ardent advocate for democratic processes, but a seasoned realist about nefarious forces in his home country.

headline: ‘The Night’ Review: Late Checkout
abstract: This Iranian-American thriller traps a married couple in a haunted hotel.
lead_paragraph: “The Night” begins with a round of the party game, Mafia. The film’s central couple Babak (Shahab Hosseini) and Neda (Niousha Jafarian) play along, each wryly accusing the other of hiding secrets, each saying that the other might be the killer. The Persian-language, Los Angeles-set thriller that follows builds tension around the resentments that have accumulated in their marriage. But the stakes never rise past the movie’s first game.

headline: ‘True Mothers’ Review: Family Entanglements
abstract: Parents clash in this Japanese melodrama from Naomi Kawase.
lead_paragraph: Remarkably resistant to sentimentality in individual scenes yet baldly manipulative in the big picture, the melodrama “True Mothers” is probably the most mainstream effort yet from Naomi Kawase, a Japanese director who hasn’t received much distribution in the United States but has been a mainstay of the Cannes Film Festival for two decades. Although the pandemic canceled the festival in May, in June the Cannes programmers announced “True Mothers” as an official selection of the event-that-wasn’t (and later screened it at a mini-festival in October). The movie has the sort of densely plotted texture and widely accessible emotions that might have earned it the Palme d’Or — not necessarily for the best reasons.

headline: ‘The Little Things’ Review: Good Old-Fashioned Police Work
abstract: Denzel Washington and Rami Malek play detectives on the trail of a serial killer in John Lee Hancock’s vintage thriller.
lead_paragraph: A note during the first scene in “The Little Things” — an effective cold opening, full of danger and suspense — indicates that it’s 1990. At first, I thought this meant that the action would quickly vault forward into the present day, but instead the movie, which takes place mainly in Los Angeles, settles into a fairly generic version of the semi-recent past, occasionally flashing back to a few years earlier.

headline: ‘The Reunited States’ Review: Hopeful Moments in a Political War
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Directed by Ben Rekhi, this documentary profiles people who have made a mission of listening to the other side.
lead_paragraph: The quelling of political warfare in the United States has to start somewhere. Topical in broad strokes yet frustratingly allergic to particulars, the well-meaning documentary “The Reunited States,” directed by Ben Rekhi and inspired by Mark Gerzon’s early-2016 book, “The Reunited States of America,” profiles people who have made a mission of listening to the other side.

headline: ‘The Dig’ Review: Carey Mulligan and Ralph Fiennes on a Treasure Hunt
abstract: A small team makes a groundbreaking discovery in this fictionalized account of an actual archaeological expedition close to home.
lead_paragraph: Carey Mulligan’s range is a thing of wonder. If you’ve already seen her as an avenging American in “Promising Young Woman,” watching her in “The Dig” may induce something like whiplash. Here she portrays, with unimpeachable credibility, Edith, an upper-class English widow and mother in the late 1930s who is fulfilling a dream too long deferred.

headline: Biden Walks the Climate-Economy Tightrope
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A climate rollout meant to avoid G.O.P. attacks: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Biden makes a big pledge on climate action, and the Capitol Police union reveals more about the Jan. 6 casualties. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Tanzania’s president says ‘vaccines don’t work,’ earning a rebuff from the W.H.O.
abstract: Tanzania’s president cast doubt on coronavirus vaccines and other measures to curb the spread of the pandemic, doubling down on his line of reasoning that only God could protect the East African nation. His comments came a day before the World Health Organization urged the nation to take measures to protect its population.
lead_paragraph: Tanzania’s president cast doubt on coronavirus vaccines and other measures to curb the spread of the pandemic, doubling down on his line of reasoning that only God could protect the East African nation. His comments came a day before the World Health Organization urged the nation to take measures to protect its population.

headline: How Does This End?
keywords: ['Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Boards of Directors']
abstract: Let’s have an honest conversation about GameStop.
lead_paragraph: Andrew here. Let’s have an honest conversation about the mania around GameStop — and its larger implications.

headline: 10 Classical Concerts to Stream in February
abstract: A Tyshawn Sorey premiere and lots of Kurt Weill from Berlin are among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: As the live performing arts continue to struggle through the coronavirus pandemic, here are 10 highlights from the flood of online music content coming in February. (Times listed are Eastern.)

headline: Sun Records, Storied Early Rock Label, Sells Its High-Wattage Catalog
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: The independent company Primary Wave Music acquired recordings by Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis and other pioneers — but not the music of one of Sun’s biggest stars, Elvis Presley.
lead_paragraph: In the 1950s, Sun Records in Memphis became one of the most dynamic forces in American music, releasing the first recordings by Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis and others, helping define rockabilly and rock ’n’ roll. Even its yellow sunburst label, with a crowing rooster, has become part of the iconography of early rock.

headline: Read Biathlon’s Report on Its Former Leaders
abstract: A report commissioned by the International Biathlon Union said its former president, Anders Besseberg, accepted gifts from Russians — including cash, hunting trips and the services of prostitutes — and then publicly defended the country, its athletes and its interests.
lead_paragraph: A report commissioned by the International Biathlon Union said its former president, Anders Besseberg, accepted gifts from Russians — including cash, hunting trips and the services of prostitutes — and then publicly defended the country, its athletes and its interests.

headline: Do You Believe in Manifesting?
abstract: Does this kind of positive thinking help you find hope in the face of uncertainty? Or is it just too unrealistic?
lead_paragraph: Do you believe that it is possible to make good things happen for yourself simply by thinking about them? Have you ever tried?

headline: The GameStop trading frenzy, explained.
abstract: It’s called a short squeeze, and it involves investors betting on which way a stock will go — up or down. These bets are placed by buying stock options, and the options allow an investor to make money even if the stock itself loses value. If the stock goes up in value, the bets can become losers. Investors who bet against a stock are called “shorts.”
lead_paragraph: It’s called a short squeeze, and it involves investors betting on which way a stock will go — up or down. These bets are placed by buying stock options, and the options allow an investor to make money even if the stock itself loses value. If the stock goes up in value, the bets can become losers. Investors who bet against a stock are called “shorts.”

headline: Here’s how the coronavirus turns the body against itself.
abstract: The coronavirus can warp the body’s defenses in many ways — disarming early warning systems, for example, or causing immune cells to misfire. But a spate of new studies suggests another insidious consequence: The infection can provoke the production of antibodies that mistakenly attack the patient’s own tissues instead of the virus.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus can warp the body’s defenses in many ways — disarming early warning systems, for example, or causing immune cells to misfire. But a spate of new studies suggests another insidious consequence: The infection can provoke the production of antibodies that mistakenly attack the patient’s own tissues instead of the virus.

headline: Biden plans to address health care, the latest policy theme to be showcased at the White House this week.
abstract: The first full week of the Biden presidency has unfolded with a certain rhythm, with each day putting a spotlight on a new policy theme. President Biden has addressed American manufacturing, racial equity and climate change since Monday.
lead_paragraph: The first full week of the Biden presidency has unfolded with a certain rhythm, with each day putting a spotlight on a new policy theme. President Biden has addressed American manufacturing, racial equity and climate change since Monday.

headline: Biden plans to reopen Obamacare exchanges in many states.
abstract: The Biden administration plans to reopen enrollment in many of the Affordable Care Act marketplaces, both to help those who may have lost health insurance during the pandemic and to offer coverage to those who did not have any and now want it.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration plans to reopen enrollment in many of the Affordable Care Act marketplaces, both to help those who may have lost health insurance during the pandemic and to offer coverage to those who did not have any and now want it.

headline: Five Poets That Yusef Komunyakaa Returns to Again and Again
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: “I’ve read Neruda, Walcott, Brooks, Lorca and Hayden multiple times — everything they have written. Over and over, and yet I continue to discover something new.”
lead_paragraph: “I’ve read Neruda, Walcott, Brooks, Lorca and Hayden multiple times — everything they have written,” says the poet, whose collection “Everyday Mojo Songs of Earth” will be released in March. “Over and over, and yet I continue to discover something new.”

headline: The Debate Over San Francisco’s School Names
abstract: Thursday: The question of whether to rename dozens of public schools is an ongoing controversy.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: People of Color Face the Most Pandemic Housing Insecurity
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Mortgages']
abstract: Census Bureau data show how households have struggled to stay current on rent and mortgage payments during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has touched every corner of American life over the past 10 months, but far from equally. Households of people of color have had the hardest time staying current with their rent or mortgage payments during the pandemic, while white households have struggled the least, according to a recent analysis of census data by the Joint Center for Housing Studies of Harvard University (JCHS).

abstract: This week’s properties are a seven-bedroom in New Rochelle, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Greenwich, Conn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are a seven-bedroom in New Rochelle, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
keywords: ['Art', 'Pizza', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Bakeries and Baked Products']
abstract: Fancy frozen meals, Egyptian housewares — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Archaeologists Discover Spot in Alaska Where Indigenous Fort Once Stood
keywords: ['Alaska Natives', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Archaeology and Anthropology']
abstract: The location of the fort, which was used by the Tlingit people to ward off Russian invaders in 1804 and was destroyed by the Russians, has eluded researchers for decades.
lead_paragraph: Archaeologists have discovered the spot in southeastern Alaska where an Indigenous tribe built a wooden fort more than two centuries ago to resist Russian invaders.

headline: Tanaka Departs as Yankees’ Remade Rotation Takes Shape
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka was not expected to return to the Bronx, and the Yankees made almost no effort to keep him. But his departure comes with risk for his old team.
lead_paragraph: Masahiro Tanaka, a mainstay of the Yankees’ pitching rotation for the last seven seasons, will return to Japan to continue his career, he said Thursday.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Capitol Riot Puts Spotlight on “Apocalyptically Minded” Global Far Right’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about white nationalist reactions to the Capitol riot. Then, they will share how they think the government and communities should respond to white supremacy.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Capitol Riot Puts Spotlight on ‘Apocalyptically Minded’ Global Far Right” by Katrin Bennhold and Michael Schwirtz

headline: Russian Court Orders Aleksei Navalny Kept in Jail
abstract: The opposition leader, speaking by video link, called the decision politically motivated. Tens of thousands of people calling for his release protested across Russia last weekend.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Russian court on Thursday ordered the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny to stay in jail, days after tens of thousands of people demanding his release filled streets and squares of cities across Russia last weekend.

headline: The Resurrection of American Magic
keywords: ["AMERICA'S CUP", 'Sailboats and Sailing', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A dramatic crash left a hole in the hull of a high-tech America’s Cup yacht. A round-the-clock repair effort has brought the boat back from the dead.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — The oblong object, 75 feet long with a pointed nose, looks more like a downed spacecraft than a sleek racing yacht.

headline: Top Pakistani Court Upholds Reversal of Conviction in Daniel Pearl Killing
keywords: ['Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The court ordered the release of Ahmed Omar Sheikh, a man previously convicted of being the mastermind of the American journalist’s abduction and murder.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s highest court on Thursday ordered the release of the man who had been convicted of being the mastermind behind the 2002 kidnapping and death of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, in a ruling that experts say shows the weakness of terrorism prosecutions in the country.

headline: Arlo Parks Offers Solace Without Illusions on Her Debut Album
abstract: The 20-year-old English songwriter faces down despair on “Collapsed in Sunbeams.”
lead_paragraph: Arlo Parks wrote her own job description into the closing song on “Collapsed in Sunbeams,” her debut album. “Making rainbows out of something painful,” she sings in “Portra 400.” The song is named after a Kodak color-negative film: a way to preserve images. Parks’s mission as a songwriter is to merge careful observation with clearheaded uplift, trying to provide solace without illusions. “I know you can’t let go of anything at the moment,” she counsels in “Hurt,” then adds, “Just know it won’t hurt so much forever.”

headline: The Great Beginning of Jules Olitski
abstract: The artist’s earliest Color Field paintings, with their indomitable colors, austere compositions and wild pictorial spaces, are among the movement’s signal achievements.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1960s, Jules Olitski (1922-2007) made some of the most astounding abstract paintings of the 20th century. Many of them still astound — even if the avuncular sexual innuendos and women’s names in most of their titles are by now wearying, the stale artifacts of a malign, oblivious era. Both conditions are established by “Jules Olitski: Color to the Core” at Yares Art in Midtown.

headline: Losing Control With Riz Ahmed
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Actors and Actresses', 'Movies', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The actor’s process is so intense, his “Sound of Metal” director refused to share dailies with him. But after all that overthinking, formidable instincts kicked in.
lead_paragraph: To call it the worst night of sleep Riz Ahmed ever had would imply that any sleep was had at all. It was the night before Ahmed began shooting “Sound of Metal” — an intense, critically acclaimed Amazon drama that has vaulted the 38-year-old into the best-actor Oscar race — and he could do little but stare at the ceiling as adrenaline coursed through his body, robbing it of rest.

headline: N.Y. Severely Undercounted Virus Deaths in Nursing Homes, Report Says
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Nursing Homes', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Attorneys General']
abstract: The state attorney general, Letitia James, said it’s likely that the Cuomo administration failed to report thousands of Covid-19 deaths of nursing home residents.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — For most of the past year, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has tried to brush away a persistent criticism that undermined his national image as the man who led New York through the pandemic: that his policies had allowed thousands of nursing home residents to die of the virus.

headline: My Wife Wants to Buy a Gun. Help?
abstract: I don’t believe we’re personally threatened by extremism, but she does.
lead_paragraph: I live with my wife and our 11-year-old son in a peaceful suburban community. Given the civil unrest that shook our nation’s capital recently, and the continuing threat of violence elsewhere, my wife is fearful and would like to buy a gun for protection. She believes that unrest threatens us personally. I disagree. I think the presence of a gun in the home markedly increases the risk of someone being shot. I am also skeptical of marauding bands in our neighborhood. Any thoughts about our conflict?

headline: A Botticelli Portrait Sells for $92 Million at Sotheby’s Auction
abstract: “Portrait of a Young Man Holding a Roundel” dates to around 1480, and its sale is the art market’s biggest test of the new year.
lead_paragraph: A small painting by Sandro Botticelli fetched $92.2 million at auction at Sotheby’s on Thursday, in the art market’s first big test of the new year.

headline: In Afghanistan, Follow the White High-Tops and You’ll Find the Taliban
abstract: The sneakers have been worn by Afghan fighters over multiple generations, but they’ve become a gruesome marker of the Taliban’s violent insurgency.
lead_paragraph: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan — The unassuming white leather high-top sneakers with green-and-yellow trim are a best seller for a roughly half-dozen shoe vendors in a sprawling bazaar in the northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif.

headline: Mississippi Prison Officials Tout Low Rates of Covid. The Reason May Be Fewer Tests.
abstract: Mississippi officials are proud their prisons have some of the country’s lowest infection rates, but they’re not testing inmates without coronavirus symptoms.
lead_paragraph: At South Mississippi Correctional Institution, inmates said they bartered Honey Bun snack cakes for smuggled bleach in a desperate attempt to avoid the coronavirus, which has sickened nearly 400 men at the prison. Even as some fell ill, they said the prison refused to test them.

headline: 20 Wines Under $20: Postcards From Around the World
abstract: In a pandemic era, when traveling is largely out of the question, these wines, good values all, can take you on a trip around the globe.
lead_paragraph: Good wine has the power to transport. As we now approach a full year locked in pandemic freeze-frame, with many people largely confined within their national borders, wine still provides an opportunity to taste the world.

headline: Health Care Unions Find a Voice in the Pandemic
keywords: ['Nursing and Nurses', 'Organized Labor', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Strikes', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Hospitals', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: Faced with the urgent need to protect nurses and other frontline workers, labor organizations are pushing hospitals to do more.
lead_paragraph: The unions representing the nation’s health care workers have emerged as increasingly powerful voices during the still-raging pandemic.

headline: Outsider Art Fair, Smaller This Year, but a Model for the Future
abstract: A scaled-back lineup includes Daniel Johnston’s colorfully nightmarish drawings, plus chunky clay cameras and quilts as abstract as anything in the MoMA.
lead_paragraph: This year’s Outsider Art Fair is a stripped-down and deconstructed one, just seven curated shows spread across four Manhattan galleries and one famous recording studio. (There are also 45 online viewing rooms if you like that sort of thing.)

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Feb. 3, 2021
abstract: Have major sports leagues lived up to their initiatives to diversify team leadership?

headline: G.M. Will Sell Only Zero-Emission Vehicles by 2035
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The move, one of the most ambitious in the auto industry, is a piece of a broader plan by the company to become carbon neutral by 2040.
lead_paragraph: The days of the internal combustion engine are numbered.

headline: Stream These 10 Great Performances by Cloris Leachman
abstract: The Oscar- and Emmy-winning actress was still pushing comedic boundaries in her 90s. Here’s a guide to some of her most fearless and memorable performances.
lead_paragraph: Onstage, on television and, finally, at the movies, there was no missing the irrepressible Cloris Leachman, who died on Wednesday at 94. She was an all-purpose entertainer who became best known for her no-holds-barred comedy. But that same openness left room for moments of disarming sensitivity and heart.

headline: MoMA Photography Curator to Lead Aperture Foundation
abstract: Sarah Meister has been named executive director of the nonprofit organization that supports and promotes the art of photography.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Meister has been named executive director of the Aperture Foundation, a nonprofit organization that supports and promotes the art of photography.

headline: GameStop and AMC rally after Robinhood says it will allow some buying.
abstract: Robinhood said it had placed more restrictions on trades of stocks like GameStop, limiting users to only selling shares they owned and buying shares they had shorted.
lead_paragraph: GameStop’s roller coaster continued Thursday, with shares in the company rallying late in the day after the stock-trading app Robinhood said it would allow its customers to resume trading on the company.

headline: Great Stage Acting Shines Through, Even From a Laptop Screen
abstract: The Lessingtage theater festival, held online this year because of the pandemic, shows some of Europe’s finest performers, in classic plays by Brecht, Schiller, Ibsen and others.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — When it comes to recorded theater, great acting translates to video much better than elaborate productions with complex concepts or intricate sets. So when the Thalia Theater, in Hamburg, Germany, asked 10 European playhouses to send their best shows for an online edition of the Lessingtage, an international festival held every January, by and large the theaters privileged accomplished performances over virtuosic stagecraft.

headline: After an outcry, Robinhood says it will allow users to trade GameStop again on Friday.
abstract: Several popular trading platforms had already curbed trading activities in certain stocks, including GameStop and AMC Entertainment Holdings, the movie theater chain.
lead_paragraph: Several retail stockbrokers, including Robinhood, said they would allow trades of GameStop and other volatile companies after restricting customers’ ability to purchase securities earlier in the day.

headline: Sundance 2021 Guide: Bundle Up and Settle in on Your Sofa
keywords: ['Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Now that the film festival has gone virtual, you can watch like an insider. But where do you start? If you liked previous hits from Park City, try these new entries.
lead_paragraph: Attending the Sundance Film Festival has never been an easy thing to do. Passes are pricey, accommodations are even pricier, the closest airport is nearly an hour away, and you end up waiting in long lines (in Utah, in January) for screenings — at least for the ones that haven’t sold out (which most do).

headline: Ella Emhoff Gets a Major Modeling Contract
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Models (Professional)', 'Inaugurations', 'your-feed-fashion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The second daughter follows the inauguration poet Amanda Gorman to IMG.

headline: Overlooked No More: Jay Jaxon, Pioneering Black Designer of French Couture

headline: A Famous Prada Print, Back With a Twist
abstract: Inspired by Formica-tiled countertops from the 1950s, one of the motifs from the brand’s spring 1996 show has been put to new use.
lead_paragraph: Cartoon bananas, Surrealist lips, apocalyptic Hawaiian florals, kitschy tail fins with flames — Miuccia Prada is known for her eccentric prints and patterns. Another iconic motif arrived 25 years ago with Prada’s spring 1996 collection, arguably one of the designer’s most influential. Dubbed Banal Eccentricity — the show notes cited a 1980 exhibition at the Venice Biennale featuring mass-produced ordinary household objects — it hewed to a palette of avocado greens, rusty ochers and eggplant purples, which featured on solid-colored minimalist pieces and those with squiggly, hand-scribbled plaids that took cues from midcentury wallpaper and kitchen design. Another print — which was composed of overlapping abstract squares inspired by 1950s Formica-tiled countertops and appeared on gabardine midlength overcoats and pencil skirts — became synonymous with the concept of ugly chic. If that now seems like an overused descriptor, revisiting the collection is a reminder of the brand’s ever-prescient vision. Ushered onto the runway by a waifish brigade that included Kate Moss and a pixie-haired Carolyn Murphy, it stood in stark contrast to the slick sexiness of Armani and Tom Ford’s Gucci — and it subverted traditional notions of good taste, and even earned comparisons to Dior’s New Look. “If I have done anything, it was making ugly cool,” Mrs. Prada herself once said. “Ugly is attractive, ugly is exciting.”

abstract: The president’s heritage is important to him. But how deep does it go?
lead_paragraph: In November, a BBC reporter shouted a question at President-elect Joe Biden. He responded, “The BBC? I’m Irish” before flashing a huge smile and disappearing through a doorway. The clip went viral and Ireland went wild.

headline: The G.O.P. Is in a Doom Loop of Bizarro
keywords: ['Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: But will it doom the rest of us, too?
lead_paragraph: Here’s what we know about American politics: The Republican Party is stuck, probably irreversibly, in a doom loop of bizarro. If the Trump-incited Capitol insurrection didn’t snap the party back to sanity — and it didn’t — nothing will.

headline: Children Need to Be Back in School Tomorrow

lead_paragraph: There’s a wave of anti-intellectualism sweeping America. There are people across the country who deny evidence, invent their own facts and live in their own fantasyland. We saw it in the Republicans who denied the reality of the Biden election victory and we see it now in the teachers unions that are shutting down schools and marring children’s lives.

keywords: ['Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity', 'Discrimination', 'News and News Media', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Newspapers', 'Apologies']

headline: Cicely Tyson, an Actress Who Shattered Stereotypes, Dies at 96
abstract: In a remarkable career of many decades, she refused to take parts that demeaned Black people and won a Tony, Emmys and an honorary Oscar.
lead_paragraph: Cicely Tyson, the stage, screen and television actress whose vivid portrayals of strong African-American women shattered racial stereotypes in the dramatic arts of the 1970s, propelling her to stardom and fame as an exemplar for civil rights, died on Thursday.  She was 96.

The department’s Inspector General’s Office now may be taking its first broad look at whether those shadowy strike forces committed war crimes along the way.

headline: It’s Liberals vs. Liberals in San Francisco After Schools Erase Contested Names
abstract: Incredulous parents and the mayor criticized the school board’s decision to change the names of 44 schools that honor historical figures like Jefferson, Lincoln and Paul Revere.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Maybe it was the suddenness, that 44 names were being deleted all at once. Or maybe it was the feeling by many that the Board of Education had gone one step too far, and during a wrenching pandemic to boot. Whatever the reasons, the decision to wipe out one-third of the city’s school names, including ones honoring Washington, Jefferson and Lincoln, has struck a nerve in San Francisco.

headline: Convictions

headline: A ‘bunch of kids’ ran a major vaccination site for Philadelphia. Then the city cut its ties.
abstract: With pressure mounting to get Covid-19 vaccine doses into arms as quickly as possible, many overburdened city health departments across the country have turned to partnerships with hospitals, nonprofit organizations and pharmacies. In Philadelphia this week, one such deal went awry after the city leaned on a start-up led by college students who were eager to get involved but had little experience.

headline: How The New York Times for Kids Explains the Capitol Attack
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Newspapers', 'Children and Childhood', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: The monthly section devoted to children started by following one of its principles: Don’t sugarcoat the news
lead_paragraph: Grappling with the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol is hard enough for adults. How do you help children make sense of it? Two articles appearing this weekend in The New York Times for Kids, a section that runs the last Sunday of every month as part of the print newspaper, tackle that challenge. The editor of the section, Amber Williams, who wrote the main article, said it was one of the most difficult pieces she had written for the section. In a lightly edited conversation, she talked about the task.

headline: Mystery Boxes and Budding Loves: New Science Fiction and Fantasy
abstract: “The Absolute Book,” by Elizabeth Knox, takes on a number of genres, while “Winter’s Orbit,” by Everina Maxwell, stays true to one.
lead_paragraph: Here are two novels that are, in some ways, opposites: one by an author who’s been publishing celebrated work for 40 years, and one a debut; one that blends numerous genres with a skillful and inquiring hand, and one that glories in modeling a single genre by hitting every one of its notes. Between them they contrast the pleasures of surprise with those of satisfied expectations.

headline: Jinkx Monsoon Goes ‘Low-Key’ on Wedding Day
abstract: The “RuPaul’s Drag Race” winner marries an Englishman, Michael Abbott, in their living room. Mr. Abbott is back in Manchester, England for now.
lead_paragraph: If Jerick Hoffer had gotten married 10 years ago instead of Jan. 9, the ceremony would have been drag queen fabulous. “I still had a yen for causing a spectacle then,” said Mx. Hoffer, who goes by the stage name Jinkx Monsoon and  uses they/them pronouns. “Nowadays, I’m much more low-key.”

headline: What’s Happening to Our Economy Is Like a Natural Disaster
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stimulus (Economic)']
abstract: Ezra Klein and Paul Krugman discuss Covid economics, cryptocurrencies and deficit delusions.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration’s first legislative priority is a $1.9 trillion economic rescue package. It’s the kind of mega-package where the individual policies contained inside it — a $15 minimum wage, $1,400 checks, a huge child tax credit expansion, a $50 billion virus testing infrastructure — would be big deals on their own. But together, this would be one of the most consequential packages ever passed.

headline: Helping a Teen Who Is Angry About House Rules on Covid
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Friendship', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Content Type: Service', 'Depression (Mental)']

lead_paragraph: Our Adolescence columnist, the psychologist Lisa Damour, responds to a reader’s question. The question has been edited.

headline: An Instant Connection, Cemented by a Sweet Gift
abstract: After their first date, Kara Cheever and Fuery Hocking felt like they had known each other for years. After their second, Mr. Hocking made sure to send Ms. Cheever her favorite dessert for her birthday.
lead_paragraph: On a Sunday night in early September 2017, Kara Eileen Cheever called her sister. She had just gotten home from her first date with Fuery Thomas Hocking, after matching with him on the dating app Bumble. What was supposed to be a casual afternoon walk in Central Park with Ms. Cheever’s dog, Percy, had lasted into evening.

headline: Should Schools Be Able to Discipline Students for What They Say on Social Media?
abstract: The case of a high school cheerleader who was suspended from her team for comments she made on social media may be heading to the Supreme Court. Do schools have the right to censor or punish students for speech outside of their grounds?
lead_paragraph: A student makes an offensive joke on Instagram.

headline: A Wedding With an Undeniable Force
abstract: When Bianca Hernandez met Frank Knight at a Star Wars event in 2016, they spoke briefly then she tracked him down on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: On a November evening in 2016, Bianca Hernandez attended Star Wars night at the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco. In a room where costumed people dueled with lightsabers, she met Frank Knight, who was staffing a table while his friend took a bathroom break.

headline: One Dose Now for Everyone Most Likely to Die
abstract: Forget boosters and more trials. America’s overly prudent vaccination strategy is killing people.
lead_paragraph: In the race to prevent ever more deaths from Covid-19, the United States faces two major problems: not having enough doses of vaccine on hand and struggling to deliver those that are available. According to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, as of Jan. 28 about 48.4 million doses had been distributed, but only 26.2 million administered.

headline: Backlash Over Virus at SUNY College: ‘Learn From Your Fall 2020 Mistakes!’
abstract: The campus with the worst outbreak of any public college in New York is set to begin in-person classes on Monday. Some students, parents and faculty members weren’t happy about it.
lead_paragraph: When the upstate New York campus that had the worst coronavirus outbreak of any public college in the state announced it would reopen for the spring semester, a petition started in protest and accumulated more than 700 signatures.

headline: From Feigning Intimacy to Falling in Love
abstract: On their first date at a small Rosh Hashana dinner, Dr. Margaret Soper and Jason Kessler made a split-second decision to act as though they were already a couple. It wasn’t long before they weren’t pretending.
lead_paragraph: It was a few days before Rosh Hashana, and Dr. Margaret Swenson Soper suddenly found herself with no plans. She had just learned that the tickets she thought she had to attend services had fallen through, and was feeling sorry for herself.

headline: New York Schools Are Segregated. Will the Next Mayor Change That?
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Gifted Students']
abstract: By deferring decisions on desegregating schools, Mayor Bill de Blasio has pushed those choices onto his successor — and into the race to replace him.
lead_paragraph: During a recent forum on education, a moderator asked the crowded field of Democrats running to be New York City’s next mayor a question they may not have wanted to answer: How would they approach the fraught issue of admissions into the city’s selective schools, where Black and Latino students are starkly underrepresented?

headline: How a Kabbalistic Tarot Card Reader Spends His Sundays
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Occult Sciences']
abstract: He was introduced to the spiritual practice while traveling to Woodstock in 1969. Now he does readings on Zoom.
lead_paragraph: Mark Horn, a tarot card expert who uses his knowledge of kabbalah (Jewish mysticism) in his readings, has been busy lately.

headline: 5 Restaurants on Why They’re Hibernating This Winter
abstract: Whether it’s because of generous landlords, loans or sheer exhaustion, owners are taking a seasonal break.
lead_paragraph: As the pandemic drags on this winter, much of the city that never sleeps is taking an extended snooze. This is especially true for restaurants, several of which are going into hibernation mode instead of braving the financially risky and uncomfortable conditions of outdoor service. Although Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s recent decision to bring back indoor service at 25 percent capacity on Feb. 14 gives the restaurant scene a glimmer of hope, some owners remain unsure about exactly how or when they will reopen. So for now, they hibernate.

headline: Am I Too Old to Keep the Bargain With My Kids?
abstract: As an older parent of young children, I feel that I am holding a big secret — my own mortality.
lead_paragraph: “I’m rea—dy!” At 2:45 a.m., our 3-year-old, Nathaniel, yells out like an excited rooster heralding the day. My wife, Lisa, and I take turns attending to these middle-of-the-night greetings. Tonight, it’s my turn.

headline: Biden Wants the Biggest Stimulus in Modern History. Is It Too Big?
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Recession and Depression', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Supporters of a ‘hot’ economy see a chance to correct the mistakes of the last recession. Others see danger.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s proposed $1.9 trillion pandemic rescue package includes money for many goals: expediting the rollout of coronavirus vaccines; reopening schools; expanding unemployment benefits; sending more cash payments to most Americans.

headline: I’m Not Actually Interested in Mitch McConnell’s Hypocrisy
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: To make his case for the filibuster, he has essentially rewritten the history of the Senate.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Mitch McConnell, now the Senate minority leader, spoke in defense of the legislative filibuster.

headline: $20,000 for a Permit? New York May Finally Offer Vendors Some Relief
keywords: ['Food Trucks and Vendors', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation', 'Small Business', 'Black Markets', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: In an attempt to shut down a thriving black market, the City Council passed a bill that would increase the number of permits for street vendors.
lead_paragraph: Ahmed Ebrahim was born into the family business, selling hot dogs, knishes and pretzels from a cart near Rockefeller Center. He and his brother and business partner, Mahmoud, inherited the work ethic of their mother, Magda, who started as a street vendor more than 30 years ago after immigrating from Egypt. They also inherited a burden: paying $20,000 every two years for a vending permit.

headline: Once the Gowanus Canal Is Rid of ‘Black Mayonnaise,’ Who Will Benefit?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Zoning', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: The city may approve a plan in Brooklyn that is one of the biggest rezoning projects in memory. But the debate is not playing out in predictable ways.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, as if an omen sent from the gods of city planning, a barge carrying toxic sediment nearly sank in Gowanus Bay. It was loaded with the “black mayonnaise” dredged up from the Gowanus Canal, sludge that appeared to be in the midst of a dangerous round trip — potentially recontaminating the water that was so slowly being cleaned up after so long. Designated a Superfund site by the federal government in 2010, the canal is a graveyard to industrial sins committed for more than a century.

headline: Marco Rubio Deserves Ivanka Trump
abstract: Will the senator’s sycophancy and shape-shifting come to naught?
lead_paragraph: It’s a measure of the Republican Party’s current depravity that I think of the period when Marco Rubio was besmirching Donald Trump’s genitalia as the good old days.

headline: After Two Dating Apps and 98 First Dates, Something Was Different About the 99th
abstract: Inimai Chettiar showed the same determination in dating as she did with her work at the Justice Action Network. Kenneth Wolf Jr. helped bring romance back into her life.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, when Inimai Manickam Chettiar debated the author and television personality Van Jones on National Public Radio, issues plaguing her since childhood came roaring back. “It was one of my scariest professional moments,” she said. “Public speaking activates all my woman of color, I-don’t-belong-here insecurities.” The man who would help her face them, who happened to be a white Army veteran, is the same man she would soon fall in love with.

headline: Kristin Hannah Reinvented Herself. She Thinks America Can Do the Same.
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: In “The Four Winds,” the author of “The Nightingale” and “The Great Alone” takes readers back to another era of environmental disaster, economic collapse and fresh starts.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in California and the Pacific Northwest, Kristin Hannah never wanted to become a novelist. It was a career for dreamers, she thought, kids who took creative writing classes and scribbled stories from the time they were 6.

headline: What Should Drive Biden’s Foreign Policy?
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Nationalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: The fiery Cold War liberalism of Hubert Humphrey provides a guide on how to act, abroad and at home.
lead_paragraph: In May 1950, Hubert Humphrey, the firebrand liberal from Minnesota, took to the floor of the Senate to call for passage of a fair employment practices commission to root out systematic racial discrimination in hiring. “So long as men and women and children of color are discriminated against in the United States,” Senator Humphrey insisted, “the colored people of the world have the right to suspect our professed friendship for them.”

headline: It’s Time for Police to Stop Lying to Suspects
keywords: ['Police', 'Interrogations', 'Confessions', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Central Park Jogger Case (1989)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Innocent people are in jail because detectives tricked them.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans don’t know this, but police officers in the United States are permitted by law to outright lie about evidence to suspects they interrogate in pursuit of a confession. Of all forms of subterfuge they deploy — like feigning sympathy and suggesting that a suspect’s confession might bring leniency — this one is particularly dangerous.

headline: Job Seekers With Trump White House on Their Résumés Face a Cold Reality
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Working at the White House has traditionally been a ticket to a lucrative future. But that hasn’t been the case so far for Trump alumni.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After announcing her departure from the Trump administration in the middle of the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol, Sarah Matthews, a deputy White House press secretary, kept running into the same question as she worked her contacts to find a new job: What was it like?

headline: Why 1850 Doesn’t Feel So Far Away
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Debates (Political)', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Bullies']
abstract: Congress has been here before. It wasn’t pretty.
lead_paragraph: Scarcely had the violence ebbed on Capitol Hill on Jan. 6 when the Republican calls for healing began. Representative Debbie Lesko of Arizona made an anti-impeachment cease-and-desist plea on Jan. 12 that was typical of many. Addressing Democrats, she warned that impeachment would “further divide our country, further the unrest and possibly incite more violence.” Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina concurred, declaring on Fox News that calls for impeachment would “incite more violence” and “divide the country.”

headline: Amazon’s Cynical, Anti-Union Attack on Mail Voting
abstract: The everything store wants its workers to vote on unionization in person, in the middle of a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: A battle over voting by mail is again being waged in an electoral contest. But now it’s Amazon that opposes a mail-ballot election in order to thwart a unionization effort at an Alabama fulfillment center.

headline: ‘Trump Just Used Us and Our Fear’: One Woman’s Journey Out of QAnon
keywords: ['Conspiracy Theories', 'QAnon', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: The ‘Roaring Kitty’ Rally: How a Reddit User and His Friends Roiled the Markets
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Social Media', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Hedge Funds', 'Short Selling']
abstract: A Massachusetts man who goes by “Roaring Kitty” on social media helped fuel the frenzy around GameStop. His $53,000 investment in the company briefly reached $48 million in value.
lead_paragraph: In mid-2019, a Reddit user — known as “Roaring Kitty” on some social media accounts — posted a picture on an online forum depicting a single $53,000 investment in the video-game retailer GameStop.

headline: Inside a Pro-Huawei Influence Campaign
keywords: ['5G (Wireless Communications)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Blacklisting', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: A covert online push to sway telecommunications policy in favor of the Chinese company may presage a new twist in social manipulation.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Edwin Vermulst, a trade lawyer in Brussels, did not think twice before he agreed to write an article for Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications giant, that would criticize a Belgian policy that threatened to box the company out of lucrative contracts. He had worked with the company for years.

headline: Can Cute Windows Resurrect a Depressed Town in Upstate New York?
abstract: A project in Cherry Valley, a longtime artists’ haven, is brightening storefronts and telling the world, “We’re still here!”
lead_paragraph: Last winter, Anne Loretto found herself gazing out at the downtown intersection where the upstate town of Cherry Valley’s lone traffic light hangs. This is the center of downtown, home of the historic village’s storefronts. The problem was, so many of them were empty — and had been for a long time.

headline: Why Barbara Kavovit, Entrepreneur and Occasional ‘Housewives’ Friend, Is Running for Mayor
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Ms. Kavovit, who struggled at times to win over her castmates on “The Real Housewives of New York City,” aims to have better luck with voters.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, another New Yorker hurled her hat into the mayor’s race ring, where it currently rests alongside the chapeaux of some 30 other individuals: Democratic candidate Barbara Kavovit. Like Maya Wiley, the former MSNBC analyst, and Andrew Yang, the former presidential candidate, Ms. Kavovit can claim some level of prior national TV exposure. Unlike Ms. Wiley and Mr. Yang, though, hers had no connection to politics, or even news: Ms. Kavovit has appeared (as herself) in several episodes of Bravo’s “The Real Housewives of New York City.” (Most notably, she was a regular on the show’s eleventh season.)

headline: He Is Israel’s ‘Prince of Torah.’ But to Some, He Is the King of Covid.
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Rabbis', 'Disease Rates', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines', 'Torah', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Rabbi Chaim Kanievsky is the spiritual authority for hundreds of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews. But his pronouncements on the virus have made him a villain to many.
lead_paragraph: BNEI BRAK, Israel — Rabbi Chaim Kanievsky, 93, can’t use a phone. He rarely leaves his house. His family says he has never successfully made a cup of tea. His closest aides think he doesn’t know the name of Israel’s prime minister. He studies the Torah for, give or take, 17 hours a day.
