lead_paragraph: MIAMI — America’s business leaders, freed from the office, looked around the country, taking note of its coronavirus lockdowns, taxes and rabble rousers. And many said as if in unison: Miami!

headline: ‘Bridgerton’ Has Nothing on the Couture
abstract: Men at Valentino and Fendi. Movies at Dior. A horse at Chanel. Thank goodness for the disruption amid the very fancy clothes.
lead_paragraph: The death of the haute couture — those wildly expensive, wildly extravagant clothes, made by hand for the very, very few — has been often predicted. It was predicted during the Great Recession, for obvious reasons. It was predicted during the rise of streetwear, thanks to social evolution. It was predicted as more and more fashion houses began to drop off the couture schedule, including Balmain and Saint Laurent.

lead_paragraph: Old houses, especially those in need of a little T.L.C., have long captured our imagination. Now, thanks to the latest breed of preservationist, one that comes with social media savvy, old houses are getting a fresh spotlight.

headline: China to Stop Recognizing Special U.K. Passports for Hong Kongers
abstract: The move was in retaliation for Britain’s offer to grant potentially millions of Hong Kong residents a path to citizenship, amid Beijing’s crackdown on the city.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China announced on Friday that it would no longer recognize certain British travel documents, in retaliation for Britain’s decision last year to grant potentially millions of Hong Kong residents visas and eventually a path to citizenship.

headline: Biden’s Health Care Moves
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Obamacare endured a grueling first decade of existence. Its launch was famously clunky. It was unpopular in its early years. It narrowly escaped repeal at both the Supreme Court and in Congress.

headline: ‘Palmer’ Review: A Crisis of Masculinity
abstract: Justin Timberlake stars as an ex-convict who interrogates his gender biases after he comes to care for a young boy in this prosaic melodrama.
lead_paragraph: Like a bad egg set to boil, a rugged ex-convict softens and then cracks in the pallid drama “Palmer.” The film, streaming on Apple TV+, opens with its stoic protagonist returning home to rural Louisiana after serving a 12-year prison sentence. Palmer (Justin Timberlake) hits the bar and carouses with buddies, but his townie itinerary changes when he finds himself saddled with caring for Sam (Ryder Allen), the cherubic child of a neglectful neighbor.

headline: Biden Moves Cautiously on Health Care
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: France and Germany slowly emerge from severe recessions.
abstract: Severe recessions in Germany and France last year, caused by the coronavirus pandemic, began to improve slightly toward the end of 2020, as a second series of lockdowns had a milder impact on their economies, those governments reported on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Severe recessions in Germany and France last year, caused by the coronavirus pandemic, began to improve slightly toward the end of 2020, as a second series of lockdowns had a milder impact on their economies, those governments reported on Friday.

headline: ‘Gomorrah’ Is Back, as Bloody (and Gripping) as Ever
abstract: The crime series is so popular in its native Italy that it has filtered into language and culture. Some critics decry its portrayal of Naples, while others praise its realism and universal themes.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A few minutes into the third season of “Gomorrah,” the highly popular Italian television series about organized crime in Naples, which began streaming on HBO Max this month, the show’s brooding protagonist muses on the recent death of his father.

headline: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Firefly’
abstract: An Emmy-winning space western that was canceled after one season, the series is a perfect mix of palliative and palate cleanser.
lead_paragraph: If, as a young teen, you experienced a fiery sexual awakening the first time you set eyes on Harrison Ford’s fitted pants in “Star Wars,” you should make Joss Whedon’s “Firefly” your next pandemic binge.

headline: Why Robinhood Had to Risk Infuriating Its Customers
keywords: ['Financial Brokers', 'Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Social Media']
abstract: The online broker raised $1 billion to prop itself up. Overcoming customer anger may be harder.
lead_paragraph: Robinhood had to raise $1 billion from investors yesterday to help it cover cash demands during the week’s trading frenzy, while traders and lawmakers sharply criticized the online broker for halting some trading in Reddit-touted stocks. In short: The consequences of the mania in GameStop, AMC and other stocks are becoming more concrete — and, in Robinhood’s case, more serious.

headline: Johnson & Johnson’s Vaccine Offers Strong Protection but Fuels Concern About Variants
abstract: The vaccine’s efficacy rate dropped from 72 percent in the United States to just 57 percent in South Africa, where a highly contagious variant is driving most cases.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson, the only major drug maker developing a single-dose vaccine for Covid, announced on Friday that its shot provided strong protection against Covid-19, potentially offering another powerful tool in a desperate race against a worldwide rise in virus mutations.

headline: The Debate Over Reopening California Schools
abstract: Friday: Education leaders and teachers have openly criticized the state’s reopening plan. Parents and legislators are not backing down.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Changes in FAFSA May Reduce College Aid for Some Families
abstract: A new formula will no longer offer a break to many parents who have multiple children in college at the same time, experts say.
lead_paragraph: A new, shorter version of the federal student aid form is aimed at encouraging more families to complete it and qualify for financial help. But tweaks to its underlying formula could reduce aid for some families, particularly more affluent ones with more than one child in college.

headline: As Bitcoin’s Price Surges, Affluent Investors Start to Take a Look
keywords: ['Virtual Currency', 'Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Content Type: Service', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Wills and Estates', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Cryptocurrencies, originally a way to conduct business outside the financial system, are increasingly seen as an asset akin to private equity or venture capital.
lead_paragraph: Cryptocurrencies have soared in value. In a decade, they’ve gone from a fringe obsession that allowed coin holders to conduct business outside the financial system to an alternative investment managed as if it were any other investment. It hasn’t hurt that the price of a single Bitcoin has gone from zero to over $30,000 in that time.

headline: The Joy of Watching Other People Clean
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Content Type: Service', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Orderliness and Clutter']
abstract: In this corner of YouTube, you can watch someone else clean the house — and you won’t be alone.

headline: What It’s Like to Give the Covid Vaccine
abstract: A doctor couple is working to get disadvantaged communities “their fair shot at getting the shot.”

headline: A Pandemic Is Hard Enough. For Some, Being Single Has Made It Harder.
abstract: “One day I realized it had been three months since I had touched a human being,” one man said.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has been rough on virtually everyone.

headline: A Victory for Farmers in a David-and-Goliath Environmental Case
keywords: ['Oil Spills', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: An appeals court said a small group of farmers in the Niger Delta region whose livelihoods were affected by oil spills in 2006 and 2007 should receive payouts.
lead_paragraph: A Dutch court ruled on Friday that a subsidiary of the British-Dutch multinational Royal Dutch Shell was liable for oil spills in the Niger Delta in Nigeria in 2006 and 2007, ordering the company to compensate a small group of residents in the region and to start purifying contaminated waters within weeks.

headline: The Rural Home of Susan Orlean
abstract: The author and writer for The New Yorker has placed her Hudson Valley home on the market.

headline: Susan Orlean Lists Her Upstate Retreat
abstract: The writer’s modern three-bedroom house, lined with wood and stone, comes with a $3.495 million price tag.
lead_paragraph: Birds’ nests may not be all that unusual in the Hudson Valley. But at the rural retreat of Susan Orlean, the author and writer for The New Yorker known for her animals beat, the most notable tangles of sticks and straw are not in trees but her kitchen, displayed along a neat bluestone wall just to the left of her refrigerator.

headline: With a Gift of Art, a Daughter Honors, if Not Absolves, Her Father
abstract: Douglas Latchford, a scholar of Khmer antiquities who was accused of trafficking in looted artifacts, bequeathed his world-class collection to his daughter. She has returned it to Cambodia.
lead_paragraph: Nawapan Kriangsak found out as a young girl that running in her father’s apartment was forbidden. Her father, Douglas A.J. Latchford, was perhaps the world’s leading collector of Cambodian antiquities and every corner of his apartment in Bangkok featured a statue of a Khmer deity too valuable to risk to horseplay.

headline: Do We Ask Too Much of Black Heroes?
abstract: Every year for a month, we celebrate the heroes of Black history. But these stories can obscure how change happens and who gets left behind.
lead_paragraph: This is the first piece in “Black History, Continued,” a series that will explore pivotal moments and transformative figures in Black culture and examine how the past shapes the present and the future.

headline: Violence May Delay U.S. Troop Withdrawal From Afghanistan
abstract: The Biden administration is reviewing a deal between its predecessor and the Taliban for a May 1 deadline to pull all American troops out of the country.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Both the Afghan government and its Taliban foes appear to be gearing up for a violent spring amid uncertainty over whether the Biden administration will meet a May 1 deadline for the withdrawal of all American troops from Afghanistan.

headline: The Work Diary of a Cinematic Chef
abstract: On “Binging With Babish,” Andrew Rea makes dishes inspired by movies, sitcoms, anime and more, but off camera he’s too busy for binge-watching TV.
lead_paragraph: Part filmmaker, part self-taught cook, Andrew Rea is the mind behind the Babish Culinary Universe, a YouTube channel best known as the home of his cooking show “Binging With Babish.”

headline: Shedding Shame and Silence in France
abstract: Camille Kouchner is pushing the country to a painful reckoning with incest, and with the elites who excuse one another’s sins.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Camille Kouchner, a slight, cleareyed woman who for decades was consumed by guilt, has become the big disrupter of French society. Her battle to liberate herself from a painful family secret has touched a nerve across France.

headline: How to Keep Your Cool in the GameStop Market
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Hedge Funds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Financial Brokers']

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Embrace projects, like fresh pasta dough, a mushroom lasagna, or Spicy Big Tray Chicken.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. We’re deep in winter on the East Coast of the United States, starting and finishing our days in darkness, frost on the windowpanes, salty grit at the doorstep. It’d be nice to have a roaring fire this weekend, at some giant pile of a house like something out a John Irving novel, sit on a couch in front of it for a while, then head into the huge kitchen to make dinner: a fresh ham; baked beans; mashed parsnips; a honking big double apple pie.

headline: Old Rivals, New Ideas and Why Some Clubs Are Reluctant to Try
abstract: Rangers and Celtic are so focused on beating one another that they may have lost sight of the future. In Brazil, two rivals enter the Copa Libertadores final toying with a new concept: coaching stability.
lead_paragraph: Nobody wants to say it is over. Steven Gerrard, the Rangers manager, will not tempt fate. He will only believe the title is won, he has said, when the math says so. Neil Lennon, his counterpart at Celtic, similarly cannot concede defeat. His team, he has said, will keep going, keep fighting, while there is still some small glimmer of hope.

headline: Indoor Dining Will Reopen in New York City at 25% Capacity

headline: Everything’s a Joke Until It’s Not

headline: If You’ve Ever Wanted to Be a Foster Parent, ‘Now Is the Time to Get Involved’
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Adoptions', 'Foster Care', 'Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: The process has changed during the pandemic, but getting started is easier than you might think.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, Chastity and Mark Gomez, of Denver, were speaking with friends who had begun the process of becoming adoptive parents. After learning about the abuse and neglect suffered by so many children in the foster care system, many of whom need homes, they decided to get involved as well.

headline: 11 Fort Bliss Soldiers Hospitalized After Drinking Antifreeze, Officials Say
abstract: Two of those taken ill were in an intensive care unit, military officials said, adding that the soldiers had believed they were consuming alcohol.

headline: Sawing Someone in Half Never Gets Old. Even at 100.

headline: Electric Cars Are Coming, and Fast. Is the Nation’s Grid Up to It?
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']

lead_paragraph: Grape-Nuts cereal, the supermarket mainstay that is made of neither grapes nor nuts, beloved by some and hated by others, has become hard to find.

headline: ‘Likely Innocent’: Judge Frees Woman Jailed 15 Years in Child’s Death
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Rosa Jimenez was imprisoned after being convicted of murder in the death of a toddler who choked on paper towels while she was babysitting him in 2003. Experts now say the death was accidental.
lead_paragraph: A Texas woman who had served 15 years in prison for the death of a young boy she was babysitting was released on bond this week after a judge found that she was “likely innocent.”

headline: Columbia students go on tuition strike, saying online classes aren’t worth full price.

lead_paragraph: Over 1,100 undergraduate and graduate students at Columbia University have pledged to withhold their tuition for the spring semester to demand a discount for what they see as a lost spring term.

headline: What Do Lars Ulrich and A.O. Scott Have in Common? A Lot, It Turns Out
abstract: The Metallica musician and our film critic have both spent their careers thinking about the creative process and how it’s received. They compared notes.
lead_paragraph: In December, Rolling Stone asked Lars Ulrich, the Metallica drummer, which celebrity he’d most want to quarantine with. His surprising answer was The New York Times’s co-chief film critic A.O. Scott. We knew they had to meet, and on Tuesday they chatted via video for more than 90 minutes about the creative process, criticism and what happens when their children disagree with their artistic tastes. Ulrich even stumped our critic when it came to movies. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Who is Aleksei Navalny?
abstract: How we told the story of the Russian opposition leader on one of the most important weeks of his life. Plus, what to listen to this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Hi everyone, Happy Friday. It was a week filled, again, with politics and the pandemic. But in between making the show, our team was watching interviews about failure, filmmaking and skateboarding and a documentary about the mayor of Ramallah, in the West Bank. We’d love to know what you’ve been watching or listening to lately. And if you missed any of our shows from this week, here’s a recap — along with some of the stories from behind the scenes.

headline: Health care unions amplify the voices of frontline workers overwhelmed by pandemic conditions.
abstract: The unions representing the nation’s health care workers have emerged as increasingly powerful voices during the still-raging pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The unions representing the nation’s health care workers have emerged as increasingly powerful voices during the still-raging pandemic.

headline: The Coup We Are Not Talking About
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Social Media', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: We can have democracy, or we can have a surveillance society, but we cannot have both.
lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, the American government left democracy’s front door open to California’s fledgling internet companies, a cozy fire lit in welcome. In the years that followed, a surveillance society flourished in those rooms, a social vision born in the distinct but reciprocal needs of public intelligence agencies and private internet companies, both spellbound by a dream of total information awareness. Twenty years later, the fire has jumped the screen, and on Jan. 6, it threatened to burn down democracy’s house.

headline: There’s Nothing Better Than This Cheesy Potato Soup
abstract: Silky-smooth and simple to make, it gets verve and heat from homemade pickled jalapeños.
lead_paragraph: One of the many upsides to having a spouse who loves to bake bread is that our soup consumption goes up as the temperatures go down. Because, really, is there a homier winter meal than a butter-slathered slice of sourdough dunked in a bowl of homemade soup?

headline: A Broadway Theater Owner Rethinks Post-Pandemic Ticket Selling
abstract: Jujamcyn, which operates five of the 41 Broadway houses, said that when theater returns it will use SeatGeek instead of Ticketmaster.
lead_paragraph: As many live performance venues rethink their operations in anticipation of a post-pandemic reopening, one of Broadway’s major theater owners has decided to overhaul its ticketing practices.

headline: Amid Critical Shortage, E.U. Moves to Limit Vaccine Exports
abstract: The bloc authorized use of AstraZeneca’s vaccine, the third it has approved, while battling the company, which it says is shirking its obligations to deliver the shots.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Desperate as doses run dry, the European Union on Friday approved its third coronavirus vaccine, while moving to restrict exports of the shot, shunning its decades-old free-trade, anti-protectionism creed amid a growing crisis.

headline: An Old Brooklyn Story Gets Fresh Reporting

headline: Hamptons Real Estate Hits Record Levels in the Pandemic
abstract: The median sale price rose by 40 percent in 2020, while the volume of sales increased 37 percent.
lead_paragraph: As New York City’s real estate market foundered during the pandemic in 2020, home sales in the Hamptons boomed.

headline: Love Letter: Falling in Love While Playing Games
abstract: And: You’re invited, now get vaccinated.
lead_paragraph: Gone are the days when cultivating a romantic relationship with someone you met online was considered taboo. However, for gaming enthusiasts who find love while battling exotic creatures in a parallel universe, explaining how you met might raise eyebrows.

headline: ‘The Lady and the Dale’ Review: The Con Artist and the Car
keywords: ['Television', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: An HBO mini-series recounts the complex, contradictory life of Elizabeth Carmichael: criminal, auto executive, transgender pioneer.
lead_paragraph: With “The Lady and the Dale,” a four-part documentary beginning Sunday, HBO has itself an I-can’t-believe-I-haven’t-heard-of-this story in the “Tiger King” or “McMillions” category. The most newsworthy events in the astonishing life of Elizabeth Carmichael — serial con artist, fugitive from the law and, for a brief moment, celebrated automotive entrepreneur — took place just long enough ago and just far enough under the pre-internet national radar that they’re fresh for the telling.

headline: ‘The Poltergeist’ Review: Portrait of the Artist as a Young Madman
abstract: A breakneck performance by Joseph Potter as an embittered former prodigy carries this unnerving monologue from Philip Ridley.
lead_paragraph: The mind of a neurotic artist is a terrifying place to be. Trust me, I know: I’ve had a 30-year residency in one, and it’s no picnic.

headline: The Misfits Shaking Wall Street
abstract: They are young, they are fearless and they are forcing everyone to pay attention.
lead_paragraph: Zane Bannink, a high school senior in Wisconsin, said that he has used the Robinhood stock trading app since he turned 18 two months ago. So far, he’s made over $800.

headline: Stream These 8 Great Performances by Cicely Tyson
abstract: The Emmy-winning actress started breaking down stereotypes with her first major TV roles in the early 1960s. Here’s a guide to some of her most trailblazing and memorable performances.
lead_paragraph: Cicely Tyson, who died on Thursday at age 96, never wanted to be confined to the roles that had been customarily reserved for Black women. She had no interest in perpetuating stereotypes. She was drawn to female characters distinguished by their dignity, strength, intelligence, compassion and bravery — even though that might have limited her available professional opportunities. “I could not do anything that would not enhance humanity, especially women,” she once said.

headline: Duke Bootee, Whose ‘Message’ Educated Hip-Hop, Dies at 69
abstract: His 1982 hit about the “jungle” of urban poverty charted a new, grittier path for rap music in its early days.
lead_paragraph: Edward Fletcher, who as Duke Bootee was the driving force behind “The Message,” the 1982 hit that pushed hip-hop from merry escapism toward chronicling the daily grind of urban poverty, died on Jan. 13 at his home in Savannah, Ga. He was 69.

headline: Cicely Tyson Kept It Together So We Didn’t Fall Apart
abstract: A wonder of poise and punch, the actress dared to declare herself a moral progenitor, taking on roles that reflected the dignity of Black women.
lead_paragraph: How odd to celebrate someone for not being who we’ve been programmed to expect. But American entertainment worked hard on the mold that Cicely Tyson refused to fit. So, really, what we’ve been saluting all these decades was historic defiance. She died on Thursday, at 96, just after the release of “Just as I Am,” a juicy, honest, passionately Cicely memoir. (“Well, child, I’ll tell you: my mouth fell open like a broken pocketbook.”) And on the opening pages resides the truth about why, as a performer, she was the way she was.

headline: Museum of the Bible Returns Artifacts to Egypt
abstract: Egypt had asserted that the items were ferreted out amid the Arab Spring. The antiquities are among those at the museum lacking proper paperwork.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of the Bible in Washington, which has been bedeviled since its inception in 2017 by claims that it acquired thousands of biblical artifacts on the black market, has quietly repatriated 5,000 manuscripts and bits of papyrus to Egypt, which has long asserted the items were ferreted from the country in 2011 amid the upheavals of the Arab Spring.

headline: Navigating the Maze of Paying for College
abstract: Ron Lieber talks about “The Price You Pay for College,” and Michael J. Stephen discusses “Breath Taking: The Power, Fragility, and Future of Our Extraordinary Lungs.”

headline: John Chaney, Hall of Fame Temple Basketball Coach, Dies at 89
abstract: He won more than 500 games and six Atlantic 10 tournament championships with Temple, and he took his teams to the N.C.A.A. tournament’s regional finals five times.
lead_paragraph: John Chaney, the famously combative Hall of Fame coach who took Temple University to 17 N.C.A.A. basketball tournaments, largely recruiting high school players from poor neighborhoods who were overlooked by the college game’s national powers, died on Friday. He was 89.

lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — American airstrikes in a joint mission with Iraqi forces have killed the top Islamic State leader in Iraq, an attack aimed at stemming the group’s resurgence and exacting retribution for a deadly double-suicide bombing in Baghdad last week.

headline: The W.H.O. drops opposition to vaccinations for pregnant women.
abstract: The change aligns the organization with the guidance from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization on Friday changed its guidance for pregnant women considering a Covid-19 vaccine, abandoning opposition to immunization for most expectant mothers unless they were at high risk.

keywords: ['Baseball', 'Minorities', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Major League Baseball celebrated the hiring of a woman as a sign of progress on diversity in its executive ranks. Every comparable hire over the last two years has been a white man.
lead_paragraph: Kim Ng brought hope to baseball when the Miami Marlins hired her as the team’s general manager in November, making her the first woman and second person of Asian descent to run a major-league team’s baseball operations.

headline: If You’re Feeling Isolated
abstract: Try writing a letter.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. The Sundance Film Festival is on until Wednesday, and like most things these days, it’s gone virtual. Make like A.O. Scott and watch it from your sofa. We’ll help you select some features that suit your taste, or you could check out The New York Times’s selection of Op-Docs from this year and previous ones. Then you’ll want to read this profile of Tabitha Jackson, the fest’s new director.

headline: Macron Tells Biden That Cooperation With U.S. Cannot Be Dependence
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: In a “very agreeable call,” the French president told his American counterpart that Europe wanted “strategic autonomy.” In an interview with foreign media, he also reflected on the pandemic and threats to democracy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France said in an interview Friday that for Europe to be a credible partner to the United States it also had to be “an autonomous partner” with its own military and technological capacities, because “cooperation cannot be dependence.”

headline: Germany won’t allow some nonresidents to enter the country, even with a negative test.
abstract: Germany on Friday announced its plans to restrict incoming travel from a handful of countries, including Britain and Ireland, in an attempt to curb the spread of infectious coronavirus variants, going beyond the measures recommended by the European Union.
lead_paragraph: Germany on Friday announced its plans to restrict incoming travel from a handful of countries, including Britain and Ireland, in an attempt to curb the spread of infectious coronavirus variants, going beyond the measures recommended by the European Union.

keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A judge rebuffed a request by prosecutors to impose a prison sentence on Kevin Clinesmith, who admitted doctoring an email used to help authorize a wiretap on a former Trump campaign aide.
lead_paragraph: A former F.B.I. lawyer who has admitted doctoring an email during preparations to seek renewed court permission to wiretap a former Trump campaign aide during the Russia investigation was sentenced on Friday to one year of probation and 400 hours of community service — but no prison time.

headline: Sharon Kay Penman, Whose Novels Plumbed Britain’s Past, Dies at 75
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Research', 'Middle Ages (Historical Period)']
abstract: The author of best-selling books set in medieval England and Wales, she insisted that historical fiction had an obligation to the facts.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Kay Penman, a former tax lawyer whose best-selling epics about medieval England and Wales drew legions of admirers for her meticulous research and commitment to historical facts, died on Jan. 22 in a hospital in Atlantic City, N.J. She was 75.

headline: Corky Lee, Who Photographed Asian-American Life, Dies at 73

lead_paragraph: Corky Lee, a photographer who was determined both to restore the contributions of Asian-Americans to the historical record and to document their present-day lives and struggles, especially those living in New York, died on Wednesday in Queens. He was 73.

headline: Which Covid Vaccine Should You Get? Experts Cite the Effect Against Severe Disease
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Clinical Trials', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: Infectious disease doctors say getting a shot of the J&J vaccine, which has a lower efficacy against the virus than other vaccines, would still be well worthwhile.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the results reported on Friday from the long-awaited trial of Johnson & Johnson’s coronavirus vaccine might have seemed disappointing. Its overall efficacy — the ability to prevent moderate and severe disease — was reported at 72 percent in the United States, 66 percent in Latin American countries and 57 percent in South Africa.

headline: Biden and Top Economic Officials Stress Urgency of More Pandemic Aid
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Recession and Depression', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Labor and Jobs']

headline: In Biden’s White House, Masks, Closed Doors and Empty Halls
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Masks', 'White House Coronavirus Outbreak (2020)']
abstract: The West Wing has become a different place in an administration serious about Covid restrictions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior staff members limit interactions with each other in most offices to a total of 15 minutes in a day. No more than six people are allowed to gather in the Oval Office at a time, and a maximum of five staff members are allowed to meet together in the spacious office of the chief of staff, Ron Klain. In the Roosevelt Room, where staff meet every afternoon for a planning meeting on the coronavirus rescue plan, gatherings are limited to 10 people.

headline: Veteran C.I.A. Officer, Who Previously Briefed George W. Bush, to Lead Biden Intelligence Sessions

abstract: The new intelligence chief wanted a briefer with experience and an apolitical record. She chose Morgan Muir, perhaps the first time a former White House briefer has returned to the post.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The new director of national intelligence has begun reshaping the office, installing a new official to lead President Biden’s daily briefings by tapping a veteran of the last Bush administration, according to current and former government officials.

headline: ‘It’s Numbing’: Nine Retired Nuns in Michigan Die of Covid-19

lead_paragraph: The religious sisters who lived in retired seclusion at the Dominican Life Center in Michigan followed strict rules to avoid an outbreak of coronavirus infection: They were kept in isolation, visitors were prohibited and masks were required by everyone on campus.

headline: G.M. Announcement Shakes Up U.S. Automakers’ Transition to Electric Cars
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Automobiles', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Every carmaker is trying to figure out how to make the leap before governments force it and Tesla and other start-ups lure away drivers.
lead_paragraph: A new president took office this month determined to fight climate change. Wall Street investors think Tesla is worth more than General Motors, Toyota, Volkswagen and Ford put together. And China, the world’s biggest car market, recently ordered that most new cars be powered by electricity in just 15 years.

headline: It’s Been 10 Months, and I Still Don’t Know When to Replace My Mask!
abstract: Practical pandemic guidance is still a huge problem.
lead_paragraph: Charlie: Zeynep, we are almost a year into this pandemic, and I still have a very basic question that I can’t seem to find the answer to: How long can you use an N95 mask before you have to replace it?

headline: For Dreamers, Action Will Speak Louder Than Words
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Biden has a bold immigration plan. But will he convince lawmakers to make it work?
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — In the months leading up to the congressional vote on the Dream Act in 2010, young people across the state organized protests to urge our elected officials to vote in favor. I was a 21-year-old communications student at Estrella Mountain Community College, in Avondale, Ariz., at the time.

headline: Violence in Afghanistan May Delay U.S. Troop Withdrawal
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The Pentagon raised doubts on Thursday that the U.S. military would withdraw from Afghanistan by May 1 — the deadline set in a February 2020 agreement with the Taliban — after accusing the Taliban of failing to uphold its commitments under the deal.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon raised doubts on Thursday that the U.S. military would withdraw from Afghanistan by May 1 — the deadline set in a February 2020 agreement with the Taliban — after accusing the Taliban of failing to uphold its commitments under the deal.

headline: Why Did the N.Y.P.D. Solve Fewer Crimes Last Year?
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police']
abstract: A confluence of factors means that too many murderers are walking free.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Abney says she knows who killed her 20-year-old son, Fabian, last August. But she is still waiting for the New York Police Department to solve the case — another unsolved murder in a city grappling with a surge of gun violence amid the pandemic.

headline: A ‘Race’ to Vaccinate, After South Africa Variant Is Detected in South Carolina
abstract: The mutation raised the stakes for South Carolina, which is reporting the second-highest rate of new infections in the nation. It is believed to be less receptive to vaccines.
lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — South Carolina was already experiencing one of the worst coronavirus outbreaks in the nation when officials got word this week of an alarming development: A new, more concerning variant of the virus, originally identified in South Africa, had been detected in the state.

headline: Biden Visits Walter Reed, the Hospital That Treated Both Him and His Son
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “I’ve spent a lot of time at Walter Reed,” Mr. Biden said as he left the White House for the visit on Friday. “They’re great Americans. They’re great people.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden spent six grueling months at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center more than 30 years ago, battling two brain aneurysms. In 2015, he was at the hospital again as his son, a major in the National Guard, lost his fight against brain cancer.

headline: A West Virginia newspaper company is suing Google and Facebook over online ads.
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: “There is no longer a competitive market in which newspapers can fairly compete for online advertising revenue,” the paper said in the suit.
lead_paragraph: The owner of The Charleston Gazette-Mail and other West Virginia news publications filed a lawsuit in federal court on Friday against Google and Facebook, accusing the companies of profiting from “anticompetitive and monopolistic practices” that have damaged the newspaper business.

headline: Share Your Memories of Someone You Lost to Covid-19
abstract: We want to hear from those who have lost a teacher, a brother, a bandmate or any of the other more than 430,000 Americans who have died in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: A study in December found that a majority of Americans knew someone who had been hospitalized or died from Covid-19, and since then the number of Americans who have died from the coronavirus has surpassed 430,000.

headline: Marjorie Taylor Greene’s Controversies Are Piling Up. Republicans Are Quiet.
keywords: ['Conspiracy Theories', 'QAnon', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'Discrimination', 'Hate Speech', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a video from 2018, Ms. Greene falsely suggested that 9/11 was a hoax, President Barack Obama was a Muslim and the Clintons were guilty of murder.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Marjorie Taylor Greene had just finished questioning whether a plane really flew into the Pentagon on Sept. 11, 2001, and flatly stating that President Barack Obama was secretly Muslim when she paused to offer an aside implicating another former president in a crime.

headline: Robert Cohan, 95, Dies; Exported Contemporary Dance to Britain
abstract: A New York-born protégé of Martha Graham, he and a rich patron revolutionized dance in the U.K. with a cutting-edge new form.
lead_paragraph: Robert Cohan, a New York-born dancer and choreographer who changed the course of British dance by helping to establish an acclaimed contemporary dance company and school in London in the late 1960s, died there on Jan. 13. He was 95.

headline: Health Providers Worldwide Welcome Biden Reversal of Anti-Abortion Rule
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Women and Girls', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: By restoring funding cut off by his predecessor, President Biden ended four years of what abortion rights advocates called a concerted assault on women’s reproductive health in the developing world.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — When President Donald J. Trump scrapped tens of millions of dollars in aid to women’s health care providers around the world four years ago, the Family Planning Association of Nepal was forced to dismiss more than 200 people and close clinics in at least four parts of the country, one of Asia’s poorest.

headline: Legal Pressure on Trump Increases With Judge’s Order in Fraud Inquiry
keywords: ['Trump Tax Returns', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The order, answering a demand for documents by New York’s attorney general, rejected a bid to shield the records with attorney-client privilege.
lead_paragraph: A New York judge on Friday increased pressure on former President Donald J. Trump’s family business and several associates, ordering them to give state investigators documents in a civil inquiry into whether the company misstated assets to get bank loans and tax benefits.

headline: Coachella music festival is canceled again.
abstract: The festivals were some of the first major events canceled back in April 2020 in the early days of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, which draws more than a hundred thousand fans daily from around the world to Southern California, is off for a third time.

headline: A Georgia Chicken Town Reels After a Plant Disaster
keywords: ['Poultry', 'Nitrogen', 'Foreign Workers', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Factory Farming', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: A nitrogen leak killed six workers and injured 11, but many in the heavily undocumented work force, advocates said, are too fearful to go in for medical checks.
lead_paragraph: GAINESVILLE, Ga. — The morning after a nitrogen leak in a chicken plant killed six people in the self-proclaimed poultry capital of the world, nearly everyone in its big Latino community choked down their grief and fear and did what they had come to Gainesville to do.

headline: After Newness Fades, Canada Settles Down to Legal Marijuana
abstract: The national upheaval predicted when Canada became the first major industrialized nation to legalize recreational marijuana has not come to pass.
lead_paragraph: As part of The Times’s Promises Made series, I’ve looked back at Canada’s experience with becoming the first major industrialized nation to legalize recreational marijuana. One thing stood out during the many weeks I spent on this reporting: It may have been a major event, but it wasn’t a revolution.

headline: In L.A., the Virus Is Pummeling Those Who Can Least Afford to Fall Ill
abstract: Los Angeles County is one of the worst Covid-19 hotspots in the country. See how hard Angelenos have been hit, neighborhood by neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles County is one of the worst Covid-19 hotspots in the country. See how hard Angelenos have been hit, neighborhood by neighborhood.

headline: Evidence Builds That Pregnant Women Pass Covid Antibodies to Newborns
abstract: A new study suggests that protective antibodies can be transferred through the placenta, and the baby may receive more of them if a mother is infected with Covid earlier in her pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: One of the many big questions scientists are trying to untangle is whether people who get Covid-19 during pregnancy will pass on some natural immunity to their newborns.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 30, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 30, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about protests in Poland over a ban on abortions in cases of fetal abnormalities misstated the name of an L.G.B.T. group protesting the laws. It is Queer Tour, not Queen Tour.

headline: Quotation of the Day: One Journey Out of the Addictive Grip of QAnon
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 30, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “I felt a part of her saying, ‘This is not the friend I recognize.’”

headline: Federal Court Lifts Block on Trump Policy Expelling Migrant Children at the Border
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Immigration Detention', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The prospect of border agents again turning away children is likely to renew pressure on the Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Friday lifted a block on a Trump-era policy of rapidly turning away migrant children as public health risks, ramping up pressure on the Biden administration to restore the asylum process at the southwestern border.

headline: One Might Carry a Torch
abstract: Nam Jin Yoon improves our Saturday with an electric puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Nam Jin Yoon’s third weekend puzzle for The New York Times, and I’m finding his style to be memorable in its breeziness. Kind of a curious reaction, but it definitely has a flow, a particular sense of humor and a gentle vibe. There are geometric similarities to Sam Ezersky’s puzzle two Saturdays ago, but the stacks are double, not triple, and they blend into the solve for me even though three of them are debuts and one is back for the first time since 1995.

headline: Proud Boys Charged With Conspiracy in Capitol Riot
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right']
abstract: The conspiracy charges were the first to emerge against members of the extremist group in connection with the assault on Congress.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors investigating the violent riot at the Capitol this month announced their first conspiracy charges against the Proud Boys on Friday night, accusing two members of the far-right nationalist group of working together to obstruct and interfere with law enforcement officers protecting Congress during the final certification of the presidential election.

headline: The Australian Open will allow up to 30,000 spectators a day.
abstract: Such numbers would make the tennis tournament a sports rarity during the pandemic, though attendance would still be down by about half from a normal year.
lead_paragraph: When the Australian Open begins next month, the grandstands may offer the closest thing to sports normalcy that the world has seen in nearly a year.

headline: Managing Up: How to Deal With a Bad Boss During Quarantine
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Telecommuting', 'Workplace Environment', 'Executives and Management (Theory)']
abstract: The medium can be just as important as the message.
lead_paragraph: Remember the good old days, when you could clear up an ambiguously curt email from your boss with a stroll by her desk? Or when the anxiety of getting a dreaded “We need to chat” Slack message could be alleviated with a quick pop-in?

headline: Trump’s Shadow Lingers Over Divided G.O.P.
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republicans seem more focused on attacking those who break with the former president, than members who continue to push violent conspiracy theories that flourished under his leadership.
