headline: A Vanishing Priest, a Wall of Secrecy and a 25-Year-Old Abuse Case
abstract: Religious orders have their own hierarchies, so they have their own ways of handling abuse allegations.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-odd years ago, 8-year-old Timothy Schlenz spent every Saturday being tutored on the sacraments at a Manhattan church. It was there, he said, that he was regularly abused.

headline: Forecast: Wild Weather in a Warming World
abstract: The polar vortex is experiencing an unusually long disturbance this year because of a “sudden stratospheric warming.” Bundle up.
lead_paragraph: Rough winter weather is working its way across the United States, with bitterly cold air hitting the Northeast and snowstorms expected along the East Coast next week.

headline: How Women Are Changing the Philanthropy Game
abstract: They’ve always been big givers, but for a long time men got most of the credit.
lead_paragraph: When MacKenzie Scott revealed in December that she had donated $4.2 billion of her fortune in the preceding four months — on top of the $1.7 billion she had given away earlier in 2020 — the internet exploded with praise.

headline: Nitrous Nation
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Opioids and Opiates', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Hippie crack. Whippets. Laughing gas. A casual party drug endures.
lead_paragraph: For decades, nitrous oxide has been widespread at raves and music festivals, used as a quick buzz. The drug doesn’t have the death toll of the opiate disaster or the widespread popularity of marijuana, but it’s widely sold — legally — all over the country, though its consumption outside medical facilities is illegal in many states.

headline: They’re Flocking to America to Make a Fortune Playing Video Games
keywords: ['E-Sports', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: League of Legends teams in the U.S. lag behind their competitors in Asia, so they recruit the world’s best players by offering huge salaries.
lead_paragraph: Crimson lights flashed and announcers yelled in shock as a star athlete pulled off a miraculous feat: leading his team to an upset victory in the semifinals of a world championship tournament.

headline: Fact-Checking Biden’s First Week in Office
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: All but three of 20 claims the president made were accurate, demonstrating his regard for basic facts and his proclivity to err when speaking off the cuff.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, in his first week in office, typically stuck to vetted scripts and verified facts — a departure from his predecessor’s freewheeling and fact-free rhetorical style.

headline: They Put the Bite in Trilobite
abstract: New research helps explain how some ancient species hunted and fed, and highlights the shell-crushing power of one large trilobite.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of millions of years ago, trilobites filled the ancient seas. Now, their iconic fossils are plucked from shale beds to fill museum shelves and eBay stores, quintessential symbols of the teeming Cambrian Period. There is even at least one newspaper column named for them.

headline: For McCarthy and McConnell, Two Paths on Trumpian Crisis Management
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)']
abstract: Kevin McCarthy, the House minority leader, and Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader, want to take back control of Congress in 2022. First they have to figure out how to handle Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The two men now leading the Republican Party usually align during political crises. But the Trumpian chaos splintering the G.O.P. is not only testing Kevin McCarthy, the House minority leader, and Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader — it’s also highlighting their differences in how to handle the former president and hampering a united strategy for retaking Congress next year.

headline: As Protests Grip Russia, Putin Critics of Many Stripes Rally Around Navalny
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Politics and Government', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: While many at the protests are critical of Aleksei A. Navalny, the Kremlin’s treatment of the opposition leader has united a disparate group of Putin’s opponents who say they can no longer tolerate official injustice.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Aleksandr Pasechnik, a socialist, sees the jailed opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny as part of the “liberal intelligentsia.” Mikhail Svetov, Russia’s best-known libertarian, recoils from Mr. Navalny’s economic populism. Olga Nikiforova, a monarchist, long refused to believe that Mr. Navalny was poisoned.

headline: A California University Tries to Shield an Entire City From Coronavirus
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Contact Tracing (Public Health)', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Masks', 'Quarantines', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The University of California, Davis, is providing free testing, masks and quarantine housing to tens of thousands of people who live nearby.
lead_paragraph: DAVIS, Calif. — The coronavirus test center on A Street was bustling on a recent morning. Michael Duey was in line, as usual, with his teenage son. Margery Hayes waited for her wife in the parking lot. Dr. Elizabeth Pham hustled her children in for a quick pit stop.

headline: How the Search for Covid-19 Treatments Faltered While Vaccines Sped Ahead
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Clinical Trials', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Hydroxychloroquine (Drug)', 'Remdesivir (Drug)', 'Research', 'United States Politics and Government', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: Vaccine development exceeded everyone’s expectations. But the next few months will still bring many sick people — and doctors have woefully few drugs with which to treat them.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year into the coronavirus pandemic, as thousands of patients are dying every day in the United States and widespread vaccination is still months away, doctors have precious few drugs to fight the virus.

headline: How a Horrifying Cycling Crash Set Up a Battle Over Safety
abstract: A series of crashes in elite road racing has galvanized riders to demand more safety measures, while the sport’s governing body promises changes.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch cyclist Fabio Jakobsen was battling for the lead near the end of the Stage 1 sprint at the Tour of Poland last summer. A sudden shift in direction by his closest rival, Dylan Groenewegen, forced Jakobsen to swerve, starting a gruesome crash that stunned even observers accustomed to the extreme hazards of the sport.

headline: What’s Next for Crypto Regulation
abstract: The rules are in flux as a new U.S. administration takes over.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, and today it takes you on a quick tour of the regulatory scene for cryptocurrency, a fast-changing field that may represent the future of the financial industry. (If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.)

headline: Paris, Shuttered, Must Be Imagined
abstract: The pandemic has enshrouded and dimmed the City of Light. But there are many reasons to soldier through the fog.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “We’ll always have Paris.” Turns out perhaps the most famous line in the movies was wrong.

headline: Ways to Help Newlyweds Feel Their Best
abstract: Health and wellness pros share their favorite presents to help couples focus on each other and their personal well-being.
lead_paragraph: Every January we collectively set intentions to become better versions of ourselves. With the desire to refresh, reset and renew at the forefront of everyone’s mind, many couples use the top of the year as a time to establish their own health and relationship goals.

headline: The West’s Patience With Uganda’s Strongman Wanes After a Bloody Election
abstract: The United States is considering action against the government of President Yoweri Museveni, a longtime ally who has crushed dissent at home. The European Union has also expressed concern.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — A bloody and contentious election season in Uganda, in which dozens of people were killed and the principal opposition candidate was placed under de facto house arrest, recently gave a sixth five-year term to President Yoweri Museveni, a staunch U.S. military ally.

headline: Scientists see the discovery of the South Africa variant in South Carolina as a ‘pivotal moment.’
abstract: South Carolina was already experiencing one of the worst coronavirus outbreaks in the nation when officials got word this week of an alarming development: A new, more concerning variant of the virus, originally identified in South Africa, had been detected in the state.
lead_paragraph: South Carolina was already experiencing one of the worst coronavirus outbreaks in the nation when officials got word this week of an alarming development: A new, more concerning variant of the virus, originally identified in South Africa, had been detected in the state.

headline: Britain’s vaccine rollout is a rare pandemic-response success for the country.
abstract: With nearly eight million people, or 11.7 percent of the population, having already received their first shot, Britain’s pace of vaccination is the fastest of any large nation in the world. Only Israel and the United Arab Emirates are moving faster.
lead_paragraph: With nearly eight million people, or 11.7 percent of the population, having already received their first shot, Britain’s pace of vaccination is the fastest of any large nation in the world. Only Israel and the United Arab Emirates are moving faster.

headline: How to Refurbish a Rental Without Doing Too Much Damage
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: But before you get started, check your lease to see what’s permitted.
lead_paragraph: Q: My partner and I live in a rental in Astoria, Queens, that we love. It has great light, a nice layout and is close to the train. We plan to stay here for at least a few years. We want to make the space feel like our own and less like a generic rental, but we also want to be mindful of the lease, making improvements that are easily reversible when we move. What are our options?

headline: E.U. Makes a Sudden and Embarrassing U-Turn on Vaccines
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Already criticized for a slow rollout for its 27 members, Brussels retreated on export controls linked to Ireland and Brexit.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union early Saturday abruptly reversed an attempt to restrict vaccine exports from the bloc into Britain via Northern Ireland, the latest stumble in the continent’s faltering vaccine rollout.

headline: Sophie, Who Pushed the Boundaries of Pop Music, Dies at 34
abstract: As a producer and performer, Sophie distilled speed, noise, melody and clarity, working simultaneously at the experimental fringes of dance music and the center of pop.
lead_paragraph: Sophie, an innovative producer and performer whose music distilled speed, noise, melody, clarity and catchiness into what would soon be called hyperpop, died on Saturday in Athens. She was 34.

headline: Doug Emhoff and the Second Gentleman Effect
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Careers and Professions', 'Parenting']
abstract: In his new role, Kamala Harris’s husband can model a masculinity that embraces support.
lead_paragraph: The list of barriers Vice President Kamala Harris has broken is thrillingly long — first Black vice president, first South Asian vice president, first female vice president — and you have to go pretty far down it to get to the fact that, thanks to her, we now have our nation’s first male vice-presidential spouse. So when social media exploded with joy last week at the presence of @SecondGentleman Doug Emhoff, I found myself apprehensive. Are we really going to give Mr. Emhoff, lovely as he seems to be, credit just for doing the support work that wives have been doing forever? (I’ve rolled my eyes too many times as my husband gets fawned over at the playground for that.) Are we really going to make this historic milestone for women even a little bit about a man?

headline: 10 Recipes Cozier Than a Weighted Blanket
abstract: When temperatures drop below freezing, nothing comforts like the cheesy and the creamy.
lead_paragraph: When temperatures drop below freezing, nothing soothes quite like cheesy toasts or heaping piles of pasta. Let comforting beige food reign, and make a few of our most popular recipes from this week. Break out the blender for a creamy cauliflower soup topped with croutons and fragrant rosemary olive oil, or pull out the sheet pan for sausages nestled in caramelized shallots and apples (above). Want something brighter? Give a positively green vegan creamy leek pasta a spin. You’ll find those, as well as other recipes our readers loved this week, in the collection below.

headline: The Senate Needs Absentee Voting, Too
abstract: The chamber’s new leadership should get serious about enabling members to vote remotely in the event of emergencies.
lead_paragraph: The Senate Democratic caucus was hit with a pair of unsettling health developments this week.

headline: The Capitol Attack Was a Failure of Policing, Not Architecture
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Fences and Property Barriers']
abstract: Building a permanent fence around the Capitol is not the right approach.
lead_paragraph: The acting chief of the Capitol Police, Yogananda Pittman, said on Thursday that Congress must build permanent fences around the Capitol. The impulse is understandable: Ms. Pittman got the job after her predecessor failed to stop the Jan. 6 attack on the building by supporters of former President Donald Trump. However, the proposal must be weighed against the public interest. There are important reasons to find other ways of protecting the Capitol.

headline: The Real Meaning of Hillbilly
abstract: I left my hometown because I felt alienated from its conservative values. Turns out many in my community had forgotten our progressive roots.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — I can’t remember the first time I heard the word “redneck,” but when I was growing up in Middle Tennessee it was usually spoken with pride — tossed around at the bluegrass festivals I went to. My grandfather would pick guitar, and I’d play fiddle, usually in a circle of old-timers under a shade tree at the Summertown Bluegrass Reunion.

headline: The Silicon Valley Start-Up That Caused Wall Street Chaos
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mobile Applications', 'Financial Brokers', 'Futures and Options Trading']
abstract: Robinhood pitched itself to investors as the antithesis of Wall Street. It didn’t say that it also entirely relies on Wall Street. This past week, the two realities collided.
lead_paragraph: The online trading app Robinhood became a cultural phenomenon and a Silicon Valley darling with a promise to wrest the stock market away from Wall Street’s traditional gatekeepers and “let the people trade” — making it as easy to put millions of dollars at risk as it is to summon an Uber.

headline: Copying Roosevelt, Biden Wanted a Fast Start. Now Comes the Hard Part.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The most daunting challenge for Mr. Biden in the weeks ahead will be balancing his stated desire for bipartisanship with his sense of urgency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the weeks before taking office, President Biden and his aides spent time digging into books about Franklin D. Roosevelt, both biographies and volumes exploring his iconic first 100 days, on the theory that no president since then has taken office with the country in a crisis quite so grave.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Why did Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon cross the road?
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — I hope none of you were eating chicken wings while you solved this puzzle! They’re a (somewhat vestigial) part of the subject of today’s excerpt, which is from a book by Maryn McKenna, a noted health journalist. The book is called “Big Chicken,” which sounds like an insult from recess but it really refers to the strange creatures that humans have developed for our delectation, ruefully described in this passage.

headline: Strategy Tips for Democrats
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs']
abstract: Readers discuss whether to eliminate the filibuster, selling the Democratic agenda to the public, statehood for D.C. and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Is Jon Cooper’s ‘Special Sauce?’
abstract: Cooper, the Tampa Bay Lightning coach, won the 2020 Stanley Cup to add to his enviable trophy case. One key to his success, a former boss said, is that he keeps learning.
lead_paragraph: After blowing a late-game lead and losing, the Green Bay Gamblers hockey players received a simple order from their coach, a former lawyer named Jon Cooper: For their next practice back home, meet at a local park at 7 a.m.

headline: At Elite French Universities, Students Demand Environmental Action
abstract: At schools known for ambition, not activism, students are calling for climate change to be at the heart of the curriculum, and telling the companies that recruit them to change their ways.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The sprawling campus of the École Polytechnique, one of the world’s finest engineering schools, has long been a magnet for major French industrial and energy companies, eager to attract some of France’s brightest minds.

headline: Mets’ Cohen Deletes Twitter Account After Threats
abstract: The Mets owner said his family had been targeted on the social media service. The move comes after he was pulled into the stock-market tug of war over GameStop.
lead_paragraph: For almost three months since he bought the Mets, Steve Cohen engaged in surprisingly lively banter with the team’s fans on Twitter, entertaining their outlandish trade suggestions and showcasing a sense of humor and genuine interest in their thoughts that was rare for a billionaire team owner.

headline: How Trump’s Focus on Antifa Distracted Attention From the Far-Right Threat
keywords: ['Antifa Movement (US)', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Whites', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Federal law enforcement shifted resources last year in response to Donald Trump’s insistence that the radical left endangered the country. Meanwhile, right-wing extremism was building ominously.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As racial justice protests erupted nationwide last year, President Donald J. Trump, struggling to find a winning campaign theme, hit on a message that he stressed over and over: The real domestic threat to the United States emanated from the radical left, even though law enforcement authorities had long since concluded it came from the far right.

headline: When a hospital refrigerator in Seattle broke, nurses gave 1,600 vaccine shots to anyone they could find.
abstract: The situation highlights the challenge posed by the two vaccines that have so far been approved in the United States — both need to be kept cold.
lead_paragraph: Wearing bathrobes, pajamas or whatever else they could quickly throw on, hundreds of people flocked to get Covid vaccines in Seattle on Thursday night after a refrigerator that was chilling 1,600 doses broke down, leading to a frenzied overnight inoculation drive.

headline: A Vast Web of Vengeance
keywords: ['Cyberharassment', 'Libel and Slander', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Outrageous lies destroyed Guy Babcock’s online reputation. When he went hunting for their source, what he discovered was worse than he could have imagined.
lead_paragraph: Guy Babcock vividly remembers the chilly Saturday evening when he discovered the stain on his family. It was September 2018. He, his wife and their young son had just returned to their home in Beckley, an English village outside of Oxford. Mr. Babcock still had his coat on when he got a frantic call from his father.

headline: After Record Turnout, Republicans Are Trying to Make It Harder to Vote
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Absentee Voting', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'States (US)']
abstract: The presidential election results are settled. But the battle over new voting rules, especially for mail-in ballots, has just begun.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Georgia, Arizona and other states won by President Biden, some leading Republicans stood up in November to make what, in any other year, would be an unremarkable statement: The race is over. And we lost, fair and square.

headline: So You Just Made a Lot of Money on GameStop. There’s One Catch: Taxes
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Income Tax', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Preparers and Preparation', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Some investors may have notched tens of thousands of dollars in profits. Depending on when they sell the stock, they may owe hefty capital gains taxes.
lead_paragraph: If you’re among the army of retail investors who have made big money trading in shares of GameStop and other previously downtrodden stocks, one thing is certain: The tax man will come.

headline: ‘Like Wartime’: Canadian Companies Unite to Start Mass Virus Testing
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Corporations', 'Disease Rates', 'Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: A consortium of some of Canada’s largest companies, representing 350,000 employees nationwide, has launched a rapid testing program aimed at reopening the country’s economy.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — As frustration mounts in Canada at the leaden weight of lockdowns and the glacial pace of vaccinations, a consortium of some of the country’s largest companies has launched a rapid testing program with the aim of protecting their 350,000 employees and publishing a playbook for businesses across Canada on how to reopen safely.

headline: San Francisco Schools, Radicalism and the Pandemic
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Right-Wing Extremism and Alt-Right', 'QAnon', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: When normal life recedes, ideology fills the vacuum.
lead_paragraph: This week, the San Francisco School Board of Education voted 6 to 1 to proceed with a plan to rename 44 of the city’s currently shuttered schools, wiping away notables like Abraham Lincoln, George Washington, Paul Revere, Robert Louis Stevenson and even Dianne Feinstein, California’s senior senator, for various forms of cooperation with white supremacy and patriarchy.

headline: Reader’s Guide: Everything You Need to Know About the GameStop Frenzy
abstract: Amateur investors, in a battle with hedge funds, bid up shares in a number of companies, including GameStop, which gained 400 percent for the week.
lead_paragraph: It was like a hurricane. Amateur investors, targeting stocks that the pros had written off as dead, bid up shares in a growing number of companies. By week’s end, GameStop had gained 400 percent, while AMC Entertainment surged 280 percent. At the center of it all was a battle of big versus small, Wall Street versus Main Street, the Robinhood army versus the hedge funds.

headline: John Chaney’s Message Was Always Clear, in Support of Black Athletes
keywords: ['Basketball (College)', 'NCAA Basketball Championships (Men)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Coaches and Managers']
abstract: “He’d say, ‘I’m not going to stick a lollipop in your mouth, I’m going to coach you like a man,’” recalled one of Chaney’s former assistant coaches.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s, Gary Charles showed up for his final exam in a physical education class at Cheyney University with a dislocated elbow in a cast. He expected his instructor to look at the state of his right arm and give him a pass on the portion of the test where he would have to shoot baskets.

headline: Biden’s Nightmare May Be China
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Think dealing with Mitch McConnell will be tough? Managing a reckless Xi Jinping will be even harder.
lead_paragraph: The first thing to say is that a war with China probably won’t happen.

headline: A 10-Year-Old GameStop Investor Cashed In. His Return? Over 5,000%.
abstract: Jaydyn Carr of San Antonio made $3,200 on shares from GameStop this week that his mother bought him in 2019 for about $60.
lead_paragraph: As amateur investors banded together this week to squeeze Wall Street hedge funds by sending GameStop’s stock prices to dizzying heights, some novice traders, like 10-year-old Jaydyn Carr of San Antonio, have seen their long-term investments pay off.

headline: The C.D.C. issued an order that requires masks for domestic travel.
abstract: A spokesman for the agency said that the order relied heavily on voluntary action to enforce the mandate.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued an order requiring travelers in the United States to wear masks as part of a new initiative aimed at stemming outbreaks of the coronavirus.

headline: Part of California Highway Collapses After Heavy Rain
abstract: A section of Highway 1 near Big Sur, Calif., collapsed into the Pacific Ocean on Thursday evening after the area was battered by heavy rains this past week.
lead_paragraph: A section of Highway 1 near Big Sur, Calif., collapsed into the Pacific Ocean on Thursday evening after the area was battered by heavy rains this past week.

headline: Sonny Fox, Whose ‘Wonderama’ Mixed Fun and Learning, Dies at 95
abstract: He was not a comic or a clown, just a smart and genial TV host who for almost a decade spoke to children, not at them. He died of Covid pneumonia.
lead_paragraph: Sonny Fox, who as the host of the children’s television show “Wonderama” presided over a four-hour combination of fun and learning on Sunday mornings from 1959 to 1967, died on Jan. 24 in Encino, Calif. He was 95.

headline: Sylvia Lieber, Creative Kindergarten Teacher, Dies at 102
abstract: She gave 5- and 6-year-olds an early introduction to classical music and museum art — and taught them where milk comes from. She died of complications of Covid-19.,
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Product Misplacement
abstract: Jim Hilger brings us a saucy Sunday debut.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today we add a new name to weekends: Jim Hilger, who arrives with a portfolio stuffed with Wednesday and Thursday themes. (I think this grid feels like a big Thursday because the theme has a kind of twist on a twist to it.) Mr. Hilger is a retired computer analyst and educator living in Amarillo, Texas, who makes cartoons, paints and boasts a collection of more than 10,000 45-r.p.m. records. Sounds like a party!

headline: Part of Highway 1 in California Falls Into the Ocean
abstract: A section of the scenic road near Big Sur collapsed after heavy rains.
lead_paragraph: A portion of Highway 1 near Big Sur, Calif., collapsed this week and fell into the Pacific Ocean after heavy rains caused a “debris flow” of trees, boulders, water and mud, leaving behind a 150-foot-wide gap.

headline: Joseph Sonnabend, Early Force in Fight Against AIDS, Dies at 88
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Medicine and Health', 'Research', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: At the epicenter of the epidemic in New York City, he was a pioneer researcher who, as a clinician, also made house calls.
lead_paragraph: When he was growing up in Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe, in the 1930s and ’40s, Joseph Sonnabend would watch his mother, a physician, make house calls in the middle of the night and talk with patients on the phone at all hours. He didn’t want to follow that path, but he did study medicine and become a medical researcher, working alongside Nobel laureates in England on virology and immunology.

headline: Pentagon Halts Plan to Vaccinate the 40 Prisoners at Guantánamo Bay
keywords: ['Detainees', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The decision to vaccinate the prisoners ignited criticism over whether the government was prioritizing terrorism suspects over American citizens.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon on Saturday halted plans to offer coronavirus vaccines next week to the 40 wartime prisoners at Guantánamo Bay after an outcry over whether the Defense Department was putting terrorism suspects before the American people.

headline: Sundance Diary, Part 3: Documentaries That Don’t Despair
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Given a choice between fiction and reality, the festival’s fact-based films provide a surprising sense of escapism.
lead_paragraph: A.O. Scott, our critic at large, is keeping a diary as he “attends” the virtual Sundance Film Festival, which runs through Wednesday. Read Part 1 and Part 2.

headline: Protesters disrupt motorists from entering Dodger Stadium vaccination site.
abstract: The closure lasted for about an hour before the entrance reopened, while vaccinations continued inside the stadium.
lead_paragraph: Motorists in line at one of the country’s largest vaccination sites were briefly halted on Saturday afternoon as demonstrators descended on Dodger Stadium, the authorities said.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Attacked by a ‘Superspreader’ of Online Smears
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 31, 2021.
lead_paragraph: “You discover that someone you’ve never met, across the country, is running a one-man troll farm against you. It’s a nightmare scenario.”

headline: Savor a Performance Series and Homemade Pizza
abstract: This week, learn about metamorphosing insects, dance your way through the Cleveland Museum of Art or watch a documentary.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: Trump Parts Ways With Five Lawyers Handling Impeachment Defense
keywords: ['Impeachment', 'Legal Profession', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)']
abstract: The departures, which include his lead lawyer, Butch Bowers, come more than a week before his Senate trial is set to begin.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has abruptly parted ways with five lawyers handling his impeachment defense, just over a week before the Senate trial is set to begin, people familiar with the situation said on Saturday.

headline: Downscale Your Super Bowl Spread
abstract: You probably won’t be watching with a crowd, but you can still have wings, dip and a sub-style sandwich to eat during the game.
lead_paragraph: There will still be a field stretching 100 yards, with 11 players on a side. But many other calculations for Super Bowl LV have shrunk.

headline: Have a Ball This Super Bowl Sunday
abstract: Go team! Even if your watch party is small or on Zoom, there are games and other activities to get even the most casual fan involved and engaged.
lead_paragraph: For many Americans, Super Bowl Sunday isn’t about defensive strategy, how the quarterbacks throw or the tantalizing prospect of your favorite team winning a championship ring.

headline: Honor and Learn This Black History Month
abstract: More than ever, this month is a welcome time for the education and celebration of Black American culture.
lead_paragraph: It’s not an understatement to describe the events of the past year as historic, and particularly for Black Americans. The nation elected its first Black vice president, a woman and a graduate of a historically Black university, and Georgia send its first Black senator to the Capitol. (Both of these realities were possible through the tireless organizing efforts of women like Stacey Abrams of Fair Fight and LaTosha Brown of Black Voters Matter.)

headline: Corrections: Jan. 31, 2021
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 31, 2021.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about the drama “The Dig” referred imprecisely to the helmet shown. It was a reconstruction of what the original Anglo-Saxon helmet might have looked like, not the original.

headline: Soak With a D.I.Y. Bath Bomb
abstract: Your first batch of scent, salt and fizz may not be beautiful, but you’ll know exactly what you’re introducing to your tub.
lead_paragraph: Whether you need stress relief or some alone time after being cooped up with your family, there are plenty of reasons you can’t seem to get enough of your bathtub this winter. But one variable to consider the next time you go for a much-needed soak: Would your bath be better with a bath bomb?

headline: Manage Your Divorce Expectations
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Marriages']
abstract: Our routines may have stalled during Covid, but the desire to divorce certainly hasn’t. Here, some of the pandemic-age challenges to consider.
lead_paragraph: When the New York divorce courts reopened in June after a nearly three-month closure, the lawyer Nancy Chemtob said she began waking up at 3 a.m. to handle all of the clients who wanted out of their marriages. And the calls and texts didn’t let up between Thanksgiving and New Year’s, traditionally a slow period in the divorce business, as people would hang on for year-end bonuses or the last family vacation before filing.

headline: Catch a Movie About Time Loops
abstract: ‘Groundhog Day’ may feel a little too close to home this year. Here are some films you may not need to relive.
lead_paragraph: The movie “Groundhog Day” came out in 1993, but it feels as if we’ve been watching it over and over ever since. This story of a smug weatherman (Bill Murray) who is stuck endlessly repeating the same day has remained popular and inspired countless movies and shows. (The latest, the romantic comedy “The Map of Tiny Perfect Things” debuts on Amazon Prime Video).

headline: Find Original Poetry Hiding in the Pages of Your Paper
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Handicrafts']
abstract: Creating an erasure poem means finding your voice lurking in another’s words. It can be a way to start writing when words fail.
lead_paragraph: The past year has been difficult for many people. The pandemic, the politics, the job loss and the isolation — most Americans have had to find some new coping mechanisms to make it through. Here’s one: erasure poetry.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Takes on Marjorie Taylor Greene and GameStop
abstract: In its first episode of 2021, “Saturday Night Live” and guest host John Krasinski also addressed the Capitol riot, Covid vaccines and the start of the Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: It was just over a month ago that “Saturday Night Live” said farewell to the Trump era, and what followed was perhaps the most historically significant hiatus in the show’s history: In the weeks that followed, America has seen a riot that breached the Capitol; the second impeachment of former President Donald J. Trump; and the inauguration of President Biden. How does a late-night sketch comedy show even begin to process this?

headline: ‘We Were Greeted by an Older Woman With Two Small Dogs’
abstract: One way to explain a T-shirt slogan, gambling on concert tickets and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: How a High-Ranking Nissan Executive Escaped His Own Trap
abstract: Hari Nada helped bring down his boss, Carlos Ghosn. In the process, he nearly met his own downfall. But with shrewd maneuvering and the protection of high-ranking allies, he survived and thrived.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — It was the fall of 2018, and Hari Nada, a high-powered Nissan executive, was afraid he might be headed to jail.

headline: Russia Protesters Defy Vast Police Operation as Signs of Kremlin Anxiety Mount
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Political Prisoners', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Tens of thousands took to the streets across Russia to show support for the jailed opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny. The police were out in force and reports of brutality flared.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Kremlin mounted Russia’s most fearsome nationwide police operation in recent memory on Sunday, seeking to overwhelm a protest movement backing the jailed opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny that swept across the country for a second weekend in a row.

headline: Daily Covid Toll in U.S. Remains Enormous, but Cases Are Falling
abstract: Several indicators, including a 40 percent drop in average new reported cases, are encouraging. But transmission is still dangerously high, and new variants could upend progress.
lead_paragraph: Several indicators, including a 40 percent drop in average new reported cases, are encouraging. But transmission is still dangerously high, and new variants could upend progress.

headline: How to Improve the Oscars? We Asked Five Culture Journalists
abstract: Yes, even in a year when the show will be held during a pandemic, the question is predictable. But these answers aren’t.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Democratic Party Enters 2021 in Power — and Flush With Cash, for a Change
abstract: The Democratic National Committee has a roughly $75 million war chest, raising the party’s hopes of keeping power in 2022 and accelerating a Democratic shift in the Sun Belt states.
lead_paragraph: After years of flirting with financial disaster, the Democratic Party entered 2021 not only in control of the White House, the House and the Senate but with more money in the bank than ever before at the start of a political cycle.

headline: Napoleon’s Brother Lived in N.J. Here’s What Happened to the Estate.
abstract: The site in Bordentown once harbored Joseph Bonaparte, a former king. A new partnership has ensured that its history won’t be forgotten.
lead_paragraph: The name Bonaparte brings to mind many locales: Corsica, Paris, Alexandria, Waterloo and, finally, St. Helena.

headline: Wall Street Makes Unprecedented Push to Get Out the Vote
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Business leaders want their employees to have a say in helping decide who will steer New York City’s economic recovery as its new mayor.
lead_paragraph: After years of dealing with a mayor hostile to business, New York’s corporate leaders had hoped that the city’s next mayor would be different.

headline: Here’s a Way to Learn if Facial Recognition Systems Used Your Photos
keywords: ['Computer Vision', 'Facial Recognition Software', 'Photography', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy']
abstract: An online tool targets only a small slice of what’s out there, but may open some eyes to how widely artificial intelligence research fed on personal images.
lead_paragraph: When tech companies created the facial recognition systems that are rapidly remaking government surveillance and chipping away at personal privacy, they may have received help from an unexpected source: your face.

headline: When Ted Cruz and A.O.C. Agree: Yes, the Politics of GameStop Are Confusing
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy', 'Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: From the populist right to the socialist left, the rush by both parties to side with young traders disrupting the markets reflects the broad recognition of the impulses driving American politics.
lead_paragraph: It’s Occupy Wall Street, the sequel. It’s elements of the Tea Party, again. It’s Bernie bros and MAGA-maniacs.

headline: He Can’t Carry a Tune, but Chang-rae Lee Has a Song to Sing
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Books and Literature', 'Korean-Americans', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Suburbs']
abstract: “My Year Abroad,” his sixth novel, is about letting yourself plunge into the world, even when it hurts. He’s been thinking about that a lot over these past, painful months.
lead_paragraph: There are times when Chang-rae Lee — Pulitzer fiction finalist, PEN/Hemingway Award winner, English professor at Stanford, beloved novelist with a sixth one on the way — wonders if he can write.

headline: As Virus Variants Spread, ‘No One Is Safe Until Everyone Is Safe’
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Rich countries are buying up coronavirus vaccines, leaving poorer regions vulnerable — and as potential breeding grounds for variants, like one found in South Africa, that could make vaccines less effective.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN, South Africa — As a dangerous variant of the coronavirus first discovered in South Africa sickens and kills thousands across the country, Jan Matsena has shown up every day to stock the shelves at a Cape Town supermarket, terrified that he, too, will catch it.

headline: This Ammonite Was Fossilized Outside Its Shell
abstract: The bizarre fossil is one of very few records of soft tissue in a creature better known as a whorled shell.
lead_paragraph: If anxious humans have nightmares of being naked in public, an anxious ammonite may have dreamed about swimming around without its shell, its soft body exposed to the elements and the leering eyes of predators.

headline: Ghosts of 2009 Drive Democrats’ Push for Robust Crisis Response
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Economy', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009)', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)']
abstract: In their quest for Republican backing, Democrats say they missed opportunities in 2009 for a stronger response to the Great Recession. They’re determined not to repeat the mistake.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats are haunted by legislative memories of 2009 as they fashion their response to the multiple crises of 2021.

headline: Trump Raised $255.4 Million in 8 Weeks as He Sought to Overturn Election Result
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The former president’s fund-raising slowed significantly after the Electoral College delivered its votes to make Joseph R. Biden Jr. the 46th president.
lead_paragraph: President Donald J. Trump and the Republican Party raised $255.4 million in the eight-plus weeks following the Nov. 3 election, new federal filings show, as he sought to undermine and overturn the results with unfounded accusations of fraud.

headline: Coronavirus Variants, GameStop, Polar Vortex: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: GameStop’s Bizarre Saga
abstract: GameStop takes markets for a ride.
lead_paragraph: Hi, everyone. Here’s your breakdown of the top news in business and tech, so you’re ready for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles

headline: Couple Forced to Adopt Their Own Children After a Surrogate Pregnancy
abstract: Tammy and Jordan Myers will have to adopt their twins after two Michigan judges denied them parental rights because the children had been carried by a surrogate.
lead_paragraph: The nursery in the home of Jordan and Tammy Myers in Grand Rapids, Mich., is painted in shades of gray, white and midnight blue for the couple’s newborn twins. Their 8-year-old daughter, Corryn, can’t stop talking about how excited she is to finally be a big sister.

headline: In Brazil, Risk and Reward, Side by Joyous Side
abstract: Coronavirus restrictions forced Palmeiras fans to watch from afar as the soccer team played Santos in the Copa Libertadores final. A last-minute win made everyone forget the distance, and the rules.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — In the cramped streets around Allianz Parque, hundreds of Palmeiras fans huddled together, craning their necks to try to catch a glimpse of whatever television screen they could find. The pandemic meant they could not go to the final in Rio de Janeiro. But it also meant they could not even go into the bars and restaurants, which are restricted to takeout service on weekends.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Forgotten Sense’
abstract: What can the coronavirus’s strangest symptom teach us about the mysteries of smell?
lead_paragraph: “Smell is a startling superpower,” writes Brooke Jarvis, the author of today’s Sunday Read. “If you weren’t used to it, it would seem like witchcraft.”

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $450,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Ten G.O.P. senators sketch out their own proposed relief bill in a letter to Biden.
keywords: ['internal-essential', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Republican moderates said they could go along with many of the president's proposals if some, like unemployment aid and direct payments, were scaled back.
lead_paragraph: Ten Republican senators wrote to President Biden on Sunday, outlining a framework for coronavirus relief legislation and pushing for Mr. Biden to compromise. The letter came as Democrats were preparing to bypass the need for Republican support in order to deliver a sweeping relief package.

headline: California Sheriff’s Deputy Is Charged With Faking Attack
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Hoaxes and Pranks', 'Cameras', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Sukhdeep Gill, a Santa Clara County deputy who claimed that he had been shot in his body camera last year, was charged with fabricating the attack, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Sukhdeep Gill, a sheriff’s deputy in Santa Clara County, Calif., said he had been walking back to his patrol car on a dark road near a reservoir when a silver sedan pulled up and cut its lights and someone inside fired at him from the passenger-side window.

headline: Two Biden Priorities, Climate and Inequality, Meet on Black-Owned Farms
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Discrimination', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Inequality', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The administration has pledged to make agriculture a cornerstone of its plan to fight warming, but also to tackle a legacy of discrimination that has pushed Black farmers off the land.
lead_paragraph: Sedrick Rowe was a running back for Georgia’s Fort Valley State University when he stumbled on an unexpected oasis: an organic farm on the grounds of the historically Black school.

headline: 21 Men Accuse Lincoln Project Co-Founder of Online Harassment
abstract: John Weaver, a longtime G.O.P. operative who advised John McCain and John Kasich, made sexual overtures to young men, sometimes offering to help them get work in politics.
lead_paragraph: John Weaver, a longtime Republican strategist and co-founder of the prominent anti-Trump group the Lincoln Project, has for years sent unsolicited and sexually provocative messages online to young men, often while suggesting he could help them get work in politics, according to interviews with 21 men who received them.

headline: After Capitol Riot, Elected Officials Under Pressure Back Home
keywords: ['Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: At least 19 state and local elected officeholders from across the country attended the Jan. 6 rally and, in some cases, stormed the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a video posted on Facebook, Couy Griffin, the founder of a group called Cowboys for Trump, bragged that he had a “first row seat” to the riot at the Capitol on Jan. 6 and considered returning for another rally in which he imagined “blood running out of that building,” the F.B.I. said. Later, he told the F.B.I. that he hoped the next demonstration would be nonviolent but there was “no option that’s off the table for the sake of freedom.”

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Dorie Greenspan has a lovely piece in The Times, focusing on savory little quick breads called cakes salés. Make them soonest.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Even before the pandemic ended dinner parties (remember them?), I had a complicated relationship with appetizers, nibbles, nuts and cheeses, any consumption that precedes a meal. I don’t like the idea of cooking for any great period of time — assembling a braise, making noodles, overthinking a salad, preparing a dessert — so that a guest can arrive in my home, eat a quarter-pound of salted cashews and then pick at dinner a half-hour later. It’s churlish of me, I know, but there you have it. I want you seated at the table hungry, and I will feed you in response.

headline: Andrew Brooks, Who Developed a Covid Spit Test, Dies at 51
abstract: His breakthrough helped millions get their results quickly in the early days of the pandemic, when tests were scarce and lines were long.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Brooks, a research professor at Rutgers University who developed the first saliva test for Covid-19, died on Jan. 23 in Manhattan. He was 51.

headline: I Miss Sitting at a Crowded Dinner Table
abstract: At a small Middle Eastern restaurant in my neighborhood, I experienced the world my family had left behind.
lead_paragraph: It took me far too long to start a conversation with an old Iraqi man named Monther. This is something I will regret all my life.

headline: Women’s Health Isn’t a Geopolitical Game
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'ABORTION']
abstract: Presidents have played politics with women’s lives for long enough.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, President Biden lifted the Mexico City Policy, known more commonly to critics as the global gag rule, which denies U.S. aid to nongovernmental organizations if they advocate for, suggest or even mention the word abortion.

headline: One Step Up and Two Steps Back
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Women and Girls', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Advances for L.G.B.T.Q. people in the Biden administration are countered by challenges in statehouses.
lead_paragraph: There he was on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial, the Boss himself, the opening act on the night of the virtual inaugural ball. His song was “Land of Hope and Dreams.” “Leave behind your sorrows,” he sang. “Let this day be the last. Tomorrow there’ll be sunshine and all this darkness past.”

headline: The Science of Reasoning With Unreasonable People
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Friendship', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Don’t try to change someone else’s mind. Instead, help them find their own motivation to change.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I made the mistake of having an argument with the most stubborn person I know. R., whose initial I’m using to protect his privacy, is a longtime friend, and when his family came to visit, he mentioned that his children had never been vaccinated — and never would be.

headline: As Biden Plans Global Democracy Summit, Skeptics Say: Heal Thyself First
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: The sense of a dysfunctional, if not entirely broken, democratic system in the United States has foreign rivals crowing — and suggesting that it has no business lecturing other nations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Among President Biden’s most specific foreign policy promises was a pledge to convene a global democracy summit during his first year in office. The gathering would be intended to take a public stand against the authoritarian and populist tides that rose during the presidency of Donald J. Trump and, as Mr. Biden and his advisers see it, threaten to swamp Western political values.

headline: Powerful Snowstorm Expected to Affect Much of the East
abstract: Winter storm warnings were issued from North Carolina to New York. Hazardous travel conditions and heavy snow were expected, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: Winter storm warnings were in place for a large swath of the Eastern United States on Sunday, from northwestern North Carolina to New York, with as much as two feet of snow and dangerous travel conditions expected in some places into Tuesday, forecasters said.

headline: Hear Sophie’s 12 Essential Songs
abstract: The producer and performer’s short but influential career had a profound impact on the way modern pop music sounds. She died after a fall in Athens.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, the forward-thinking pop producer and musician Sophie died after an accident in Athens. She was 34. “True to her spirituality,” her family wrote in a statement, “she had climbed up to watch the full moon and accidentally slipped and fell.” The story was at once tragic and beautiful, full of pain, shock and underneath it all an almost otherworldly yearning. It was like a Sophie song.

headline: In Photos: Crowds of Police Couldn’t Quell Russia’s Pro-Navalny Protests
abstract: More than 4,000 people were detained, but allies of the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny called Sunday's demonstrations a success.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people turned out across Russia on Sunday for a second consecutive weekend rally in support of a jailed opposition leader, Aleksei A. Navalny. But where the protesters went, so did the police, meeting them in sometimes brutal clashes.

headline: Russia’s Economic Slump Erodes Consensus That Shielded Putin
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The rally-around-the-flag effect of President Vladimir V. Putin’s assertive foreign policy known as the Crimea consensus is unraveling with the economy.
lead_paragraph: KALININGRAD, Russia — Aleksandr Dobralsky took to the streets to protest the arrest this past month of Russia’s most prominent opposition leader. But he had other grievances as well.

headline: Understanding Biden’s Catholic Faith
abstract: Readers reflect on what Catholicism means to the president, and to society.

headline: Australia locks down a whole city after finding a single new coronavirus case.
abstract: Australian officials abruptly locked down the city of Perth in Western Australia for five days, after one person tested positive there for the coronavirus — a security guard at a quarantine hotel. The state of Western Australia had gone nearly ten months without any sign of community transmission.
lead_paragraph: Australian officials abruptly locked down the city of Perth in Western Australia for five days, after one person tested positive there for the coronavirus — a security guard at a quarantine hotel. The state of Western Australia had gone nearly ten months without any sign of community transmission.

headline: Black and Latino New Yorkers Trail White Residents in Vaccine Rollout
abstract: Data showed that while 24% of city residents are Black, only 11% of vaccine recipients were. White New Yorkers received a disproportionate share of the shots.
lead_paragraph: The rollout of vaccines in New York City — once the epicenter of the pandemic — has been plagued by stark racial disparities, with Black and Latino residents receiving far fewer doses than white residents, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Sunday.

headline: New York City postpones vaccine appointments as a snowstorm approaches.
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York announced on Sunday that vaccine appointments scheduled to take place in the city on Monday would be postponed because of a looming winter storm that is expected to dump up to 16 inches of snow on the region.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York announced on Sunday that vaccine appointments scheduled to take place in the city on Monday would be postponed because of a looming winter storm that is expected to dump up to 16 inches of snow on the region.

headline: Militants Storm Hotel in Somali Capital and Blasts Rock Area
abstract: The authorities said an evacuation operation was still underway at the Afrik Hotel, with reports of at least two dead and 11 injured. A  militant group, the Shabab, was believed to be behind the attack.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Militants with the extremist group al-Shabab stormed a major hotel in the Somali capital Mogadishu on Sunday evening, the authorities said, raising fears of growing violence in the Horn of Africa nation as it faces a bitterly contested election season and the withdrawal of American troops.

headline: Not Yet Desperate, Japan and South Korea Plod Toward Vaccinations
abstract: The slower pace gives the East Asian countries a chance to learn from mistakes elsewhere but also poses risks as more contagious and perhaps deadlier variants of the virus emerge.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s biggest cities are under a state of emergency as coronavirus deaths rise, even while the country tries to convince the world it can safely hold the Summer Olympics. South Korea is prohibiting gatherings of five or more people to keep a recent surge in cases under control. Hong Kong imposed stringent lockdowns on some of its poorest neighborhoods to stop an uptick.

headline: The Pop Star Wants to Be an Olympian
abstract: Cody Simpson has been a singer, a dancer, an actor and an author. Now, with support from Michael Phelps and Ian Thorpe, he is resurrecting a childhood swimming dream.
lead_paragraph: Australia’s princeling of pop was holed up in a hotel in the summer of 2019, preparing for his country’s inaugural season of the “The Masked Singer,” when he started following the world swimming championships. As he watched records fall, Cody Simpson soon found himself focused on one thought:

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Thousands detained in Russia protests.
lead_paragraph: The police were out in large numbers in dozens of cities and towns across Russia on Sunday as tens of thousands took to the streets to show support for the jailed opposition leader Aleksei Navalny. It was one of the most imposing shows of police force seen in the country’s recent history.

headline: N.Y.C. Facing ‘Profound Disparity’ in Covid Vaccinations, Mayor Says
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said data on the city’s vaccine rollout showed Black and Latino New Yorkers being vaccinated at starkly lower rates than white residents, who have gotten a disproportionate share of the shots.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio said data on the city’s vaccine rollout showed Black and Latino New Yorkers being vaccinated at starkly lower rates than white residents, who have gotten a disproportionate share of the shots.
